--Word--
type 2 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or pertaining to some forms of diabetes, especially the non-insulin-dependent type.
--Examples--
--Word--
c/- 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Care of.
--Examples--
--Word--
point 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The tapered, sharp end of a tool, weapon, or other object.
A pointed flake or blade, especially one that has been worked.
The tip of a person's chin as a spot for a blow.
The prong of a deer's antler.
A dot or other punctuation mark, in particular a full stop.
A decimal point.
A dot or small stroke used in Semitic languages to indicate vowels or distinguish particular consonants.
A very small dot or mark.
A particular spot, place, or position in an area or on a map, object, or surface.
A particular moment in time or stage in a process.
The critical or decisive moment.
The verge or brink of (doing or being something)
A stage or level at which a change of state occurs.
A socket in a wall for connecting a device to an electrical supply or communications network.
(in geometry) something having position but not spatial extent, magnitude, dimension, or direction, for example the intersection of two lines.
A single item or detail in an extended discussion, list, or text.
An argument or idea.
The significant or essential element of something being planned or discussed.
Advantage or purpose that can be gained from doing something.
Relevance or effectiveness.
A distinctive feature or characteristic, typically a good one, of a person or thing.
(in sports and games) a mark or unit of scoring awarded for success or performance.
A unit used in measuring value, achievement, or extent.
An advantage or success in an argument or discussion.
A unit of credit towards an award or benefit.
A percentage of the profits from a film or recording offered to certain people involved in its production.
(in piquet) the longest suit in a player's hand, containing a specified number of up to eight cards.
A unit of weight (2 mg) for diamonds.
A unit of varying value, used in quoting the price of stocks, bonds, or futures.
A value assigned to certain cards (4 points for an ace, 3 for a king, 2 for a queen, and 1 for a jack, sometimes with extra points for long or short suits) by a player in assessing the strength of their hand.
Each of thirty-two directions marked at equal distances round a compass.
A direction towards the horizon corresponding to the direction marked on a compass.
The angular interval between two successive points of a compass, i.e. one eighth of a right angle.
Unspecified places considered in terms of their direction from a specified place.
A narrow piece of land jutting out into the sea.
A junction of two railway lines, with a pair of linked tapering rails that can be moved laterally to allow a train to pass from one line to the other.
A unit of measurement for type sizes and spacing (in the UK and US 0.351 mm, in Europe 0.376 mm).
A fielding position on the off side near the batsman.
A fielder at the point position.
Either of two areas to the left and right of the net, just inside the blue line where it meets the boards.
A position at the front of the court, usually manned by the guard who sets up the team's defence.
(in a motor vehicle) each of a set of electrical contacts in the distributor.
A small leading party of an advanced guard of troops.
The position at the head of a column or wedge of troops.
The extremities of an animal, typically a horse or cat, such as the face, paws, and tail of a Siamese cat.
A spot to which a straight run is made.
A straight run.
A tagged piece of ribbon or cord used for lacing a garment or attaching a hose to a doublet.
A short piece of cord at the lower edge of a sail for tying up a reef.
The action or position of a dog in pointing.
An important phrase or subject, especially in a contrapuntal composition.
Direct someone's attention towards something by extending one's finger or something held in one's hand.
Indicate a particular time, direction, or reading.
Direct or aim (something) at someone or something.
Face or be turned in a particular direction.
(of a dog) indicate the presence of (game) by standing rigid while looking towards it.
Cite a fact or situation as evidence of something.
(of a fact or situation) indicate that (something) is likely to happen or be the case.
Give force or emphasis to (words or actions)
Extend (the toes or feet) in line with the leg by tensing the foot and ankle in such a way as to form a point.
Fill the joints of (brickwork or masonry) with smoothly finished mortar.
Give a sharp, tapered point to.
Insert points in (written text of Semitic languages).
Mark (Psalms) with signs for chanting.
--Examples--
‘the point of his dagger’
‘a pencil point’
‘Andrews caught him on the point’
‘a fine buck of eight points’
‘fifty-five point nine’
‘the sky was studded with points of light’
‘turn left at the point where you see a sign to Appleford’
‘the furthermost point of the gallery’
‘the check-in point’
‘from this point onwards the teacher was completely won over’
‘when it came to the point he would probably do what was expected of him’
‘she was on the point of leaving’
‘local kennels are full to bursting point’
‘a power point’
‘the main points of the Edinburgh agreement’
‘he made the point that economic regulation involves controls on pricing’
‘it took her a long time to come to the point’
‘some speakers rambled and never seemed to get to the point’
‘that's not the point’
‘there was no point in denying the truth’
‘what's the point of having things I don't need?’
‘he has his good points’
‘he kicked a penalty goal to put Bangor eight points ahead’
‘the shares index was down seven points’
‘she smiled, assuming she had won her point’
‘points were allocated according to the inadequacy of the existing accommodation’
‘in Acol it is permissible to open with only twelve points’
‘they headed down Highway 401 to Ontario and points west’
‘the boat came round the point’
‘Blakeney Point’
‘the train gave a lurch as it passed over the points’
‘he walked point and I took the tail’
‘a pure white dog with black points’
‘our fox made his point to Moorhill’
‘a bird dog on point’
‘the lads were nudging each other and pointing at me’
‘a sign pointing left’
‘he pointed the torch beam at the floor’
‘two of its toes point forward and two point back’
‘he points to several factors supporting this conclusion’
‘everything pointed to an Eastern attack’
‘he wouldn't miss the opportunity to point a moral’
‘reach up with your arms and point your toes’
‘the bricks have been poorly pointed’
‘he twisted and pointed his moustache’

--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
carbon-12 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The commonest natural carbon isotope, of mass 12. It is the basis for the accepted scale of atomic mass units.
--Examples--
--Word--
post-16 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to education after the age of sixteen.

--Word--
Wellington, 1st Duke of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1769–1852), British soldier and Tory statesman, prime minister 1828–30 and 1834; born Arthur Wellesley; known as the Iron Duke. He served as commander of the British forces in the Peninsular War (1808–14) and in 1815 defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo, so ending the Napoleonic Wars.
--Examples--
--Word--
’t 
--Type--
contraction
--Meanings--
The word “it,” attached to the end of a verb, especially in the transcription of regional spoken use.
--Examples--
‘I'll never do ’t again’
--Word--
'd 
--Type--
contraction
--Meanings--
Had.
Would.
--Examples--
‘they'd already gone’
‘I'd expect that’

--Meanings--

--Word--
Rochester, 2nd Earl of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1647–80), English poet and courtier; born John Wilmot. Infamous for his dissolute life at the court of Charles II, he wrote sexually explicit love poems and verse satires.
--Examples--
--Word--
3D 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Three-dimensional.
Relating to or denoting a film or video game that creates an impression of depth and solidity, typically by means of stereoscopic techniques.
The quality of being three-dimensional.
--Examples--
‘a 3D model’
‘a 3D first-person shooter game’
‘all their projects are modelled in 3D from start to finish’
‘today saw the debut of the BBC's new weather graphics, in 3D and with dynamic imaging’
--Word--
three-dimensional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or appearing to have length, breadth, and depth.
(of a literary or dramatic work) sufficiently full in characterization and representation of events to be believable.
--Examples--
‘a three-dimensional object’
‘the drama is never anything less than three-dimensional’
--Word--
Salisbury, 3rd Marquess of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1830–1903), British Conservative statesman, prime minister 1885–6, 1886–92, and 1895–1902; born Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoigne-Cecil. He supported the policies which resulted in the Second Boer War (1899–1902).

--Word--
4D 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Four-dimensional.
Relating to or denoting a 3D film or video game featuring additional effects such as smells, movement, and simulated weather.
Relating to an ultrasound scan of a fetus featuring 3D images and movement.
The quality of being four-dimensional.
--Examples--
‘the motion of the pendulum in a 4D space’
‘a fully immersive 4D film experience’
‘they went for a 4D scan of her twins at 30 weeks’
‘the film has even been released in 4D in Japan, complete with smog effects and seat movement’

--Meanings--
(1784–1860), British Conservative statesman, prime minister 1852–5; born George Hamilton Gordon.
--Examples--
--Word--
5:2 diet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diet that involves eating normally for five days out of a seven-day period and greatly restricting the amount of food eaten on the other two days.
--Examples--
‘I've been on the 5:2 diet for seven weeks’

Rosebery, 5th Earl of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1847–1929), British Liberal statesman, prime minister 1894–5; born Archibald Philip Primrose.
--Examples--
--Word--
omega-6 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating unsaturated fatty acids whose molecules have a double bond between the carbon atoms that are sixth and fifth from the end of the hydrocarbon chain. Also written ω-6.
An omega-six fatty acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
Economy 7 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An energy tariff which provides low-cost night-time electricity during a specified seven-hour period.
--Examples--
--Word--
Shaftesbury, 7th Earl of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1801–85), English philanthropist and social reformer; born Anthony Ashley Cooper. A dominant figure of the 19th-century social reform movement, he inspired much of the legislation designed to improve conditions for the large working class created as a result of the Industrial Revolution. His reforms included the introduction of the ten-hour working day (1847).
--Examples--

‘the shares index was down seven points’
‘she smiled, assuming she had won her point’
‘points were allocated according to the inadequacy of the existing accommodation’
‘in Acol it is permissible to open with only twelve points’
‘they headed down Highway 401 to Ontario and points west’
‘the boat came round the point’
‘Blakeney Point’
‘the train gave a lurch as it passed over the points’
‘he walked point and I took the tail’
‘a pure white dog with black points’
‘our fox made his point to Moorhill’
‘a bird dog on point’
‘the lads were nudging each other and pointing at me’
‘a sign pointing left’
‘he pointed the torch beam at the floor’
‘two of its toes point forward and two point back’
‘he points to several factors supporting this conclusion’
‘everything pointed to an Eastern attack’
‘he wouldn't miss the opportunity to point a moral’
‘reach up with your arms and point your toes’
‘the bricks have been poorly pointed’
‘he twisted and pointed his moustache’
--Word--
9/11 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An attack on 11 September 2001 in which two hijacked airliners were flown directly into the World Trade Center in New York City, causing the complete collapse of the twin towers, and a third airliner was flown into the Pentagon. A fourth aircraft was brought to the ground in Pennsylvania as a result of what is thought to be passenger intervention. The airliners were hijacked by Islamic fundamentalist terrorists believed to be involved with al-Qaeda.
--Examples--
--Word--
a 
--Type--
determiner, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
Used when mentioning someone or something for the first time in a text or conversation.
Used with units of measurement to mean one such unit.
One single; any.
Used when mentioning the name of someone not known to the speaker.
Someone like (the name specified)
Used to indicate membership of a class of people or things.
In, to, or for each; per (used when expressing rates or ratios)
(in travel timetables) arrives.
(in units of measurement) atto- .
(with reference to sporting fixtures) away.
(used before a date) before.
Acceleration.
The first letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the first in a set of items, categories, sizes, etc.
Denoting the first of two or more hypothetical people or things.
The highest class of academic mark.
(in the UK) denoting the most important category of road, other than a motorway.
Denoting the highest-earning socio-economic category for marketing purposes, including top management and senior professional personnel.
Denoting the first file from the left, as viewed from White's side of the board.
The first constant to appear in an algebraic expression.
Denoting the uppermost soil horizon, especially the topsoil.
The human blood type (in the ABO system) containing the A antigen and lacking the B.
(with numeral) denoting a series of international standard paper sizes each twice the area of the next, as A0, A1, A2, A3, A4, etc., A4 being 210 × 297 mm.
A shape like that of a capital A.
The sixth note of the diatonic scale of C major. The A above middle C is usually used as the basis for tuning and in modern music has a standard frequency of 440 Hz.
A key based on a scale with A as its keynote.

Aalto, Alvar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1976), Finnish architect and designer; full name Hugo Alvar Henrik Aalto. He often used materials such as brick, copper, and timber in his building designs to blend with the landscape. As a designer he is known as the inventor of bent plywood furniture.

--Word--
axis 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An imaginary line about which a body rotates.
An imaginary straight line passing through the centre of a symmetrical solid, about which a plane figure can be conceived as rotating to generate the solid.
An imaginary line which divides something into equal or roughly equal halves, especially in the direction of its greatest length.
A fixed reference line for the measurement of coordinates.
A straight central part in a structure to which other parts are connected.
The central column of an inflorescence or other growth.
The skull and backbone of a vertebrate animal.
The second cervical vertebra, below the atlas at the top of the backbone.
An agreement or alliance between two or more countries that forms a centre for an eventual larger grouping of nations.
The alliance of Germany and Italy formed before and during the Second World War, later extended to include Japan and other countries.
A deer that has lyre-shaped antlers and a yellowish-brown coat with white spots, native to India and Sri Lanka.
--Examples--
‘the Earth revolves on its axis once every 24 hours’
‘the variable that is thought of as a cause is placed on the horizontal axis, and the variable that is thought of as an effect on the vertical axis’
‘the leaflets are arranged in rows on a slender axis’
‘the Anglo-American axis’
‘the Axis Powers’

aband 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To abandon, give up, forsake.
--Examples--
--Word--
abandon 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cease to support or look after (someone); desert.
Leave (a place or vehicle) empty or uninhabited, without intending to return.
Condemn someone or something to (a specified fate) by ceasing to take an interest in them.
Give up completely (a practice or a course of action)
Discontinue (a scheduled event) before completion.
Allow oneself to indulge in (a desire or impulse)
Complete lack of inhibition or restraint.
--Examples--
‘her natural mother had abandoned her at an early age’
‘derelict houses were abandoned’
‘an attempt to persuade businesses not to abandon the area to inner-city deprivation’
‘he had clearly abandoned all pretence of trying to succeed’
‘negotiations were abandoned and fighting intensified’
‘fans invaded the pitch and the match was abandoned’
‘they abandoned themselves to despair’
‘she sings and sways with total abandon’

--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective, adjective

--Word--
abbasi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Persian silver coin (originally weighing approx. 9.33 grams) equivalent in value to two mahmudi or 200 dinars, first issued by the Safavid Shah Abbas I (reigned 1587–1629) and continuing in use until the 19th cent.; a money of account derived from this.

--Word--
abate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of something unpleasant or severe) become less intense or widespread.
Make (something) less intense.
Reduce or remove (a nuisance)
--Examples--
‘the storm suddenly abated’
‘nothing abated his crusading zeal’
‘this action would not have been sufficient to abate the odour nuisance’

abatement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of abating or being abated; ending or subsiding.
The reduction or removal of a nuisance.
--Examples--
‘this trend shows no sign of abatement’
‘it was resolved to serve an abatement notice’

--Word--
abat-jour 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An architectural device for deflecting the light from a wall or roof opening in a particular direction; specifically (a) a skylight set in an angled or slanting aperture or light well; (b) a screen on the outside of a window angled outward and upward so as to allow light into the room while at the same time obscuring the view below.
--Examples--
--Word--
abaton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place to which access is restricted, especially a sacred space or enclosure; a sanctuary.
Specifically. An enclosure or building attached to a temple of Asclepius, in which supplicants wishing to be cured slept.

abaxile 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the core of an apple or other pome (when viewed in transverse section): having the seed chambers arranged asymmetrically and distant from the main axis of the fruit. Of the seed chambers of the core: having this arrangement and distant from the axis of the fruit. Now rare.

noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the woof or weft in a web. Later also: the warp in a web. Frequently attributive, as "abb thread", "abb wool", etc.

noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(in the New Testament) God as father.

--Word--
Nasser, Gamal Abdel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1918–70), Egyptian colonel and statesman, prime minister 1954–6 and president 1956–70. He deposed King Farouk in 1952 and President Muhammad Neguib in 1954. His nationalization of the Suez Canal brought war with Britain, France, and Israel in 1956; he also waged two unsuccessful wars against Israel (1956 and 1967).
--Examples--

--Word--
Abdominales 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A (former) division of bony fishes comprising those with pelvic fins located on the belly, between the pectoral and anal fins; fishes of this division.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abdominalia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A former order of barnacles which bore into a variety of calcareous material, comprising typically small, shell-less forms having several pairs of cirri towards the end of the thorax.

--Word--
abdominoscopy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: examination of the abdomen by visual inspection or by other standard methods of physical examination (palpation, percussion, etc.) (now disused). In later use: endoscopic examination of the abdominal cavity.
--Examples--
--Word--
abdominous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person) having a large belly; fat.
--Examples--
--Word--
Salam, Abdus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–1996), Pakistani theoretical physicist. He independently developed a unified theory to explain electromagnetic interactions and the weak nuclear force. In 1979 he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Physics, shared with Sheldon Lee Glashow and Steven Weinberg.
--Examples--
--Word--
abduce 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Anatomy= "abduct". Now rare.
Adduce. Now rare.
Chiefly Philosophy. Originally with reference to the writings of C. S. Peirce: to form or infer (a hypothesis or explanation) by a process of abduction.
--Examples--

--Word--
abducent 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Zoology. Designating the abducens nerve; of or relating to this nerve.
Anatomy and Zoology. Originally: †an abductor muscle, especially the lateral rectus muscle of the eye (obsolete). In later use: the abducens nerve.

--Word--
abduct 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take (someone) away illegally by force or deception; kidnap.
(of a muscle) move (a limb or part) away from the midline of the body or from another part.
--Examples--
‘the millionaire who disappeared may have been abducted’
‘the posterior rectus muscle, which abducts the eye’

--Word--
abduction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of forcibly taking someone away against their will.
(in legal use) the illegal removal of a child from its parents or guardians.
The movement of a limb or other part away from the midline of the body, or from another part.
--Examples--
‘they organized the abduction of Mr Cordes on his way to the airport’
‘abductions by armed men in plain clothes’
‘the man is also accused of the attempted abduction of another youngster’
--Word--
abduction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of forcibly taking someone away against their will.
(in legal use) the illegal removal of a child from its parents or guardians.
The movement of a limb or other part away from the midline of the body, or from another part.
--Examples--
‘they organized the abduction of Mr Cordes on his way to the airport’
‘abductions by armed men in plain clothes’
‘the man is also accused of the attempted abduction of another youngster’
--Word--
abductor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who abducts another person.
A muscle whose contraction moves a limb or part away from the midline of the body, or from another part.
Any of a number of specific muscles in the hand, forearm, or foot.
--Examples--
‘she endured a two-hour ordeal at the hands of her abductors’
‘abductor pollicis’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
abductor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who abducts another person.
A muscle whose contraction moves a limb or part away from the midline of the body, or from another part.
Any of a number of specific muscles in the hand, forearm, or foot.
--Examples--
‘she endured a two-hour ordeal at the hands of her abductors’
‘abductor pollicis’
--Word--
abductor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who abducts another person.
A muscle whose contraction moves a limb or part away from the midline of the body, or from another part.
Any of a number of specific muscles in the hand, forearm, or foot.
--Examples--
‘she endured a two-hour ordeal at the hands of her abductors’
‘abductor pollicis’
--Word--
abduct 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take (someone) away illegally by force or deception; kidnap.
(of a muscle) move (a limb or part) away from the midline of the body or from another part.
--Examples--
‘the millionaire who disappeared may have been abducted’
‘the posterior rectus muscle, which abducts the eye’
--Word--
Abdul Rahman, Tunku 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–90), Malayan statesman, first prime minister of independent Malaya 1957–63 and of Malaysia 1963–70.

Fortas, Abe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1910–82), US Supreme Court associate justice 1965–69. Criticized for his financial dealings with a known criminal, he was the first justice ever forced to resign by public criticism.
--Examples--
--Word--
be- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
(forming verbs) all over; all round.
(forming verbs) thoroughly; excessively.
(added to intransitive verbs) expressing transitive action.
(added to adjectives and nouns) expressing transitive action.
(added to nouns) affect with.
(added to adjectives) cause to be.
(forming adjectives ending in -ed) having; covered with.
--Examples--
‘bespatter’
‘bewilder’
‘bemoan’
‘befool’
‘befriend’
‘befog’
‘befoul’
‘bejewelled’
--Word--
abeam 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
On a line at right angles to a ship's or an aircraft's length.
Opposite the middle of (a ship or aircraft)
--Examples--
‘the lighthouse was abeam at noon’
‘she was lying almost abeam of us’
‘before I knew it, I was abeam the ship’
--Word--
abear 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To endure, suffer; to tolerate. Now always with cannot. Compare "abide". informal and regional (chiefly English) after Middle English.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
abecedary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Alphabetical. Also, of a poem, etc.: that has each verse or line beginning with a different letter of the alphabet, in alphabetical order.
--Examples--
--Word--
abecedarium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The alphabet; especially (in early use) the Roman alphabet as opposed to the Greek; (in later use) an alphabet belonging to an ancient writing system, or an inscription of this.
In the work of British economist and logician W. S. Jevons: the series of possible combinations of letters in a system for solving logical problems; (also) the mechanical device invented by Jevons for generating and displaying these combinations.
An alphabetical wordbook or wordlist, usually elementary; especially a primer for teaching the basics of reading and spelling.

abelian

--Word--
Abelite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a small religious sect in North Africa, active in the 4th cent., for whom, according to St Augustine, marriage was compulsory but its consummation forbidden, after the supposed example of Abel (no children of whom are mentioned in the Bible).
--Examples--
--Word--
Abell 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With following numeral: any of certain galaxy clusters distinguished by their richness (i.e. the number and density of galaxies in their central regions) and listed by Abell in his catalogue.
Attributive and in the possessive. Designating rich galaxy clusters listed in Abell's catalogue; relating to such clusters. Frequently in "Abell cluster".
--Examples--
--Word--
abelmosk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several plants of the tropical genus Abelmoschus, especially A. moschatus, with aromatic seeds which yield a musky oil, formerly used medicinally and as a substitute for animal musk, and A. esculentus, the plant okra, cultivated for its edible seed pods; these pods themselves.
--Examples--

Abernathy, Ralph David 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–90), US minister and civil rights activist. He served as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) from 1968 until 1977. His autobiography, And the Walls Came Tumbling Down, was published in 1989.

--Word--
aberrating 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
aberration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
A characteristic that deviates from the normal type.
The failure of rays to converge at one focus because of a defect in a lens or mirror.
The apparent displacement of a celestial object from its true position, caused by the relative motion of the observer and the object.
--Examples--
‘they described the outbreak of violence in the area as an aberration’
‘I see these activities as some kind of mental aberration’
‘colour aberrations’
--Word--

--Type--
adjective

noun

--Word--
abide 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Accept or act in accordance with (a rule, decision, or recommendation)
Be unable to tolerate (someone or something)
(of a feeling or memory) continue without fading or being lost.
Live; dwell.
--Examples--
‘I said I would abide by their decision’
‘if there is one thing I cannot abide it is a lack of discipline’
‘at least one memory will abide’
‘many unskilful Men do abide in our City of London’

--Word--
Warburg, Aby 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1866–1929), German art historian; full name Aby Moritz Warburg. From 1905 he built up a library in Hamburg, dedicated to preserving the classical heritage of Western culture. In 1933 it was transferred to England and housed in the Warburg Institute (part of the University of London).

abietic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A terpenoid acid which is the main constituent of rosin; (also) any of a group of resin acids having structures closely related to this.
--Examples--
--Word--
abietinic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dibasic acid obtained from resin, said to have the formula C₄₄H₆₄O₅.
(In later use) = abietic acid.

--Type--

--Meanings--
Forming nouns of quality corresponding to adjectives ending in -able (such as suitability corresponding to suitable).

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Physical rather than biological; not derived from living organisms.
Devoid of life; sterile.
--Examples--
‘abiotic chemical reactions’
‘soils are seldom completely abiotic’
--Word--
abiotically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an abiotic manner; without the involvement of living cells or organisms; abiogenically.
--Examples--
--Word--
abiotically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an abiotic manner; without the involvement of living cells or organisms; abiogenically.
--Examples--
--Word--
abiotrophy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Premature degeneration of cells or tissue (now usually within the central nervous system), especially when hereditary or otherwise independent of external factors; an instance of this; any condition characterized by this.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abipon 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a South American people formerly inhabiting the Gran Chaco region of Argentina and Paraguay.
The extinct Guaycuruan language of the Abipon.
Of or designating the Abipon or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abiquiu 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A ranching community in northern New Mexico, the longtime home of artist Georgia O'Keeffe.
--Examples--
--Word--
abirritant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That reduces irritation. Also as noun: a soothing drug, ointment, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
Warburg, Aby 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1866–1929), German art historian; full name Aby Moritz Warburg. From 1905 he built up a library in Hamburg, dedicated to preserving the classical heritage of Western culture. In 1933 it was transferred to England and housed in the Warburg Institute (part of the University of London).
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
An abyss.
--Examples--
‘the abysm from which nightmares crawl’

adjective
--Meanings--
Extremely bad; appalling.

‘waterfalls that plunge into abysmal depths’

abysmally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the abysm from which nightmares crawl’
--Word--
abyss 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A deep or seemingly bottomless chasm.
A wide or profound difference between people; a gulf.
The regions of hell conceived of as a bottomless pit.
A catastrophic situation seen as likely to occur.
--Examples--
‘a rope led down into the dark abyss’
‘the abyss between the two nations’
‘Satan's dark abyss’
‘teetering on the edge of the abyss of a total political wipeout’
--Word--
abyssal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the depths or bed of the ocean, especially between about 3000 and 6000 metres down.
--Examples--
‘the abyssal depths of the Atlantic’
‘the genera found in the abyssal North Atlantic’

--Word--
abiu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An evergreen tree, Pouteria caimito (family Sapotaceae), of tropical South America, yielding hard heavy timber and edible ovoid or round fruit; (also) the fruit itself, which is yellow-skinned and has mild-flavoured, mucilaginous white flesh.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree.

‘abject poverty’

abkari 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In India: the production and sale of distilled alcoholic drinks; the duty levied on this. Also used allusively with reference to the system of managing the sale of alcohol solely through certain licensed contractors.

Abkhaz 
--Type--
adjective, noun

--Examples--
--Word--
Abkhazia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An autonomous territory in north-western Georgia, west of the Caucasus mountains on the Black Sea; population 215,972 (2003); capital, Sokhumi. In 1992 Abkhazia unilaterally declared itself independent, sparking armed conflict with Georgia, and the following year drove Georgian forces from its territory.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abkhazian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the autonomous north-western Georgian territory Abkhazia, or its people or language.
The language of the autonomous north-western Georgian territory Abkhazia.
A native or inhabitant of the autonomous north-western Georgian territory Abkhazia.
--Examples--
‘the leader of the Abkhazian government’
‘he didn't expect the traveller to speak Abkhazian’
‘the total number of Abkhazians all over the world reached 95,000 in 1983’

--Word--
ablate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Remove (body tissue) surgically.
Gradually remove material from or erode (a surface or object) by melting, evaporation, frictional action, etc., or erode (material) in this way.
--Examples--
‘therapeutic intervention to ablate existing cancer cells’
‘drying winds slowly ablate away the ice’
‘the laser beam can ablate solid rock from seven metres away’

--Word--
ablation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The surgical removal of body tissue.
The removal of snow and ice from a glacier or iceberg by melting or evaporation.
The erosion of rock, typically by wind action.
The loss of surface material from a spacecraft or meteorite through evaporation or melting caused by friction with the atmosphere.

--Word--
ablative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a case (especially in Latin) of nouns and pronouns and words in grammatical agreement with them indicating an agent, instrument, or source, expressed by ‘by’, ‘with’, or ‘from’ in English.
(of surgical treatment) involving ablation.
Relating to or subject to ablation through melting or evaporation.
A word in the ablative case.
The ablative case.
--Examples--
‘all nine patients were treated by ablative surgery’
‘the spacecraft's ablative heat shield’
--Word--
ablatively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Grammar. In the ablative case; as an ablative.
Astronautics, Materials Science, etc. By means of ablation. Chiefly with reference to protection from heat using ablative materials.
--Examples--
--Word--
ablative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a case (especially in Latin) of nouns and pronouns and words in grammatical agreement with them indicating an agent, instrument, or source, expressed by ‘by’, ‘with’, or ‘from’ in English.
(of surgical treatment) involving ablation.

The ablative case.
--Examples--
‘all nine patients were treated by ablative surgery’
‘the spacecraft's ablative heat shield’
--Word--
ablator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Astronautics and Materials Science. A protective surface layer (e.g. in a rocket engine) made of a material which ablates readily when heated and so reduces the transfer of external heat to the underlying material.
--Examples--

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1819–93), US army officer. A Union general in the Civil War, he was credited in 1908 with creating the modern game of baseball, although this claim has been discounted.

noun
--Meanings--
Habitual residence in a place; = "abode".
--Examples--
--Word--
abode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place of residence; a house or home.
Residence.
A stay; a sojourn.
--Examples--
‘my humble abode’
‘their right of abode in Britain’
--Word--
aboding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is ominous (of a specified thing); boding, portentous. Chiefly as the second element in compounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
aboding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is ominous (of a specified thing); boding, portentous. Chiefly as the second element in compounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
aboil 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Scottish. In or into a boiling state; at boiling point.
In predicative use. Boiling, seething.
--Examples--
--Word--
aboiteau 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Especially in the Maritime Provinces of Canada: a sluice gate in a dyke, which allows water draining from the land to flow out but does not allow sea water to enter.
--Examples--

aboriginal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Inhabiting or existing in a land from the earliest times or from before the arrival of colonists; indigenous.
Relating to the Australian Aborigines or their languages.

Any of the numerous Australian Aboriginal languages.

--Type--
noun, adjective

--Word--
abort 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Carry out or undergo the abortion of (a fetus)
(of a pregnant woman or female animal) have a miscarriage, with loss of the fetus.
(of an embryonic organ or organism) remain undeveloped; fail to mature.
Bring to a premature end because of a problem or fault.
An act of aborting a flight, space mission, or other enterprise.
An aborted enterprise.
--Examples--
‘the decision to abort the fetus’
‘many doctors assume that women who undergo testing would choose to abort’
‘an organism that infects sheep and can cause pregnant ewes to abort’
‘the flight crew aborted the take-off’
‘an abort because of bad weather’
‘I've wasted almost a year on an abort’

--Word--
aborter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who performs an abortion; = "abortionist". Also figurative. Now rare.
A woman who undergoes a spontaneous or induced abortion, or who does so repeatedly. Also: a female animal who aborts her young, especially as a result of infectious disease.
--Examples--
--Word--
aborter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who performs an abortion; = "abortionist". Also figurative. Now rare.
A woman who undergoes a spontaneous or induced abortion, or who does so repeatedly. Also: a female animal who aborts her young, especially as a result of infectious disease.

--Word--
abortion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The deliberate termination of a human pregnancy, most often performed during the first 28 weeks of pregnancy.
The expulsion of a fetus from the uterus by natural causes before it is able to survive independently.
The arrest of the development of a seed, fruit, or other organ.
An object or undertaking that is unpleasant or badly made or carried out.
--Examples--
‘concerns such as abortion and euthanasia’
‘illegal abortions’

--Word--
abortionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the practice of inducing abortion. In later use (depreciative): support for or advocacy for permitting induced abortion, especially as a woman's right.
--Examples--
--Word--
abortive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Failing to produce the intended result.
(of a virus infection) failing to produce symptoms.
(of an organ or organism) rudimentary; arrested in development.
Causing or resulting in abortion.
--Examples--
‘the rebel officers who led the abortive coup were shot’
‘abortive medusae’
‘abortive techniques’

--Word--
about 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
On the subject of; concerning.
So as to affect.
Used to indicate movement within a particular area.
Used to express location in a particular place.
Used to describe a quality apparent in a person.
Used to indicate movement within an area.
Used to express location in a particular place.
(used with a number or quantity) approximately.
--Examples--
‘I was thinking about you’
‘a book about ancient Greece’
‘it's all about having fun’
‘there's nothing we can do about it’
‘she looked about the room’
‘rugs were strewn about the hall’
‘he produced a knife from somewhere about his person’
‘there was a look about her that said everything’
‘men were floundering about’
‘finding my way about’
‘there was a lot of flu about’
‘reduced by about 5 per cent’
‘he's about 35’
--Word--
about-turn 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
(chiefly in military contexts) a turn made so as to face the opposite direction.
A complete change of opinion or policy.
Turn so as to face the opposite direction.
A military command to make an about-turn.
--Examples--
‘he did an about-turn and marched out of the tent’
‘the government made an about-turn over the bill’
‘suddenly he about-turned and saluted again’

--Word--
above 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
In extended space over and not touching.
Extending upwards over.
Higher than and to one side of; overlooking.
At a higher level or layer than.
Higher in grade or rank than.
Considered of higher status or worth than; too good for.
In preference to.
At a higher volume or pitch than.
Higher than (a specified amount, rate, or norm)
At a higher level or layer.
Higher in grade or rank.
Higher than a specified amount, rate, or norm.
(in printed text) mentioned earlier or further up on the same page.
--Examples--
‘a display of fireworks above the town’
‘a cable runs above the duct’
‘she held her arms above her head’
‘in the hills above the capital’
‘on the wall above the altar’
‘from his flat above the corner shop’
‘bruises above both eyes’
‘at a level above the common people’
‘I always like to say that I married above myself’
‘the firm cynically chose profit above car safety’
‘he seldom spoke above a whisper’
‘the doorbell went unheard above the din’
‘the food was well above average’
‘above sea level’
‘place a quantity of mud in a jar with water above’
‘an officer of the rank of superintendent or above’
‘boats of 31 ft or above’
‘the two cases described above’
‘see above left’
‘at the above address’
‘since writing the above, I have reconsidered’
--Word--
above board 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Legitimate, honest, and open.
--Examples--
‘certain transactions were not totally above board’
‘the accountants acted completely above board’

‘any of the above-named books will give the interested reader much more information’
--Word--
above-quoted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Quoted previously in the present text.
--Examples--
--Word--
reported 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having been formally or officially announced or described.
Described or talked of, but not verified or confirmed.
--Examples--
‘an increase in reported crime’
‘there have been 122 reported cases of influenza in Boston since October’
‘he's now a reported £50,000 in debt’
‘fans were agog with news of a reported training ground bust-up’
--Word--
above 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
In extended space over and not touching.
Extending upwards over.
Higher than and to one side of; overlooking.
At a higher level or layer than.
Higher in grade or rank than.
Considered of higher status or worth than; too good for.
In preference to.
At a higher volume or pitch than.
Higher than (a specified amount, rate, or norm)
At a higher level or layer.
Higher in grade or rank.
Higher than a specified amount, rate, or norm.
(in printed text) mentioned earlier or further up on the same page.
--Examples--
‘a display of fireworks above the town’
‘a cable runs above the duct’
‘she held her arms above her head’
‘in the hills above the capital’
‘on the wall above the altar’
‘from his flat above the corner shop’
‘bruises above both eyes’
‘at a level above the common people’
‘I always like to say that I married above myself’
‘the firm cynically chose profit above car safety’
‘he seldom spoke above a whisper’
‘the doorbell went unheard above the din’
‘the food was well above average’
‘above sea level’
‘place a quantity of mud in a jar with water above’
‘an officer of the rank of superintendent or above’
‘boats of 31 ft or above’
‘the two cases described above’
‘see above left’
‘at the above address’
‘since writing the above, I have reconsidered’

abovesaid

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Mentioned previously in the present text; aforesaid.
A person or thing mentioned previously in the present text; the aforesaid.

--Type--
exclamation, noun

A word said by conjurors when performing a magic trick.

--Word--
Abraham 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in the Bible) the Hebrew patriarch from whom all Jews trace their descent (Gen. 11:27–25:10). In Gen. 22 he is ordered by God to sacrifice his son Isaac as a test of faith, a command later revoked.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abrahamic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting any or all of the religions (Judaism, Christianity, and Islam) that revere Abraham, the Biblical patriarch.
Relating specifically to the Biblical patriarch Abraham.
--Examples--
‘the monotheistic faiths that grew out of the Abrahamic heritage’
--Word--
Abraham man 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A beggar claiming to have been released on licence from the Hospital of St Mary of Bethlehem in London, or any similar institution; (more generally) any vagabond or petty criminal who feigns insanity, especially in order to obtain money by begging.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abraham man 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A beggar claiming to have been released on licence from the Hospital of St Mary of Bethlehem in London, or any similar institution; (more generally) any vagabond or petty criminal who feigns insanity, especially in order to obtain money by begging.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abrahams, Harold 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1899–1978), English athlete; full name Harold Maurice Abrahams. In 1924 he became the first Englishman to win the 100 metres in the Olympic Games. His story was the subject of the film Chariots of Fire (1981).
--Examples--
--Word--
Garfield, James Abram 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1831–81), American Republican statesman, 20th president of the US March–September 1881. He was assassinated within months of becoming president.
--Examples--

abranchiate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

abrasax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instance or utterance of the cabbalistic word ‘abrasax’, supposed (especially in Gnosticism) to act as a charm. Frequently attributive, especially with reference to inscribing such a charm on a stone.

--Word--
abrasive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a substance or material) capable of polishing or cleaning a hard surface by rubbing or grinding.
Tending to rub or graze the skin.
Showing little concern for the feelings of others; harsh.
A substance used for grinding, polishing, or cleaning a hard surface.
--Examples--
‘the wood should be rubbed down with fine abrasive paper’
‘don't use abrasive kitchen cleaners’
‘the trees were abrasive to the touch’
‘her abrasive and arrogant personal style won her few friends’
‘the refrigerator is easily damaged by abrasives’

--Word--
abraum salt 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In plural: a mixture of salts, including chlorides and sulphates of sodium, potassium, and magnesium, found associated with rock salt at Stassfurt, Germany. In singular: any such salt; such salts collectively.

--Word--
abreaction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The expression and consequent release of a previously repressed emotion, achieved through reliving the experience that caused it (typically through hypnosis or suggestion)
--Examples--
‘he was using dream abreaction to treat a schizoid patient’
‘a series of interviews and abreactions’

abroad 
--Type--
adverb, noun
--Meanings--
In or to a foreign country or countries.
In different directions; over a wide area.
(of a feeling or rumour) widely current.
Freely moving about.
Out of doors.
Wide of the mark; in error.
Foreign countries considered collectively.

‘there is a new buccaneering spirit abroad’
‘hospital inmates abroad on the streets of the town’
‘few people ventured abroad from their warm houses’
‘servicemen returning from abroad’

adjective

--Word--
abscond 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
(of a person on bail) fail to surrender oneself for custody at the appointed time.
(of a colony of honeybees, especially Africanized ones) entirely abandon a hive or nest.
--Examples--
‘the barman absconded with a week's takings’
‘176 detainees absconded’
‘charges of absconding while on bail’

noun
--Meanings--
The action or an act of absconding; (a) concealment, seclusion; (b) removal to a place of concealment or hiding; flight, especially from creditors, arrest, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
absconder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
absconder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
abscond 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
(of a person on bail) fail to surrender oneself for custody at the appointed time.
(of a colony of honeybees, especially Africanized ones) entirely abandon a hive or nest.
--Examples--
‘the barman absconded with a week's takings’
‘176 detainees absconded’
‘charges of absconding while on bail’
--Word--
abscond 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
(of a person on bail) fail to surrender oneself for custody at the appointed time.
(of a colony of honeybees, especially Africanized ones) entirely abandon a hive or nest.
--Examples--
‘the barman absconded with a week's takings’
‘176 detainees absconded’
‘charges of absconding while on bail’
--Word--
abseil 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Descend a rock face or other near-vertical surface by using a doubled rope coiled round the body and fixed at a higher point.
A descent made by abseiling.
--Examples--
‘team members had to abseil down sheer cliffs to reach the couple’
‘a 120 ft abseil’
--Word--
abseil 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Descend a rock face or other near-vertical surface by using a doubled rope coiled round the body and fixed at a higher point.

‘team members had to abseil down sheer cliffs to reach the couple’
‘a 120 ft abseil’
--Word--
abseiling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The sport or activity of descending a rock face or other near-vertical surface by using a doubled rope coiled round the body and fixed at a higher point.
--Examples--
‘there are facilities for abseiling and rock climbing’

--Word--
absence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being away from a place or person.
An occasion or period of being away from a place or person.
The non-existence or lack of.
--Examples--
‘the letter had arrived during his absence’
‘I supervised the rehearsal in the absence of the director’
‘repeated absences from school’
‘she found his total absence of facial expression disconcerting’

--Word--
absent 
--Type--
adjective, verb, preposition
--Meanings--
Not present in a place, at an occasion, or as part of something.
(of an expression or manner) showing that someone is not paying attention to what is being said or done.
Go away or remain away.
Without.
--Examples--
‘most pupils were absent from school at least once’
‘absent colleagues’
‘wings are absent in several species of crane flies’
‘she looked up with an absent smile’
‘halfway through the meal, he absented himself from the table’
‘absent a willingness to negotiate, you can't have collective bargaining’
--Word--
absentness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being absent in mind; distractedness, absent-mindedness.
--Examples--

--Word--
absinthe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A potent green aniseed-flavoured alcoholic spirit, made with the shrub wormwood.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A potent green aniseed-flavoured alcoholic spirit, made with the shrub wormwood.

absinthe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A potent green aniseed-flavoured alcoholic spirit, made with the shrub wormwood.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or suggestive of wormwood; (figurative) bitter, harsh.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or suggestive of wormwood; bitter, harsh. In later use also: of or relating to absinthe and its properties (especially its yellow-green colour).
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthiated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Impregnated or flavoured with wormwood. In later use: steeped in or affected by absinthe (also figurative).
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthiated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Impregnated or flavoured with wormwood. In later use: steeped in or affected by absinthe (also figurative).

absinthiated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Impregnated or flavoured with wormwood. In later use: steeped in or affected by absinthe (also figurative).
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acid reportedly obtained from common wormwood, Artemisia absinthium, and sometimes identified with succinic acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange crystalline compound that is the chief bitter constituent of common wormwood, Artemisia absinthium.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the characteristics of wormwood; bitter, harsh.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Acute or (usually) chronic intoxication with absinthe.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The plant absinth; (also) the dried leaves and flowering tops of the plant, especially as an ingredient of drinks and herbal remedies. Formerly also †figurative.
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An oily liquid that is a constituent of several essential oils, notably oil of wormwood; = "thujone".
--Examples--
--Word--
absinthism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Acute or (usually) chronic intoxication with absinthe.
--Examples--
--Word--
absit omen 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
Used when referring to something undesirable, in the hope that the thing mentioned will not occur.
--Examples--
--Word--
absolute 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Not qualified or diminished in any way; total.
Used for emphasis when expressing an opinion.
(of powers or rights) not subject to any limitation; unconditional.
(of a ruler) having unrestricted power.
(of a decree) final.
Viewed or existing independently and not in relation to other things; not relative or comparative.
(of a construction) syntactically independent of the rest of the sentence, as in dinner being over, we left the table.
(of a transitive verb) used without an expressed object (e.g. guns kill).
(of an adjective) used without an expressed noun (e.g. the brave).
A value or principle which is regarded as universally valid or which may be viewed without relation to other things.
Something that exists without being dependent on anything else.
Ultimate reality; God.
--Examples--
‘absolute secrecy’
‘absolute silence’
‘the policy is absolute folly’
‘no one dare challenge her absolute authority’
‘the right to life is absolute’
‘Dom Miguel proclaimed himself absolute monarch’
‘the decree of nullity was made absolute’
‘absolute moral standards’
‘good and evil are presented as absolutes’
--Word--
absolutely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With no qualification, restriction, or limitation; totally.
Used to emphasize a strong or exaggerated statement.
None whatsoever.
Used to express and emphasize one's assent or agreement.
Not viewed in relation to other things.
(of a verb) without a stated object.
--Examples--
‘she trusted him absolutely’
‘you're absolutely right’
‘he absolutely adores that car’
‘Dad was absolutely furious’
‘she had absolutely no idea what he was talking about’
‘‘Did they give you a free hand when you joined the band?’ ‘Absolutely!’’
‘white-collar crime increased both absolutely and in comparison with other categories’

absolutize

--Meanings--
Make or treat (something) as absolute.
--Examples--
‘modes of absolutizing what is merely relative’
--Word--
absolute 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Not qualified or diminished in any way; total.
Used for emphasis when expressing an opinion.
(of powers or rights) not subject to any limitation; unconditional.
(of a ruler) having unrestricted power.
(of a decree) final.
Viewed or existing independently and not in relation to other things; not relative or comparative.
(of a construction) syntactically independent of the rest of the sentence, as in dinner being over, we left the table.
(of a transitive verb) used without an expressed object (e.g. guns kill).
(of an adjective) used without an expressed noun (e.g. the brave).
A value or principle which is regarded as universally valid or which may be viewed without relation to other things.
Something that exists without being dependent on anything else.
Ultimate reality; God.
--Examples--
‘absolute secrecy’
‘absolute silence’
‘the policy is absolute folly’
‘no one dare challenge her absolute authority’
‘the right to life is absolute’
‘Dom Miguel proclaimed himself absolute monarch’
‘the decree of nullity was made absolute’
‘absolute moral standards’
‘good and evil are presented as absolutes’

noun

‘she had been granted absolution for her sins’

‘these claims might strike many people as absolutist and extreme’

--Word--
absolvitor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A decree or decision of a court in favour of a defendant in an action. Also as postpositive. In later use only in "decree of absolvitor".
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--
Out of tune; unharmonious, dissonant.

--Examples--
--Word--
absorb 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take in or soak up (energy or a liquid or other substance) by chemical or physical action.
Take in and understand fully (information, ideas, or experience)
Take control of (a smaller or less powerful entity) and make it a part of a larger one.
Use or take up (time or resources)
Take up and reduce the effect or intensity of (sound or an impact)
Take up the attention of (someone); interest greatly.
--Examples--
‘buildings can be designed to absorb and retain heat’
‘steroids are absorbed into the bloodstream’
‘she absorbed the information in silence’
‘the family firm was absorbed into a larger group’
‘arms spending absorbs roughly two per cent of the national income’
‘deep-pile carpets absorbed all sound of the outside world’
‘she sat in an armchair, absorbed in a book’
‘the work absorbed him and continued to make him happy’
--Word--
absorbability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
absorbable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be absorbed, especially into the body.
--Examples--
--Word--
absorbance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A measure of the capacity of a substance to absorb light of a specified wavelength. It is equal to the logarithm of the reciprocal of the transmittance.
--Examples--
‘a plot of absorbance versus wavelength would give a Gaussian curve’
‘absorbances were recorded with a clinical photometer’
--Word--
absorbancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Absorbency.
Physics. The ratio of the absorbance of a solution to that of a similar body of pure solvent, giving a measure of the concentration of the solute.
--Examples--

absorptance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

abstain 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something.
Refrain from drinking alcohol.
Formally decline to vote either for or against a proposal or motion.
--Examples--
‘she intends to abstain from sex before marriage’
‘most pregnant women abstain or drink very little’
‘forty-one voted with the Opposition, and some sixty more abstained’
--Word--
abstain 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something.
Refrain from drinking alcohol.
Formally decline to vote either for or against a proposal or motion.
--Examples--
‘she intends to abstain from sex before marriage’
‘most pregnant women abstain or drink very little’
‘forty-one voted with the Opposition, and some sixty more abstained’

noun

--Type--

--Word--
abstract 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence.
Dealing with ideas rather than events.
Not based on a particular instance; theoretical.
(of a noun) denoting an idea, quality, or state rather than a concrete object.
Relating to or denoting art that does not attempt to represent external reality, but rather seeks to achieve its effect using shapes, colours, and textures.
Consider something theoretically or separately from (something else)
Extract or remove (something)
Used euphemistically to indicate that someone has stolen something.
Withdraw.
Make a written summary of (an article or book)
A summary of the contents of a book, article, or speech.
An abstract work of art.
--Examples--
‘abstract concepts such as love or beauty’
‘the novel was too abstract and esoteric to sustain much attention’
‘we have been discussing the problem in a very abstract manner’
‘abstract pictures’
‘to abstract science and religion from their historical context can lead to anachronism’
‘applications to abstract more water from streams’
‘his pockets contained all he had been able to abstract from the flat’
‘as our relationship deepened you seemed to abstract yourself’
‘staff who abstract material for an online database’
‘an abstract of her speech’
‘a big unframed abstract’
--Word--
abstractable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being abstracted from something or someone, especially capable of being treated separately or in the abstract.
--Examples--
--Word--
abstracted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking concentration on what is happening around one.
--Examples--
‘she seemed abstracted and unaware of her surroundings’
‘an abstracted smile’
--Word--
abstractedly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
abstractedness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Separation; apartness, isolation. Chiefly with from.
A state of seclusion or withdrawal from worldly or sensual things; contemplation of or concentration on the spiritual. Frequently with from. Now rare and chiefly historical.
The quality of existing or being presented in abstract form, rather than with reference to concrete details or particular instances.
Lack of awareness of or concentration on what is happening around one; absence of mind.
--Examples--
--Word--
abstractor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who analyses or summarizes information, in particular a person whose job is to collect and maintain data or records.
--Examples--
‘we require an abstractor for our new research and development centre’

abstract 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence.
Dealing with ideas rather than events.
Not based on a particular instance; theoretical.

Extract or remove (something)

A summary of the contents of a book, article, or speech.
An abstract work of art.

--Word--
abstraction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of dealing with ideas rather than events.
Something which exists only as an idea.
Freedom from representational qualities in art.
An abstract work of art.
A state of preoccupation.
The process of considering something independently of its associations or attributes.
The process of removing something, especially water from a river or other source.
--Examples--
‘topics will vary in degrees of abstraction’
‘the question can no longer be treated as an academic abstraction’
‘geometric abstraction has been a mainstay in her work’
‘critics sought the meaning of O'Keeffe's abstractions’
‘a series of black-and-white abstractions’
‘she sensed his momentary abstraction’
‘the question cannot be considered in abstraction from the historical context in which it was raised’
‘the abstraction of water from springs and wells’
‘abstractions from the Lowther in Cumbria’
--Word--
abstractional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to abstraction, especially to the consideration of things in the abstract.
--Examples--
--Word--
abstractionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The principles and practice of abstract art.
The presentation of ideas in abstract terms.
--Examples--
‘O'Keeffe did not abandon abstractionism’
‘his tendency to abstractionism’

--Word--
abstractive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or expressing abstract ideas or concepts; engaged in, or able to engage in, the process of considering something theoretically or in the abstract.
A person, thing, or other entity which is characterized by being abstract; (now) specifically an abstract noun.

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an abstract manner, rather than in relation to concrete examples or particular instances; in the abstract; abstractly.

noun

--Word--
abstractness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being abstract, especially the quality of existing or being presented in abstract form, rather than with reference to concrete details or particular instances (frequently opposed to concreteness). Also occasionally: an example of this; an abstraction.

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
abstriction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. Separation or detachment by constriction; formation by this means; (Mycology) the separation of a spore from a hypha or sporangiophore, especially by narrowing of the connecting tissue and usually preceded by the formation of a septum.
--Examples--

--Word--
ad absurdum 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
To the point of absurdity; so as to demonstrate that the consequence of making a particular assumption is something absurd or contradictory; (also more generally) to an absurd or extreme degree.
Designating a method of demonstrating the falsity of a hypothesis by showing that the consequence of assuming it to be true is something absurd or contradictory; relating to or characteristic of such a hypothesis or demonstration.
--Examples--

abt.

--Meanings--

abthane

--Meanings--

In the early Scottish church: an abbacy; the lands of an abbey.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abu Simbel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The site of two huge rock-cut temples in southern Egypt, built during the reign of Ramses II in the 13th century BC and commemorating him and his first wife Nefertari. Following the building of the High Dam at Aswan, the monument was rebuilt higher up the hillside.
--Examples--

--Word--
Abu Simbel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The site of two huge rock-cut temples in southern Egypt, built during the reign of Ramses II in the 13th century BC and commemorating him and his first wife Nefertari. Following the building of the High Dam at Aswan, the monument was rebuilt higher up the hillside.

--Word--
abundance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very large quantity of something.
The state or condition of having a copious quantity of something; plentifulness.
Plentifulness of the good things of life; prosperity.
The quantity or amount of something present in a particular area, volume, or sample.
(in solo whist) a bid by which a player undertakes to make nine or more tricks.
--Examples--
‘the tropical island boasts an abundance of wildlife’
‘vines and figs grew in abundance’
‘she was blessed with talent and charm in abundance’
‘the growth of industry promised wealth and abundance’
‘estimates of the abundance of harp seals’
--Word--
abundance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very large quantity of something.
The state or condition of having a copious quantity of something; plentifulness.
Plentifulness of the good things of life; prosperity.
The quantity or amount of something present in a particular area, volume, or sample.

--Word--
abusage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Abuse, misuse. Formerly also: immoral behaviour; defilement. In later use frequently contrasted with usage.
--Examples--
--Word--
abuse 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Use (something) to bad effect or for a bad purpose; misuse.
Make excessive and habitual use of (alcohol or drugs, especially illegal ones)
Treat with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
Assault (someone, especially a woman or child) sexually.
Masturbate.
Use or treat in such a way as to cause damage or harm.
Speak to (someone) in an insulting and offensive way.
The improper use of something.
Unjust or corrupt practice.
Cruel and violent treatment of a person or animal.
Violent treatment involving sexual assault, especially on a regular basis.
Insulting and offensive language.
--Examples--
‘the judge abused his power by imposing the fines’
‘at various times in her life she abused both alcohol and drugs’
‘riders who abuse their horses should be prosecuted’
‘he was a depraved man who had abused his two young daughters’
‘he had been abusing his body for years’
‘the referee was abused by players from both teams’
‘alcohol abuse’
‘an abuse of public funds’
‘protection against fraud and abuse’
‘human rights abuses’
‘a black eye and other signs of physical abuse’
‘young people who have suffered sexual abuse’
‘waving his fists and hurling abuse at the driver’
--Word--
abused 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or animal) treated with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
Used in a wrong or inappropriate way.
--Examples--
‘abused children’
‘an abused rescue dog’
‘‘next generation’ is an abused term’
‘food can be an abused substance’
--Word--
abusee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is or has been abused.
--Examples--
--Word--
abuseful 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Full of abuse; abusive; harmful. In later use frequently used jocularly in contrast with useful.
--Examples--
--Word--
abusefully 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an abusive manner; abusively; improperly.
--Examples--
--Word--
ab-usefulness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Capacity to be used improperly.
--Examples--
--Word--
abuser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who uses something to bad effect or for a bad purpose.
A person who makes excessive and habitual use of alcohol or drugs, especially illegal ones.
A person who treats another person or animal with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
A person who sexually assaults someone, especially a woman or child.
--Examples--
‘notorious abusers of the English language’
‘a chronic cocaine abuser’
‘abusers often control the victim's access to friends and family’
‘how much do we know about what makes someone a sexual abuser?’
--Word--
abuser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who uses something to bad effect or for a bad purpose.
A person who makes excessive and habitual use of alcohol or drugs, especially illegal ones.
A person who treats another person or animal with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
A person who sexually assaults someone, especially a woman or child.
--Examples--
‘notorious abusers of the English language’
‘a chronic cocaine abuser’
‘abusers often control the victim's access to friends and family’
‘how much do we know about what makes someone a sexual abuser?’
--Word--
abuse 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Use (something) to bad effect or for a bad purpose; misuse.
Make excessive and habitual use of (alcohol or drugs, especially illegal ones)
Treat with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
Assault (someone, especially a woman or child) sexually.
Masturbate.
Use or treat in such a way as to cause damage or harm.
Speak to (someone) in an insulting and offensive way.
The improper use of something.
Unjust or corrupt practice.
Cruel and violent treatment of a person or animal.
Violent treatment involving sexual assault, especially on a regular basis.
Insulting and offensive language.
--Examples--
‘the judge abused his power by imposing the fines’
‘at various times in her life she abused both alcohol and drugs’
‘riders who abuse their horses should be prosecuted’
‘he was a depraved man who had abused his two young daughters’
‘he had been abusing his body for years’
‘the referee was abused by players from both teams’
‘alcohol abuse’
‘an abuse of public funds’
‘protection against fraud and abuse’
‘human rights abuses’
‘a black eye and other signs of physical abuse’
‘young people who have suffered sexual abuse’
‘waving his fists and hurling abuse at the driver’
--Word--

--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
abusive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Extremely offensive and insulting.
Engaging in or characterized by habitual violence and cruelty.
Involving injustice or illegality.
--Examples--
‘the goalkeeper was sent off for using abusive language’
‘he became quite abusive and swore at her’
‘abusive parents’
‘an abusive relationship’
‘the abusive and predatory practices of businesses’

--Word--
abut 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a building or an area of land) be next to or have a common boundary with.
Touch or lean on.
--Examples--
‘gardens abutting Great Prescott Street’
‘a park abutting on an area of waste land’
‘masonry may crumble where a roof abuts it’
--Word--
abutilon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant or shrub of warm climates, typically bearing showy yellow, red, or mauve flowers and sometimes used for fibre.

--Word--
abutment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A structure built to support the lateral pressure of an arch or span, e.g. at the ends of a bridge.
The process of supporting something with an abutment.
A point at which something abuts against something else.
--Examples--
‘the first bridge was of timber with stone abutments’
‘efficient abutment is needed at this point’
‘a mirror with a delicate border of engraved blue glass in ten sections, each abutment masked by a thin metal strip’

acacia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tree or shrub of warm climates which bears spikes or clusters of yellow or white flowers and is typically thorny.
--Examples--
--Word--
Acacian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower of the Arian Christological doctrines of Acacius, a 4th-cent. bishop of Caesarea.
Of, relating to, or associated with Acacius, a 4th-cent. Arian bishop of Caesarea, or his doctrines.
Of, relating to, or associated with Acacius, a 5th-cent. Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, who caused a split between the Eastern and Western Church from 484 to 519; especially in "Acacian schism".
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
academe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The academic environment or community; academia.
--Examples--
‘bridging the gap between industry and academe’
‘a lifetime in the groves of academe’
--Word--
academy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place of study or training in a special field.
A place of study.
(in England) an inner-city school which is funded by the government and sometimes also by a private individual or organization but is not controlled by the local authority.
A secondary school, in the US typically a private one.
The teaching school founded by Plato.
A society or institution of distinguished scholars and artists or scientists that aims to promote and maintain standards in its particular field.
--Examples--
‘a police academy’
‘he was educated privately at academies in Margate’
‘Mark left St Andrews Academy with five highers, and studied maths at Glasgow University’
‘the Royal Academy of Arts’
--Word--
academia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The environment or community concerned with the pursuit of research, education, and scholarship.
--Examples--
‘he spent his working life in academia’
--Word--
academian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an academy; an academician or (now less commonly) academic.
--Examples--
--Word--
academia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The environment or community concerned with the pursuit of research, education, and scholarship.
--Examples--
‘he spent his working life in academia’
--Word--
academic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to education and scholarship.
Relating to an educational or scholarly institution or environment.
(of an institution or a course of study) placing a greater emphasis on reading and study than on technical or practical work.
(of a person) interested in or excelling at scholarly pursuits and activities.
(of an art form) conventional, especially in an idealized or excessively formal way.
Not of practical relevance; of only theoretical interest.
A teacher or scholar in a university or other institute of higher education.
--Examples--
‘academic achievement’
‘he had no academic qualifications’
‘students resplendent in academic dress’
‘a very academic school aiming to get pupils into Oxford or Cambridge’
‘Ben is not an academic child but he tries hard’
‘academic painting’
‘the debate has been largely academic’
‘the EU offers grants to academics for research on approved projects’
--Word--
academical 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to a college or university.
Formal university attire.
--Examples--
‘the academical year’
‘the procession was robed in academicals’
--Word--
academically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that relates to education and scholarship.
--Examples--
‘applicants must excel academically’
--Word--
academical 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to a college or university.
Formal university attire.
--Examples--
‘the academical year’
‘the procession was robed in academicals’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an academy, especially the Royal Academy of Arts or the Académie française.
An academic or intellectual.

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Académie française 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A French literary academy responsible for the standard form of the French language and for compiling and revising a definitive dictionary of the French language.
--Examples--

--Word--
academize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To bring under the influence or control of an academy.
British Education. Chiefly in form academise. In England: to convert (a school) into an independent publicly run academy. Also without object: (of a school) to become an academy.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the opposition between academicism and creative authenticity’
--Word--
Academite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Also with lower-case initial. A member of any of various academies; especially a member of the Royal Naval Academy, at Portsmouth (now historical).

--Word--
Acadia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former French colony established in 1604 in the territory now forming Nova Scotia in Canada. It was contested by France and Britain until it was eventually ceded to Britain in 1763; French-speaking Acadians were deported to other parts of North America, especially Louisiana.
--Examples--
--Word--
acadialite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A reddish mineral long recognized as a particular form of chabazite.
--Examples--
--Word--
Acadian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Acadia or its people.
A native or inhabitant of Acadia.
A French-speaking descendant of the early French settlers in Acadia.
A descendant of the Acadians deported to Louisiana in the 18th century; a Cajun.

--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming adjectives such as maniacal, often from nouns ending in -ac (as in maniacal from maniac).

acalculia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Loss of the ability to perform simple calculations, typically resulting from disease or injury of the parietal lobe of the brain.

--Word--
Acalepha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural: a former class of coelenterate organisms including jellyfish, comb jellies, siphonophores, and (originally) sea anemones. With singular concord (also in form acalepha): an animal of this class (usually in plural, the animals of this class collectively).
--Examples--
--Word--
acalyculate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Zoology. Of a hemipenis of a snake or lizard: lacking calyces (sculptured surface features with a central depression).
--Examples--
--Word--
acalypha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any plant of the large genus Acalypha (family Euphorbiaceae), comprising herbs and shrubs found in tropical and subtropical climates, including the chenille plant, A. hispida. Also (in form Acalypha): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
acanonical
