adjective
--Meanings--
Not included in a canon, specifically the biblical canon; uncanonical.

--Word--
acanthaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of an acanthus; (in later use) specifically belonging to or characteristic of the family Acanthaceae, comprising chiefly tropical shrubs and vines and having the genus Acanthus as the type genus.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
Acanthopterygii 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A class (or subclass) of bony fishes comprising the ray-finned fishes, characterized by having hard and spiny rays in the dorsal fins.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disease of the skin affecting the prickle-cell layer (stratum spinosum) of the epidermis; hyperplasia of prickle cells; an instance of this.

acanthosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disease of the skin affecting the prickle-cell layer (stratum spinosum) of the epidermis; hyperplasia of prickle cells; an instance of this.

acanthus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant or shrub with bold flower spikes and spiny decorative leaves, found in warm regions of the Old World.
A conventionalized representation of an acanthus leaf, used especially as a decoration for Corinthian column capitals.

A herbaceous plant or shrub with bold flower spikes and spiny decorative leaves, found in warm regions of the Old World.

acapnia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Reduction of the level of carbon dioxide in the blood; = "hypocapnia". Also: absence of carbon dioxide in the blood or in an organism's ambient atmosphere (rare).

Acari 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A large order (or subclass) of small arachnids which comprises the mites and ticks. They are distinguished by an apparent lack of body divisions.
--Examples--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Acaridae 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A family of arachnids, originally comprising the mites and ticks (equivalent to the current subclass Acari), and in later use restricted to certain small mites.

Acari 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A large order (or subclass) of small arachnids which comprises the mites and ticks. They are distinguished by an apparent lack of body divisions.
--Examples--
--Word--
acarine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small arachnid of the order Acari; a mite or tick.
Relating to or denoting acarines.
--Examples--
--Word--
acarine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small arachnid of the order Acari; a mite or tick.
Relating to or denoting acarines.
--Examples--
--Word--
acaroid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A resin obtained in Australia from some kinds of grass tree, used in making varnish.
--Examples--
--Word--
acarology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of mites and ticks.
--Examples--
--Word--
acarologist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
acarophilous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That lives in or is adapted for a symbiotic relationship with mites; specifically (of a plant) pollinated by mites.
--Examples--
--Word--
acarpous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not producing fruit; unfruitful, sterile; (Botany). Frequently figurative: failing to achieve the desired results, unproductive; barren.
--Examples--
--Word--
acarus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mite or tick; specifically (in later use) a mite of the genus Acarus (family Acaridae). Also (in form Acarus): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
ACAS 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
(in the UK) Advisory, Conciliation, and Arbitration Service.
--Examples--
--Word--
acatalectic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a line of verse) having the full number of syllables.
A line of acatalectic verse.
--Examples--
--Word--
acatalepsy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Unknowability, incomprehensibility, originally as a characteristic of all things, according to the ancient Sceptics. Hence also: scepticism, profession of ignorance.
--Examples--
--Word--
acataleptic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An adherent of the doctrine of acatalepsy; a sceptic.
Incomprehensible, unknowable.
Of or relating to acatalepsy; adhering to the doctrine of acatalepsy, sceptical.
--Examples--
--Word--
acatallactic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not concerned with or involving exchange, especially of money.
--Examples--
--Word--
acategorical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not belonging to or fitting into a category; not using categories or categorization; unsystematic in reasoning.
--Examples--
--Word--
acater 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A purchaser of provisions; a provider or preparer of foodstuffs or delicacies; a purveyor, a caterer.
--Examples--
--Word--
acatry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) Provisions bought in rather than made in the house, especially meat and fish. (b) A place of storage of, or staff responsible for, such provisions in a large household, specifically the English royal household.
--Examples--
--Word--
acatholic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Non-Catholic; especially a non-Catholic inhabitant of a Catholic state.
Non-Catholic.

--Examples--
--Word--
Akkadian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of Akkad.
The extinct language of Akkad, written in cuneiform, with two dialects, Assyrian and Babylonian, widely used from about 3500 BC. It is the oldest Semitic language for which records exist.
Relating to Akkad or its language.
--Examples--
--Word--
accede 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Agree to a demand, request, or treaty.
Assume an office or position.
Become a member of an organization.
--Examples--
‘the authorities did not accede to the strikers' demands’
‘Elizabeth I acceded to the throne in 1558’
‘Albania acceded to the IMF in 1990’

UnKnownKind, noun

accelerant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance used to aid the spread of fire.

--Examples--
‘stolen accelerants could be used as fire bombs’
‘accelerant factors for carcinoma’
--Word--
accelerate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(especially of a vehicle) begin to move more quickly.
Increase in rate, amount, or extent.
Undergo a change in velocity.
--Examples--
‘the car accelerated towards her’
‘inflation started to accelerate’
‘the key question is whether stress accelerates ageing’
‘an accelerating electron radiates off some of its energy’

noun

--Word--
accelerator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that causes something to happen or develop more quickly.
A venture or scheme that promotes and aids the rapid growth of selected new small businesses.
A device, typically a foot pedal, which controls the speed of a vehicle's engine.
An apparatus for accelerating charged particles to high velocities; a particle accelerator.
A substance that speeds up a chemical process.
--Examples--
‘the country has been the main accelerator of global growth for a decade’
‘an accelerator for start-up technology companies in Buenos Aires’
‘a record number of women-led start-ups are participating in the accelerator program’
‘he pressed the accelerator to the floor and the taxi shot forward’
‘the bank will have its foot on the accelerator until the economy starts to recover’
‘electron accelerators’

adjective
--Meanings--

accension

noun

--Examples--
--Word--
accent 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A distinctive way of pronouncing a language, especially one associated with a particular country, area, or social class.
A distinct emphasis given to a syllable or word in speech by stress or pitch.
A mark on a letter, typically a vowel, to indicate pitch, stress, or vowel quality.
An emphasis on a particular note or chord.
A special or particular emphasis.
A feature which gives a distinctive visual emphasis to something.
Emphasize (a particular feature)
Play (a note or beat) with emphasis.
--Examples--
‘a strong American accent’
‘she never mastered the French accent’
‘the accent falls on the middle syllable’
‘a circumflex accent’
‘short fortissimo accents’
‘the accent is on participation’
‘blue woodwork and accents of red’
‘fabrics which accent the background colours in the room’
‘the quick tempo means there is less scope for accenting offbeat notes’
--Word--
accented 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Spoken with or characterized by a particular accent.
(of a word, syllable, or musical note or chord) stressed or emphasized.
--Examples--
‘he spoke in slightly accented English’
‘a metrical foot consisting of two unaccented syllables followed by one accented syllable’
--Word--
accent 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A distinctive way of pronouncing a language, especially one associated with a particular country, area, or social class.

‘fabrics which accent the background colours in the room’
‘the quick tempo means there is less scope for accenting offbeat notes’
--Word--
accentless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not having vocal accent or stress; not having musical or rhythmic stress; unaccented.
Not characterized by a foreign, regional, or class accent.

accentuator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who accentuates something; specifically a person who marks words with written accents.
A device or substance for accentuating something; a means of accentuation; specifically (a) a device for marking accents and keeping time in music; (b) a garment or device for accentuating a woman's breasts.

--Examples--
--Word--
accept 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Consent to receive or undertake (something offered)
Give an affirmative answer to (an offer or proposal); say yes to.
Say yes to a proposal of marriage from (a man)
Receive as adequate, valid, or suitable.
Regard favourably or with approval; welcome.
(of a thing) be designed to allow (something) to be inserted or applied.
Believe or come to recognize (a proposition) as valid or correct.
Take upon oneself (a responsibility or liability); acknowledge.
Tolerate or submit to (something unpleasant or undesired)
--Examples--
‘he accepted a pen as a present’
‘she accepted a temporary post as a clerk’
‘he would accept their offer and see what happened’
‘Tim offered Brian a lift home and he accepted’
‘what if Elizabeth accepted Darcy the first time?’
‘the college accepted her as a student’
‘credit cards are widely accepted’
‘the Irish never accepted him as one of them’
‘vending machines that accepted 100-yen coins for cans of beer’
‘this tentative explanation came to be accepted by the men’
‘it is accepted that ageing is a continuous process’
‘Jenkins is willing to accept his responsibility’
‘he accepts that he made a mistake’
‘they accepted the need to cut overheads’
--Word--
acceptability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being tolerated or allowed.
The quality of being accepted.
--Examples--
‘what has changed is the social acceptability of such actions’
‘it was simply beyond the limits of acceptability to attack someone who could not defend himself’
‘money derives its purchasing power entirely from its acceptability as a medium of exchange’

acceptably

adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
acceptable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be agreed on; suitable.
Moderately good; satisfactory.
Pleasing; welcome.
Able to be tolerated or allowed.
--Examples--
‘the electoral arrangements must be acceptable to the people’
‘an acceptable substitute for champagne’
‘some coffee would be most acceptable’
‘pollution in the city had reached four times the acceptable level’

--Word--
acceptance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of consenting to receive or undertake something offered.
A draft or bill of exchange that is accepted by being signed.
The process or fact of being received as adequate, valid, or suitable.
Agreement with or belief in an idea or explanation.
Willingness to tolerate a difficult situation.
--Examples--
‘charges involving the acceptance of bribes’
‘a banker's acceptance’
‘you must wait for acceptance into the village’
‘acceptance of the teaching of the Church’
‘a mood of resigned acceptance’

--Word--
acceptedly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
So as to be well received or favourably accepted; gratifyingly, pleasingly. In later use also: acceptably, satisfactorily; in a manner that is tolerated or permitted.
As is accepted generally or by the speaker; admittedly.
--Examples--
--Word--
acceptee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who accepts or agrees to something; a recipient; specifically (in early use) = "acceptor".
A person who is accepted; a person who gets acceptance.
--Examples--
--Word--
acceptee 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
acceptor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that accepts or receives something.
An atom or molecule which is able to bind to or accept an electron or other species.
An acceptor atom forming a positive hole in a semiconductor.
--Examples--
‘he hoped to make the most of being one of the first acceptors of bitcoin in the Sydney marketplace’
‘don't all award accepters memorize what to say beforehand?’
‘some microorganisms can use oxygen as an electron acceptor’

--Word--
acceptilation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Release from a debt by an acquittance without payment; an instance of this. Formerly also figurative: †free remission of sins (obsolete).

‘Tim offered Brian a lift home and he accepted’
‘what if Elizabeth accepted Darcy the first time?’
‘the college accepted her as a student’
‘credit cards are widely accepted’
‘the Irish never accepted him as one of them’
‘vending machines that accepted 100-yen coins for cans of beer’
‘this tentative explanation came to be accepted by the men’
‘it is accepted that ageing is a continuous process’
‘Jenkins is willing to accept his responsibility’
‘he accepts that he made a mistake’
‘they accepted the need to cut overheads’
--Word--
access 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The means or opportunity to approach or enter a place.
The right or opportunity to use or benefit from something.
The right or opportunity to approach or see someone.
The process of obtaining or retrieving information stored in a computer's memory.
Denoting broadcasting produced by minority and specialist interest groups, rather than by professionals.
An attack or outburst of an emotion.
Approach or enter (a place)
Obtain or retrieve (computer data or a file)
--Examples--
‘the staircase gives access to the top floor’
‘wheelchair access’
‘do you have access to a computer?’
‘awards to help people gain access to training’
‘we were denied access to our grandson’
‘this prevents unauthorized access or inadvertent deletion of the file’
‘access television’
‘I was suddenly overcome with an access of rage’
‘single rooms have private facilities accessed via the balcony’
‘information can be accessed from several files and displayed at the same time’
--Word--
accessively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an accessible manner; so as to be accessible.
--Examples--
--Word--
accessory 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A thing which can be added to something else in order to make it more useful, versatile, or attractive.

--Examples--
‘optional accessories include a battery charger and shoulder strap’
‘she wore the suit with perfectly matching accessories—hat, bag, shoes’
‘she was charged as an accessory to murder’
‘functionally the maxillae are a pair of accessory jaws’

--Word--
accessibility 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being able to be reached or entered.
The quality of being easy to obtain or use.
The quality of being easily understood or appreciated.
The quality of being easily reached, entered, or used by people who have a disability.
--Examples--
‘the restoration project involved repairing the roof and improving accessibility’
‘students were concerned about the accessibility of quality academic counselling’
‘the accessibility of his work helped to popularize modern art’
‘many architects believe that accommodating wheelchairs is all there is to providing accessibility’

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
accessible 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a place) able to be reached or entered.
Able to be easily obtained or used.
Easily understood or appreciated.
Able to be reached, entered, or used by people who have a disability.
(of a person, especially one in a position of authority) friendly and easy to talk to; approachable.
--Examples--
‘the town is accessible by bus’
‘this room is not accessible to elderly people’
‘making learning opportunities more accessible to adults’
‘an accessible account of his theories’
‘features such as non-slip floors and accessible entrances’
‘he is more accessible than most tycoons’

--Word--
accession 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The attainment or acquisition of a position of rank or power.
The action or process of formally joining or being accepted by an institution or group.
The formal acceptance of a treaty or agreement.
A new item added to an existing collection of books, paintings, or artefacts.
An amount added to an existing quantity of something.
Record the addition of (a new item) to a library, museum, or other collection.
--Examples--
‘the Queen's accession to the throne’
‘the accession of Spain and Portugal to the EU’
‘accession to the Treaty of Rome was effected in 1971’
‘the day-to-day work of cataloguing new accessions’
‘the accession number’
‘substantial accessions of gold’
‘each book must be accessioned and the data entered into the computer’

accessional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
accidence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of grammar that deals with the inflections of words.
--Examples--
--Word--
accidency 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chance occurrence or circumstance; (contextually) a fortuitous event, a mishap. In non-count use: fortuitous disposition, chance. Compare "accident". rare.
US. Usually with capital initial. Preceded by a possessive, as a mock title of respect given to a person who has succeeded to an office (especially the presidency of the United States) by chance or mishap, such as the death of the previous incumbent. Chiefly in "His Accidency".
--Examples--
--Word--
accidency 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chance occurrence or circumstance; (contextually) a fortuitous event, a mishap. In non-count use: fortuitous disposition, chance. Compare "accident". rare.
US. Usually with capital initial. Preceded by a possessive, as a mock title of respect given to a person who has succeeded to an office (especially the presidency of the United States) by chance or mishap, such as the death of the previous incumbent. Chiefly in "His Accidency".
--Examples--
--Word--
accident 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An unfortunate incident that happens unexpectedly and unintentionally, typically resulting in damage or injury.
A crash involving road or other vehicles.
An incidence of incontinence by a child or animal.
An event that happens by chance or that is without apparent or deliberate cause.
The working of fortune; chance.
(in Aristotelian thought) a property of a thing which is not essential to its nature.
--Examples--
‘he had an accident at the factory’
‘if you are unable to work owing to accident or sickness’
‘four people were killed in a road accident’
‘he had a little accident, but I washed his shorts out’
‘the pregnancy was an accident’
‘it is no accident that Manchester has produced more than its fair share of professional comics’
‘members belong to the House of Lords through hereditary right or accident of birth’
--Word--
accidental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Happening by chance, unintentionally, or unexpectedly.
Incidental; subsidiary.
(in Aristotelian thought) relating to or denoting properties which are not essential to a thing's nature.
A sign indicating a momentary departure from the key signature by raising or lowering a note.
--Examples--
‘a verdict of accidental death’
‘the damage might have been accidental’
‘the location is accidental and contributes nothing to the poem’
‘horn parts are usually written without key signature, the necessary accidentals being added’
--Word--
accidentalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being accidental; accidental manner or nature.
A theory or belief which proposes that events occur as a result of chance or contingency, and are not preordained or attributable to a single definite cause.
--Examples--
--Word--
accidentalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who believes that events occur (either generally, or in a particular context) as a result of chance or contingency rather than viewing them as preordained or attributable to a single definite cause.
Designating a theory or belief that events occur as the result of chance or contingency; of or relating to such a theory or belief.
--Examples--
--Word--
accidentality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or fact of being accidental.
--Examples--

accidentally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By chance; inadvertently.
--Examples--
‘his gun went off accidentally’
‘accidentally knocked the vase over’

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Become accustomed to a new climate or new conditions; adjust.
Respond physiologically or behaviourally to changes in a complex of environmental factors.
Harden off (a plant).
--Examples--
‘it's unknown whether people will acclimatize to increasingly warm weather’
--Word--
acclimatize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Become accustomed to a new climate or new conditions; adjust.
Respond physiologically or behaviourally to changes in a complex of environmental factors.
Harden off (a plant).
--Examples--
‘it's unknown whether people will acclimatize to increasingly warm weather’

accolade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An award or privilege granted as a special honour or as an acknowledgement of merit.
An expression of praise or admiration.
A touch on a person's shoulders with a sword at the bestowing of a knighthood.
--Examples--
‘the hotel has won numerous accolades’
‘poignant accolades and urgent testimonials of thanks’
--Word--
accoladed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That has received the accolade of knighthood; knighted, dubbed. Also: honoured with an accolade of praise or distinction.

--Word--
accommodate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a building or other area) provide lodging or sufficient space for.
Fit in with the wishes or needs of.
Adapt to.
--Examples--
‘the cottages accommodate up to six people’
‘any language must accommodate new concepts’
‘making users accommodate to the realities of today's marketplace’

--Word--
accommodation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A room, group of rooms, or building in which someone may live or stay.
Lodgings, sometimes also including board.
The available space for occupants in a building, vehicle, or vessel.
The provision of a room or lodgings.
A convenient arrangement; a settlement or compromise.
The process of adapting or adjusting to someone or something.
The automatic adjustment of the focus of the eye by flattening or thickening of the lens.
--Examples--
‘they were living in temporary accommodation’
‘the company offers a number of guest house accommodations in Oberammergau’
‘there was lifeboat accommodation for 1,178 people’
‘the building is used exclusively for the accommodation of guests’
‘the prime minister was seeking an accommodation with Labour’
‘accommodation to a separate political entity was not possible’
‘the power of accommodation to near objects’
--Word--
accommodational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or providing acceptable accommodation.
Involving or tending to conciliation.
--Examples--
--Word--
accommodationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or political group that seeks compromise with an opposing point of view.
--Examples--

--Word--
accompany 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Go somewhere with (someone) as a companion or escort.
Be present or occur at the same time as (something else)
Provide a complement or addition to.
Play a musical accompaniment for.
--Examples--
‘the two sisters were to accompany us to London’
‘the illness is often accompanied by nausea’
‘home-cooked ham accompanied by brown bread’
‘he would play his violin, and Mother used to accompany him on our organ’

--Word--
accompaniment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A musical part which supports or partners an instrument, voice, or group.
A piece of music played as a complement or background to an activity.
Something that supplements or complements something else.
--Examples--
‘she sang to a guitar accompaniment’
‘sonatas for piano with violin accompaniment’
‘lush string accompaniments to romantic scenes in films’
‘we filed out to the accompaniment of the organ’
‘these biscuits are a lovely accompaniment to tea’

fait accompli 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing that has already happened or been decided before those affected hear about it, leaving them with no option but to accept it.
--Examples--
‘the results were presented to shareholders as a fait accompli’

noun

--Word--
accord 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition)
(of a concept or fact) be harmonious or consistent with.
An official agreement or treaty.
Agreement or harmony.
--Examples--
‘the powers accorded to the head of state’
‘the national assembly accorded the General more power’
‘his views accorded well with those of Merivale’
‘opposition groups refused to sign the accord’
‘a peace accord’
‘the government and the rebels are in accord on one point’

--Word--
according 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
As stated by or in.
In a manner corresponding or conforming to.
In proportion or relation to.
Depending on whether.
--Examples--
‘the outlook for investors is not bright, according to financial experts’
‘cook the rice according to the instructions’
‘salary will be fixed according to experience’
‘the distribution of his property differed widely according as it was real or personal estate’
--Word--
accordingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that is appropriate to the particular circumstances.
As a result; therefore.
--Examples--
‘we have to discover what his plans are and act accordingly’
‘there was no breach of the rules; accordingly, there will be no disciplinary inquiry’
--Word--
accordion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A musical instrument played by stretching and squeezing with the hands to work a central bellows that blows air over metal reeds, the melody and chords being sounded by buttons or keys.
Folding like the bellows of an accordion.
--Examples--
‘her five brothers and sisters were singing to the accompaniment of an accordion’
‘an accordion player’
‘an accordion pleat’

accordion 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
accordioned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Folded, pleated, or collapsed so as to resemble the bellows of an accordion; having the form or appearance of an accordion's bellows.

--Word--
account 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A report or description of an event or experience.
An interpretation or rendering of a piece of music.
A record or statement of financial expenditure and receipts relating to a particular period or purpose.
The department of a company that deals with financial accounts.
A bill for goods or services provided over a period.
An arrangement by which a body holds funds on behalf of a client or supplies goods or services to them on credit.
A client having an account with a supplier.
A contract to do work for a client.
A fixed period on a stock exchange, at the end of which payment must be made for stock that has been bought.
An arrangement by which a user is given personalized access to a computer, website, or application, typically by entering a username and password.
Importance.
Consider or regard in a specified way.
Give or receive an account for money received.
--Examples--
‘a detailed account of what has been achieved’
‘a lively account of Offenbach's score’
‘the barman was doing his accounts’
‘the people from Accounts’
‘there's no money to pay the tradesmen's accounts this month’
‘a bank account’
‘I began buying things on account’
‘selling bibles to established accounts in the North’
‘another agency was awarded the account’
‘we've reset your password to prevent others from accessing your account’
‘money was of no account to her’
‘her visit could not be accounted a success’
‘he accounted himself the unluckiest man alive’
‘after 1292 he accounted to the Westminster exchequer’
--Word--
accountability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact or condition of being accountable; responsibility.
--Examples--
‘lack of accountability has corroded public respect for business and political leaders’
--Word--
accountably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
accountable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Required or expected to justify actions or decisions; responsible.
Able to be explained or understood.
--Examples--
‘ministers are accountable to Parliament’
‘parents cannot be held accountable for their children's actions’
‘the delayed introduction of characters' names is accountable, if we consider that names have a low priority’

--Meanings--

--Word--
accounting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or work of keeping financial accounts.
--Examples--
‘an investigation into suspected false accounting’
‘standard accounting practice’
--Word--
accountment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or work of accounting or reckoning for something; responsibility. Also: the manner in which something is accounted for; an instance of accounting.
--Examples--
--Word--
accountment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or work of accounting or reckoning for something; responsibility. Also: the manner in which something is accounted for; an instance of accounting.
--Examples--
--Word--
account 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A report or description of an event or experience.
An interpretation or rendering of a piece of music.
A record or statement of financial expenditure and receipts relating to a particular period or purpose.
The department of a company that deals with financial accounts.
A bill for goods or services provided over a period.
An arrangement by which a body holds funds on behalf of a client or supplies goods or services to them on credit.
A client having an account with a supplier.
A contract to do work for a client.
A fixed period on a stock exchange, at the end of which payment must be made for stock that has been bought.
An arrangement by which a user is given personalized access to a computer, website, or application, typically by entering a username and password.
Importance.
Consider or regard in a specified way.
Give or receive an account for money received.
--Examples--
‘a detailed account of what has been achieved’
‘a lively account of Offenbach's score’
‘the barman was doing his accounts’
‘the people from Accounts’
‘there's no money to pay the tradesmen's accounts this month’
‘a bank account’
‘I began buying things on account’
‘selling bibles to established accounts in the North’
‘another agency was awarded the account’
‘we've reset your password to prevent others from accessing your account’
‘money was of no account to her’
‘her visit could not be accounted a success’
‘he accounted himself the unluckiest man alive’
‘after 1292 he accounted to the Westminster exchequer’

--Meanings--

accouplement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Of persons. Frequently: marriage union.
Of things.
Woodworking and Engineering. A component used to bind or brace together two other components of a structure; the structure so bound. Compare "tie". rare.

--Word--
accra 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(in West Africa and the Caribbean) a fritter made with black-eyed peas or a similar pulse, or, especially in Trinidad, mashed fish.
The capital of Ghana, a port on the Gulf of Guinea; population 1,970,400 (est. 2005).
--Examples--
--Word--
accredit 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give credit to (someone) for something.
Attribute an action, saying, or quality to.
(of an official body) give authority or sanction to (someone or something) when recognized standards have been met.
Give official authorization for (someone, typically a diplomat or journalist) to be in a particular place or to hold a particular post.
--Examples--
‘he was accredited with being one of the world's fastest sprinters’
‘the discovery of distillation is usually accredited to the Arabs’
‘institutions that do not meet the standards will not be accredited for teacher training’
‘no journalist accredited to the UN has ever been expelled’

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

accreditate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Accredit; (in recent use especially) to confer official accreditation on (a school, programme, etc.). Now chiefly in pass.
--Examples--
--Word--
accreditation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of officially recognizing someone as having a particular status or being qualified to perform a particular activity.
Official certification that a school or course has met standards set by external regulators.
An acknowledgement of a person's responsibility for or achievement of something.
--Examples--
‘the accreditation of professionals’
‘a simple accreditation process’
‘the first fully online university to receive national accreditation’
‘the accreditation of professional training programs in Canada’
‘both parties create authorship, and to make this clear I have always used joint accreditations’

noun

--Word--
accresce 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Chiefly with to in early use. To increase by accretion, grow up.
To come by way of an addition or increase, to accrue. Chiefly of a failed share (Law, chiefly and now only Scottish Law): to pass to others (especially co-legatees), augmenting their shares. Chiefly with to.
--Examples--
--Word--
accrescence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or fact of growing by accretion or addition. Now rare.
Something which grows on or is attached to another by accretion.
--Examples--
--Word--
accrescent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That grows or increases continuously or by accretion; ever increasing.
Botany. Continuing to grow; growing larger after flowering; specifically designating parts of a flower which normally fall off or wither after fertilization but instead continue growing.

--Word--
accrete 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Grow by accumulation or coalescence.
Form (a composite whole) by gradual accumulation.
(with reference to matter or a body) come or bring together under the influence of gravitation.
--Examples--
‘ice that had accreted grotesquely into stalactites’
‘the collection of art he had accreted was to be sold’
‘the gas will cool and then accrete to the galaxy's core’

--Word--
accretion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Growth or increase by the gradual accumulation of additional layers or matter.
A thing formed or added by gradual growth or increase.
The coming together and cohesion of matter under the influence of gravitation to form larger bodies.
--Examples--
‘the accretion of sediments in coastal mangroves’
‘the growing accretion of central government authority’
‘the city has a historic core surrounded by recent accretions’
‘during the later stages of accretion the outer 100 km or so of the Moon melted’
--Word--
accretionary prism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mass of sedimentary material scraped off a region of oceanic crust during subduction and piled up at the edge of a continental crustal plate.
--Examples--

--Word--
accroach 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To draw to oneself, catch, attract, acquire. In later use: specifically to assume (the prerogative of power) from another, to usurp.
With to (also †toward) (oneself). To seize or appropriate (what is not one's own); to usurp (authority or jurisdiction).
To encroach upon (especially land or authority).
--Examples--
--Word--
accroach 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To draw to oneself, catch, attract, acquire. In later use: specifically to assume (the prerogative of power) from another, to usurp.
With to (also †toward) (oneself). To seize or appropriate (what is not one's own); to usurp (authority or jurisdiction).
To encroach upon (especially land or authority).

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of accruing; = "accretion"; an instance of this; "right of accruer": the right to benefit from the action of accretion, especially in the context of shares under probate or trusts.

--Word--
accrue 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a benefit or sum of money) be received by someone in regular or increasing amounts over time.
Accumulate or receive (payments or benefits) over time.
Make provision for (a charge) at the end of a financial period for work that has been done but not yet invoiced.
--Examples--
‘financial benefits will accrue from restructuring’
‘they accrue entitlements to holiday pay’
‘at 31 December the amount due for the final quarter is accrued’
--Word--
accrued

‘accrued leave’
‘accrued expenses’

accumulator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that accumulates something.
A large rechargeable battery.
A bet placed on a series of races (or other events), the winnings and stake from each being placed on the next.
A register used to contain the results of an arithmetical or logical operation.
--Examples--
‘he's a voracious accumulator of economic facts and data’
‘rugs are the greatest accumulators of dust and dirt in every house’
‘an eight-horse accumulator’

--Word--
accuracy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being correct or precise.
The degree to which the result of a measurement, calculation, or specification conforms to the correct value or a standard.

--Word--
accurate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of information, measurements, or predictions) correct in all details; exact.
(of an instrument or method) capable of giving accurate information.
Providing a faithful representation of someone or something.
(with reference to a weapon, missile, or shot) capable of or successful in reaching the intended target.
--Examples--
‘accurate information about the illness is essential’
‘an accurate assessment’
‘an accurate thermometer’
‘the portrait is an accurate likeness of Mozart’
‘reliable, accurate rifles’
‘a player who can deliver long accurate passes to the wingers’
--Word--
accurately 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that is correct in all details; exactly.
--Examples--
‘we are simply unable to predict long-term trends accurately’
‘every single vote was accurately counted’

adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the accusative case.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(in Latin, Greek, German, and some other languages) denoting a case of nouns, pronouns, and adjectives which expresses the object of an action or the goal of motion.
A word in the accusative case.
The accusative case.
--Examples--
--Word--
dative-accusative 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A form having the functions of both the dative and the accusative case.
Of or relating to both the dative and the accusative case.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusatively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Grammar. In the form or manner of an accusative.
In an accusatory manner; accusingly.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusativity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being accusative.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(in Latin, Greek, German, and some other languages) denoting a case of nouns, pronouns, and adjectives which expresses the object of an action or the goal of motion.
A word in the accusative case.
The accusative case.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An accuser; specifically a plaintiff, a prosecutor.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusatory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Indicating or suggesting that one believes a person has done something wrong.
--Examples--
‘he pointed an accusatory finger in her direction’
--Word--
accusatorial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a trial or legal procedure) involving accusation by a prosecutor and a verdict reached by an impartial judge or jury.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusatorially 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an accusatory manner; accusingly, reproachfully.
--Examples--
--Word--
accusatrix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female accuser.
--Examples--
--Word--
accuse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Charge (someone) with an offence or crime.
Claim that (someone) has done something wrong.
--Examples--
‘he was accused of murdering his wife's lover’
‘he was accused of favouritism’
--Word--
accused 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or group of people who are charged with or on trial for a crime.
--Examples--
‘the accused was ordered to stand trial on a number of charges’
‘two of the accused were sentenced to thirteen years in prison’
--Word--
accuser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who claims that someone has committed an offence or done something wrong.
--Examples--
‘I dislike any law that puts the burden of proof on the accused rather than the accuser’
‘Hero faints before her three accusers leave’

--Word--
accustom 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make someone or something accept (something) as normal or usual.
Be used to.
--Examples--
‘I accustomed my eyes to the lenses’
‘sixth-form education is supposed to accustom pupils to think for themselves’
‘I am not accustomed to having my word questioned’
--Word--
accustomation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of making usual, habitual, or familiar; familiarization.

--Meanings--

--Word--
AC/DC 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an electrical system or device) compatible with both alternating current and direct current.
Bisexual.
--Examples--
--Word--
ace 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
A person who excels at a particular sport or other activity.
A pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft.
(in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point.
A hole in one.
Very good.
(in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
Score an ace on (a hole) or with (a shot)
Achieve high marks in (a test or exam)
Outdo someone in a competitive situation.
--Examples--
‘the ace of diamonds’
‘life had started dealing him aces again’
‘a motorcycle ace’
‘a Battle of Britain ace’
‘Nadal banged down eight aces in the set’
‘his hole in one at the 15th was Senior's second ace as a professional’
‘an ace swimmer’
‘Ace! You've done it!’
‘he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph’
‘there was a prize for the first player to ace the hole’
‘I aced my grammar test’
‘the magazine won an award, acing out its rivals’
--Word--
-acea 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming the names of zoological groups.
--Examples--
‘Crustacea’
--Word--
-aceae 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming the names of families of plants.
--Examples--
‘Liliaceae’
--Word--
-acean 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming the singular of group names ending in -acea (such as crustacean from Crustacea).
--Examples--

--Word--
acephal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Church History= Acephalian. Also: †a priest who is not subject to the authority of a bishop (obsolete rare). Usually with capital initial.
An (imaginary) headless animal or person. Compare acephali. Now rare.
Having or recognizing no ruler, head, or chief; = "acephalous". Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Acephala 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A former class of invertebrates lacking distinct heads, broadly equivalent to Bivalvia (bivalve molluscs) but also including tunicates; (also in form acephala) invertebrates of this class collectively. Occasionally with singular concord (also in form acephala): an invertebrate of this class.
--Examples--
--Word--
acephalan 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the former invertebrate class Acephala; designating or relating to this class.
--Examples--
--Word--
acephali 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Church History. With capital initial. A group of extreme Monophysites who seceded from the main body in the 5th cent., acknowledging no leaders and rejecting episcopal control. Also in singular, in form Acephalus: a member of such a group.
An (imaginary) race of headless people.
--Examples--
--Word--
acephalia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Absence of a head, especially as a congenital malformation.
--Examples--

--Word--
acervulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy. More fully "acervulus cerebri": a collection of small calcified concretions situated within or near the pineal body; = brain sand. In later use also: an individual concretion of this kind.
Mycology. In certain fungi pathogenic to plants: a flat, typically round mass of hyphae bearing conidiophores which is produced below the epidermis of the host plant.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--

--Word--
acescence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of becoming acid or sour; a tendency to become acid or sour; the process of acetous fermentation. Also: acidity, sourness. In later use chiefly with reference to the volatile acidity of wine.
--Examples--
--Word--
acescency 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being acescent; sourness, acidity. In later use especially: the volatile acidity of wine.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Tending to turn acid or sour; acidic; sour. Also figurative. Now chiefly historical.

acetate 
--Type--
noun

acetazolamide

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
acetylacetonate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound in which one or more acetylacetone molecules (or anions derived from them) are bonded to a metal atom, usually as bidentate ligands.
--Examples--
--Word--
acetylacetone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pale yellow liquid diketone which readily forms coordination complexes with metals and is used as a solvent and as a reagent in organic and organometallic synthesis.
--Examples--
--Word--
acetylate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Introduce an acetyl group into (a molecule or compound)

--Word--
acetylator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
acetylcholine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound which occurs throughout the nervous system, in which it functions as a neurotransmitter.
--Examples--
--Word--
acetylcholinesterase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enzyme that causes rapid hydrolysis of acetylcholine. Its action serves to stop excitation of a nerve after transmission of an impulse.
--Examples--
--Word--
acetylenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made or derived from acetylene; containing the carbon–carbon triple bond characteristic of acetylene and the alkynes.
--Examples--
--Word--
acetylene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless pungent-smelling hydrocarbon gas, which burns with a bright flame, used in welding and formerly in lighting.

--Word--

A colourless pungent-smelling hydrocarbon gas, which burns with a bright flame, used in welding and formerly in lighting.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

acetylide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound formed from acetylene and a metal, containing the anion (C≡C)²- or HC≡C-. Acetylides are typically unstable or explosive.

Achates 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A companion of Aeneas. His loyalty to his friend was so exemplary as to become proverbial, hence the term fidus Achates (‘faithful Achates’).
--Examples--
--Word--
ache 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A continuous or prolonged dull pain in a part of one's body.
An emotion experienced with painful or bittersweet intensity.
Suffer from a continuous dull pain.
Feel intense sadness or compassion.
Feel an intense desire for.
--Examples--
‘the ache in her head worsened’
‘he had stomach ache’
‘an ache in her heart’
‘my legs ached from the previous day's exercise’
‘I'm aching all over’
‘she sat still and silent, her heart aching’
‘she looked so tired that my heart ached for her’
‘she ached for his touch’
‘he was aching to get his hands on the ball’

--Word--
Acheson, Dean 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1971), American statesman, Secretary of State 1949–53; full name Dean Gooderham Acheson. He was instrumental in the formation of NATO, and implemented the Marshall Plan and the Truman Doctrine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Acheulian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the main Lower Palaeolithic culture in Europe (preceding the Mousterian) and a similar culture in Africa. It is represented by hand-axe industries, which are dated as a whole to about 1,500,000–150,000 years ago.
The Acheulian culture or period.
--Examples--
--Word--
Acheulian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the main Lower Palaeolithic culture in Europe (preceding the Mousterian) and a similar culture in Africa. It is represented by hand-axe industries, which are dated as a whole to about 1,500,000–150,000 years ago.
The Acheulian culture or period.

--Examples--
--Word--
Achilles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A hero of the Trojan War, son of Peleus and Thetis. During his infancy his mother plunged him in the Styx, thus making his body invulnerable except for the heel by which she held him. During the Trojan War Achilles killed Hector but was later wounded in the heel by an arrow shot by Paris and died.

acholuria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Absence of bile pigments in the urine in certain types of jaundice, especially that associated with chronic haemolytic anaemias. In early use also: a disorder giving rise to this, specifically hereditary spherocytosis (now historical).

adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--

--Meanings--
(chiefly of crystals) needle-shaped.
--Examples--
--Word--
acicularity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property (of crystals or other particles) of being acicular; a measure of this property.
--Examples--
--Word--
acicularly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of needles or aciculae; in needle-shaped forms.
--Examples--
--Word--
acicula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slender spine, prickle, or other needle-like structure; (in polychaete annelids) a chitinous rod forming an internal support for a parapodium.
--Examples--
--Word--
aciculate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Needle-shaped, acicular. Also: (a) covered with or bearing aciculae; (b) marked as if scratched with a needle (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
aciculated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Marked with narrow lines (as if produced by a needle), finely striated.
--Examples--
--Word--
acicula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slender spine, prickle, or other needle-like structure; (in polychaete annelids) a chitinous rod forming an internal support for a parapodium.
--Examples--
--Word--
acid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance with particular chemical properties including turning litmus red, neutralizing alkalis, and dissolving some metals; typically, a corrosive or sour-tasting liquid of this kind.
Bitter or cutting remarks or tone of voice.
A molecule or other species which can donate a proton or accept an electron pair in reactions.
The drug LSD.
Containing acid or having the properties of an acid; having a pH of less than 7.
Sharp-tasting or sour.
(of a person's remarks or tone) bitter or cutting.
(of a colour) strikingly intense or bright.
(of rock, especially lava) containing a relatively high proportion of silica.
Relating to or denoting steel-making processes involving silica-rich refractories and slags.
--Examples--
‘trees were exposed to mixtures of heavy metals, acids, and overdoses of nutrients’
‘traces of acid’
‘she was unable to quell the acid in her voice’
‘she didn't have a clue the sweet had acid in it’
‘a bad acid trip’
‘acid soils’
‘acid fruit’
‘she was stung into acid defiance’
‘an acid green’
‘the magma may start off fairly basic and end up at the close of the eruption much more acid’
‘the acid Bessemer process’
--Word--
acidaemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Increased acidity of the blood; an instance of this; = "acidosis". Frequently with distinguishing word, typically indicating the type of excess acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
acidanthera 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the genus or former genus Acidanthera (family Iridaceae), which comprises tropical and southern African herbaceous perennials having spikes of hooded fragrant flowers.
--Examples--
--Word--
binding 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A strong covering holding the pages of a book together.
Fabric cut or woven in a strip, used for binding the edges of a piece of material.
A mechanical device fixed to a ski to grip a ski boot, especially either of a pair used for downhill skiing which hold the toe and heel of the boot and release it automatically in a fall.
The action of fastening or holding together, or of being linked by chemical bonds.
(in Chomskyan linguistics) the relationship between a referentially dependent noun (such as a reflexive) and the independent noun phrase which determines its reference.
(of an agreement or promise) involving an obligation that cannot be broken.
--Examples--
‘the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces’
‘business agreements are intended to be legally binding’

acid-fast 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting bacteria that cannot be decolorized by an acid after staining, which is characteristic of the mycobacteria that cause tuberculosis and leprosy.
--Examples--
--Word--
acid-fastness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property of being acid-fast, especially as a diagnostic criterion (typically for mycobacteria) in bacteriology.
--Examples--
--Word--
formic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless irritant volatile acid made catalytically from carbon monoxide and steam. It is present in the fluid emitted by some ants.

acidic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the properties of an acid, or containing acid; having a pH below 7.
Sharp-tasting or sour.
(of a person's remarks or tone) bitter or cutting.
(of a colour) strikingly intense or bright.
(of rock, especially lava) relatively rich in silica.
Relating to or denoting steel-making processes involving silica-rich refractories and slags.
--Examples--
‘a cocktail of acidic pollutants’
‘acidic wine’
‘the occasional acidic comment’
‘an acidic yellow’
‘acidic granite batholiths’
‘acidic slag’

--Word--
acidifier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: (Chemistry) †a supposed active principle in forming acids, especially oxygen (obsolete). In later use: a substance or other agent that makes something acid or causes acidification.
--Examples--

acidity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The level of acid in substances such as water, soil, or wine.
The level of acid in the gastric juices, typically when excessive and causing discomfort.
Bitterness or sharpness in a person's remarks or tone.
--Examples--
‘the increased acidity of rainfall’
‘smoking does not affect gastric acidity’
‘the cutting acidity in his voice’

--Word--
acidize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To treat with acid, to acidify; specifically to inject acid into (a well) in order to enlarge pores in the surrounding rock and stimulate the flow of oil, water, etc.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

acidolysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A reaction in which a chemical bond is broken by an acid and the hydrogen and anion of the acid become independently attached to the two separated parts; the decomposition of a compound in this way.

--Word--
acid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance with particular chemical properties including turning litmus red, neutralizing alkalis, and dissolving some metals; typically, a corrosive or sour-tasting liquid of this kind.
Bitter or cutting remarks or tone of voice.
A molecule or other species which can donate a proton or accept an electron pair in reactions.
The drug LSD.
Containing acid or having the properties of an acid; having a pH of less than 7.
Sharp-tasting or sour.
(of a person's remarks or tone) bitter or cutting.
(of a colour) strikingly intense or bright.
(of rock, especially lava) containing a relatively high proportion of silica.
Relating to or denoting steel-making processes involving silica-rich refractories and slags.
--Examples--
‘trees were exposed to mixtures of heavy metals, acids, and overdoses of nutrients’
‘traces of acid’
‘she was unable to quell the acid in her voice’
‘she didn't have a clue the sweet had acid in it’
‘a bad acid trip’
‘acid soils’
‘acid fruit’
‘she was stung into acid defiance’
‘an acid green’
‘the magma may start off fairly basic and end up at the close of the eruption much more acid’
‘the acid Bessemer process’
--Word--
treat 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Behave towards or deal with in a certain way.
Regard something as being of a specified nature with implications for one's actions concerning it.
Present or discuss (a subject)
Give medical care or attention to; try to heal or cure.
Apply a process or a substance to (something) to protect or preserve it or to give it particular properties.
Provide someone with (food, drink, or entertainment) at one's own expense.
Give someone (something) as a favour.
Do or have something that gives one great pleasure.
Negotiate terms with someone, especially an opponent.
An event or item that is out of the ordinary and gives great pleasure.
An act of treating someone to something.
A sweet, biscuit, or other item of sweet food.
--Examples--
‘she had been brutally treated’
‘he treated her with grave courtesy’
‘the names are being treated as classified information’
‘the issue is more fully treated in chapter five’
‘the two were treated for cuts and bruises’
‘the lawns were treated with weedkiller every year’
‘he treated her to a slap-up lunch’
‘he treated her to one of his smiles’
‘treat yourself—you can diet tomorrow’
‘propagandists claimed that he was treating with the enemy’
‘he wanted to take her to the pictures as a treat’
‘‘My treat,’ he insisted, reaching for the bill’

--Word--
orotic aciduria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive excretion of orotic acid in the urine; specifically a genetic (autosomal recessive) disorder of pyrimidine metabolism in humans, in which deficient activity of the enzyme uridine monophosphate synthase, which catalyses the two-step conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate, results in the accumulation of orotic acid and in megaloblastic anaemia that responds to uridine administration.
--Examples--
--Word--
orotic aciduria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive excretion of orotic acid in the urine; specifically a genetic (autosomal recessive) disorder of pyrimidine metabolism in humans, in which deficient activity of the enzyme uridine monophosphate synthase, which catalyses the two-step conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate, results in the accumulation of orotic acid and in megaloblastic anaemia that responds to uridine administration.
--Examples--
--Word--
aciduric

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
ace 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
A person who excels at a particular sport or other activity.
A pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft.
(in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point.
A hole in one.
Very good.
(in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
Score an ace on (a hole) or with (a shot)
Achieve high marks in (a test or exam)
Outdo someone in a competitive situation.
--Examples--
‘the ace of diamonds’
‘life had started dealing him aces again’
‘a motorcycle ace’
‘a Battle of Britain ace’
‘Nadal banged down eight aces in the set’
‘his hole in one at the 15th was Senior's second ace as a professional’
‘an ace swimmer’
‘Ace! You've done it!’
‘he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph’
‘there was a prize for the first player to ace the hole’
‘I aced my grammar test’
‘the magazine won an award, acing out its rivals’

ackee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tropical West African tree which is cultivated for its fruit and has been introduced into the Caribbean and elsewhere.

--Word--
Ackermann 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating a steering mechanism designed so that, when a vehicle turns, both the outer and the inner wheels remain perpendicular to the radius of the turn, even though the outer wheels trace a larger circle than the inner wheels; relating to or employing this mechanism.
--Examples--
--Word--
acknowledge 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Accept or admit the existence or truth of.
Recognize the importance or quality of.
Express gratitude for or appreciation of.
Accept the validity or legitimacy of.
Show that one has noticed or recognized (someone) by making a gesture or greeting.
Confirm (receipt of something)
--Examples--
‘the plight of the refugees was acknowledged by the authorities’
‘the government acknowledged that the tax was unfair’
‘‘That's true,’ she acknowledged’
‘the art world has begun to acknowledge his genius’
‘the hotel is widely acknowledged as one of Cornwall's finest’
‘he received a letter acknowledging his services’
‘Henry acknowledged Richard as his heir’
‘she refused to acknowledge my presence’
‘I should be grateful if you would acknowledge receipt of this letter’

--Examples--

--Word--
acknowledgement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Acceptance of the truth or existence of something.
Recognition of the importance or quality of something.
The expression of gratitude or appreciation for something.
The action of showing that one has noticed someone or something.
A letter confirming receipt of something.
A statement printed at the beginning of a book expressing the author's or publisher's gratitude to others.
--Examples--
‘there was no acknowledgement of the family's trauma’
‘he received an award in acknowledgement of his work’
‘he touched his hat in acknowledgement’
‘I received an acknowledgement of my application’
‘the reproduction on page 50 wasn't mentioned in the acknowledgements’

--Meanings--
Acceptance of the truth or existence of something.
Recognition of the importance or quality of something.
The expression of gratitude or appreciation for something.
The action of showing that one has noticed someone or something.
A letter confirming receipt of something.
A statement printed at the beginning of a book expressing the author's or publisher's gratitude to others.
--Examples--
‘there was no acknowledgement of the family's trauma’
‘he received an award in acknowledgement of his work’
‘he touched his hat in acknowledgement’
‘I received an acknowledgement of my application’
‘the reproduction on page 50 wasn't mentioned in the acknowledgements’
--Word--
acknowledgement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Acceptance of the truth or existence of something.
Recognition of the importance or quality of something.
The expression of gratitude or appreciation for something.
The action of showing that one has noticed someone or something.
A letter confirming receipt of something.
A statement printed at the beginning of a book expressing the author's or publisher's gratitude to others.

‘he received an award in acknowledgement of his work’
‘he touched his hat in acknowledgement’
‘I received an acknowledgement of my application’
‘the reproduction on page 50 wasn't mentioned in the acknowledgements’

--Word--
clock 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mechanical or electrical device for measuring time, indicating hours, minutes, and sometimes seconds by hands on a round dial or by displayed figures.
Time taken as a factor in an activity, especially in competitive sports.
A measuring device such as a speedometer, taximeter, or milometer.
An electronic device used to initiate and synchronize internal operations.
A downy spherical seed head, especially that of a dandelion.
A person's face.
Attain or register (a specified time, distance, or speed)
Achieve (a victory)
Record as attaining a specified time or rate.
Notice or watch.
Hit (someone), especially on the head.
Wind back the milometer of (a car) illegally in order to make the vehicle appear to have travelled fewer miles than it really has.
--Examples--
‘the church clock struck four’
‘a clock face’
‘this stage is played against the clock’
‘a car with over 82,000 miles on the clock’
‘I thought I recognized your clock’
‘Thomas has clocked up forty years service’
‘this is a generous CD, clocking in at more than 60 minutes’
‘he clocked up his first win of the year’
‘the tower operators clocked a gust at 185 mph’
‘I noticed him clocking her in the mirror’
‘someone clocked him for no good reason’
‘beware of motorists who clock their car before selling it’
‘they had sold clocked vehicles’

cock 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A male bird, especially of a domestic fowl.
Used in names of birds, especially game birds, e.g. watercock.
A male lobster, crab, or salmon.
A friendly form of address among men.
A man's penis.
Nonsense.
A firing lever in a gun which can be raised to be released by the trigger.
A stopcock.
Tilt (something) in a particular direction.
Bend a (limb or joint) at an angle.
(of a male dog) lift (a back leg) in order to urinate.
Raise the cock of (a gun) in order to make it ready for firing.
Ruin something as a result of incompetence or inefficiency.
--Examples--
‘the biggest salmon I ever had was a 45 lb cock’
‘please yourself, cock’
‘that's all a lot of cock’
‘she cocked her head slightly to one side’
‘Madge threw herself into the armchair and cocked her legs over the side’
‘a greyhound cocked its leg against the tree’
‘he took the loaded pistol from his belt and cocked it’
‘the party cocked up the Euro-elections’

--Word--
compass 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An instrument containing a magnetized pointer which shows the direction of magnetic north and bearings from it.
An instrument for drawing circles and arcs and measuring distances between points, consisting of two arms linked by a movable joint, one arm ending in a point and the other usually carrying a pencil or pen.
The range or scope of something.
The enclosing limits of an area.
The range of notes that can be produced by a voice or a musical instrument.
Go round (something) in a circular course.
Surround or hem in on all sides.
Contrive to accomplish (something)
--Examples--
‘walkers should be equipped with a map and compass’
‘a magnetic compass’
‘Crewe was ideally placed on the rail network, with connections running to all points of the compass’
‘a regular heptagon cannot be constructed accurately with only ruler and compass’
‘the event had political repercussions which are beyond the compass of this book’
‘goods and services which fall within the compass of the free market’
‘this region had within its compass many types of agriculture’
‘the cellos were playing in a rather sombre part of their compass’
‘the ship wherein Magellan compassed the world’
‘we were compassed round by a thick fog’
‘he compassed his end only by the exercise of violence’
--Word--
Aconcagua 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain in the Andes, in western Argentina near the Chilean border, rising to 22,834 feet (6,960 m). It is the highest mountain in the western hemisphere.

aconitum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A preparation or extract of the root of an aconite (genus Aconitum), especially A. napellus, used as a drug (now mainly in alternative forms of medicine) or as a poison.
Any of various perennial plants of the Eurasian genus Aconitum (family Ranunculaceae), which comprises the aconites. Also (in form Aconitum): the genus itself.

acorus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the plant sweet flag, Acorus calamus. In later use: any plant of the genus Acorus (family Acoraceae), the members of which are rushlike flowering plants with inconspicuous flowers, native chiefly to wetlands in Europe and Asia. Also (in form Acorus): the genus itself.

--Word--
acousmatic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of disciples of Pythagoras who unquestioningly followed his doctrines and precepts rather than studying his scientific proofs and demonstrations. Opposed to mathematic, mathematician.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of this group. Also in extended use: thoughtless, unthinking.
Of, designating, or characterized by sound produced without a visible source, or a visual component or association; audible but unseen.
--Examples--
--Word--
acoustic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to sound or the sense of hearing.
(of building materials) used for soundproofing or modifying sound.
(of a device or system) utilizing sound energy in its operation.
(of an explosive mine or other weapon) able to be set off by sound waves.
(of popular music or musical instruments) not having electrical amplification.
The properties or qualities of a room or building that determine how sound is transmitted in it.
The branch of physics concerned with the properties of sound.
--Examples--
‘dogs have a much greater acoustic range than humans’
‘acoustic tiles’
‘a sad, gentle acoustic ballad’
‘old-fashioned acoustic instruments’
‘the Symphony Hall has perfect acoustics’
‘Tyndall lectured on acoustics’
‘these German-made acoustics are exceptional value and a pleasure to play’

verb
--Meanings--

A purchase of one company by another.
The buying or obtaining of assets or objects.
The learning or developing of a skill, habit, or quality.
--Examples--
‘the legacy will be used for new acquisitions’
‘there were many acquisitions among travel agents’
‘the company intends to grow within itself rather than by acquisition’
‘western culture places a high value on material acquisition’
‘the acquisition of management skills’

noun, proper noun

--Word--
acre-foot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of volume equal to the volume of a sheet of water one acre (0.405 hectare) in area and one foot (30.48 cm) in depth; 43,560 cubic feet (1233.5 cubic metres).
--Examples--
--Word--
inch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A unit of linear measure equal to one twelfth of a foot (2.54 cm)
A person's height or waist measurement.
A very small amount or distance.
(as a unit of rainfall) a quantity that would cover a horizontal surface to a depth of one inch, equivalent to 253.7 cubic metres per hectare.
(as a unit of atmospheric pressure) an amount that would support a column of mercury one-inch high in a barometer (equal to 33.86 millibars, 29.5 inches being equal to one bar).
(as a unit of map scale) so many inches representing one mile on the ground.
Move along slowly and carefully.
Cause (something) to move slowly and carefully.
--Examples--
‘the toy train is four inches long’
‘eighteen inches of thread’
‘my only reservation is the goalkeeper's lack of inches’
‘I had no intention of budging an inch’
‘more than four inches of rain is expected’
‘one-inch maps of the east Midland counties’
‘he inched away as I approached’
‘Spain's conservatives are inching ahead’
‘he inched the car forward’

cry 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Shed tears, typically as an expression of distress, pain, or sorrow.
Shout or scream, typically to express fear, pain, or grief.
Say something loudly in an excited or anguished tone of voice.
(of a street trader) shout out the name of (goods for sale)
(of a bird or other animal) make a loud characteristic call.
A loud inarticulate shout or scream expressing a powerful feeling or emotion.
A loud excited utterance of a word or words.
The call of a street trader selling goods.
An urgent appeal or entreaty.
A demand or opinion expressed by many people.
The loud characteristic call of a bird or other animal.
A spell of shedding tears.
A pack of hounds.
--Examples--
‘don't cry—it'll be all right’
‘you'll cry tears of joy’
‘the little girl fell down and cried for mummy’
‘‘Where will it end?’ he cried out’
‘there was a bustle of activity as vendors cried their wares, offering shellfish to potential buyers’
‘the wild birds cried out over the water’
‘a cry of despair’
‘there was a cry of ‘Silence!’’
‘the city comes to life after 10 p.m., with the din of car horns, and the cries of street hawkers’
‘fund-raisers have issued a cry for help’
‘peace became the popular cry’
‘the harsh cries of magpies’
‘I still have a cry, sometimes, when I realize that my mother is dead’
‘he kept a cry of hounds to hunt in the wilderness’

acroclinium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the former genus Acroclinium (now included in Rhodanthe), of the family Asteraceae (Compositae), which comprises herbaceous annuals native chiefly to Australia; especially a plant of one of the numerous cultivated varieties grown widely for their persistent flowers (everlastings), which are typically red, pink or white, and often used dried in arrangements. Also (in form Acroclinium): the former genus itself.

acrodynia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disorder characterized by swelling and pain or paraesthesia of the hands and feet, with gastrointestinal and various other symptoms, probably resulting from mercury poisoning but originally also attributed to ergotism or arsenic poisoning; (in later use) specifically = pink disease.

--Word--
acrodont 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An animal, especially a reptile, whose teeth lack sockets and are permanently attached to the summit of the alveolar ridge of the jaw.
Designating teeth which are permanently attached to the summit of the alveolar ridge of the jaw, as in many squamate reptiles and some teleost fish; of, relating to, or characterized by such teeth.

acrophony 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of a graphic symbol originally representing a word (or the object to which it refers) to denote the initial syllable or sound of that word.
--Examples--

acrophonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or based on acrophony. Also of the symbol for a numeral: based on the letter representing the initial sound of the numeral.

acropolis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A citadel or fortified part of an ancient Greek city, typically one built on a hill.
The ancient citadel at Athens, containing the Parthenon and other notable buildings, mostly dating from the 5th century BC.

acropolis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A citadel or fortified part of an ancient Greek city, typically one built on a hill.
The ancient citadel at Athens, containing the Parthenon and other notable buildings, mostly dating from the 5th century BC.

acrosome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A membrane-bound, darkly staining, granular structure surrounding the anterior end of the nucleus in a spermatozoon, containing enzymes that assist in the penetration of the ovum.

--Word--
acrospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †a stalked antheridium of a moss, liverwort, or other cryptogam (obsolete rare). In later use: a spore produced at the apex of a hypha or other cellular filament forming the structural element of a fungus; a basidiospore.
--Examples--
--Word--
acrosporous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characterized by acrospores.
--Examples--
--Word--
across 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
From one side to the other of (a place, area, etc.)
Used with an expression of measurement.
Expressing position or orientation.
Referring to a crossword answer which reads horizontally.
--Examples--
‘I ran across the street’
‘travelling across Europe’
‘he had swum across’
‘mounds some 30 metres across’
‘they lived across the street from one another’
‘the bridge across the river’
‘he looked across at me’
‘halfway across, Jenny jumped’
‘19 across’
--Word--
across the board 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Applying to all.
(in horse racing) denoting a bet in which equal amounts are staked on the same horse to win, place, or show in a race.
--Examples--
‘the cutbacks might be across the board’

noun
--Meanings--
A poem, word puzzle, or other composition in which certain letters in each line form a word or words.

--Word--
acrostichal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of the bristles on the mesothorax of some dipteran flies: arranged in rows on the dorsal part of this (the mesonotum).
An acrostichal bristle.
--Examples--
--Word--
acrostichic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or in the form of an acrostic.
--Examples--
--Word--
acrostichoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: †designating a fern in which the sori arise as a continuous mass covering the lower surface of the fertile frond, typified by, but not exclusive to, the genus Acrostichum (family Polypodiaceae); characteristic of such a fern (obsolete). Now: specifically designating or relating to sori with this pattern of distribution.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
act 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take action; do something.
Take action according to or in the light of.
Take action in order to bring about.
Represent (someone) on a contractual, legal, or paid basis.
Be motivated by.
Behave in the way specified.
Fulfil the function or serve the purpose of.
Take effect; have a particular effect.
Perform a role in a play, film, or television.
Behave so as to appear to be; pretend to be.
Perform a narrative as if it were a play.
Express repressed emotion or impulses in overt behaviour as a defensive substitute for conscious recall, typical of some behavioural disorders.
A thing done; a deed.
A New Testament book immediately following the Gospels and relating the history of the early Church.
A pretence.
A particular type of behaviour or routine.
A written law passed by Parliament, Congress, etc.
A document attesting a legal transaction.
The recorded decisions or proceedings of a committee or an academic body.
A main division of a play, ballet, or opera.
A set performance.
A performing group.
--Examples--
‘they urged Washington to act’
‘governments must act to reduce pollution’
‘I shall certainly act on his suggestion’
‘one's ability to act for community change’
‘he chose a solicitor to act for him’
‘you acted from greed’
‘they challenged a man who was seen acting suspiciously’
‘he acts as if he owned the place’
‘try to act like civilized adults’
‘they need volunteers to act as foster-parents’
‘a day-care centre which will act as a meeting place’
‘bacteria act on proteins and sugar’
‘she acted in her first professional role at the age of six’
‘he acted the role of the king’
‘I acted dumb at first’
‘encouraging pupils to act out the stories’
‘a criminal act’
‘the act of writing down one's thoughts’
‘an act of heroism’
‘she was putting on an act and laughing a lot’
‘he did his Sir Galahad act’
‘the 1989 Children Act’
‘the first act’
‘her one-woman poetry act’
‘an act called the Apple Blossom Sisters’

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
actinide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the series of fifteen metallic elements from actinium (atomic number 89) to lawrencium (atomic number 103) in the periodic table. They are all radioactive, the heavier members being extremely unstable and not of natural occurrence.
--Examples--
--Word--
actinide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the series of fifteen metallic elements from actinium (atomic number 89) to lawrencium (atomic number 103) in the periodic table. They are all radioactive, the heavier members being extremely unstable and not of natural occurrence.
--Examples--
--Word--
actiniform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: (of a polyp) having the form or structure of a sea anemone. Later (more widely): having a radiated form; having rays diverging from a centre.

--Meanings--

actinobacillosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disease of cattle, other livestock, and occasionally humans caused by infection with bacteria of the genus Actinobacillus, typically characterized by suppurating nodules like those of actinomycosis but also seen as septicaemia in foals.

noun
