--Word--
Actinomyces 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic bacteria with rod-shaped and branching filamentous forms, which form part of the normal mucosal flora in mammals but may cause opportunistic infections. Also (in form actinomyces): a bacterium of this genus (also called ray fungus).
--Examples--
--Word--
actinomycete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bacterium of an order that typically has a non-motile filamentous form. They include the economically important streptomycetes, and were formerly regarded as fungi.
--Examples--
--Word--
actinomycin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of substances with antibiotic and antineoplastic properties originally isolated from soil-dwelling microorganisms (actinomycetes) of the genus Streptomyces (formerly Actinomyces).
--Examples--
--Word--
actinomycosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disease caused by bacteria of the genus Actinomyces in cattle, other animals, or humans, typically characterized by the formation of nodular suppurating abscesses, most commonly in the region of the head and neck; an instance or type of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
actinomycotic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to actinomycosis; of the nature of or resembling actinomycosis.

--Word--
Actinopoda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With plural (or occasionally singular) concord: a phylum of amoeboid protozoans comprising the ‘radiolarians’ and heliozoans, characterized by a spherical body with radiating axopodia. Also treated as plural: protozoans of this phylum (collectively or individually).
--Examples--
--Word--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the group Actinopterygii of bony fishes characterized by membranous fins supported by slender rays or spines.
A fish of the group Actinopterygii; a ray-finned fish.

actinula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
action 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The fact or process of doing something, typically to achieve an aim.
The way in which something such as a chemical has an effect or influence.
The events represented in a story or play.
Exciting or notable activity.
Used by a film director as a command to begin.
A thing done; an act.
A gesture or movement.
The way in which something works or moves.
The mechanism that makes a machine or instrument work.
Armed conflict.
A military engagement.
Legal proceedings; a lawsuit.
Take action on; deal with.
--Examples--
‘ending child labour will require action on many levels’
‘strike action was threatened’
‘the seeds require the catalytic action of water to release heat’
‘the rank and file want to call the action off’
‘the action is set in a country house’
‘the weekend sporting action begins on Saturday’
‘people in media want to be where the action is’
‘lights, camera, action’
‘she frequently questioned his actions’
‘his actions emphasized his words’
‘the weapon has a smooth action’
‘a piano with an escapement action’
‘servicemen listed as missing in action during the war’
‘a rearguard action’
‘a civil action for damages’
‘your request will be actioned’

--Meanings--

actionable

adjective
--Meanings--

‘an actionable assertion’
‘insightful and actionable information on the effect advertising is having on your brand’
--Word--
actionably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
So as to give cause for legal action.

--Meanings--
Law. Of or relating to legal actions; actionable.

Grammar. That expresses an action.

A thing done; an act.
A gesture or movement.
The way in which something works or moves.
The mechanism that makes a machine or instrument work.
Armed conflict.
A military engagement.
Legal proceedings; a lawsuit.
Take action on; deal with.
--Examples--
‘ending child labour will require action on many levels’
‘strike action was threatened’
‘the seeds require the catalytic action of water to release heat’
‘the rank and file want to call the action off’
‘the action is set in a country house’
‘the weekend sporting action begins on Saturday’
‘people in media want to be where the action is’
‘lights, camera, action’
‘she frequently questioned his actions’
‘his actions emphasized his words’
‘the weapon has a smooth action’
‘a piano with an escapement action’
‘servicemen listed as missing in action during the war’
‘a rearguard action’
‘a civil action for damages’
‘your request will be actioned’

actionize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To act upon; to put into action.

Actium, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
active 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Engaging or ready to engage in physically energetic pursuits.
Moving or tending to move about vigorously or frequently.
Characterized by busy or lively activity.
(of a person's mind or imagination) alert and lively.
Pursuing an occupation or activity at a particular place or in a particular way.
Participating or engaged in a particular sphere or activity in a positive or spontaneous rather than a passive way.
(of a thing) working; operative.
(of an electric circuit) capable of modifying its state or characteristics automatically in response to input or feedback.
(of a volcano) that is erupting or has erupted in historical times.
(of a disease) in which the symptoms are manifest; not in remission or latent.
Having a chemical or biological effect on something.
Denoting a voice of verbs in which the subject is typically the person or thing performing the action and which can take a direct object (e.g. she loved him as opposed to the passive form he was loved).
An active form of a verb.
--Examples--
‘although he was seventy he was still robust and active’
‘I couldn't feel the baby moving, and it was normally very active’
‘they enjoyed an active social life’
‘Caroline nodded slowly, her active mind already racing ahead’
‘the artist was active in the 1920s’
‘tigers are active mainly at night’
‘a politically active student body’
‘sexually active teenagers’
‘she was an active member of the society’
‘he had never been very active in the affairs of the institute’
‘he enjoyed the active support of the government’
‘the old watermill was active until 1960’
‘the receiver is continuously active whenever the vehicle ignition is switched on’
‘the volcano became active on 28 March last year’
‘Etna is Europe's highest and most active volcano’
‘active colitis’
‘active ingredients’
--Word--
bodied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘we are bodied beings’
‘crayfish are heavy bodied crustaceans’
‘the narrow bodied hangar’
‘a medium bodied Cabernet’

‘actively growing weeds’

‘long-limbed’

--Word--
activity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition in which things are happening or being done.
Busy or vigorous action or movement.
A thing that a person or group does or has done.
A recreational pursuit or pastime.
A thermodynamic quantity representing the effective concentration of a particular component in a solution or other system, equal to its concentration multiplied by an activity coefficient.
--Examples--
‘there has been a sustained level of activity in the economy’
‘the only sign of human activity now is the boatload of day trippers from the mainland’
‘the room was a hive of activity’
‘the firm's marketing activities’
‘a range of sporting activities’

--Word--
act 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take action; do something.
Take action according to or in the light of.
Take action in order to bring about.
Represent (someone) on a contractual, legal, or paid basis.
Be motivated by.
Behave in the way specified.
Fulfil the function or serve the purpose of.
Take effect; have a particular effect.
Perform a role in a play, film, or television.
Behave so as to appear to be; pretend to be.
Perform a narrative as if it were a play.
Express repressed emotion or impulses in overt behaviour as a defensive substitute for conscious recall, typical of some behavioural disorders.
A thing done; a deed.
A New Testament book immediately following the Gospels and relating the history of the early Church.
A pretence.
A particular type of behaviour or routine.
A written law passed by Parliament, Congress, etc.
A document attesting a legal transaction.
The recorded decisions or proceedings of a committee or an academic body.
A main division of a play, ballet, or opera.
A set performance.
A performing group.
--Examples--
‘they urged Washington to act’
‘governments must act to reduce pollution’
‘I shall certainly act on his suggestion’
‘one's ability to act for community change’
‘he chose a solicitor to act for him’
‘you acted from greed’
‘they challenged a man who was seen acting suspiciously’
‘he acts as if he owned the place’
‘try to act like civilized adults’
‘they need volunteers to act as foster-parents’
‘a day-care centre which will act as a meeting place’
‘bacteria act on proteins and sugar’
‘she acted in her first professional role at the age of six’
‘he acted the role of the king’
‘I acted dumb at first’
‘encouraging pupils to act out the stories’
‘a criminal act’
‘the act of writing down one's thoughts’
‘an act of heroism’
‘she was putting on an act and laughing a lot’
‘he did his Sir Galahad act’
‘the 1989 Children Act’
‘the first act’
‘her one-woman poetry act’
‘an act called the Apple Blossom Sisters’

--Word--
actualism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Philosophy. The doctrine that only what is actual exists, and hence entities which are only possible do not exist; belief in the importance of the actual.
Realism in description or representation; = "actuality".
Geology. The theory or principle that changes in the geological past can be explained in terms of processes observable in the present. Compare actualist. Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
actualist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Geology. A person who believes that the geological past can be explained in terms of processes observable in the present; a proponent of actualism. Compare "uniformitarian". Now chiefly historical.
Chiefly Philosophy. A person who advocates the theory that only what is actual exists; a proponent of actualism.
Philosophy and Geology. Characterized by or advocating actualism.
--Examples--
--Word--
actualistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by or concerned with action or the actual; (Philosophy) relating to the theory that only what is actual exists.
Geology. Of or relating to actualism.
--Examples--

--Word--
actually 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
As the truth or facts of a situation; really.
Used to emphasize that something someone has said or done is surprising.
Used when expressing a contradictory or unexpected opinion or correcting someone.
Used to introduce a new topic or to add information to a previous statement.
--Examples--
‘we must pay attention to what young people are actually doing’
‘he actually expected me to be pleased about it!’
‘‘Tom's happy anyway.’ ‘He isn't, actually, not any more.’’
‘he had a thick Cockney accent—he sounded like my grandad actually’

actus reus

noun
--Meanings--

‘failure to prevent death may be the actus reus of manslaughter’
--Word--
wait 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Stay where one is or delay action until a particular time or event.
Stay where one is or delay action until (someone) arrives or is ready.
Be left until a later time before being dealt with.
Defer (a meal) until a person's arrival.
Remain in readiness for a purpose.
(of a vehicle) be parked for a short time at the side of a road.
Used to indicate that one is eagerly impatient to do something or for something to happen.
Act as a waiter or waitress, serving food and drink.
A period of waiting.
Street singers of Christmas carols.
Official bands of musicians maintained by a city or town.
--Examples--
‘he did not wait for a reply’
‘we're waiting for Allan to get back’
‘Vera did not wait on a Home Office ruling’
‘Ben stood on the street corner waiting to cross’
‘I had to wait my turn to play’
‘he sits on the corner waiting for Mary’
‘she was waiting on her boyfriend’
‘we shall need a statement later, but that will have to wait’
‘I told my parents not to wait supper’
‘he found the train waiting on the platform’
‘I can't wait to tell Nick what happened’
‘a local man was employed to wait on them at table’
‘we had to wait tables in the mess hall’
‘we had a long wait’

--Meanings--
Of speech or thought: pointed, incisive, keen, pungent.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--

--Word--
aculeus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. A sharply pointed projection on a plant, such as a thorn or a spine; especially one growing directly from the epidermis or forming an extension of it.
Zoology. The sting of an insect or other animal.
--Examples--

acuminate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a plant or animal structure, e.g. a leaf) tapering to a point.

--Word--
acuminated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Brought to a sharp point, pointed. Also figurative: (of speech) sharp, pointed, stinging.
--Examples--
--Word--
acuminating 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Tapering or narrowing to a point; (Mineralogy, of three or more planes) meeting so as to form a point by their intersection (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
acumination 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pointed or tapering part; (Mineralogy) †a part of a crystal regarded as notionally resulting from acumination (obsolete). Now chiefly Botany and Zoology.
The action of giving a point to something or bringing something to a point (chiefly figurative); (Mineralogy) †the notional replacement of an angle or plane of a crystal by three or more planes meeting in a point (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
acuminose 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Tapering gradually to a narrow but not pointed end.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

acuminulate

acupressure 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
acupuncture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of complementary medicine in which fine needles are inserted in the skin at specific points along what are considered to be lines of energy (meridians), used in the treatment of various physical and mental conditions.

--Word--
acute 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of an unpleasant or unwelcome situation or phenomenon) present or experienced to a severe or intense degree.
(of a disease or its symptoms) severe but of short duration.
Denoting or designed for patients with an acute form of a disease.
Having or showing a perceptive understanding or insight; shrewd.
(of a physical sense or faculty) highly developed; keen.
(of an angle) less than 90°.
Having a sharp end; pointed.
(of a sound) high; shrill.
--Examples--
‘an acute housing shortage’
‘the problem is acute and getting worse’
‘acute appendicitis’
‘an acute ward’
‘acute patients’
‘an acute awareness of changing fashions’
‘an acute sense of smell’
--Word--
acute-angled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Especially of a triangle: having acute angles; forming an acute angle.
--Examples--
--Word--
acutely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
(with reference to something unpleasant or unwelcome) intensely.
(in relation to illness) in a way that progresses rapidly but lasts for a short period.
In a way that shows a perceptive understanding or insight.
--Examples--
‘the whole situation was acutely embarrassing’
‘Elizabeth felt Jane's distress acutely’
‘an acutely inflamed gall bladder’
‘we are all acutely aware of the fragility of our world’

--Word--
day 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the twenty-four-hour periods, reckoned from one midnight to the next, into which a week, month, or year is divided, and corresponding to a rotation of the earth on its axis.
The part of a day when it is light; the time between sunrise and sunset.
The part of a day spent working.
A single rotation of a planet in relation to its primary.
The period on a planet when its primary star is above the horizon.
Daylight.
A particular period of the past; an era.
The present time.
A particular period in a person's life or career.
The most active or successful period of a person's life or career.
The remaining period of someone's life.
--Examples--
‘they only met a few days ago’
‘we'll leave the day after tomorrow’
‘‘What day is it?’ ‘Sunday’’
‘she spent five days in hospital’
‘the animals hunt by day’
‘he works an eight-hour day’
‘by the time they had all gone it was broad day’
‘in Shakespeare's day’
‘the laws were very strict in those days’
‘the political issues of the day’
‘my student days’
‘he had been a star in his day’
‘she cared for him for the rest of his days’

proper noun

--Word--
adamantinoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a tumour of odontogenic epithelial cells (adamantoblasts) occurring in the jaws; = "ameloblastoma" (now rare). In later use: a tumour with a similar histological appearance occurring especially in the tibia.

--Word--
adamite 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Church History. A member of any of a number of sects, both in the early church and later, who imitated the biblical Adam by going naked, typically as a symbol of purity.
A person who is descended from the biblical Adam, especially a member of a specific branch of humanity derived from the biblical Adam rather than some other ancestor.
Specifically. A white Caucasian. Now chiefly historical.
Descended or deriving from the biblical Adam.
A zinc mineral occurring as yellow, green, or colourless crystals or crystal aggregates.

adamsite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organic arsenic compound which induces vomiting and is irritating to the eyes and lungs, used in the form of an aerosol in chemical warfare, riot control, etc.; also called DM (diphenylaminechlorasine).

noun

adapid

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of various extinct prosimian primates of the family Adapidae, resembling lemurs and known from fossil remains of the Eocene period.

--Word--
adapt 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (something) suitable for a new use or purpose; modify.
Become adjusted to new conditions.
Alter (a text) to make it suitable for filming, broadcasting, or the stage.
--Examples--
‘hospitals have had to be adapted for modern medical practice’
‘the policies can be adapted to suit individual needs’
‘a large organization can be slow to adapt to change’
‘the film was adapted from a Turgenev short story’

adaptation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of adapting or being adapted.
A film, television drama, or stage play that has been adapted from a written work.
The process of change by which an organism or species becomes better suited to its environment.

‘the adaptation of teaching strategy to meet students' needs’
‘adaptations to the school curriculum’
‘a three-part adaptation of Hard Times’
‘living in groups is an adaptation to increase the efficiency of hunting’

noun
--Meanings--
(in the Jewish calendar) the sixth month of the civil and twelfth of the religious year, usually coinciding with parts of February and March. It is known in leap years as Second Adar.
An intercalary month preceding Adar in leap years, also called First Adar.
--Examples--
--Word--
adat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Islamic regions of South-East Asia: custom, accepted practice.
--Examples--

adatom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An atom that has been adsorbed on a surface.

--Meanings--

adaxial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Facing towards the stem of a plant (in particular denoting the upper surface of a leaf).

--Examples--
--Word--
add 
--Type--
verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Join (something) to something else so as to increase the size, number, or amount.
Put in (an additional element, ingredient, etc.)
Contribute (an enhancing quality) to something.
Put together (two or more numbers or amounts) to calculate their total value.
Say as a further remark.
add up
Increase in amount, number, or degree.
Seem reasonable or consistent; make sense.
add up to
Amount to.
Analogue digital digital, indicating that a music recording was made in analogue format before being mastered and stored digitally.
Attention deficit disorder.
--Examples--
‘a new wing was added to the building’
‘some box offices now add on a convenience charge’
‘chlorine is added to the water to kill bacteria’
‘the suite will add a touch of class to your bedroom’
‘they added all the figures up’
‘add the two numbers together’
‘‘I hope we haven't been too much trouble,’ she added politely’
‘we would like to add our congratulations’
‘watch those air miles add up!’
‘many things in her story didn't add up’
‘this adds up to a total of 400 calories’
‘these isolated incidents don't add up to a true picture of the situation’

adda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place where people gather for conversation.
An illicit drinking place.
Informal conversation among a group of people.
A junction point for public transport.
--Examples--

‘‘Go upstairs and enjoy a little adda with our neighbours.’’

--Word--
Addams, Jane 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1935), American social reformer, feminist, and pacifist. In 1889 she founded Hull House, a centre for the care and education of the poor of Chicago. Nobel Peace Prize (1931).
--Examples--
--Word--
Addams, Jane 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1935), American social reformer, feminist, and pacifist. In 1889 she founded Hull House, a centre for the care and education of the poor of Chicago. Nobel Peace Prize (1931).

--Word--
addendum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An item of additional material added at the end of a book or other publication.
The radial distance from the pitch circle of a cogwheel or wormwheel to the crests of the teeth or ridges.

--Word--
adder 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small venomous Eurasian snake which has a dark zigzag pattern on its back and bears live young. It is the only poisonous snake in Britain.
Used in names of snakes that are similar or related to the adder, e.g. death adder, puff adder.
A unit which adds together two input variables. A full adder can add a bit carried from another addition as well as the two inputs, whereas a half adder can only add the inputs together.
--Examples--
--Word--
adder 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small venomous Eurasian snake which has a dark zigzag pattern on its back and bears live young. It is the only poisonous snake in Britain.
Used in names of snakes that are similar or related to the adder, e.g. death adder, puff adder.
A unit which adds together two input variables. A full adder can add a bit carried from another addition as well as the two inputs, whereas a half adder can only add the inputs together.
--Examples--
--Word--
adder's grass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several plants thought to resemble a snake in some way, or used to treat snakebites; especially adder's tongue, genus Ophioglossum, and †bistort, Persicaria bistorta (obsolete); compare adderwort. Now historical and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
adder's meat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Greater stitchwort, Stellaria holostea.
--Examples--
--Word--
adder's mouth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(Frequently with distinguishing word) any of various North American orchids of the genus Malaxis (formerly Microstylis), typically having very small green or white flowers.

Addington, Henry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Viscount Sidmouth (1757–1844), British Tory statesman, prime minister 1801–4 and Home Secretary (1812–22).

addition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of adding something to something else.
A person or thing added or joined.
The process of calculating the total of two or more numbers or amounts.
The process of combining matrices, vectors, or other quantities under specific rules to obtain their sum or resultant.
--Examples--
‘the hotel has been extended with the addition of more rooms’
‘you will find the coat a useful addition to your wardrobe’
‘she began with simple arithmetic, addition and then subtraction’
‘the concepts of vectors and vector addition’

‘the video monitor uses the additive colours red, green, and blue’

addle 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Make (someone) unable to think clearly; confuse.
(of an egg) become rotten, producing no chick.
Not clear or cogent; muddled.
(of an egg) rotten.
--Examples--
‘being in love must have addled your brain’
‘the extremely hot and dry weather had caused the eggs to addle’
‘the film is addle-brained’

--Word--
address 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The particulars of the place where someone lives or an organization is situated.
The place where someone lives or an organization is situated.
A string of characters which identifies a destination for email messages or the location of a website.
A binary number which identifies a particular location in a data storage system or computer memory.
A formal speech delivered to an audience.
A person's manner of speaking to someone else.
Courteous or amorous approaches to someone.
Skill, dexterity, or readiness.
Write the name and address of the intended recipient on (an envelope, letter, or parcel)
Speak to (a person or an assembly)
Name someone (in the specified way) when talking to them.
Say or write remarks or a protest to.
Think about and begin to deal with (an issue or problem)
Take up one's stance and prepare to hit (the ball)
--Examples--
‘they exchanged addresses and agreed to keep in touch’
‘our officers called at the address’
‘a numerical value which acts as a storage address for the data’
‘an address to the European Parliament’
‘his address was abrupt and unceremonious’
‘he persecuted her with his addresses’
‘he rescued me with the most consummate address’
‘I addressed my letter to him personally’
‘she addressed the open-air meeting’
‘she addressed my father as ‘Mr Stevens’’
‘address your complaints to the Trading Standards Board’
‘a fundamental problem has still to be addressed’
‘ensure that your weight is evenly spread when you address the ball’
--Word--
addressability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property or quality of being addressable; specifically the ability to direct a signal or information to individual users.
--Examples--
--Word--
addressable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a memory unit in which all locations can be separately accessed by a particular program.

add 
--Type--
verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Join (something) to something else so as to increase the size, number, or amount.
Put in (an additional element, ingredient, etc.)
Contribute (an enhancing quality) to something.
Put together (two or more numbers or amounts) to calculate their total value.
Say as a further remark.
add up
Increase in amount, number, or degree.
Seem reasonable or consistent; make sense.
add up to
Amount to.
Analogue digital digital, indicating that a music recording was made in analogue format before being mastered and stored digitally.
Attention deficit disorder.
--Examples--
‘a new wing was added to the building’
‘some box offices now add on a convenience charge’
‘chlorine is added to the water to kill bacteria’

‘this adds up to a total of 400 calories’

deep 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Extending far down from the top or surface.
Extending or situated far in from the outer edge or surface.
(after a measurement and in questions) extending a specified distance from the top, surface, or outer edge.
As far up or down as a specified point.
In a specified number of ranks one behind another.
Taking in or giving out a lot of air.
(of a fielding position) relatively distant from the batsman; near the boundary.
(in ball games) to or from a position far down or across the field.
Very intense or extreme.
(of an emotion or feeling) intensely felt.
Profound or penetrating in awareness or understanding.
Difficult to understand.
Fully absorbed or involved in (a state or activity)
(of a person) unpredictable and secretive.
(of sound) low in pitch and full in tone; not shrill.
(of colour) dark and intense.
The sea.
A deep part of the sea.
The part of the field distant from the batsman.
Far down or in; deeply.
(in sport) distant from the batsman or forward line of one's team.
--Examples--
‘a deep gorge’
‘the lake was deep and cold’
‘a deep alcove’
‘deep in the woods’
‘the well was 200 feet deep’
‘they stood waist-deep in the water’
‘they were standing three-deep at the bar’
‘she took a deep breath’
‘deep midwicket’
‘a deep cross from Neill’
‘she was in deep trouble’
‘a deep sleep’
‘deep disappointment’
‘a deep analysis’
‘this is all getting too deep for me’
‘they were deep in their own thoughts’
‘that Thomas is a deep one’
‘a deep, resonant voice’
‘a deep pink’
‘denizens of the deep’
‘the dark and menacing deeps’
‘the deeps of her imagination’
‘he travelled deep into the forest’
‘he swung the ball in deep’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating plays performed at or in a style characteristic of the Adelphi Theatre in London, especially (in early use, chiefly in "Adelphi screamer") a type of broad comedy or farce; (later) a type of melodrama which was prevalent in the last decades of the 19th cent., typically with the dialogue written in a literary rather than natural, conversational style.

Aden 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port in Yemen at the mouth of the Red Sea; population 588,900 (est. 2004). Aden was formerly under British rule, first as part of British India (from 1839), then from 1935 as a Crown Colony. It was capital of the former South Yemen from 1967 until 1990.

--Word--
adequation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The result of being made equal, balanced or commensurate; equivalence; exact correspondence; (also occasionally concrete) an equivalent. Frequently, especially in early use, in philosophical contexts with reference to truth.
The action of making commensurate, equal, or balanced; the matching or proportioning of one thing to another.
Linguistics. In or with reference to the theories of Gustaf Stern: a type of semantic change arising from a change in the perception of a word's referent, e.g. the word horn coming to refer to a wind instrument as this became the predominant use for animal horns.
--Examples--

adequative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
adherer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who adheres to a person or thing; an adherent.
--Examples--
--Word--
adherer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who adheres to a person or thing; an adherent.
--Examples--
--Word--
adhere 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Stick fast to (a surface or substance)
Believe in and follow the practices of.
Closely follow, observe, or represent.
--Examples--
‘paint won't adhere well to a greasy surface’
‘I do not adhere to any organized religion’
‘the account adhered firmly to fact’
--Word--
adherescent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Adhering or tending to adhere; adhesive; associated. rare after 18th cent.
Ancient Greek Grammar. Of a negative particle: modifying the meaning of an adjacent word such that the two words may function as a single lexical unit expressing negation.
--Examples--
--Word--
adhere 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Stick fast to (a surface or substance)
Believe in and follow the practices of.
Closely follow, observe, or represent.
--Examples--
‘paint won't adhere well to a greasy surface’
‘I do not adhere to any organized religion’
‘the account adhered firmly to fact’
--Word--
adhesion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of adhering to a surface or object.
The frictional grip of wheels, shoes, etc. on a surface.
The sticking together of particles of different substances.
Allegiance to a particular person, party, or set of ideas.
An abnormal adhering of surfaces due to inflammation or injury.
--Examples--
‘the adhesion of the gum strip to the paper’
‘the sole unit provides good adhesion for walking on all surfaces’
‘he was harshly criticized for his adhesion to Say's law’
‘endoscopic surgery for pelvic adhesions’
--Word--
adhesion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of adhering to a surface or object.
The frictional grip of wheels, shoes, etc. on a surface.

adjective, noun

‘tile adhesive’

adiabat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An adiabatic curve or line; = "adiabatic".
--Examples--
--Word--
adiabatic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a process or condition in which heat does not enter or leave the system concerned.
Impassable to heat.
A curve or formula representing adiabatic phenomena.
--Examples--
‘the adiabatic expansion of a perfect gas’

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
adiaphoral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to issues and practices not considered central to the Christian faith; adiaphorous. See adiaphoron. Also (occasionally) as noun: †an adiaphoron (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
adiaphorism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Adiaphoristic beliefs or principles; latitude or indifference in religious matters; indifferentism, latitudinarianism; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
adiaphorist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Church History. Any one of a group of moderate Lutherans led by Phillipp Melanchthon, who advocated certain issues and ceremonies to be considered as adiaphora and not central to the Protestant faith.
A person who holds that differences of religious belief are unimportant; one who allows latitude or flexibility with regard to religious matters; an indifferentist, a latitudinarian.
Of, relating to, or of the nature of an adiaphorist or adiaphorists; that allows latitude in religious matters.
--Examples--
--Word--
adiaphoristic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to adiaphora or adiaphorists; = adiaphorist.
--Examples--
--Word--
adiaphoron 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Usually in plural An issue or practice not considered to be central to a religion, especially Christianity; a religious matter that allows latitude; a non-essential element of a faith. Also: something of a morally neutral nature; a thing which is neither inherently good nor bad.
In predicative use. Of the nature of an adiaphoron or adiaphora.
--Examples--
--Word--
adiaphorous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Neutral, impartial; indifferent to; peripheral, irrelevant; specifically of or relating to adiaphora or religious issues not considered to be central to a particular faith; governed or guided by what is considered adiaphora.
--Examples--
--Word--
adiate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
In Roman-Dutch law: to accept (an inheritance) as an heir or (in South Africa) a beneficiary of a will.

--Examples--
--Word--
Buddha 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A title given to the founder of Buddhism, Siddartha Gautama (c.563–c.483 BC). Born a prince in what is now Nepal, he renounced wealth and family to become an ascetic, and after achieving enlightenment while meditating, taught all who came to learn from him.
A person who has attained full enlightenment.
A statue or picture of the Buddha.
--Examples--
--Word--
adience 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tendency to seek out or maximize the impact of a stimulus; behaviour of this type. Opposed to abience.
--Examples--
--Word--
adient 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Exhibiting, involving, or relating to a tendency to seek out or maximize the impact of a stimulus. Opposed to abient.

--Word--
Trentino-Alto Adige 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of north-eastern Italy, comprising Bolzano-Bozen and Trento provinces. Situated on the border with Austria, it includes the Dolomites.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adyghe 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a mainly Sunni Muslim people of the NW Caucasus, especially Adygea.
The North Caucasian language of the Adyghe, with about 100,000 speakers in the Caucasus and 100,000 elsewhere.
Relating to the Adyghe or their language.
--Examples--

adynamia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: severe physical weakness; prostration; debility.
--Examples--
--Word--
adynamic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: resulting in or characterized by weakness or debility; specifically designating fevers, especially typhus and typhoid, which have a marked debilitating effect (now rare). In later use: specifically exhibiting, characterized by, or resulting from reduced or absent muscular contraction.
Designating bone or bone disorders in which new bone formation is greatly diminished or absent.

--Word--
adiposis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: obesity of the body; fatty infiltration of an organ; (now rare). In later use also (usually with distinguishing English or scientific Latin word): any of various disorders affecting adipose tissue, especially subcutaneous adipose tissue.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: obesity of the body; fatty infiltration of an organ; (now rare). In later use also (usually with distinguishing English or scientific Latin word): any of various disorders affecting adipose tissue, especially subcutaneous adipose tissue.

Adirondack shelter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An open-fronted shelter of a type traditionally built alongside hiking trails in the Adirondacks, typically made from wood and having a roof that slopes steeply backward; also occasionally "Adirondack shelter-camp".

aditus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Zoology. The opening of or entrance into a cavity or channel (frequently with distinguishing scientific Latin word or phrase denoting the cavity or channel); especially (more fully "aditus ad antrum") the opening between the tympanic cavity and the mastoid antrum.
--Examples--

Adivasi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of any of the aboriginal tribal peoples living in India before the arrival of the Aryans in the second millennium BC.
A descendant of any of the Adivasi peoples.

--Word--
adjoint 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a function or quantity related to a given function or quantity by a particular process of transposition.
Denoting a matrix that is the transpose of the complex conjugates or the cofactors of a given square matrix.
An adjoint matrix, function, or quantity.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjoint 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a function or quantity related to a given function or quantity by a particular process of transposition.
Denoting a matrix that is the transpose of the complex conjugates or the cofactors of a given square matrix.
An adjoint matrix, function, or quantity.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjourn 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Break off (a meeting, legal case, or game) with the intention of resuming it later.
(of a group of people) go somewhere for rest or refreshment.
Put off or postpone (a resolution or sentence)
--Examples--
‘the meeting was adjourned until December 4’
‘let's adjourn and reconvene at 2 o'clock’
‘they adjourned to a local pub’
‘sentence was adjourned for a social inquiry report’
--Word--
adjournal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "Act of Adjournal". Originally: a ruling of a criminal court, specifically one ordering a particular party to satisfy another within a specified time (now historical). Later: any ruling or regulation made by the High Court of Justiciary relating to judicial procedure in criminal courts.
In full "Books of Adjournal". A register of Acts of Adjournal.
--Examples--

verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘the court adjudged legal damages to her’
‘the defaulter was adjudged to pay the whole amount’

--Word--
adjudicate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a formal judgement on a disputed matter.
Act as a judge in a competition.
Pronounce or declare judicially.
--Examples--
‘the Committee adjudicates on all betting disputes’
‘the case was adjudicated in the High Court’
‘we asked him to adjudicate at the local flower show’
‘he was adjudicated bankrupt’

--Examples--
‘the proposal to close the school will have to go before an adjudicator’
--Word--
adjudicative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
adjudicator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who adjudicates.
--Examples--
‘the proposal to close the school will have to go before an adjudicator’
--Word--
adjudicatory 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of adjudication; having the power or authority to adjudicate.
A person or body of people that adjudicates; specifically (in later use, in certain denominations of the Christian church) a body with the authority to make official rulings on church matters.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjudicator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who adjudicates.
--Examples--
‘the proposal to close the school will have to go before an adjudicator’
--Word--
adjudicature 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of adjudicating; adjudication.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjunct 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A thing added to something else as a supplementary rather than an essential part.
A person who is another's assistant or subordinate.
A word or phrase that constitutes an optional element or is considered of secondary importance in a sentence, for example on the table in we left some flowers on the table.
(in systemic grammar) an obligatory or optional adverbial functioning as a constituent of clause structure.
Connected or added to something.
(of an academic post) attached to the staff of a university in a temporary or assistant capacity.
--Examples--
‘computer technology is an adjunct to learning’
‘a talented adjunct desperately grabbing at officer status’
‘other adjunct therapies include immunotherapy’
‘an adjunct professor of entomology’
--Word--
adjunction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The joining of two sets which without overlapping jointly constitute a larger set, or the relation between two such sets.
The asserting in a single formula of two previously asserted formulae.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjunctive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Added to something else as a supplement rather than an essential part.
--Examples--
‘additional medications may be used as adjunctive therapy’
--Word--
adjunctively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an adjunctive manner; as an adjunct.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjunctly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
= adjunctively.

--Word--
adjust 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Alter or move (something) slightly in order to achieve the desired fit, appearance, or result.
Permit small alterations or movements so as to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result.
Adapt or become used to a new situation.
Assess (loss or damages) when settling an insurance claim.
--Examples--
‘he smoothed his hair and adjusted his tie’
‘a single control adjusts the water flow’
‘a harness that adjusts to the correct fit’
‘she must be allowed to grieve and to adjust in her own way’
‘his eyes had adjusted to semi-darkness’
‘the insurance agent may have the responsibility of adjusting small losses’
--Word--
adjustability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

‘an adjustable spanner’

--Word--
ajutage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the outlet tube or mouthpiece of a fountain. Later also: a nozzle or mouthpiece attached to a pipe or aperture so as to facilitate the flow of liquid out of it or to determine the character of the flow.
--Examples--

--Word--
adjutant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A military officer who acts as an administrative assistant to a senior officer.
A person's assistant or deputy.
A large black-and-white stork with a massive bill and a bare head and neck, found in India and SE Asia.
--Examples--
‘he eventually became adjutant to the commander of the tactical air force’
‘Hoare was his adjutant in all the talks with the government’

--Word--
adjutator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person empowered to act on behalf of others; specifically each of the delegates chosen to represent the private soldiers of some units of the Parliamentary army during the English Civil War, initially at the Army Council of June 1647. Later also (occasionally) more generally: a helper, an assistant.
--Examples--

--Word--
adjuvant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of therapy) applied after initial treatment for cancer, especially to suppress secondary tumour formation.
A substance which enhances the body's immune response to an antigen.
--Examples--
--Word--
adjuvant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Stevenson, Adlai 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1900–1965), US statesman and politician; full name Adlai Ewing Stevenson II. A popular supporter of social reform and internationalism, he was governor of Illinois 1949–53 and was the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for the presidency 1952 and 1956. He later served as US ambassador to the United Nations 1961–65.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adler, Alfred 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1870–1937), Austrian psychologist and psychiatrist. Adler disagreed with Freud's idea that mental illness was caused by sexual conflicts in infancy, arguing that society and culture were significant factors. He introduced the concept of the inferiority complex.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adlerian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or influenced by Alfred Adler's theories of psychotherapy, especially his views that society and culture were significant factors in the formation of an individual's personality.
A follower of Alfred Adler or his methods.
--Examples--
‘recent studies of Adlerian and social learning approaches’
‘he not only studied with Adler but identified himself as an Adlerian’
--Word--
adless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a newspaper, radio station, etc.: that is without advertisements; not carrying advertisements.
--Examples--
--Word--
ad lib 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Spoken or performed without previous preparation.
(especially as a direction) with free rhythm and expression.
As much and as often as desired.
Speak or perform in public without previously preparing one's words.
A remark or speech made without previous preparation.
--Examples--
‘I spoke ad lib’
‘an ad-lib commentary’
‘the price includes meals and drinks ad lib’
‘the pigs are fed on an ad-lib basis’
‘Charles had to ad-lib because he'd forgotten his script’
‘he came up with an apt ad lib’

admaxillary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Situated close to or connected with the maxilla; (in early use) specifically designating accessory salivary glands associated with the parotid and submaxillary glands in certain mammals. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
admeasure 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To measure, make measurement of. In later use chiefly: specifically to make formal measurement of (a ship) in order to determine its capacity or tonnage.
With complement. To be of a specified capacity, tonnage, size, etc.; to have an admeasurement of a specified weight or magnitude.
Chiefly Law. To assign or allot (something) to each person according to his or her due share; to apportion. Also: to allot or measure out the stipulated or agreed share of something to (someone).
--Examples--
--Word--
admeasured 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is or has been admeasured; measured; apportioned, allocated.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
adminiculum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Entomology. Originally: each of a number of minute spines or processes on the abdominal surface of certain subterranean insect pupae, used in locomotion (usually in plural; now rare). Later also: an unpaired accessory sclerite in the genitalia of certain male flies.
Zoology and Palaeontology. Each of a number of tapering processes on the internal surface of the shell of certain articulated brachiopods. Usually in plural.
--Examples--
--Word--
administer 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Manage and be responsible for the running of (a business, organization, etc.)
Be responsible for the implementation or use of (law or resources)
Dispense or apply (a remedy or drug)
Deal out or inflict (punishment)
(of a priest) perform the rites of (a sacrament)
Direct the taking of (an oath)
Give help or service.
--Examples--
‘each school was administered separately’
‘a Health and Safety agency would administer new regulations’
‘paramedic crews are capable of administering drugs’
‘retribution was administered to those found guilty’
‘he administered the sacraments to the flock’
‘he administered the Oath of Supremacy to Thomas Percy’
‘we must selflessly administer to his needs’

--Word--
administration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or activity of running a business, organization, etc.
The people responsible for running a business, organization, etc.
The management and disposition of the property of a deceased person, debtor, or insolvent company, by a legally appointed administrator.
The management of public affairs; government.
The government in power.
The term of office of a political leader or government.
(in the US) a department or agency of the government.
The action of dispensing, giving, or applying something.
--Examples--
‘the day-to-day administration of the company’
‘a career in arts administration’
‘the university administration took their demands seriously’
‘the company went into administration’
‘the inhabitants of the island voted to remain under French administration’
‘successive Conservative administrations enjoyed a comfortable majority’
‘the early years of the Reagan Administration’
‘the US Food and Drug Administration’
‘the oral administration of the antibiotic’
‘the administration of justice’

administrational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Meanings--

admirably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that arouses or deserves respect and approval.
--Examples--
‘he behaved himself admirably’
‘an admirably concise and clear summary’
--Word--
admiral 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The most senior commander of a fleet or navy.
A naval officer of the second most senior rank, above vice admiral and below Admiral of the Fleet or Fleet Admiral.
A butterfly which has dark wings with bold red or white markings.
--Examples--

--Word--
Admiralty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK) the government department that administered the Royal Navy, now incorporated in the Ministry of Defence and current only in titles.
The jurisdiction of courts of law over cases concerning ships or the sea and other navigable waters.
--Examples--
‘it is necessary to issue a summons for directions in an admiralty case’
--Word--
Admiralty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK) the government department that administered the Royal Navy, now incorporated in the Ministry of Defence and current only in titles.
The jurisdiction of courts of law over cases concerning ships or the sea and other navigable waters.
--Examples--
‘it is necessary to issue a summons for directions in an admiralty case’

--Word--
admiration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Respect and warm approval.
Something regarded as impressive or worthy of respect.
Pleasurable contemplation.
--Examples--
‘I have the greatest admiration for all those involved in the project’
‘her house was the admiration of everyone’
‘they were lost in admiration of the scenery’

--Word--
admirative 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Grammar. A word, sentence, etc., expressing surprise. Now chiefly: specifically (especially in various languages of the Balkans) the admirative mood; an admirative verbal construction or form.
Characterized by or full of admiration; admiring.
Grammar. Designating a word, sentence, etc., expressing surprise. Now chiefly: specifically (especially in various languages of the Balkans) designating a verbal mood, construction, or form expressing surprise, unexpectedness, disbelief, or the fact that the information is based on a report.
--Examples--
--Word--
admiratively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Chiefly Grammar. By means of, or in the manner of, an admirative statement; in the admirative mood.
With admiration; admiringly.
--Examples--
--Word--
admirator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An admirer.
--Examples--

verb
--Meanings--

‘we were just admiring your garden’

--Word--
admission 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A statement acknowledging the truth of something.
The process or fact of entering or being allowed to enter a place or organization.
The fee charged for entry to a public place.
The number of people entering a place.
A person admitted to hospital for treatment.
--Examples--
‘an admission of guilt’
‘a tacit admission that things had gone wrong’
‘the evening before her admission to hospital’
‘the country's admission to the UN’
‘admission is £1 for adults and 50p for children’
‘cinema admissions have been rising recently’
‘there was a substantial reduction in hospital admissions’

--Examples--
--Word--
admit 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Confess to be true or to be the case.
Confess to (a crime or fault, or one's responsibility for it)
Acknowledge (a failure or fault)
Allow (someone) to enter a place.
Receive (a patient) into a hospital for treatment.
Allow (a person, country, etc.) to join an organization.
Allow (someone) to share in a privilege.
Accept as valid.
Allow the possibility of.
--Examples--
‘the Home Office finally admitted that several prisoners had been injured’
‘‘I am feeling pretty tired,’ Jane admitted’
‘he was sentenced to prison after admitting 47 charges of burglary’
‘the paramilitaries admitted to the illegal possession of arms’
‘after searching for an hour, she finally had to admit defeat’
‘old-age pensioners are admitted free to the museum’
‘she was admitted to hospital suffering from a chest infection’
‘Canada was admitted to the League of Nations’
‘he was admitted to the freedom of the city in 1583’
‘the courts can refuse to admit police evidence which has been illegally obtained’
‘the need to inform him was too urgent to admit of further delay’

‘he admonished the people against the evil of such practices’

admonitioner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
adobo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Filipino dish of chicken or pork stewed in vinegar, garlic, soy sauce, bay leaves, and peppercorns.
The marinade in which adobo is cooked.
A paste or marinade made from chillies, vinegar, herbs, and spices, used in Mexican cooking to flavour meat or fish.

--Type--

--Word--
adolescence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The period following the onset of puberty during which a young person develops from a child into an adult.
--Examples--
‘Mary spent her childhood and adolescence in Europe’
‘during adolescence teenagers often experience violent mood swings’
--Word--
adolescency 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Adolescence.
--Examples--
--Word--
adolescent 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a young person) in the process of developing from a child into an adult.
Relating to or characteristic of adolescence.
An adolescent boy or girl.
--Examples--
‘many parents find it hard to understand their adolescent children’
‘his adolescent years’
‘adolescent problems’
‘the books are aimed at children and adolescents’

--Examples--
--Word--
Windaus, Adolf 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1876–1959), German organic chemist. He did pioneering work on the chemistry and structure of steroids and their derivatives, notably cholesterol. He also investigated the D vitamins and vitamin B₁, and discovered histamine. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1928).
--Examples--
--Word--
Zukor, Adolph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1873–1976), US movie producer and executive; born in Hungary. He created the Famous Players Film Company in 1912. Through mergers and name changes it evolved as Paramount Pictures with Zukor at the head.
--Examples--
--Word--
Gustavus Adolphus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1594–1632), king of Sweden 1611–32. His repeated victories in battle made Sweden a European power, and in 1630 he intervened on the Protestant side in the Thirty Years War. His domestic reforms laid the foundation of the modern state.
--Examples--
--Word--

Adonian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, connected with, or characteristic of Adonis or an Adonis; Adonean.
Prosody. = Adonic. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adonic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A metre consisting of a dactyl followed by a spondee; a verse or line written in this metre.
Of a verse or line: written in a metre consisting of a dactyl followed by a spondee.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adonis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A beautiful youth loved by both Aphrodite and Persephone. He was killed by a boar, but Zeus decreed that he should spend the winter of each year in the underworld with Persephone and the summer months with Aphrodite.
An extremely handsome young man.
--Examples--
‘not all of us have the body of an Adonis’
--Word--
Adonis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A beautiful youth loved by both Aphrodite and Persephone. He was killed by a boar, but Zeus decreed that he should spend the winter of each year in the underworld with Persephone and the summer months with Aphrodite.

--Examples--
‘not all of us have the body of an Adonis’

--Meanings--
Ribitol.
--Examples--
--Word--
adonize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To adorn, beautify; to titivate. Chiefly refl. (used chiefly of men). Formerly also with †it, with reflexive meaning. Now historical.
To adorn or beautify oneself; to primp. Used chiefly of men.
--Examples--

--Word--
Doors 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An American rock group chiefly remembered for flamboyant lead singer Jim Morrison (1943–71) and for dramatic songs such as ‘Light My Fire’ (1967).
--Examples--
--Word--
adopt 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Legally take (another's child) and bring it up as one's own.
Choose to take up or follow (an idea, method, or course of action)
Choose and move to (a country or city) as one's permanent place of residence.
Take on or assume (an attitude or position)
Choose (someone) as a candidate for office.
Formally approve or accept (a report or suggestion)
(of a local authority) accept responsibility for the maintenance of (a road).
--Examples--
‘there are many people eager to adopt a baby’
‘this approach has been adopted by many big banks’
‘he adopted a patronizing tone’
‘she was recently adopted as Labour candidate for the constituency’
‘the committee voted 5–1 to adopt the proposal’

--Word--
Adorno, Theodor W. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–69), German philosopher, sociologist, and musicologist; born Theodor Wiesengrund. A member of the Frankfurt School, Adorno argued that philosophical authoritarianism is inevitably oppressive and that all theories should be rejected.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adorno, Theodor W. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–69), German philosopher, sociologist, and musicologist; born Theodor Wiesengrund. A member of the Frankfurt School, Adorno argued that philosophical authoritarianism is inevitably oppressive and that all theories should be rejected.

--Word--
adosculation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Impregnation or fertilization of an animal by the external contact of genital orifices, without intromission. Also: †fertilization of plants by pollination (obsolete). Also figurative and in extended use: mouth-to-mouth kissing. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
adown 
--Type--
adverb, preposition
--Meanings--
To a lower place or position; downward, down; towards the earth. Frequently with verbs of motion, often those signifying descent, as fall, sink, kneel, etc..
Figurative and in figurative contexts. During, over the course of, or after (a period of time); throughout (the course of time).

--Word--
adradial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
In radially symmetrical invertebrates such as jellyfishes and echinoderms: relating to or situated near or beside primary rays or axes.
An adradial organ or body part.
--Examples--
--Word--
adradius 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In an invertebrate with radial symmetry, as a cnidarian or an echinoderm: any of the tertiary (third order) rays or axes (each located between a perradius and an interradius).
--Examples--
--Word--
adream 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a dream. Also occasionally as adjective (in predicative use): dreaming, asleep.
--Examples--
--Word--
adrectal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Situated at or near the rectum; especially (formerly) designating the glands of certain gastropod molluscs from which Tyrian purple was obtained (now usually called hypobranchial).
--Examples--
--Word--
adrenal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a pair of ductless glands situated above the kidneys. Each consists of a core region (adrenal medulla) secreting adrenaline and noradrenaline, and an outer region (adrenal cortex) secreting corticosteroids.
An adrenal gland.
--Examples--
‘adrenal function was normal in this group of patients’
--Word--
adrenalectomy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Surgical excision of one or both adrenal glands; an instance of this. In later use also: suppression or abolition of the synthesis of adrenal hormone by means of drugs.
--Examples--
--Word--
adrenalectomy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Surgical excision of one or both adrenal glands; an instance of this. In later use also: suppression or abolition of the synthesis of adrenal hormone by means of drugs.

--Word--
adrenaline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hormone secreted by the adrenal glands that increases rates of blood circulation, breathing, and carbohydrate metabolism and prepares muscles for exertion.
--Examples--
‘performing live really gets your adrenaline going’
--Word--
adrenaline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hormone secreted by the adrenal glands that increases rates of blood circulation, breathing, and carbohydrate metabolism and prepares muscles for exertion.
--Examples--
‘performing live really gets your adrenaline going’
--Word--
adrenalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Chiefly Surgery. To treat with adrenaline. Now rare.
To produce adrenaline; to become stressed, excited, or energized.
To rouse into activity; to stir up, excite, energize.
--Examples--

--Word--
adrenal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a pair of ductless glands situated above the kidneys. Each consists of a core region (adrenal medulla) secreting adrenaline and noradrenaline, and an outer region (adrenal cortex) secreting corticosteroids.
An adrenal gland.
--Examples--
‘adrenal function was normal in this group of patients’
--Word--
adrenergic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting nerve cells in which adrenaline, noradrenaline, or a similar substance acts as a neurotransmitter.

--Word--
adrenochrome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sulphur-containing extract of the adrenal glands of animals, used medicinally (disused).
A red pigment formed by the oxidation of adrenaline.

adrenocorticotrophic hormone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hormone secreted by the pituitary gland and stimulating the adrenal cortex.

--Word--
adrenocorticotrophin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
adrenocorticotropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Acting to stimulate the adrenal cortex; especially in adrenocorticotropic hormone.
--Examples--
--Word--
adrenolytic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Destructive of the adrenal gland or its function; suppressing adrenal function, especially hormone synthesis by the cortex.
Blocking or inhibiting the effect of adrenergic nerves or neurotransmitters.
An adrenolytic substance or agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
adrenomedullary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the adrenal medulla.
--Examples--
--Word--
adrenotropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Acting (specifically) upon the adrenal gland; specifically = adrenocorticotropic.
Adrenergic (now historical).

--Word--
adrift 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a boat or its passengers) floating without being either moored or steered.
Without purpose, direction, or guidance.
No longer fixed in position.
Failing to reach a target or winning position.
--Examples--
‘a cargo ship went adrift’
‘the seamen are adrift in lifeboats’
‘she found herself cast adrift in a land full of strangers’
‘the film industry was adrift in a sea of debt’
‘one of my fillings has come adrift’
‘the team are three points adrift of the leaders’

--Word--
adscript 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Geometry. A circumscribed or inscribed line, especially a tangent of a curve. Now rare and historical.
An adscript feudal serf.
A comment or note added to a manuscript, especially one which in error becomes incorporated into the text.
Of a feudal serf: hereditarily attached to an estate, and transferred with it.
Written after; opposed to subscript. Chiefly in "iota adscript".
--Examples--
--Word--
adscripted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is or resembles an adscript.
--Examples--
--Word--
adscription 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attachment as an adscript serf.
--Examples--
--Word--
adscript 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Geometry. A circumscribed or inscribed line, especially a tangent of a curve. Now rare and historical.
An adscript feudal serf.
A comment or note added to a manuscript, especially one which in error becomes incorporated into the text.
Of a feudal serf: hereditarily attached to an estate, and transferred with it.
Written after; opposed to subscript. Chiefly in "iota adscript".
--Examples--

adsignify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To signify or indicate in addition, especially through the use of grammar (as by declension, case, tense, etc.). Compare earlier adsignification.
--Examples--
--Word--
adsignification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Additional or further signification added to the basic sense of a word or phrase, typically through grammatical elements indicating tense, gender, etc.

--Word--
adstipulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Agreement, (formal) assent; approval, support.
Roman Law. Acting as a second stipulator in a contract or bargain; the system or process by which this is done.
--Examples--
--Word--
adstipulator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Roman Law. A person who acts as a second stipulator in a contract or bargain.

adsum 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
‘I am here’ (used to indicate the speaker is present). Hence as noun: this statement as an answer in a roll-call, etc.

--Word--
adularia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A potassium feldspar that occurs in schists (notably in the Swiss Alps), often with a distinctive opalescence, and is now regarded as a variety of orthoclase.
--Examples--

--Word--
Adullamite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a dissident political group (originally applied to a group of British MPs who seceded from the Liberal party in 1866).
--Examples--
--Word--
adult 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A person who is fully grown or developed.
A fully developed animal.
A person who has reached the age of majority.
Fully grown or developed.
Of or for adult people.
Emotionally and mentally mature.
Suitable only for adults (used euphemistically to refer to a sexually explicit film, book, or magazine).
Behave in a way characteristic of a responsible adult, especially by accomplishing mundane but necessary tasks.
--Examples--
‘children should be accompanied by an adult’
‘an adult woman’
‘adult education’
‘an effort to be adult and civilized’
‘I've adulted with moderate success this week by compiling invoices and billing my client’
‘I am 24 and still trying to figure out how to adult’
--Word--
adulter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An adulterer, especially a male one.
To commit or practise adultery.
To corrupt, debase, dilute the purity of (literally or figuratively).

adumbral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shadowy, shady.
--Examples--
--Word--
adumbrant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Casting shadows; shadowy, shady. In extended use: represented in outline; vague, indistinct.
--Examples--
--Word--
adumbrate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Represent in outline.
Indicate faintly.
Foreshadow (a future event)
Overshadow.
--Examples--
‘Hobhouse had already adumbrated the idea of a welfare state’
‘the walls were only adumbrated by the meagre light’
‘tenors solemnly adumbrate the fate of the convicted sinner’
‘her happy reminiscences were adumbrated by consciousness of something else’

--Word--
Advaita 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Vedantic doctrine that identifies the individual self (atman) with the ground of reality (brahman). It is associated especially with the Indian philosopher Shankara (c.788–820).
--Examples--
--Word--
advance 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Move forwards in a purposeful way.
Move forward in time.
Change the date of (an event) so as to occur earlier than planned.
Make or cause to make progress.
(of shares) increase in price.
Put forward (a theory or suggestion)
Lend (money) to (someone)
Pay (money) to (someone) before it is due.
A forward movement.
A development or improvement.
An increase in amount or price.
An amount of money paid before it is due or for work only partly completed.
A loan.
An approach made to someone with the aim of initiating sexual or amorous relations.
Done, sent, or supplied beforehand.
--Examples--
‘he advanced towards the dispatch box’
‘the troops advanced on the capital’
‘as the nineteenth century advanced’
‘I advanced the schedule by several weeks’
‘our knowledge is advancing all the time’
‘it was a chance to advance his own interests’
‘the food group advanced 12p to 639p’
‘the hypothesis I wish to advance in this article’
‘the building society advanced them a loan’
‘he advanced me a month's salary’
‘the rebels' advance on Madrid was well under way’
‘the advance of civilization’
‘advances in engineering techniques’
‘decades of great scientific advance’
‘share prices showed significant advances’
‘the author was paid a £250,000 advance’
‘an advance from the bank’
‘her tutor made advances to her’
‘advance notice’
‘advance warning’
‘advance payment’
--Word--
advanceable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being advanced.
--Examples--
--Word--
advanced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Far on or ahead in development or progress.
New and not yet generally accepted.
--Examples--
‘negotiations are at an advanced stage’
‘his advanced views made him unpopular’

--Word--
advantage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A condition or circumstance that puts one in a favourable or superior position.
The opportunity to gain something; benefit or profit.
A favourable or desirable feature.
A score marking a point interim between deuce and winning the game.
Put in a favourable or superior position.
--Examples--
‘companies with a computerized database are at an advantage’
‘she had an advantage over her mother's generation’
‘you could learn something to your advantage’
‘he saw some advantage in the proposal’
‘the village's proximity to the town is an advantage’
‘‘Advantage, Federer.’’
--Word--
advantaged

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘children from less advantaged homes’

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
advent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The arrival of a notable person or thing.
The first season of the Church year, leading up to Christmas and including the four preceding Sundays.
The coming or second coming of Christ.
--Examples--
‘the advent of television’
--Word--
adventive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
That comes from outside or from some external source; extrinsically added; extraneous; foreign.
Ecology. Originally: (of a plant) occurring in a region in which it is not native, but imperfectly naturalized, e.g. restricted to cultivated land, areas around human habitation, etc. In later use also: (of a plant or animal) occurring in but not native to the region in which it appears.
Botany. Designating an embryo which develops asexually from a somatic cell of the ovule (e.g. the nucellus) as a result of a form of apomixis which occurs in certain plants.
Ecology. An adventive plant or animal.
--Examples--
--Word--
Adventism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Adventist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of any of various Christian sects emphasizing belief in the imminent second coming of Christ.

--Word--
adventitious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Happening as a result of an external factor or chance rather than design or inherent nature.
Coming from outside; not native.
Formed accidentally or in an unusual anatomical position.
(of a root, shoot, etc.) produced in an unusual part of a plant.
--Examples--
‘adventitious similarities’
‘the adventitious population’
‘adventitious lobes may appear between the primaries’

--Meanings--
That comes from outside or from some external source; extrinsically added; extraneous; foreign.
Ecology. Originally: (of a plant) occurring in a region in which it is not native, but imperfectly naturalized, e.g. restricted to cultivated land, areas around human habitation, etc. In later use also: (of a plant or animal) occurring in but not native to the region in which it appears.
Botany. Designating an embryo which develops asexually from a somatic cell of the ovule (e.g. the nucellus) as a result of a form of apomixis which occurs in certain plants.
Ecology. An adventive plant or animal.
--Examples--
--Word--
adventive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
That comes from outside or from some external source; extrinsically added; extraneous; foreign.
Ecology. Originally: (of a plant) occurring in a region in which it is not native, but imperfectly naturalized, e.g. restricted to cultivated land, areas around human habitation, etc. In later use also: (of a plant or animal) occurring in but not native to the region in which it appears.
Botany. Designating an embryo which develops asexually from a somatic cell of the ovule (e.g. the nucellus) as a result of a form of apomixis which occurs in certain plants.
Ecology. An adventive plant or animal.
--Examples--
--Word--
advent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The arrival of a notable person or thing.
The first season of the Church year, leading up to Christmas and including the four preceding Sundays.
The coming or second coming of Christ.
--Examples--
‘the advent of television’
--Word--
adventual 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the season of Advent, or to Christ's advent on earth; (in later use also) of or relating to belief in the Second Coming of Christ.
--Examples--
--Word--
adventure 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An unusual and exciting or daring experience.
Excitement associated with danger or the taking of risks.
A reckless or potentially hazardous action or enterprise.
A commercial venture.
Engage in daring or risky activity.
Put (one's money or life) at risk.
--Examples--
‘her recent adventures in Italy’
‘she travelled the world in search of adventure’
‘in any military adventure, the first casualty is truth’
‘I sold my East India adventure of £250 principal for £750’
‘they had adventured into the forest’
‘he adventured £300 in the purchase of land’

--Word--
adventurer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who enjoys or seeks adventure.

A financial speculator.
A mercenary soldier.
--Examples--
‘every year adventurers attempt the Canol Trail using all manner of conveyances’
‘a political adventurer’

advertisable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
advertise 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Describe or draw attention to (a product, service, or event) in a public medium in order to promote sales or attendance.
Publicize information about (a vacancy)
Make (a quality or fact) known.
Notify (someone) of something.
--Examples--
‘a billboard advertising beer’
‘for every job we advertise we get a hundred applicants’
‘he advertised for dancers in the trade papers’
‘Meryl coughed briefly to advertise her presence’
‘some prisoners advertised the French of this terrible danger’

--Word--
advice 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Guidance or recommendations offered with regard to prudent future action.
A formal notice of a financial transaction.
Information; news.
--Examples--
‘my advice is to see your doctor’
‘on their solicitors' advice, the trustees have accepted £577,000 by way of compensation’
‘he took my advice and put his house up for sale’
‘remittance advices’
‘the want of fresh advices from Europe’

--Word--
advise 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Offer suggestions about the best course of action to someone.
Recommend.
Inform (someone) about a fact or situation in a formal or official way.
--Examples--
‘I advised him to go home’
‘he advised caution’
‘we advise against sending cash by post’
‘sleeping pills are not advised’
‘you will be advised of the requirements’
‘the lawyer advised the court that his client wished to give evidence’

--Word--
advisory 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having or consisting in the power to make recommendations but not to take action enforcing them.
Recommended but not compulsory.
An official announcement or warning.
--Examples--
‘the Commission acts in an advisory capacity’
‘the EC has put forward an advisory maximum figure’
‘a frost advisory’

--Word--
advocacy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
advocate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy.
A person who puts a case on someone else's behalf.
A professional pleader in a court of justice.
A barrister.
Publicly recommend or support.
--Examples--
‘he was an untiring advocate of economic reform’
‘care managers can become advocates for their clients’
‘solicitors may act as advocates in Crown Courts’
‘voters supported candidates who advocated an Assembly’

advocatess 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female advocate. In early use specifically (Christian Church): the Virgin Mary.
--Examples--
--Word--
advocate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy.
A person who puts a case on someone else's behalf.
A professional pleader in a court of justice.
A barrister.
Publicly recommend or support.
--Examples--
‘he was an untiring advocate of economic reform’
‘care managers can become advocates for their clients’
‘solicitors may act as advocates in Crown Courts’
‘voters supported candidates who advocated an Assembly’
--Word--
advocation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
advocator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
advocator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
advocatory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an advocate; of the nature of or characterized by advocacy.
--Examples--
--Word--
advocatrix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female advocate; specifically (Christian Church) the Virgin Mary.
--Examples--
--Word--
advoke 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Law. To summon (a legal action) from a lower court to a higher court, especially the papal Court of Rome. Compare "advocate", "advocation". Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
advolution 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of developing in a specific direction or towards a particular end; an instance of this. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
advowee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A guardian, protector, or patron of a church or religious house; (Ecclesiastical Law) one holding the right to present a member of the clergy to a particular benefice or living. Compare "advowson". Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
advowry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) Ecclesiastical Law. = "advowson"; the office or function of an advowee. (b) = "avowry"; (also) a person responsible for providing this protection (or perhaps: the payments made to ensure this).
--Examples--
--Word--
advowson 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in ecclesiastical law) the right to recommend a member of the Anglican clergy for a vacant benefice, or to make such an appointment.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--
(in ecclesiastical law) the right to recommend a member of the Anglican clergy for a vacant benefice, or to make such an appointment.

noun
--Meanings--
(as written abbreviation) an advertisement.
--Examples--

--Word--
adze 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tool similar to an axe, with an arched blade at right angles to the handle, used for cutting or shaping large pieces of wood.
Cut away the surface of (a piece of wood) with an adze.
--Examples--
‘by the time it has been adzed out, you will only have a small edge to clean up’

Æ 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A letter used in Old English to represent a vowel intermediate between a and e and from the 16th century onwards used in Latin or Latinized Greek words, representing an original diphthong ae or ai.
--Examples--
