aecial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an aecium; characterized by the presence of aecia; productive of aeciospores.
--Examples--
--Word--
aecidial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an aecidium; characterized by the presence of aecidia; productive of aecidiospores.
--Examples--
--Word--
aecidiospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spore formed in an aecidium; an aeciospore.
--Examples--
--Word--
aecidium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any fungus of the former genus of pathogenic fungi, Aecidium, now known to represent the aecial stage (anamorph) of rusts of the genus Puccinia and other members of the order Uredinales. Also (in form Aecidium): the genus itself. Now rare.
Originally: an aecium. In later use: specifically one which is cup-shaped and which is enclosed within a protective membrane.
--Examples--
--Word--
aeciospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dikaryotic spore of a rust fungus, which is produced in an aecium and in a heteroecious species infects the primary host.
--Examples--
--Word--
aecium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fruiting body produced on the mycelium of a rust fungus at a particular stage in its life cycle (especially, in heteroecious species, that occurring on an alternate host), within which aeciospores are produced.
--Examples--
--Word--
aedeagus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In insects: the male copulatory or sperm-depositing organ; an insect phallus or (typically) part of it, especially the distal portion.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aedes 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large and widespread genus of small mosquitoes (family Culicidae) including several vectors of human disease, notably Aedes aegypti, the principal carrier of yellow fever. Also (in form aedes): a mosquito of this genus (more fully "aedes mosquito").
--Examples--
--Word--
aedicula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally in Roman architecture: a niche (for a statue), especially one framed by two columns supporting a pediment or an entablature; such a structure forming a shrine.
--Examples--
--Word--
aedicule 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= aedicula; specifically the structure covering the Holy Sepulchre. Also: a representation of a structural feature (usually in miniature) for ornamental purposes.
--Examples--
--Word--
aedile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two (later four) Roman magistrates responsible for public buildings and originally also for the public games and the supply of corn to the city.

aefauld 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of only one part, element, or unit; single; = "onefold". Now rare (Scottish and Irish English (northern) after Middle English).
Free from duplicity; sincere, honest, faithful; plain, straightforward. Scottish after Middle English.

aegilops 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. An abscess or ulcer of the inner canthus of the eye, especially when involving a lacrimal duct or the lacrimal sac.
Any grass of the southern European genus Aegilops, considered to be the wild ancestor of modern varieties of domestic wheat. Also (in form Aegilops): the genus itself.
--Examples--

Aegipan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A goat-like creature similar to a satyr. Also: (the name of) a Greek god resembling, and sometimes considered to be identical to, the god Pan.

aegirine

noun
--Meanings--

aegis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.
(in classical art and mythology) an attribute of Zeus and Athene (or their Roman counterparts Jupiter and Minerva) usually represented as a goatskin shield.
--Examples--
‘the negotiations were conducted under the aegis of the UN’

aegithognathism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition of being aegithognathous.
--Examples--
--Word--
aegithognathous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a conformation of the bones of the palate typical of passerine birds, with the maxillopalatines separate and the vomer broad and truncated at the front; exhibiting such a palatal structure, which is found also in woodpeckers and swifts (formerly grouped with passerines in a division called Aegithognathae).
--Examples--
--Word--
aegophony 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In auscultation of the chest: vocal resonance with a bleating or tremulous quality, occurring especially in cases of pleural effusion.
--Examples--
--Word--
aegrotat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A certificate stating that a university student is too ill to attend an examination.
An examination pass awarded to a student having an aegrotat.
--Examples--
--Word--
aeluroid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating the division or superfamily Aeluroidea of the mammalian order Carnivora, comprising the cat family Felidae and allied families; characteristic of this division or superfamily. Compare "Arctoid".
A mammal of the division or superfamily Aeluroidea.
--Examples--
--Word--
-aemia 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
In nouns denoting that a substance is present in the blood.
--Examples--
‘septicaemia’
‘leukaemia’
--Word--
Aeneas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Trojan leader, son of Anchises and Aphrodite, and legendary ancestor of the Romans. When Troy fell to the Greeks he escaped and after wandering for many years eventually reached Italy. The story of his voyage is recounted in Virgil's Aeneid.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aeneas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Trojan leader, son of Anchises and Aphrodite, and legendary ancestor of the Romans. When Troy fell to the Greeks he escaped and after wandering for many years eventually reached Italy. The story of his voyage is recounted in Virgil's Aeneid.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aeneid 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Latin epic poem in twelve books by Virgil which relates the travels and experiences of Aeneas after the fall of Troy.
--Examples--

aeneous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling brass in colour or lustre; brassy.

aenigmatite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A titanium-containing mineral occurring as long prismatic crystals of a black or dark brown colour, typically as a constituent of pegmatites.

--Word--
Aeolic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Aeolia or to the Aeolians or their language; Aeolian.
Geomorphology. Usually with lower-case initial. = "Aeolian".
Any of a group of ancient Greek dialects, including those of Aeolia, Lesbos, Thessaly, and Boeotia.
--Examples--

aeon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An indefinite and very long period of time.
A unit of time equal to a thousand million years.
A major division of geological time, subdivided into eras.
(in Neoplatonism, Platonism, and Gnosticism) a power existing from eternity; an emanation or phase of the supreme deity.
--Examples--
‘he reached the crag aeons before I arrived’
‘the Precambrian aeon’

aery 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to the air; aerial; (hence) ethereal, spiritual, incorporeal, insubstantial.
--Examples--
--Word--
aerial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Existing, happening, or operating in the air.
Coming or carried out from the air, especially using aircraft.
(of a part of a plant) growing above ground.
(of a bird) spending much of its time in flight.
Of or in the atmosphere; atmospheric.
A rod, wire, or other structure by which signals are transmitted or received as part of a radio or television transmission or receiving system.
A type of freestyle skiing in which the skier jumps from a ramp and carries out manoeuvres in the air.
--Examples--
‘an aerial battle’
‘an intrepid aerial adventurer’
‘aerial bombardment of civilian targets’
‘aerial photography’
‘a huge banyan tree whose aerial roots hung back down to the ground’
‘the more aerial and terrestrial birds are less dependent on a strictly aquatic habitat’
--Word--
aerialist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who performs acrobatics high above the ground on a tightrope or trapezes.
--Examples--
--Word--
aerialist

noun

aeroballistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to aeroballistics; designating or characteristic of missiles or other objects whose trajectory in the atmosphere can be described in terms of combination of ballistics and aerodynamics.
--Examples--

aeroballistics 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The combined sciences of aerodynamics and ballistics, especially as applied to the flight path of projectiles.

--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Loops, rolls, and other feats of spectacular flying performed in one or more aircraft to entertain an audience on the ground.

aerodynamics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The study of the properties of moving air and the interaction between the air and solid bodies moving through it.
The properties of a solid object regarding the manner in which air flows around it.
--Examples--
‘the plane has the aerodynamics of a brick once the forward thrust is lost’

aerometric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a method for measuring the density or relative density of a liquid, especially milk and beer, by means of a set of small hollow spheres or ‘beads’.
Of or relating to the measurement of the mechanical properties of air and other gases; (in later use chiefly) of or relating to the measurement of air pollutants.

--Word--
aerophile 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
= aerophilic.
An aerobe; specifically one that exhibits optimal growth at an oxygen concentration equal to or greater than that of the air (approximately 20%).
--Examples--
--Word--
aerophilic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to aerobic microorganisms, specifically those exhibiting optimal growth at an oxygen concentration equal to or greater than that of the air (approximately 20%). In later use also: = aerophilous.
--Examples--
--Word--
aerophilous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Microbiology. Aerobic; aerophilic. rare.
Ecology. Especially of diatoms and other algae: tolerating or requiring an environment that is exposed to air; living on land (as opposed to in water); subaerial.

aerophobia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Dread of or abnormal sensitivity to (the movement of) air, specifically as a symptom of rabies.
Dislike of fresh air; irrational fear of draughts. Now rare.
The fear of air travel.

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Exhibiting aerophobia; sensitive to (the movement of) air. rare.
Averse to or suspicious of fresh air.
Afraid of air travel.
A person who is afraid of air travel.

aerophore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. In certain ferns: a specialized structure with numerous stomata for aeration, usually seen as a band of pale tissue on the stem or a small outgrowth at the base of a frond.
Any of several forms of respirator, especially one with a portable supply of air for use by divers and miners. Now historical.

Æ 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
Aeschylean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Aeschylus, the Athenian tragic poet, or his works, style, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aeschylus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.525–c.456 BC), Greek playwright. Aeschylus is best known for his trilogy the Oresteia (458 BC, consisting of the tragedies Agamemnon, Choephoroe, and Eumenides), which tells the story of Agamemnon's murder at the hands of his wife Clytemnestra and the vengeance of their son Orestes.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aeschines 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.390–c.314 BC), Athenian orator and statesman. He opposed Demosthenes' efforts to unite the Greek city states against Macedon, with which he attempted to make peace.
--Examples--
--Word--
aeschynite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark brown rock-forming mineral containing cerium, titanium, and niobium; now also more fully "aeschynite-(Ce)". Also: either of two related minerals, in which cerium and calcium are replaced either by yttrium, erbium, and calcium (more fully "aeschynite-(Y)"), or else by neodymium and cerium (more fully "aeschynite-(Nd)").
--Examples--
--Word--

adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to medicine or physicians.

aesculetin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
aesculin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline compound present in the bark and other parts of some trees (notably the horse chestnut, Aesculus hippocastanum), and used in tests to identify certain bacteria by means of its fluorescence.

proper noun
--Meanings--
(6th century BC), Greek storyteller. The moral animal fables associated with him were probably collected from many sources, and initially communicated orally. Aesop is said to have lived as a slave on the island of Samos.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aesopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Aesop, a semi-legendary Greek fabulist of the 6th cent. b.c.
In relation to Russian and (Soviet) Communist literature: using a style or language that has hidden or ambiguous meaning, especially as a device to disguise dissident political writing in allegorical form and so avoid official censorship.
--Examples--
--Word--
aesthesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Sensory capacity or ability of an organism, organ, etc.; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
aesthesics 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of the perception of something, especially music.
--Examples--

aesthesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The perception of the external world by the senses.
--Examples--
--Word--
aesthete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is appreciative of and sensitive to art and beauty.
--Examples--
--Word--
aesthete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is appreciative of and sensitive to art and beauty.
--Examples--
--Word--
aesthetic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
Giving or designed to give pleasure through beauty.
A set of principles underlying the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
--Examples--
‘the pictures give great aesthetic pleasure’
‘the law applies to both functional and aesthetic objects’
‘the Cubist aesthetic’
--Word--
aesthetical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to aesthetics; relating to the philosophy or theory of beauty.
--Examples--
--Word--
aesthetically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that gives pleasure through beauty.
With regard to beauty.
--Examples--
‘the buildings and gardens of the factory have been aesthetically designed and laid out’
‘an aesthetically pleasing landscape’
‘his naive use of rhyme makes his poetry sound aesthetically amateurish’
--Word--
aesthetician 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is knowledgeable about aesthetics.
A beautician.
--Examples--
--Word--
aestheticism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An approach to art exemplified by the Aesthetic Movement.
--Examples--
--Word--
aestheticist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An adherent or practitioner of aestheticism; an aesthetician.
Of, relating to, or characterized by aestheticism.
--Examples--
--Word--
aestheticize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Represent as beautiful or artistically pleasing.
--Examples--
‘the director relentlessly aestheticizes the world of his fathers’
--Word--
aesthetics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A set of principles concerned with the nature and appreciation of beauty.
The branch of philosophy which deals with questions of beauty and artistic taste.

--Word--
ether 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pleasant-smelling colourless volatile liquid that is highly flammable. It is used as an anaesthetic and as a solvent or intermediate in industrial processes.
Any organic compound with a similar structure to ether, having an oxygen atom linking two alkyl or other organic groups.
The clear sky; the upper regions of air beyond the clouds.
Air regarded as a medium for radio.
A very rarefied and highly elastic substance formerly believed to permeate all space, including the interstices between the particles of matter, and to be the medium whose vibrations constituted light and other electromagnetic radiation.
--Examples--
‘methyl t-butyl ether’
‘nasty gases and smoke disperse into the ether’
‘choral evensong still wafts across the ether’
‘the motion of the planets would be retarded by the ether through which they moved’
--Word--
aethionema 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the genus Aethionema (family Brassicaceae (Cruciferae)), which comprises mostly low-growing plants with showy racemes of pink, lilac, yellow, or white flowers, native to the Mediterranean but cultivated elsewhere as garden plants; also called stone cress. Also (in form Aethionema): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
aetiology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The cause, set of causes, or manner of causation of a disease or condition.
The causation of diseases and disorders as a subject of investigation.
The investigation or attribution of the cause or reason for something, often expressed in terms of historical or mythical explanation.
--Examples--
‘the importance of sunlight in the aetiology of melanoma’
‘a group of distinct diseases with different aetiologies’
--Word--
aetiological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
aetiologically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
aetites 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hollow nodule or pebble of hydrated iron oxide containing a loose kernel that makes a noise when rattled, formerly regarded as having medicinal and magical properties; the eagle stone; = "achate", "perdicle".
--Examples--
--Word--
Aetolian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of ancient Aetolia, a region of west-central Greece north of the Gulf of Corinth.
Of or relating to ancient Aetolia or its inhabitants.
--Examples--
--Word--
aetosaur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any reptile of the extinct order (or suborder) Aetosauria, known from fossil remains of the Triassic period, and comprising herbivorous diapsids that resembled heavily armoured crocodiles.
--Examples--

afar

adverb, noun, adjective

--Word--
affair 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An event or sequence of events of a specified kind or that has previously been referred to.
A matter that is a particular person's concern or responsibility.
Matters of public interest and importance.
Business and financial dealings.
A love affair.
An object of a particular type.
--Examples--
‘the board admitted responsibility for the affair’
‘I wanted the funeral to be a family affair’
‘what you do in your spare time is your affair’
‘commissions were created to advise on foreign affairs’
‘his time was spent in winding up his affairs’
‘his wife is having an affair’
‘her dress was a black low-cut affair’

--Word--
affect 
--Type--
verb, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Have an effect on; make a difference to.
Touch the feelings of; move emotionally.
Pretend to have or feel (something)
Use, wear, or assume (something) pretentiously or so as to make an impression on others.
Emotion or desire as influencing behaviour.
--Examples--
‘the dampness began to affect my health’
‘your attitude will affect how successful you are’
‘he was visibly affected by the tragedy’
‘as usual I affected a supreme unconcern’
‘a book that affects to loathe the modern world’
‘an Anglophile who had affected a British accent’
--Word--
affectability

noun
--Meanings--
The capacity to be affected or influenced; especially susceptibility to physical or emotional stimuli.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

noun

‘an affectation of calm’

affeer 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To determine, decide, assess; (Law) to fix or settle the amount of (a fine or amercement), typically by adjusting a generally prescribed penalty according to the particular circumstances of an offender and his or her offence; to settle the amount to be paid by (a person); to perform this task for (a certain community or region).
--Examples--

affeerer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= affeeror.

--Word--
affeerment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fixing or settling of a fine or amercement, typically by adjusting a generally prescribed penalty according to the particular circumstances of an offender and his or her offence; assessment, especially of the fairness and suitability of fines and amercements.
--Examples--
--Word--
affeeror 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person appointed to determine the values of fines and amercements, typically charged with adjusting a generally prescribed penalty according to the particular circumstances of an offender and his or her offence.

--Examples--
--Word--
affettuoso 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Music. Of a piece or style of music: performed with emotion or tenderness, usually at a fairly slow tempo; affecting, moving, tender; (as an indication of the tempo of a piece) fairly slow.
In extended use: characterized by the qualities associated with affettuoso music, such as emotion, tenderness, etc.
Music. An affettuoso style; an affettuoso movement, part, or piece.
--Examples--
--Word--
affettuoso 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Music. Of a piece or style of music: performed with emotion or tenderness, usually at a fairly slow tempo; affecting, moving, tender; (as an indication of the tempo of a piece) fairly slow.
In extended use: characterized by the qualities associated with affettuoso music, such as emotion, tenderness, etc.
Music. An affettuoso style; an affettuoso movement, part, or piece.

affiche 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A notice or sign for public display, typically intended to be affixed to a wall; a placard, a poster. Frequently in French contexts.
To fix, fasten; to affix; (in modern use) specifically to fix (a poster or placard) to a wall. rare after 15th cent.
To parade, flaunt; to make known, give notice of; to advertise, publicize; to display, show.
--Examples--
--Word--

Capable of being affiliated, linked, or connected.
--Examples--
--Word--
affiliate 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Officially attach or connect (a subsidiary group or a person) to an organization.
(of an organization) admit as a member.
Officially join or become attached to an organization.
A person or organization officially attached to a larger body.
--Examples--
‘they are national associations affiliated to larger organizations’
‘the main party agreed to affiliate four Conservative associations’
‘almost all students affiliate to the Students' Union’
‘the firm established links with American affiliates’
--Word--
affiliated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a subsidiary group or a person) officially attached or connected to an organization.
--Examples--
‘affiliated union members’
‘Microsoft and its affiliated companies’
--Word--
affiliate 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Officially attach or connect (a subsidiary group or a person) to an organization.
(of an organization) admit as a member.
Officially join or become attached to an organization.

--Examples--
‘they are national associations affiliated to larger organizations’

‘the firm established links with American affiliates’

--Word--
affiliation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or process of affiliating or being affiliated.
--Examples--
‘the group has no affiliation to any preservation society’
‘his political affiliations’

--Word--
affinage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cheese-making. The process of maturing cheese, usually in a cellar or climate-controlled room.
--Examples--
--Word--
affinal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Concerning or having a family relationship by marriage.
--Examples--
--Word--
affination 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Metallurgy. The process of refining (precious) metal, especially by treatment with hot concentrated sulphuric acid.
The initial process in the refining of sugar whereby raw sugar crystals are treated with a warm syrup to remove the thin layer of molasses.
--Examples--

affine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Allowing for or preserving parallel relationships.
A relative by marriage.

--Meanings--

affly

--Meanings--

--Word--
affinitative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by affinity; of the nature of affinity. In later use: of or relating to affinity.
--Examples--
--Word--
affinitative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by affinity; of the nature of affinity. In later use: of or relating to affinity.
--Examples--
--Word--
affinity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A natural liking for and understanding of someone or something.
A similarity of characteristics suggesting a relationship, especially a resemblance in structure between animals, plants, or languages.
Relationship, especially by marriage as opposed to blood ties.
The degree to which a substance tends to combine with another.
--Examples--
‘he had a special affinity with horses’
‘a semantic affinity between two words’
‘the distinction between kinship and affinity is not always clear-cut’
‘the bacterial proteins bind to these molecules with high affinity’
--Word--
affinity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A natural liking for and understanding of someone or something.
A similarity of characteristics suggesting a relationship, especially a resemblance in structure between animals, plants, or languages.
Relationship, especially by marriage as opposed to blood ties.
The degree to which a substance tends to combine with another.
--Examples--
‘he had a special affinity with horses’
‘a semantic affinity between two words’
‘the distinction between kinship and affinity is not always clear-cut’
‘the bacterial proteins bind to these molecules with high affinity’
--Word--
affinition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact of having affinity with something; the formation or recognition of affinity with a person or thing; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
affinity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A natural liking for and understanding of someone or something.

--Word--
affinitive 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An affinity, relationship, or connection.
Characterized by affinity or mutual attraction.
Closely connected or related.
--Examples--
--Word--
affirm 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
State emphatically or publicly.
Declare one's support for; uphold; defend.
Accept or confirm the validity of (a judgement or agreement); ratify.
Make a formal declaration rather than taking an oath.
Offer (someone) emotional support or encouragement.
Give (life) a heightened sense of value, typically through the experience of something emotionally or spiritually uplifting.
--Examples--
‘he affirmed the country's commitment to peace’
‘they affirmed that policies were to be judged by their contribution to social justice’
‘the referendum affirmed the republic's right to secede’
‘the Court of Appeal affirmed a decision of the High Court’
‘he refused to take the oath but chose simply to affirm on being admitted to the Privy Council’
‘there are five common ways parents fail to affirm their children’
‘good teachers know that students need to be both affirmed and challenged’
‘it is a rich and challenging motion picture that both affirms life and emphasizes its fragility’
--Word--
affirmable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being affirmed or asserted.
--Examples--
--Word--
affirmably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Positively; affirmatively. rare.
In a way capable of being affirmed; demonstrably.
--Examples--
--Word--
affirmance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Confirmation, corroboration; an instance of this. Frequently in "in affirmance" (of something).
Law. Ratification or confirmation of a law, etc.; the upholding of a legal decision; specifically an appellate court's confirmation of the judgment or order of a lower court. Chiefly with of.
--Examples--
--Word--
affirmant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who affirms (something); a person who makes a statement or declaration.
Chiefly Law and Logic. That affirms something. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
affirmation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of affirming something.
A formal declaration by a person who declines to take an oath.
Emotional support or encouragement.
--Examples--
‘he nodded in affirmation’
‘an affirmation of basic human values’
‘the lack of one or both parents' affirmation leaves some children emotionally crippled’

--Word--
affirmative 
--Type--
adjective, noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Agreeing with or consenting to a statement or request.
Stating that a fact is so; making an assertion.
(of a vote) expressing approval or agreement.
Relating to or denoting proposed legislation which must receive a parliamentary vote in its favour before it can come into force.
Offering emotional support.
A statement of agreement with or consent to an assertion or request.
A word used in making assertions or to express consent.
A statement asserting that something is true of the subject of a proposition.
A position of agreement or confirmation.
Expressing agreement with or consent to a statement or request; yes.
--Examples--
‘an affirmative answer’
‘affirmative sentences’
‘regulations under the Bill would be subject to the affirmative procedure’
‘the family is usually a source of encouragement from which affirmative influences come’
‘he accepted her reply as an affirmative’
‘his answer veered towards the affirmative’
--Word--
affirmative action 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the context of the allocation of resources or employment) the practice or policy of favouring individuals belonging to groups known to have been discriminated against previously; positive discrimination.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Meanings--

--Word--
affix 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Stick, attach, or fasten (something) to something else.
Be able to be fixed.
An addition to the base form or stem of a word in order to modify its meaning or create a new word.
--Examples--
‘panels to which he affixes copies of fine old prints’
‘the strings affix to the back of the bridge’

--Meanings--

--Word--
afflict 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a problem or illness) cause pain or trouble to; affect adversely.
(of a celestial body) be in a stressful aspect with (another celestial body or a point on the ecliptic)
--Examples--
‘his younger child was afflicted with a skin disease’
‘serious ills afflict the industry’
‘he comforted the afflicted’
‘Jupiter is afflicted by Mars in opposition’

--Word--
afforcement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly English Law. Reinforcement of a deliberative body; especially (in the Middle Ages) the addition of members to a jury when the original jurors cannot agree a majority verdict.
--Examples--

--Word--
afford 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Have enough money to pay for.
Have (a resource such as money or time) available or to spare.
Be able to do something without risk of adverse consequences.
Provide or supply (an opportunity or facility)
--Examples--
‘the best that I could afford was a first-floor room’
‘we could never have afforded to heat the place’
‘it was taking up more time than he could afford’
‘only aristocrats could afford to stoop to such practices’
‘the rooftop terrace affords beautiful views’
‘they were afforded the luxury of bed and breakfast’
--Word--
affordable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Inexpensive; reasonably priced.
--Examples--
‘affordable homes’

--Word--
afforest 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Convert (land) into forest, especially for commercial exploitation.
Bring (woodland) under the jurisdiction of forest law for the purpose of hunting.
--Examples--
‘a grant paid to farmers who afforest agricultural land’
‘a great part of the county had been afforested by Henry I’

--Meanings--

--Word--
affricate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A phoneme which combines a plosive with an immediately following fricative or spirant sharing the same place of articulation, e.g. ch as in chair and j as in jar.
--Examples--
--Word--
affricated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Phonetics. Of a sound: that has been changed into an affricate. Also of pronunciation: that exhibits affrication.

‘she was affronted by his familiarity’

--Word--
affrontee 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who is or has been affronted; an insulted or offended person.
Originally Heraldry. Of two figures in a design: facing each other. Compare "affronted", "confronté". Now rare.
Heraldry. Of a figure: facing the viewer; showing the full face.

--Meanings--

--Word--
affuse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(Chiefly in pass.). Christian Church. To baptize (a person) by affusion.
--Examples--
--Word--
affusion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or an act of pouring a liquid on to something or someone. Now rare.
The pouring of water on the body or a part of the body for therapeutic purposes; an instance of this. Frequently with distinguishing word specifying the temperature of the water, especially in "cold affusion". Also figurative. Now historical.
Christian Church. The administration of baptism by pouring or sprinkling water over a person's head (opposed to immersion and aspersion); an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Christian Church. The administration of baptism by pouring or sprinkling water over a person's head (opposed to immersion and aspersion); an instance of this.

noun

--Examples--
--Word--
flat 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Having a level surface; without raised areas or indentations.
(of land) without hills.
(of an expanse of water) calm and without waves.
Not sloping.
Having a broad level surface but little height or depth; shallow.
(of shoes) without heels or with very low heels.
Lacking emotion; dull and lifeless.
(of a person) without energy or enthusiasm.
(of trade, prices, etc.) not showing much activity; sluggish.
(of a colour) uniform.
(of a photograph or negative) lacking contrast.
(of a sparkling drink) having lost its effervescence.
(of something kept inflated, especially a tyre) having lost some or all of its air, typically because of a puncture.
(of a battery) having exhausted its charge.
(of a fee, wage, or price) the same in all cases, not varying with changed conditions or in particular cases.
(of a denial, contradiction, or refusal) completely definite and firm; absolute.
(of musical sound) below true or normal pitch.
(of a key) having a flat or flats in the signature.
(of a note) a semitone lower than a specified note.
Relating to flat racing.
In or to a horizontal position.
Lying in close juxtaposition, especially against another surface.
So as to become smooth and even.
Completely; absolutely.
Used with an expression of time to emphasize how quickly something can be done or has been done.
Below the true or normal pitch of musical sound.
The flat part of something.
An area of low level ground, especially near water.
A shallow container in which seedlings are grown and sold.
A shoe with a very low heel or no heel.
A railway wagon with a flat floor and no sides or roof; a flatcar.
An upright section of stage scenery mounted on a movable frame.
A flat tyre.
Flat racing.
A musical note lowered a semitone below natural pitch.
The sign ♭, indicating a flat.
Lower (a note) by a semitone.
Make flat; flatten.
--Examples--
‘he sat down on a flat rock’
‘trim the surface of the cake to make it completely flat’
‘thirty-five acres of flat countryside’
‘the flat roof of a garage’
‘a flat rectangular box’
‘a flat cap’
‘‘I'm sorry,’ he said, in a flat voice’
‘his sense of intoxication wore off until he felt flat and weary’
‘the UK housing market was flat’
‘a flat shade of grey’
‘she sipped some of the flat champagne’
‘a flat fare of £2.50’
‘the request was met with a flat refusal’
‘E flat’
‘the Flat season’
‘he was lying flat on his back’
‘she had been knocked flat by the blast’
‘his black curly hair was blown flat across his skull’
‘I hammered the metal flat’
‘I thought you'd turn me down flat’
‘Myers was flat broke’
‘you can prepare a healthy meal in ten minutes flat’
‘it wasn't a question of singing flat, but of simply singing the wrong notes’
‘she placed the flat of her hand over her glass’
‘the shingle flats of the lake’
‘she wore a white strapless dress and a pair of electric blue flats’
‘I've got a flat—there were nails under the wheel’
‘‘blue’ harmony emphasizing the flatted third and seventh’
‘flat the loaves down’

noun

--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--

--Word--
Africanization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Africanize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make African in character.
(in Africa) restructure (an organization) by replacing white employees with black Africans.
Hybridize (honeybees of European stock) with bees of African stock, producing an aggressive strain.
--Examples--
‘in his attempt to Africanize his novel, he deconstructs the French language’
‘we recognize the need to Africanize the civil service in preparation for independence’
--Word--
Africanized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made African in character.
Denoting an aggressive strain of honeybee, originally produced by crossing honeybees of European stock with bees of African stock.
--Examples--
‘an Africanized form of Cajun music’
‘Africanized bees do not store adequate food supplies for the harsh months’
--Word--
Africanize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make African in character.
(in Africa) restructure (an organization) by replacing white employees with black Africans.
Hybridize (honeybees of European stock) with bees of African stock, producing an aggressive strain.
--Examples--
‘in his attempt to Africanize his novel, he deconstructs the French language’
‘we recognize the need to Africanize the civil service in preparation for independence’
--Word--
Africanoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a division of mankind represented by the indigenous peoples of Africa; of or relating to this group; resembling (and thus supposedly derived from) such peoples.
--Examples--
--Word--
African 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person from Africa, especially a black person.
A person of black African descent.
Relating to Africa or people of African descent.
--Examples--
--Word--
Africanthropus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several extinct fossil hominids of the former genus or subgenus Africanthropus, known from Pleistocene fossil remains found in South and East Africa, and now regarded as various archaic forms of Homo sapiens.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afridi 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Pashto-speaking people inhabiting the mountainous region between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Of or relating to the Afridi.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrika Korps 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A German army force sent to North Africa in 1941 under General Rommel.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikaans 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A language of southern Africa, derived from the form of Dutch brought to the Cape by Protestant settlers in the 17th century. It is an official language of South Africa, spoken by around 6 million people as their first language.
Relating to the Afrikaner people, their way of life, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikander 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An animal of a South African breed of sheep or longhorn cattle.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikanderdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Afrikanerdom.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikanderism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= Afrikanerism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikaner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Afrikaans-speaking white person in South Africa, especially one descended from the Dutch and Huguenot settlers of the 17th century.
A gladiolus native to southern Africa.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikanerdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Afrikanerize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To bring under the influence or rule of Afrikaners; to cause to resemble an Afrikaner.
--Examples--

Afro 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Afro-Asian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the region comprising Africa and Asia.
Of or relating to both Africa and Asia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Afro-Asiatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a family of languages spoken in the Middle East and North Africa. They can be divided into five groups: Semitic, Omotic, Berber, Cushitic, and Chadic. Ancient Egyptian was also a member of this family.
--Examples--

Semitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a family of languages that includes Hebrew, Arabic, and Aramaic and certain ancient languages such as Phoenician and Akkadian, constituting the main subgroup of the Afro-Asiatic family.
Relating to the peoples who speak Semitic languages, especially Hebrew and Arabic.

aft 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
At, near, or towards the stern of a ship or tail of an aircraft.

--Word--
after 
--Type--
preposition
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
In the time following (an event or another period of time)
In phrases indicating something happening continuously or repeatedly.
Past (used in specifying a time)
During the time following the departure or action of.
Behind.
(with reference to looking or speaking) in the direction of someone who is moving further away.
In pursuit or quest of.
Next to and following in order or importance.
In allusion to (someone or something with the same or a related name)
In imitation of.
During the period of time following (an event)
Later.
Nearer the stern of a ship.
--Examples--
‘shortly after their marriage they moved to Colorado’
‘after a while he returned’
‘he'd gone out with his secretary for an after-work drink’
‘day after day we kept studying’
‘I strolled in about ten minutes after two’
‘visitors will be required to clean up after their dogs’
‘I tend to just tidy up after myself rather than doing a full clean all at once’
‘she went out, shutting the door after her’
‘she stared after him’
‘chasing after something you can't have’
‘in their order of priorities health comes after housing’
‘they named her Pauline, after Barbara's mother’
‘a drawing after Millet's The Reapers’
‘bath time ended in a flood after the taps were left running’
‘Duke Frederick died soon after’
‘he was sorry in after years’
‘the after cabin’
--Word--
after 
--Type--
preposition
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
In the time following (an event or another period of time)
In phrases indicating something happening continuously or repeatedly.
Past (used in specifying a time)
During the time following the departure or action of.
Behind.
(with reference to looking or speaking) in the direction of someone who is moving further away.
In pursuit or quest of.
Next to and following in order or importance.
In allusion to (someone or something with the same or a related name)
In imitation of.
During the period of time following (an event)
Later.
Nearer the stern of a ship.
--Examples--
‘shortly after their marriage they moved to Colorado’
‘after a while he returned’
‘he'd gone out with his secretary for an after-work drink’
‘day after day we kept studying’
‘I strolled in about ten minutes after two’
‘visitors will be required to clean up after their dogs’

--Word--
community-acquired 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(Of an infection) acquired in the community or general environment (as opposed to in hospital).
--Examples--
--Word--
afterbeat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. A beat of the heart or of the pulse following a main or normal beat; (in later use) specifically an extrasystole. Now rare.
An ending to a trill comprising two notes, the first being one step lower than the main note, the second being the main note itself.
An offbeat; an accentuated backbeat.
--Examples--
--Word--
afterbirth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The placenta and fetal membranes discharged from the uterus after the birth of offspring.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
after-blow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Especially in the basic Bessemer process: continuation of the blow for a short time after decarburization is complete, in order to dephosphorize the steel.
--Examples--
--Word--
after-born 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Law. Of a child: born after the father's death, or after the execution of the father's will. Also (Roman Law): born after the composition of the father's last will.
Born later; born after another person, especially a sibling; younger.
Now usually in form afterborn. An after-born person or child. Also (treated as plural, usually with the): after-born people or children considered collectively. Now chiefly Law.
--Examples--
--Word--
afterburner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An auxiliary burner in which extra fuel is burned in the exhaust of a jet engine, to increase thrust.
--Examples--
--Word--
afterburner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An auxiliary burner in which extra fuel is burned in the exhaust of a jet engine, to increase thrust.
--Examples--
--Word--
afterburning 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Generally. Burning that takes place after some event.
Burning of timber after it has been felled.
Burning of combustible waste material following some previous process; (Engineering) the spontaneous burning of ejected gases or particulates after they have left an internal-combustion engine or a rocket engine.
In an internal-combustion engine: combustion that takes place in the part of a cycle which occurs immediately after the time of maximum pressure.
The use of an aircraft's afterburner; combustion in the afterburner of an aircraft.
Of a jet engine: fitted with or using an afterburner.
--Examples--
--Word--
aftercare 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Care of a patient after a stay in hospital or of a person on release from prison.
Support or advice offered to a customer following the purchase of a product or service.

Attributive Used in or relating to the process of applying a mordant to an already dyed material; designating this process; (of a dye) subjected to or requiring after-chroming.

after-dinner 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The time after dinner; a period of time after dinner, often devoted to recreation; the remainder of the day after dinner.
Following dinner; taking place after dinner; (of a speech, toast, etc.) given or made after dinner, prior to leaving the table; (of a speaker) that gives such speeches.
Of drink, food, or tobacco: consumed or taken after dinner, especially as a digestive.

afterguard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The sailors stationed on the quarterdeck and poop of a sailing ship, charged with operating the sails and other equipment aft of the mainmast. Now chiefly historical.
The officers on a ship. Now chiefly historical.
Originally US. On a large racing yacht: the crew members responsible for tactics and strategy, usually positioned towards the rear of the boat.

--Word--
afterpiece 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any additional item that follows a main work; (Theatre) an additional entertainment, spoken or sung, usually but not invariably comic, intended to be performed after a play or other theatrical work (now historical).
Nautical. A piece of timber attached to the main-piece of a rudder; the heel of a rudder. Also: the part of a ship's keel nearest to the stern. Now chiefly historical.

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Identify clearly and definitely.
State a fact or requirement clearly and precisely.
Include in an architect's or engineer's specifications.
--Examples--

‘the agency failed to specify that the workers were not their employees’
‘naval architects specified circular portholes’
--Word--
after 
--Type--
preposition
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
In the time following (an event or another period of time)
In phrases indicating something happening continuously or repeatedly.
Past (used in specifying a time)
During the time following the departure or action of.
Behind.
(with reference to looking or speaking) in the direction of someone who is moving further away.
In pursuit or quest of.
Next to and following in order or importance.
In allusion to (someone or something with the same or a related name)
In imitation of.
During the period of time following (an event)
Later.
Nearer the stern of a ship.
--Examples--
‘shortly after their marriage they moved to Colorado’
‘after a while he returned’
‘he'd gone out with his secretary for an after-work drink’
‘day after day we kept studying’
‘I strolled in about ten minutes after two’
‘visitors will be required to clean up after their dogs’
‘I tend to just tidy up after myself rather than doing a full clean all at once’
‘she went out, shutting the door after her’
‘she stared after him’
‘chasing after something you can't have’
‘in their order of priorities health comes after housing’
‘they named her Pauline, after Barbara's mother’
‘a drawing after Millet's The Reapers’
‘bath time ended in a flood after the taps were left running’
‘Duke Frederick died soon after’
‘he was sorry in after years’
‘the after cabin’

again 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Another time; once more.
Returning to a previous position or condition.
In addition to what has already been mentioned.
Used to introduce a further point for consideration, supporting or contrasting with what has just been said.
Used to ask someone to repeat something.
--Examples--
‘it was great to meet old friends again’
‘he rose, tidied the bed, and sat down again’
‘the wages were low but they made half as much again in tips’
‘I never saw any signs, but then again, maybe I wasn't looking’
‘what was your name again?’

--Word--
against 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
In opposition to.
In opposition to, with reference to legal action.
In opposition to, with reference to a sporting contest.
In anticipation of and preparation for (a problem or difficulty)
In resistance to; as protection from.
In relation to (an amount of money owed, due, or lent) so as to reduce, cancel, or secure it.
(in betting) in anticipation of the failure of.
In or into physical contact with (something), so as to be supported by or collide with it.
In conceptual contrast to.
In visual contrast to.
--Examples--
‘the fight against crime’
‘he decided against immediate publication’
‘swimming against the tide’
‘the first victim gave evidence against him’
‘the championship match against Somerset’
‘he gritted his teeth against the pain’
‘makeshift barricades against tank attacks’
‘he turned up his collar against the wind’
‘money was advanced against the value of the property’
‘the odds were 5–1 against England’
‘she stood with her back against the door’
‘frustration made him bang his head against the wall’
‘the benefits must be weighed against the costs’
‘he was silhouetted against the light of the stair window’

agalactia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Failure to produce milk after giving birth; an instance of this.
More fully "contagious agalactia", "infectious agalactia". An infectious disease of goats and sheep caused by Mycoplasma agalactiae and characterized by inflammation of the eye, joints, and (in females) udder.

--Word--
Agamemnon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
King of Mycenae and brother of Menelaus, commander-in-chief of the Greek expedition against Troy. On his return home from Troy he was murdered by his wife Clytemnestra and her lover Aegisthus; his murder was avenged by his son Orestes and daughter Electra.

--Word--
Agapemone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly with the. The headquarters of the religious sect founded by the Rev. Henry James Prince (1811–99) at Spaxton in Somerset in the mid 19th cent., or a similar establishment run by his successor, the Rev. John Hugh Smyth-Pigott (1852–1927), at Clapton, London; = "Abode of Love". Now historical.
Generally. A community characterized by love, an ‘abode of love’; (in extended use) an occasion or situation characterized by the sharing of communal love or the practice of free love.

agarita 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An evergreen barberry, Mahonia trifoliata (family Berberidaceae), of the south-western United States and Mexico, having greyish, sharply pointed trifoliate leaves, clusters of yellow flowers, and bright red edible berries; the berry itself, which is sharp-tasting and used especially for making preserves. Also: any of several similar plants of the genera Mahonia or Berberis (rare).

--Word--
Christie, Dame Agatha 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1890–1976), English writer of detective fiction. She wrote over seventy novels, many of which feature the Belgian sleuth Hercule Poirot or the resourceful Miss Marple. Notable works: Murder on the Orient Express (1934), Death on the Nile (1937), and The Mousetrap (play, 1952).

Agaw 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(The name of) a group of various related peoples of Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Djibouti; a member of one of these peoples.
The group of Cushitic languages spoken by or associated with the Agaw.
Of, relating to, or designating the Agaw, or the languages associated with them.

--Word--
agba 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large West African hardwood tree, Gossweilerodendron balsamiferum (family Fabaceae (Leguminosae)). Also: the pale-coloured, lightweight timber of this tree, used especially for furniture.

--Examples--
--Word--
age 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The length of time that a person has lived or a thing has existed.
A particular stage in someone's life.
The state of being old.
A distinct period of history.
A division of time that is a subdivision of an epoch, corresponding to a stage in chronostratigraphy.
A very long time.
Grow old or older.
Cause to appear old or older.
(with reference to an alcoholic drink, cheese, etc.) mature or allow to mature.
Determine how old (something) is.
--Examples--
‘he died from a heart attack at the age of 51’
‘he must be nearly 40 years of age’
‘children of primary school age’
‘fine wine improves with age’
‘an age of technological growth’
‘I haven't seen her for ages’
‘the tiredness we feel as we age’
‘he even tried ageing the painting with a spoonful of coffee’
‘the wine ages in open vats or casks’
‘a cheese that has been aged for four months’
‘we didn't have a clue how to age these animals’

UnKnownKind, adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘a bent cop’
‘a missionary bent on saving souls’
‘a mob bent on violence’
‘a man of a religious bent’
‘she had no natural bent for literature’

--Word--
cracked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Damaged and showing lines on the surface from having split without coming apart.
(of a person's voice) having an unusual harshness or pitch, especially through strain.
Crazy; insane.
--Examples--
‘the old pipes were cracked and leaking’
‘her voice emerged, cracked, from a throat tight with dread’
‘the captain was screaming orders in a cracked baritone’
‘you must think my family are cracked’
--Word--
aged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having lived for a specified length of time; of a specified age.
(of a horse or farm animal) over a certain defined age of maturity, typically 6 to 12 years for horses, 3 or 4 years for cattle.
Having lived or existed for a long time; very old.
Having been subjected to ageing.
--Examples--
‘young people aged 14 to 18’
‘he died aged 60’
‘aged men with white hair’
‘replica guitar with aged finish’

--Word--
ageing 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The process of growing old.
The process of change in the properties of a material occurring over a period, either spontaneously or through deliberate action.
(of a person) growing old; elderly.
(of a thing) reaching the end of useful life.
--Examples--
‘the external signs of ageing’
‘the ageing process’
‘the judicious use of oak ageing means the wines are capable of being confused with the great French Chardonnays’
‘an ageing population’
‘looking after ageing relatives’
‘the world's ageing fleet of oil tankers’

--Word--
agent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who acts on behalf of another person or group.
A person who manages business, financial, or contractual matters for an actor, performer, writer, etc.
A person or company that provides a particular service, typically one that involves organizing transactions between two other parties.
A person who works secretly to obtain information for a government or other official body.
A person or thing that takes an active role or produces a specified effect.
A substance that brings about a chemical or physical effect or causes a chemical reaction.
The doer of an action, typically expressed as the subject of an active verb or in a by phrase with a passive verb.
An independently operating Internet program, typically one that performs background tasks such as information retrieval or processing on behalf of a user or other program.
--Examples--
‘in the event of illness, a durable power of attorney enabled her nephew to act as her agent’
‘his agent was able to negotiate a long-term contract’
‘speak to your letting agent about refurbishing the property’
‘a trained intelligence agent’
‘universities are usually liberal communities that often view themselves as agents of social change’
‘there is an urgent need for new antimicrobial agents to combat infections’
‘the bleaching agent used is hydrogen peroxide’

suffix

ageratum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various flowering plants constituting the genus Ageratum (family Asteraceae (Compositae)), native chiefly to tropical America; especially any of the many cultivated varieties of A. houstonianum (formerly A. mexicanum) commonly grown in gardens for their clusters of pink, purple, or blue flowers.

aggie 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
An agriculturalist, specifically a student at an agricultural college. Frequently (and in earliest use): a member of a sports team from such a college; (in plural) the team itself.
An agricultural institution or college (often as the nickname of a specific institution).
Of or belonging to an Aggy or Aggies; relating to an agricultural college, department, team, etc.
A type of highly-prized playing marble made of agate or variegated glass resembling agate.

verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Collect or form into a mass or group.
A mass or collection of things.
A volcanic rock consisting of large fragments bonded together.
Collected or formed into a mass.
--Examples--
‘he is seeking to agglomerate the functions of the Home Office’
‘these small particles soon agglomerate together’
‘a multimedia agglomerate’
--Word--
agglomeratic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of an agglomerate.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglomerate 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Collect or form into a mass or group.
A mass or collection of things.
A volcanic rock consisting of large fragments bonded together.
Collected or formed into a mass.
--Examples--
‘he is seeking to agglomerate the functions of the Home Office’
‘these small particles soon agglomerate together’
‘a multimedia agglomerate’
--Word--
agglomeration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mass or collection of things; an assemblage.
--Examples--
‘the arts centre is an agglomeration of theatres, galleries, shops, restaurants and bars’
--Word--
agglomeration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mass or collection of things; an assemblage.
--Examples--
‘the arts centre is an agglomeration of theatres, galleries, shops, restaurants and bars’

agglomerative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
agglomerator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something that causes or promotes agglomeration, especially an apparatus or device, or (occasionally) a binding substance.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or property of being agglutinable; the extent to which cells, bacteria, etc. are agglutinable.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to undergo agglutination; involved in or responsible for agglutination.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
That causes agglutination; that glues, binds, or unites; agglutinative; agglutinating.
An adhesive, a glue.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Firmly stick or be stuck together to form a mass.
(with reference to bacteria or red blood cells) clump together.
(of a language) combine (word elements) to express compound ideas.
--Examples--
‘this secretion may form crusts agglutinating the eyelids’
‘the petals agglutinate to form a compact mass’
‘these strains agglutinate human red cells’
‘cell fragments agglutinate and form intricate meshes’
--Word--
agglutinated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Firmly stuck together to form a mass.
--Examples--
‘rhinoceros horns are agglutinated masses of hair’

agglutinative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a language, e.g. Hungarian, Turkish, Korean, and Swahili) tending to express concepts in complex words consisting of many elements, rather than by inflection or by using isolated elements.

agglutinator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An agglutinant; (in later use) specifically an agglutinin.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An antibody, lectin, or other substance that causes agglutination.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An antibody, lectin, or other substance that causes agglutination.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Agglutinate.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An antigenic substance present in blood cells, bacteria, etc., which stimulates the formation of an agglutinin in blood serum.
--Examples--
--Word--
agglutinoid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An antibody capable of binding antigen but not of causing agglutination; an agglutinin altered so as to lose its agglutinating ability.
--Examples--
--Word--
aggradation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The deposition of material by a river, stream, or current.
--Examples--
--Word--
aggrade 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
And without object. Of a river, current, or other agency: to build up (a valley, plain, etc.) by deposition of detrital material. Contrasted with "degrade".
--Examples--

--Word--
aggravator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which aggravates.
Slang. A greased lock of hair, especially one worn over the temple or forehead. Compare "lovelock", Newgate knocker. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
aggravate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (a problem, injury, or offence) worse or more serious.
Annoy or exasperate.
--Examples--
‘military action would only aggravate the situation’

adjective
--Meanings--

(of a penalty) made more severe in recognition of the seriousness of an offence.
--Examples--
‘aggravated burglary’
‘aggravated damages’

‘I don't need this aggravation’

--Type--
adjective

--Word--
aggregant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
That promotes or causes aggregation; aggregating.

--Examples--
--Word--
aggregate 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A whole formed by combining several separate elements.
The total score of a player or team in a fixture comprising more than one game or round.
A material or structure formed from a mass of fragments or particles loosely compacted together.
Pieces of broken or crushed stone or gravel used to make concrete and in building.
Formed or calculated by the combination of several separate elements; total.
(of a group of species) comprising several very similar species formerly regarded as a single species.
Denoting the total supply or demand for goods and services in an economy at a particular time.
Form or group into a class or cluster.
Collect (related items of content) so as to display or link to them.
--Examples--
‘the council was an aggregate of three regional assemblies’
‘he set the pace with a one-over-par aggregate of 151’
‘the result put the sides level on aggregate’
‘the specimen is an aggregate of rock and mineral fragments’
‘use aggregate for the first layer when filling the trench’
‘the aggregate amount of grants made’
‘socio-occupational groups aggregate men sharing similar kinds of occupation’
‘the butterflies aggregate in dense groups’
‘tools that aggregate data from all of the security devices are a good first step’

--Word--
aggregation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The formation of a number of things into a cluster.
A cluster of things that have come or been brought together.
(on the Internet) the collection of related items of content so that they can be displayed or linked to.
--Examples--
‘a single dose of aspirin irreversibly inhibits the normal aggregation of platelets’
‘the pelican is the other bird likely to be found in large aggregations in East Africa's wetlands’
‘a desktop aggregation app that brings together Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn’

aggressin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
aggression 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Feelings of anger or antipathy resulting in hostile or violent behaviour; readiness to attack or confront.
The action of attacking without provocation.
Forcefulness.
--Examples--
‘his chin was jutting with aggression’
‘territorial aggression between individuals of the same species’
‘he called for an end to foreign aggression against his country’
‘the president has been emboldened by the success of his latest aggressions’
‘the sheer volume and aggression of his playing’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

aggressively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a manner resulting from or betraying aggression.
In a determined and forceful way.
--Examples--
‘he resisted violently and continued to behave aggressively in the police car’
‘foreign-owned banks are aggressively marketing credit cards’

aggressiveness

noun
--Meanings--
Hostile or violent behaviour.
Determination and forcefulness.
--Examples--
‘recent research has linked violent video games to increased aggressiveness in youths’
‘smaller, quicker players use their speed and aggressiveness to make up for lack of bulk’

aggry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance which forms the material of certain kinds of bead used in West Africa. Chiefly in "aggry bead": a type of variegated glass bead found especially in Ghana.

--Word--
agile 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to move quickly and easily.
Able to think and understand quickly.
Relating to or denoting a method of project management, used especially for software development, that is characterized by the division of tasks into short phases of work and frequent reassessment and adaptation of plans.
--Examples--
‘Ruth was as agile as a monkey’
‘his vague manner concealed an agile mind’
‘agile methods replace high-level design with frequent redesign’

--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
Agincourt, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle in northern France in 1415 during the Hundred Years War, in which the English under Henry V defeated a large French army. The victory, achieved largely by use of the longbow, allowed Henry to occupy Normandy.
--Examples--
--Word--
ageing 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The process of growing old.
The process of change in the properties of a material occurring over a period, either spontaneously or through deliberate action.
(of a person) growing old; elderly.
(of a thing) reaching the end of useful life.
--Examples--
‘the external signs of ageing’
‘the ageing process’
‘the judicious use of oak ageing means the wines are capable of being confused with the great French Chardonnays’
‘an ageing population’
‘looking after ageing relatives’
‘the world's ageing fleet of oil tankers’

ageism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Prejudice or discrimination on the grounds of a person's age.
--Examples--
‘ageism in recruitment is an increasing problem’
--Word--
aginer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is against something; one who opposes a proposal, course of action, point of view, etc. Also more generally: a person having a habitually negative attitude; one who opposes any change as a matter of principle.

agitate

verb
--Meanings--
Make (someone) troubled or nervous.

‘they agitated for a reversal of the decision’

Agnes, St. 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(died c.304), Roman martyr. The patron saint of virgins, her emblem is a lamb (Latin agnus). Feast day, January 21.
(c.1211–82), patron saint of Bohemia. She was canonized in 1989. Feast day, March 2.

Agnew, Spiro T. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1918–96), US politician; full name Spiro Theodore Agnew. He served as Richard Nixon's vice president 1969–73 but was forced to resign because of corruption charges against him that stemmed from his time as governor of Maryland 1967–69.

agnostic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who believes that nothing is known or can be known of the existence or nature of God.
Relating to agnostics or agnosticism.
(in a non-religious context) having a doubtful or non-committal attitude towards something.
Denoting or relating to hardware or software that is compatible with many types of platform or operating system.
--Examples--
‘until now I've been fairly agnostic about electoral reform’
‘many common file formats (JPEG, MP3, etc.) are platform-agnostic’
‘our industry is moving towards a device-agnostic model’

--Meanings--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
agonize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

Cause mental anguish to.

‘a question which will agonize the technocrats’

--Word--
agon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A public celebration of games, including athletic, dramatic, and musical contests, in the ancient Greek or Roman world; a contest for a prize at such games.
A verbal contest or dispute between two characters in an ancient Greek play.
A painful struggle, especially a psychological one; a conflict, fight, competition.
--Examples--
--Word--
good 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
To be desired or approved of.
Pleasing and welcome.
Showing approval.
Having the required qualities; of a high standard.
Skilled at doing or dealing with a specified thing.
Healthy, strong, or well.
Useful, advantageous, or beneficial in effect.
Appropriate to a particular purpose.
(of language) with correct grammar and pronunciation.
Strictly adhering to or fulfilling all the principles of a particular religion or cause.
Possessing or displaying moral virtue.
Showing kindness.
Obedient to rules or conventions.
Used to address or refer to people in a courteous, patronizing, or ironic way.
Commanding respect.
Belonging or relating to a high social class.
Giving pleasure; enjoyable or satisfying.
Pleasant to look at; attractive.
(of clothes) smart and suitable for formal wear.
Thorough.
Used to emphasize that a number is at least as great as one claims.
Used to emphasize a following adjective or adverb.
Fairly large in number, amount, or size.
Valid.
Likely to provide.
Sufficient to pay for.
Used in conjunction with the name of God or a related expression as an exclamation of extreme surprise or anger.
That which is morally right; righteousness.
Benefit or advantage to someone or something.
Merchandise or possessions.
Things to be transported, as distinct from passengers.
The genuine article.
Well.
--Examples--
‘it's good that he's back to his old self’
‘a good quality of life’
‘Good! The more people the better!’
‘we've had some good news’
‘it's good to see you again’
‘the play had good reviews’
‘a good restaurant’
‘his marks are just not good enough’
‘I'm good at crosswords’
‘he was good with children’
‘she's not feeling too good’
‘too much sun is not good for you’
‘this is a good month for planting seeds’
‘she speaks good English’
‘I am the eldest of five in a good Catholic family’
‘her father was a good man’
‘it was good of you to come’
‘accustom the child to being rewarded for good behaviour’
‘a man very like your good self, in fact’
‘the good lady of the house’
‘he was concerned with establishing and maintaining his good name’
‘he comes from a good family’
‘the streets fill up with people looking for a good time’
‘you're looking pretty good’
‘he went upstairs to change out of his good suit’
‘now is the time to have a really good clear-up’
‘have a good look around’
‘they're a good twenty years younger’
‘we had a good long hug’
‘it'll be good and dark by then’
‘the match attracted a good crowd’
‘there's a good chance that we may be able to help’
‘the ticket is good for travel from May to September’
‘she's always good for a laugh’
‘his money was good for a bottle of whisky’
‘good heavens!’
‘a mysterious balance of good and evil’
‘he convinces his father to use his genius for the good of mankind’
‘the preservation of old buildings matters because they contribute to the general public good’
‘he is too clever for his own good’
‘imports of luxury goods’
‘stolen goods’
‘the market price of an agricultural good’
‘a means of transporting passengers as well as goods’
‘a goods train’
‘my mother could never cook this good’
‘I'm feeling pretty good, all things considered’

agoraphobia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Extreme or irrational fear of entering open or crowded places, of leaving one's own home, or of being in places from which escape is difficult.
--Examples--
--Word--
agoraphobic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having an extreme or irrational fear of entering open or crowded places, of leaving one's own home, or of being in places from which escape is difficult.
A person with an extreme or irrational fear of entering open or crowded places, of leaving their own home, or of being in places from which escape is difficult.
--Examples--
‘lately I've become completely agoraphobic’
‘a seemingly agoraphobic young woman’
‘an agoraphobic who has not been out of her house for many months’

--Word--
Agostini, Giacomo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1942), Italian racing motorcyclist. Between 1966 and 1975 he won a record fifteen world titles, and won the Isle of Man TT ten times.

--Word--
agouti 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large long-legged burrowing rodent related to the guinea pig, native to Central and South America.
Fur in which each hair has alternate dark and light bands, producing a grizzled appearance.
A rodent, especially a mouse, having agouti fur.

--Word--
Agra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city on the River Jumna in Uttar Pradesh state, northern India; population 1,638,200 (est. 2009). Founded in the early 16th century, Agra was the capital of the Mogul empire until 1658. It is the site of the Taj Mahal.
--Examples--
--Word--
agraffe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of fastener or clasp consisting of a hook attached to a ring or loop, often richly ornamented and worn especially on military uniforms, women's gowns, ceremonial costumes, etc. (sometimes having a purely decorative function). Now chiefly historical.
Any of various things resembling an agraffe in form or function, especially an object or device that serves to bridge, join, or fasten two other parts or components. Now rare.
Winemaking. Usually in form agrafe. A metal clip used to secure the cork in a bottle of champagne or sparkling wine during secondary fermentation.
Music. A device on a piano consisting of a metal guide or holder fixed to the plate near the tuning pins, through or over which the individual strings are passed to keep them at the correct height and position.
--Examples--
--Word--

agreer 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
agreer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who agrees.
--Examples--
--Word--
agree 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Have the same opinion about something; concur.
Approve of (something) with regard to its moral correctness.
Say that one will do something which has been suggested by another person.
Reach agreement about (something) after negotiation.
Be consistent with.
Have the same number, gender, case, or person as.
Be healthy or appropriate for (someone)
--Examples--
‘I completely agree with your recent editorial’
‘we both agreed on issues such as tougher penalties for criminals’
‘‘Yes, dreadful, isn't it,’ she agreed’
‘I don't agree with random drugs testing in schools’
‘she had agreed to go and see a movie with him’
‘if they had agreed a price the deal would have gone through’
‘the commission agreed on a proposal to limit imports’
‘your body language does not agree with what you are saying’
‘the verb agrees with the final noun’
‘she's eaten something which did not agree with her’

--Word--
agreeingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an agreeing manner. In early use: correspondingly, consistently, suitably. Later: in a manner that indicates agreement, harmony, or accord; agreeably.
--Examples--
--Word--
agreement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Harmony or accordance in opinion or feeling.
A negotiated and typically legally binding arrangement between parties as to a course of action.
The absence of incompatibility between two things; consistency.
The condition of having the same number, gender, case, and/or person as another word.
--Examples--
‘the governments failed to reach agreement’
‘the two officers nodded in agreement’
‘a trade agreement’
‘a verbal agreement to sell’
‘agreement between experimental observations and theory’

agrobacterium

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Agrostis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous grasses found in temperate climates worldwide constituting the genus Agrostis, which includes some important turf and forage grasses, as creeping bent grass, A. stolonifera, and common bent grass, A. capillaris.
--Examples--
--Word--
agrostography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A systematic account or description of the grasses; the branch of botany concerned with this.

Ahom 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating an ancient Tai language once spoken in Assam but now confined to written texts and ceremonial contexts.
Of, belonging to, or designating a people of the Assam region in north-east India where this language was spoken.
A member of the Ahom people.
The Ahom language.
--Examples--
--Word--
horizon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The line at which the earth's surface and the sky appear to meet.
The circular boundary of the part of the earth's surface visible from a particular point, ignoring irregularities and obstructions.
A great circle of the celestial sphere, the plane of which passes through the centre of the earth and is parallel to that of the apparent horizon of a place.
The limit of a person's knowledge, experience, or interest.
A layer of soil or rock, or a set of strata, with particular characteristics.
A level of an excavated site representing a particular period.
--Examples--
‘the sun rose above the horizon’
‘she wanted to leave home and broaden her horizons’
‘the upper horizon of the site showed an arrangement of two rows of features’

ahuehuete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "ahuehuete tree". A Mexican cypress, Taxodium mucronatum (family Cupressaceae), which can attain great girth, commonly grown as an ornamental and also important for the production of timber and (especially formerly) medicinal resins.
--Examples--
--Word--
ahull 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Of a ship: so as to float or drift solely with the force of the wind or current on the hull, i.e. with the sails furled or the engines turned off. Chiefly with lie.

--Word--
hunt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Pursue and kill (a wild animal) for sport or food.
Pursue (a wild animal, especially a fox or deer) on horseback using hounds.
Use (a hound or a horse) for hunting.
(of an animal) chase and kill (its prey)
Search determinedly for someone or something.
(of the police) search for (a criminal)
Search for and capture someone.
(of a device or system) oscillate about a desired speed, position, or state.
(of an aircraft or rocket) oscillate about a mean flight path.
(in change-ringing) move the place of a bell in a simple progression.
An act of hunting wild animals or game.
An association of people who meet regularly to hunt, especially with hounds.
An area where hunting takes place.
A search.
An oscillating motion about a desired speed, position, or state.
--Examples--
‘in the autumn they hunted deer’
‘they hunted and fished’
‘an old dog fox who had been hunted many times before’
‘he used to hunt’
‘he hunted his hounds every day’
‘mice are hunted by weasels and foxes’
‘lionesses hunt in groups’
‘he desperately hunted for a new job’
‘the gang is being hunted by police’
‘police are hunting for her attacker’
‘the killers will be hunted down’
‘on weak stereo signals this circuit can hunt over mono and stereo in a very disconcerting manner’
‘a bear-hunt’
‘police launched a hunt for the killer’
