alizarin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A red pigment present in madder root, used in dyeing.
Denoting dyes derived from or similar to alizarin.
--Examples--
‘alizarin crimson’

noun
--Meanings--
(Slight) alkalinity; tendency to become alkaline.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalescent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Tending to become alkaline; incipiently or slightly alkaline; promoting alkalinity. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkali 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound with particular chemical properties including turning litmus blue and neutralizing or effervescing with acids; typically, a caustic or corrosive substance of this kind such as lime or soda.
--Examples--
‘flint is not subject to chemical weathering except by strong alkalis’
‘the reaction is followed by measuring the concentration of alkali at various times’
--Word--
alkalic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a rock or mineral) richer in sodium and/or potassium than is usual for its type.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Affected, especially adversely, by strongly alkaline or saline conditions of the ground or water; poisoned by alkaline water.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make alkaline; (in early use) to convert into an alkali.
To become alkaline, or an alkali. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalifiable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being alkalified.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make alkaline; (in early use) to convert into an alkali.
To become alkaline, or an alkali. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make alkaline; (in early use) to convert into an alkali.
To become alkaline, or an alkali. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkalifying 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: combining with other substances to form alkalies; compare "acidifying". In later use more widely: making alkaline.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaligen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: (A. F. de Fourcroy's name for) nitrogen. Later: a supposed essential component of alkalis.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaligenous 
--Type--
adjective

alkaline 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the properties of an alkali, or containing alkali; having a pH greater than 7.
--Examples--
‘an alkaline soil’
‘a slightly alkaline solution’
--Word--
alkalinize 
--Type--
verb, verb
--Meanings--
Treat with alkali; alkalize.
To make alkaline.
--Examples--
‘there is little evidence showing that alkalinized water provides health benefits’

--Word--
alkali 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound with particular chemical properties including turning litmus blue and neutralizing or effervescing with acids; typically, a caustic or corrosive substance of this kind such as lime or soda.
--Examples--
‘flint is not subject to chemical weathering except by strong alkalis’
‘the reaction is followed by measuring the concentration of alkali at various times’
--Word--

noun

‘the reaction is followed by measuring the concentration of alkali at various times’

--Word--
alkaloid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of nitrogenous organic compounds of plant origin which have pronounced physiological actions on humans. They include many drugs (morphine, quinine) and poisons (atropine, strychnine).
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaloidal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of an alkaloid; of or relating to alkaloids.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaloid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of nitrogenous organic compounds of plant origin which have pronounced physiological actions on humans. They include many drugs (morphine, quinine) and poisons (atropine, strychnine).
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaloid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of nitrogenous organic compounds of plant origin which have pronounced physiological actions on humans. They include many drugs (morphine, quinine) and poisons (atropine, strychnine).

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
alcanna 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Alkanet, Alkanna tinctoria, a southern European plant with a root which is used to produce a red dye; the root of this plant or the dye (or other extract) itself. Occasionally also: any of various other plants of the genus Alkanna. Compare "alkanet", 2. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkanol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aliphatic alcohol, considered as a substituted alkane; especially any of the series of monohydric alcohols having the formula R—OH, where R is an alkyl group.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkapton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acidic substance, later identified with homogentisic acid, which is excreted by people with alkaptonuria and causes their urine, left standing, to turn dark through oxidation.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaptonuria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The presence of homogentisic acid (alkapton) in the urine; an inherited (autosomal recessive) metabolic disorder characterized by this, and by ochronosis and arthritis, especially of the spine.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkaptonuric 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Affected with alkaptonuria; characteristic of alkaptonuria.
An individual affected with alkaptonuria.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
alkermes 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dried bodies of scale insects (females of Kermes ilicis and K. vermilio, family Kermesidae), found in the Mediterranean region on the kermes oak (Quercus coccifera) and formerly used medicinally and as a source of red dye; a medicinal preparation containing these insects, especially confection of alkermes. Compare "kermes". Now historical.
An Italian alcoholic liqueur, coloured red with kermes or cochineal, and typically flavoured with herbs and spices including cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves.

--Meanings--

alkylene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An alkene or olefin; a divalent radical or group derived from an alkene by the loss of two hydrogen atoms. Chiefly attributive or as a formative element in names of compounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
alkylidene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound derived from an alkane by the replacement of two hydrogen atoms on the same carbon atom with one double-bonded atom or group; the divalent functional group =CR′R″ characteristic of such a compound.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various resins, oils, and pitch-like substances with a practical use; specifically (a) mineral pitch, native asphalt; (b) the resin from trees such as pine and cedar.

alkoxide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of salt-like organic compounds containing anions of the form RO−, where R is an alkyl group, typically formed by the reaction of alcohols with metals.

noun
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
all 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to the whole quantity or extent of a particular group or thing.
Any whatever.
Used to emphasize the greatest possible amount of a quality.
The only thing (used for emphasis)
(used to refer to surroundings or a situation in general) everything.
Completely.
Used to emphasize a temporary quality.
(in games) used after a number to indicate an equal score.
--Examples--
‘all the people I met’
‘she left all her money to him’
‘10 per cent of all cars sold’
‘he slept all day’
‘carry all of the blame’
‘we all have different needs’
‘he denied all knowledge of it’
‘they were in all probability completely unaware’
‘with all due respect’
‘all I want is to be left alone’
‘all was well’
‘all is not lost yet’
‘dressed all in black’
‘she's been all round the world’
‘all by himself’
‘my ankle's gone all wobbly’
‘he was all of a dither’
‘after extra time it was still two all’

allactite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rare reddish-brown or pink mineral consisting of a basic arsenate of manganese, typically occurring as prisms and as crusts on manganese ores.

all-aged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally Horse Racing (later also Coursing and in greyhound racing). Of a race: open to competitors of all ages. Also of the animals eligible to take part in a race: of all ages.
Forestry. Designating a forest made up of a mixture of trees of all ages.
--Examples--
--Word--
allagite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A green or brownish-red mineral of uncertain identity (perhaps an altered form of rhodonite) consisting of a silicate and carbonate of manganese.

proper noun

--Word--
Allahabad 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the state of Uttar Pradesh, north central India; population 1,125,000 (est. 2009). Situated at the confluence of the sacred Jumna and Ganges Rivers, it is a place of Hindu pilgrimage.
--Examples--

noun

allayer

noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which allays something; especially a person who or thing which tempers, restrains, or alleviates pain, a strong emotion, etc.; a mitigator, an assuager.

--Word--
air 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The invisible gaseous substance surrounding the earth, a mixture mainly of oxygen and nitrogen.
Air regarded as necessary for breathing.
The free or unconfined space above the surface of the earth.
Referring to the use of aircraft.
The earth's atmosphere as a medium for transmitting radio waves.
One of the four elements in ancient and medieval philosophy and in astrology (considered essential to the nature of the signs of Gemini, Aquarius, and Libra)
A breeze or light wind.
An impression of a quality or manner given by someone or something.
An annoyingly affected and condescending manner.
A tune or short melodious song.
A jump off the ground on a snowboard or skateboard.
Express (an opinion or grievance) publicly.
Broadcast (a programme) on radio or television.
Parade or show (something) ostentatiously.
Expose (a room) to the open air in order to ventilate it.
Warm (washed laundry) to remove dampness.
Go out in the fresh air.
--Examples--
‘the air was stale’
‘the doctor told me to get some fresh air’
‘he celebrated by tossing his hat high in the air’
‘air traffic’
‘all goods must come in by air’
‘radio stations have successfully sold products over the air’
‘an air sign’
‘she answered with a faint air of boredom’
‘he leaned over with a confidential air’
‘he began to put on airs and think he could boss us around’
‘traditional Scottish airs sung in the Gaelic tongue’
‘a meeting in which long-standing grievances were aired’
‘the programmes were aired on India's state TV network’
‘he took the opportunity of airing his knowledge of antiquity’
‘the window sashes were lifted regularly to air the room’
‘I was airing the sheets’
‘to go and air myself in my native fields’

allay 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Diminish or put at rest (fear, suspicion, or worry)

--Examples--

all-American 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Possessing qualities characteristic of US ideals, such as honesty, industriousness, and health.
Drawn only from America or the US.
Involving or representing the whole of America or the US.
(of a sports player) honoured as one of the best amateur competitors in the US.

‘an all-American anthology’

--Word--
allantois 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fetal membrane lying below the chorion in many vertebrates, formed as an outgrowth of the embryo's gut. In birds and reptiles it grows to surround the embryo; in eutherian mammals it forms part of the placenta.
--Examples--
--Word--
allantoidean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Embryology= "allantoic".

allantoin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
allantois 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fetal membrane lying below the chorion in many vertebrates, formed as an outgrowth of the embryo's gut. In birds and reptiles it grows to surround the embryo; in eutherian mammals it forms part of the placenta.

A device or charge.

‘a disposer of grants and subsidies’
--Word--
divine 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of or like God or a god.
Devoted to God; sacred.
Very pleasing; delightful.
A cleric or theologian.
Providence or God.
Discover (something) by guesswork or intuition.
Have supernatural or magical insight into (future events)
Discover (water) by dowsing.
--Examples--
‘heroes with divine powers’
‘paintings of shipwrecks being prevented by divine intervention’
‘divine liturgy’
‘he had the most divine smile’
‘mum had divined my state of mind’
‘they had divined that he was a fake’
‘frauds who claimed to divine the future in chickens' entrails’
‘he showed him how to divine water’

--Word--
dreadful 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing or involving great suffering, fear, or unhappiness; extremely bad or serious.
Extremely disagreeable.
(of a person) unwell or troubled.
Used to emphasize the degree to which something is the case, especially something regarded with sadness or disapproval.
--Examples--
‘there's been a dreadful accident’
‘the weather was dreadful’
‘I feel dreadful—I hate myself’

‘this was all a dreadful mistake’
‘you're a dreadful flirt’

--Type--

--Meanings--

alley 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A narrow passageway between or behind buildings.
A path lined with trees, bushes, or stones.
A long, narrow area in which games such as skittles and bowling are played.
Either of the two side strips between the singles sideline and the sidelines which count as part of the court in a doubles match.
The area between the outfielders in left-centre or right-centre field.
--Examples--
‘he took a short cut along an alley’
‘there were a few muggings in the backstreets and alleys’
‘alleys of standing stones’
‘a skittle alley’

--Word--
all 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to the whole quantity or extent of a particular group or thing.
Any whatever.
Used to emphasize the greatest possible amount of a quality.
The only thing (used for emphasis)
(used to refer to surroundings or a situation in general) everything.
Completely.
Used to emphasize a temporary quality.
(in games) used after a number to indicate an equal score.
--Examples--
‘all the people I met’
‘she left all her money to him’
‘10 per cent of all cars sold’
‘he slept all day’
‘carry all of the blame’
‘we all have different needs’
‘he denied all knowledge of it’
‘they were in all probability completely unaware’
‘with all due respect’
‘all I want is to be left alone’
‘all was well’
‘all is not lost yet’
‘dressed all in black’
‘she's been all round the world’
‘all by himself’
‘my ankle's gone all wobbly’
‘he was all of a dither’
‘after extra time it was still two all’

allemontite

--Word--
old land 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
British (now chiefly English regional). Originally: arable land lying fallow. Later (also): specifically arable land sown with grass for more than two years.
US. Land that has been in cultivation for a long time, or exhausted by a long period of cultivation. Now rare.
With the, and frequently with capital initials. In the language of colonists or those living or travelling abroad: a country of origin, especially. Britain or Ireland. Compare "old country". Now rare.
Geology (Usually oldland.) Land which lies behind a coastal plain of more recent origin, especially where the coastal plain has been built up from sedimentary material derived from that same land. Also: an area of very ancient crystalline rocks, especially when reduced to low relief.
--Examples--

retour

Return (to a place); a return. Now rare.

--Word--
essential 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Absolutely necessary; extremely important.
Fundamental or central to the nature of something or someone.
(of an amino acid or fatty acid) required for normal growth but not synthesized in the body and therefore necessary in the diet.
(of a disease) with no known external stimulus or cause; idiopathic.
A thing that is absolutely necessary.
The fundamental elements or characteristics of something.
--Examples--
‘it is essential to keep up-to-date records’
‘fibre is an essential ingredient of our diet’
‘the essential weakness of the plaintiff's case’

--Word--
allaesthesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
gas 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance or matter in a state in which it will expand freely to fill the whole of a container, having no fixed shape (unlike a solid) and no fixed volume (unlike a liquid)
A gaseous substance that cannot be liquefied by the application of pressure alone.
A flammable gas used as a fuel.
A gaseous anaesthetic such as nitrous oxide, used in dentistry.
Gas or vapour used as a poisonous agent in warfare.
Gas generated in the alimentary canal; flatulence.
An explosive mixture of firedamp with air.
Used in reference to power or the accelerator of a car.
An entertaining or amusing person or situation.
Enjoyment, amusement, or fun.
Kill or harm by exposure to gas.
(of a storage battery or dry cell) give off gas.
Talk excessively about trivial matters.
Fill the tank of (a motor vehicle) with petrol.
Very amusing or entertaining.
--Examples--
‘hot balls of gas that become stars’
‘poisonous gases’
‘cooking is done by bottled gas’
‘gas was one of the most dreaded weapons of the war’
‘we stopped for gas’
‘I ordered my friend to step on the gas’
‘the party would be a gas’
‘it was great gas in the club last night’
‘my son was gassed at Verdun’
‘the maintenance-free charger controls the input without inducing gassing’
‘I thought you'd never stop gassing’
‘after gassing up the car, he went into the restaurant’
‘Ruthie, that's gas—you're a gem’

--Word--
great 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Of an extent, amount, or intensity considerably above average.
Impressive or grand.
Used in names of animals or plants which are larger than similar kinds, e.g. great tit, greater celandine.
Denoting the larger or largest part of a place.
(of a city) including adjacent urban areas.
Of ability, quality, or eminence considerably above average.
Used as a title to denote the most important person of the name.
Very good; excellent.
(of a person) very skilled in a particular area.
Used before a noun to emphasize a particular description of someone or something.
Denoting the element of something that is the most important or the most worthy of consideration.
Used to reinforce another adjective of size or extent.
Used to express surprise, admiration, or contempt, especially in exclamations.
(in names of family relationships) denoting one degree further removed upwards or downwards.
(of two people) on very close or intimate terms.
An important or distinguished person.
Very well; excellently.
--Examples--
‘the article was of great interest’
‘she showed great potential as an actor’
‘a great ocean between them’
‘the great Victorian house’
‘Great Malvern’
‘Greater Manchester’
‘the great Italian conductor’

Forming adverbs from adjectives ending in -al (such as radically from radical).
--Examples--
--Word--
ally 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A state formally cooperating with another for a military or other purpose.
A person or organization that cooperates with or helps another in a particular activity.
The countries that fought with Britain in the First and Second World Wars.
Combine or unite a resource or commodity with (another) for mutual benefit.
Side with or support.
--Examples--
‘debate continued among NATO allies’
‘he was forced to dismiss his closest political ally’
‘they were caught between the German army of occupation and the advancing Allies’
‘he allied his racing experience with his father's business acumen’
‘he allied himself with the forces of change’
--Word--
allyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Of or denoting the unsaturated hydrocarbon radical —CH₂CH=CH₂
--Examples--
‘allyl alcohol’
--Word--
allylamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless to pale yellow liquid unsaturated amine; also called acrylamine.
--Examples--
--Word--
allylate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An alkoxide or (occasionally) other compound containing an allyl group.
--Examples--
--Word--
allylene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= propyne.
= propadiene. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
allylic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
illuminatingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
allyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Of or denoting the unsaturated hydrocarbon radical —CH₂CH=CH₂
--Examples--
‘allyl alcohol’
--Word--
imitate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take or follow as a model.
Copy (a person's speech or mannerisms), especially for comic effect.
Copy or simulate.
--Examples--
‘his style was imitated by many other writers’
‘she imitated my Scots accent’
‘synthetic fabrics can now imitate everything from silk to rubber’
--Word--
all-important 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Vitally important; crucial.
--Examples--
‘the town's all-important tourist industry’
--Word--
impressive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Evoking admiration through size, quality, or skill; grand, imposing, or awesome.
--Examples--
‘an impressive view of the mountains’
‘impressive achievements in science’
--Word--
alliin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance found in garlic, originally thought to be a glucoside. Now disused.
An amino acid found in garlic and other species of the genus Allium, which when brought into contact with the enzyme alliinase (e.g. by crushing a garlic clove), is converted to the strong-smelling compound allicin.
--Examples--
--Word--
all-in 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Inclusive of everything.
--Examples--
‘an all-in fee’
--Word--
including 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
Containing as part of the whole being considered.
--Examples--
‘languages including Welsh and Gaelic’
‘weapons were recovered from the house, including a shotgun’
--Word--
all-inclusive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Including everything or everyone.
Denoting or relating to a holiday in which all or most meals, drinks, and activities are included in the overall price.
--Examples--
‘an all-inclusive holiday’
‘the book doesn't claim to be all-inclusive’
--Word--
all-inclusiveness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being all-inclusive.
--Examples--
--Word--
India 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in southern Asia occupying the greater part of the Indian subcontinent; population 1,311,000,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, Hindi and English (fourteen other languages are recognized as official in certain regions; of these, Bengali, Gujarati, Marathi, Tamil, Telugu, and Urdu have most first-language speakers); capital, New Delhi.
A code word representing the letter I, used in radio communication.

Allison tuna 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The yellowfin tuna, Thunnus albacares; specifically the larger adult with long sickle-shaped fins (formerly regarded as a separate species, Thunnus (or Neothunnus) allisoni).
--Examples--
--Word--
alliteral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Alliterative, alliterating; (in later use sometimes) specifically designating or relating to (a characteristic of) the Nguni group of languages, in which there is an assimilation of the initial letters of grammatically connected words in a sentence.
--Examples--
--Word--
alliterate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a phrase or line of verse) contain words which begin with the same sound or letter.
Use words beginning with the same sound or letter.
--Examples--
‘his first and last names alliterated’

--Word--
noble 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging by rank, title, or birth to the aristocracy.
Having or showing fine personal qualities or high moral principles.
Of imposing or magnificent size or appearance.
Of excellent or superior quality.
(especially in former times) a person of noble rank or birth.
A former English gold coin first issued in 1351.
--Examples--
‘the medieval palace was once owned by a noble Florentine family’
‘the Duchess of Kent and several other noble ladies’
‘the promotion of human rights was a noble aspiration’
‘noble arches and massive granite columns’
‘there is nothing more noble than a mature pine forest’
‘Chardonnay is the noble grape from which some of the finest white wines are produced’
‘the greater a noble's military power, the more land he could control’
‘the king imposed a tax on both nobles and peasants’

--Word--
allochiria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a condition in which a person is unable to determine on which side of the body a stimulus has been applied. In later use: specifically a condition in which a stimulus applied or presented to one side of the body is perceived as occurring on the opposite side.
--Examples--

allogenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a mineral or sediment) transported to its present position from elsewhere.

--Examples--
--Word--
allograft 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tissue graft from a donor of the same species as the recipient but not genetically identical.
--Examples--
--Word--
allograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of two or more alternative forms of a letter of an alphabet or other grapheme, for example the capital, lower case, italic, and various handwritten forms of a letter.
Each of two or more letters or letter combinations representing a single phoneme in different words. Allographs of the phoneme /f/ include the (f) of ‘fake’ and the (ph) of ‘phase’.
--Examples--
--Word--
allographic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
alloy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A metal made by combining two or more metallic elements, especially to give greater strength or resistance to corrosion.
An inferior metal mixed with a precious one.
Mix (metals) to make an alloy.
Debase (something) by adding something inferior.
--Examples--
‘an alloy of nickel, bronze, and zinc’
‘alloy wheels’
‘alloying tin with copper to make bronze’
‘a salutary fear alloyed their admiration’
--Word--
alloyage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of alloying metals.
--Examples--
--Word--
alloy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A metal made by combining two or more metallic elements, especially to give greater strength or resistance to corrosion.
An inferior metal mixed with a precious one.
Mix (metals) to make an alloy.
Debase (something) by adding something inferior.
--Examples--
‘an alloy of nickel, bronze, and zinc’
‘alloy wheels’
‘alloying tin with copper to make bronze’
‘a salutary fear alloyed their admiration’
--Word--
alloy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A metal made by combining two or more metallic elements, especially to give greater strength or resistance to corrosion.
An inferior metal mixed with a precious one.
Mix (metals) to make an alloy.
Debase (something) by adding something inferior.
--Examples--
‘an alloy of nickel, bronze, and zinc’
‘alloy wheels’
‘alloying tin with copper to make bronze’
‘a salutary fear alloyed their admiration’
--Word--
oil 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A viscous liquid derived from petroleum, especially for use as a fuel or lubricant.
Petroleum.
Any of various viscous liquids which are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents and are obtained from animals or plants.
A liquid preparation used on the hair or skin as a cosmetic.
Any of a group of natural esters of glycerol and various fatty acids, which are liquid at room temperature.
Oil paint.
An oil painting.
Information or facts.
Lubricate, coat, or impregnate with oil.
Supply with oil as fuel.
--Examples--
‘400 birds were coated with oil which spilled out from an opened valve’
‘the oil industry’
‘potatoes fried in vegetable oil’
‘suntan oil’
‘a portrait in oils’
‘a dark discoloured oil of an elderly cleric’
‘Young had some good oil on the Adelaide races’
‘a lightly oiled baking tray’
‘attempts should not be made to oil individual tanks too rapidly’

allophyle 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of another tribe; a foreigner, an alien. rare.
Foreign, alien; = Allophylian.
--Examples--
--Word--
Allophylian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(A) In the terminology of J. C. Prichard: designating the peoples of Asia and Europe whose languages belong neither to the Indo-European nor the Semitic groups, and were supposed to have been the original inhabitants of these regions; belonging to or characteristic of these peoples or their languages. Later also: relating to or designating all the languages of Eurasia, or of the world, outside the Indo-European and Semitic families. Now historical. (b) More generally: ethnically or linguistically unrelated.
A member of an Allophylian race or people. Now historical and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
allophone 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of the various phonetic realizations of a phoneme in a language, which do not contribute to distinctions of meaning. For example, in English an aspirated p (as in pin) and unaspirated p (as in spin) are allophones of /p/, whereas in ancient Greek the distinction was phonemic.
(especially in Quebec) an immigrant whose first language is neither French nor English.
--Examples--
--Word--
allophone 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of the various phonetic realizations of a phoneme in a language, which do not contribute to distinctions of meaning. For example, in English an aspirated p (as in pin) and unaspirated p (as in spin) are allophones of /p/, whereas in ancient Greek the distinction was phonemic.
(especially in Quebec) an immigrant whose first language is neither French nor English.

--Word--
overtop 
--Type--
verb
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Exceed in height.
(especially of water) rise over the top of (a barrier)
Be superior to.
Over.
--Examples--
‘no building is allowed to overtop the cathedral’

--Word--
allow 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Let (someone) have or do something.
Let (someone) enter a place or go in a particular direction.
Declare or decide that (an event or activity) is legal or acceptable.
Give the necessary time or opportunity for.
Make provision or provide scope for.
Take (something) into consideration when making plans or calculations.
Provide or set aside for a particular purpose.
Admit the truth of; concede.
Be of the opinion; assert.
--Examples--
‘the dissident was allowed to leave the country’
‘she was allowed a higher profile’
‘the river was patrolled and few people were allowed across’
‘political advertising on television is not allowed’
‘they agreed to a ceasefire to allow talks with the government’
‘he stopped to allow his eyes to adjust’
‘the house was demolished to allow for road widening’
‘income rose by 11 per cent allowing for inflation’
‘allow an hour or so for driving’
‘he allowed that the penalty appeared too harsh for the crime’
‘‘Could happen,’ she allowed indifferently’
‘Lincoln allowed that he himself could never support the man’
--Word--
allowable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Allowed, especially within a set of regulations; permissible.
(of an amount of money) able to be earned or received free of tax.
--Examples--
‘the loan deal has been extended to the maximum allowable three months’
‘tax is payable after deduction of allowable expenses’

allowableness

--Meanings--

--Word--
allowably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
allowance 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The amount of something that is permitted, especially within a set of regulations or for a specified purpose.
An amount of money that can be earned or received free of tax.
A deduction in the weight that a horse is required to carry in a race.
A sum of money paid regularly to a person to meet needs or expenses.
A small amount of money given regularly to a child by their parents.
Tolerance.
Give (someone) a sum of money as an allowance.
--Examples--
‘your baggage allowance’
‘a personal allowance’
‘the elderly receive a heating allowance every winter’
‘the allowance of slavery in the South’
‘I have made up my mind to allowance him’

‘‘Could happen,’ she allowed indifferently’
‘Lincoln allowed that he himself could never support the man’
--Word--
allow 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Let (someone) have or do something.
Let (someone) enter a place or go in a particular direction.
Declare or decide that (an event or activity) is legal or acceptable.
Give the necessary time or opportunity for.
Make provision or provide scope for.
Take (something) into consideration when making plans or calculations.
Provide or set aside for a particular purpose.
Admit the truth of; concede.
Be of the opinion; assert.
--Examples--
‘the dissident was allowed to leave the country’
‘she was allowed a higher profile’
‘the river was patrolled and few people were allowed across’
‘political advertising on television is not allowed’
‘they agreed to a ceasefire to allow talks with the government’
‘he stopped to allow his eyes to adjust’
‘the house was demolished to allow for road widening’
‘income rose by 11 per cent allowing for inflation’
‘allow an hour or so for driving’
‘he allowed that the penalty appeared too harsh for the crime’
‘‘Could happen,’ she allowed indifferently’
‘Lincoln allowed that he himself could never support the man’

(of a person) not prone to speak much; taciturn.
--Examples--
‘the wood was still and silent’
‘she fell silent for a moment’
‘a silent prayer’
‘a silent ‘h’’
‘she appeared in a number of silent films’
‘the poems are silent on the question of marriage’
‘I'm the strong, silent type’

weak 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking the power to perform physically demanding tasks; having little physical strength or energy.
Lacking power or influence.
(of a team or military force) containing too few members or members of insufficient quality.
(of a faculty or part of the body) not able to fulfil its functions properly.
Of a low standard; performing or performed badly.
Not convincing or logically forceful.
Exerting only a small force.
Liable to break or give way under pressure; easily damaged.
Lacking the force of character to hold to one's own decisions, beliefs, or principles; irresolute.
(of a belief) not held with conviction or intensity.
(of prices or a market) having a downward tendency.
Lacking intensity or brightness.
(of a liquid or solution) heavily diluted.
Displaying or characterized by a lack of enthusiasm or energy.
(of features) not striking or strongly marked.
(of a syllable) unstressed.
Denoting a class of verbs in Germanic languages that form the past tense and past participle by addition of a suffix (in English, typically -ed).
Relating to or denoting the weakest of the known kinds of force between particles, which is very much weaker than the electromagnetic and the strong interactions, and conserves neither strangeness, parity, nor isospin.
--Examples--
‘she was recovering from flu, and was very weak’
‘the central government had grown too weak to impose order’
‘the new king used his powers to protect the weak’
‘their problems arose from fielding weak teams in league matches’
‘he had a weak stomach’
‘the choruses on this recording are weak’
‘the argument is an extremely weak one’
‘a weak plot’
‘a weak magnetic field’
‘the salamander's tail may be broken off at a weak spot near the base’
‘he was not weak or a compromiser’
‘their commitment to the project is weak’
‘a weak light from a single street lamp’
‘a cup of weak coffee’
‘she managed a weak, nervous smile’
‘his beard covered a weak chin’

--Word--
working 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having paid employment.
Engaged in manual labour.
Relating to, suitable for, or for the purpose of work.
(of an animal) used in farming, hunting, or for guard duties; not kept as a pet or for show.
Functioning or able to function.
(of parts of a machine) moving and causing a machine to operate.
(of a theory, definition, or title) used as the basis for work or argument and likely to be developed or improved later.
Sufficient to work with at a basic level.
The action of doing work.
A scheduled duty or trip performed by a locomotive, train, bus, or other vehicle.
The way in which a machine, organization, or system operates.
The record of the successive calculations made in solving a mathematical problem.
A mine or a part of a mine from which minerals are being extracted.
--Examples--
‘the size of the working population’
‘the vote is no longer sufficient protection for the working man’
‘improvements in living and working conditions’
‘the Norfolk Terrier was developed as a working dog on farms’
‘the mill still has a working waterwheel’
‘the working parts of a digital watch’
‘his working title for the book was Why People Are Poor’
‘they have a working knowledge of contract law’
‘working with animals teaches patience’
‘locomotive 37418 is often seen on this working’
‘we will be less secretive about the workings of government’
‘show details of workings in your answer book’
‘a modern mine on the site of old workings’

The former capital of the central Asian republic of Kazakhstan; population 1,247,900 (est. 2006).
--Examples--
--Word--
almucantar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A circle on the celestial sphere parallel to the horizon; a parallel of altitude.
A telescope mounted on a float resting on mercury, used to determine stellar altitude and azimuth.
--Examples--

almacenista 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Spain: a wine dealer and stockholder who buys sherry directly from the producer and sells it on to bottlers or shippers.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Almagest 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An influential treatise on astronomy written by the Greek astronomer and geographer Ptolemy in the second century AD.
(in the Middle Ages) any celebrated textbook on astrology and alchemy.
--Examples--
--Word--
Almagest 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An influential treatise on astronomy written by the Greek astronomer and geographer Ptolemy in the second century AD.
(in the Middle Ages) any celebrated textbook on astrology and alchemy.
--Examples--
--Word--
almagre 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Especially in Spain and Spanish-speaking countries: red ochre.
--Examples--
--Word--
Almain 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Germany or the lands corresponding to modern Germany; a German. Chiefly archaic and literary in later use.
A kind of dance, especially one of a form cultivated in the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries in England, similar to (and sometimes identified with) the allemande, but typically livelier and accompanied by a simpler melody. Now historical.
Music. A piece of music based on or accompanying an Almain. Compare "allemande". Now chiefly historical.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Germany or the German language; German. Now archaic and historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
Almain 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Germany or the lands corresponding to modern Germany; a German. Chiefly archaic and literary in later use.
A kind of dance, especially one of a form cultivated in the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries in England, similar to (and sometimes identified with) the allemande, but typically livelier and accompanied by a simpler melody. Now historical.
Music. A piece of music based on or accompanying an Almain. Compare "allemande". Now chiefly historical.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Germany or the German language; German. Now archaic and historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
almain rivet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of flexible light armour, originating in Germany, and featuring overlapping plates sliding on rivets; a suit or piece of this armour.

almanac 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An annual calendar containing important dates and statistical information such as astronomical data and tide tables.
A handbook, typically published annually, containing information of general interest or on a sport or pastime.

almendron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several tropical trees bearing nuts resembling almonds; especially the Brazil nut tree, Bertholletia excelsa, of forests on the banks of the Amazon and Rio Negro, and the Indian almond, Terminalia catappa, native to south East Asia and cultivated in parts of tropical America.

--Meanings--

almighty 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having complete power; omnipotent.
Very great; enormous.
A name or title for God.
--Examples--
‘I swear by almighty God’
‘the silence was broken by an almighty roar’
‘I wanted to beg the Almighty for mercy’
--Word--
almightily 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With great strength, vigour, or power; employing or embodying superhuman or divine power.
To a high degree, to a great extent; greatly, very much. Now chiefly informal.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
The quality or fact of being almighty; omnipotence. Also in weakened sense: prevailing strength, supremacy.

--Word--
almond 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The oval edible nutlike seed (kernel) of the almond tree, growing in a woody shell, widely used as food.
The tree that produces almonds, related to the peach and plum. Native to western Asia, it is widely cultivated in warm climates.
--Examples--
‘almond biscuits’
--Word--
almond-eyed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having almond-shaped eyes.
--Examples--
--Word--
furnace 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enclosed structure in which material can be heated to very high temperatures, e.g. for smelting metals.
An appliance fired by gas or oil in which air or water is heated to be circulated throughout a building in a heating system.
Used to describe a very hot place.
--Examples--
‘her car was a furnace’

almondy

adjective
--Meanings--

noun

alnage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fee or duty charged for alnage of cloth; the revenue raised by this means.
The action of formally determining whether woollen cloth conforms to particular standards of shape and quality, as required at various times under British law; attestation that these standards have been achieved, by the affixing of a lead seal.

alnöite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark, alkaline, intrusive igneous rock chiefly composed of augite, biotite, and olivine phenocrysts in a groundmass of augite and melilite.
--Examples--
--Word--
alocasia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants constituting the genus Alocasia (family Araceae), comprising rhizomatous and tuberous perennials native chiefly to tropical Asia, which have large cordate or sagittate leaves borne on long petioles, and are grown for ornament and sometimes as a food crop. Also (in form Alocasia): this genus itself.

--Meanings--

--Word--
aloe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A succulent plant with a rosette of thick tapering leaves and bell-shaped or tubular flowers on long stems, native to the Old World.
A strong laxative obtained from the bitter juice of various kinds of aloe.
The fragrant heartwood of a tropical Asian tree.
The resin obtained from aloes wood, used in perfume, incense, and medicine.
--Examples--
--Word--
aloed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Bitter; full of pain, sadness, or affliction. Also in literal use: mixed or flavoured with aloes.

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
alone 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Having no one else present; on one's own.
Without others' help or participation; single-handed.
Isolated and lonely.
Indicating that something is confined to the specified subject or recipient.
Used to emphasize that only one factor out of several is being considered and that the whole is greater or more extreme.
--Examples--
‘she was alone that evening’
‘he lives alone’
‘team members are more effective than individuals working alone’
‘they were not alone in dissenting from the advice’
‘she was terribly alone and exposed’
‘he is answerable to Parliament alone’
‘it was a smile for him alone’
‘there were fifteen churches in the town centre alone’

--Word--
along 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Moving in a constant direction on (a more or less horizontal surface)
Used to refer to the passage of time or the making of progress.
Extending in a more or less horizontal line on.
In or into company with others.
--Examples--
‘soon we were driving along a narrow road’
‘he saw Gray run along the top of the wall’
‘we continued to plod along’
‘you'll pick up some valuable tips along the way’
‘they asked how the construction was coming along’
‘cars were parked along the grass verge’
‘the path along the cliff’
‘he had brought along a friend of his’
--Word--
alongships 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In line with the length of the ship; in a lengthwise direction; fore and aft. Contrasted with "athwart-ships".
--Examples--

alp 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A high mountain, especially a snow-capped one.
(in Switzerland) an area of green pasture on a mountainside.
Australian Labor Party.
--Examples--
--Word--
alpaca 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long-haired domesticated South American mammal related to the llama, valued for its wool.
The wool of the alpaca.
Fabric made from alpaca wool.
--Examples--
‘a mixture of wool, alpaca, and silk’
‘an alpaca jersey’

noun

alpestrine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: of or characteristic of mountains, especially the Alps. In later use: (specifically) designating a zone of vegetation growing below the tree line in a mountainous habitat; of or characteristic of this zone.
--Examples--
--Word--
alpha 
--Type--
noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
The first letter of the Greek alphabet (Α, α), transliterated as ‘a’.
Denoting the first of a series of items or categories, e.g. forms of a chemical compound.
A first-class mark given for an examination paper or piece of school or college work.
Denoting the dominant animal or human in a particular group.
Denoting a person who has a dominant role or position within a particular sphere.
The first (typically the brightest) star in a constellation.
Relating to alpha decay or alpha particles.
A code word representing the letter A, used in radio communication.
A plane angle.
Angular acceleration.
Right ascension.
--Examples--
‘the α and β chains of haemoglobin’
‘he had been awarded alpha double plus’
‘the pack is a tightly knit, highly organized group, led by an alpha wolf’
‘take turns cooking for each other if one of you is too much of an alpha chef’
‘Alpha Orionis’
‘an alpha emitter’
--Word--
amylase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enzyme, found chiefly in saliva and pancreatic fluid, that converts starch and glycogen into simple sugars.
--Examples--
--Word--
alphabet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A set of letters or symbols in a fixed order used to represent the basic set of speech sounds of a language, especially the set of letters from A to Z.
The basic elements in a system which combine to form complex entities.
--Examples--
‘the first letter of the alphabet’
‘a phonetic alphabet’
‘DNA's 4-letter alphabet’
--Word--
alphabetarian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is learning the alphabet or who is engaged in elementary education; one who is inexperienced in a particular subject; a novice, a beginner. Compare "abecedarian". Now somewhat rare.
--Examples--

--Word--
alphabetism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Representation of spoken sounds by means of letters.
Originally US. Prejudice or discrimination resulting from a person's position on a (notional) alphabetical list; specifically discrimination against people whose names begin with letters from the latter part of the alphabet.
--Examples--

alpha cellulose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of cellulose consisting of long polymer chains; specifically the portion of a cellulosic material that is insoluble in sodium hydroxide solution.

noun

--Word--
tocopherol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several closely related compounds, found in wheatgerm oil, egg yolk, and leafy vegetables, which collectively constitute vitamin E. They are fat-soluble alcohols with antioxidant properties, important in the stabilization of cell membranes.
--Examples--

Mucha, Alphonse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1939), Czech painter and designer; born Alfons Maria. He was a leading figure in the art nouveau movement, noted for his flowing poster designs, typically featuring the actress Sarah Bernhardt.

alpine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to high mountains.
Relating to the Alps.
Relating to or denoting skiing downhill.
A plant native to mountain districts, often suitable for growing in rock gardens.
A North American butterfly which has brownish-black wings with orange-red markings.

‘Alpine guides’
‘an alpine ski team’
‘a collection of alpines and dwarf bulbs’

alpiste 
--Type--

--Word--
Alps 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain system in Europe extending in a curve from the coast of south-eastern France through north-western Italy, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, southern Germany, and Austria into Slovenia. The highest peak of the Alps, Mont Blanc, rises to a height of 4,807 m (15,771 ft).
--Examples--
--Word--
alquifou 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Galena (lead ore) used as the basis of a green pottery glaze, especially in Spain and France; potter's ore.
--Examples--
--Word--
already 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Before or by now or the time in question.
As surprisingly soon or early as this.
Used after a word or phrase to express impatience.
--Examples--
‘Anna has suffered a great deal already’
‘it was already past four o' clock’
‘just stop already, no one feels sorry for you’
--Word--

--Word--
all right 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, exclamation
--Meanings--
Of a satisfactory or acceptable quality.
In a satisfactory mental or physical state.
Permissible; allowable.
In a satisfactory manner or to a satisfactory extent; fairly well.
Used to emphasize how certain one is about something.
Expressing or asking for assent, agreement, or acceptance.
--Examples--
‘the tea was all right’
‘do you feel all right to walk home?’
‘it's all right for you to go now’
‘we get on all right’
‘‘Are you sure it's him?’ ‘It's him all right.’’
‘all right, I'll tell you’
--Word--
ALS 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease affecting motor neurons of the spinal cord, which causes progressive weakness and atrophy of muscles.
--Examples--
‘the rock guitarist was stricken by ALS more than 20 years ago’
--Word--
Alsace 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of north-eastern France, on the borders with Germany and Switzerland. Alsace was annexed by Prussia, along with part of Lorraine (forming Alsace-Lorraine), after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870–1, and restored to France after the First World War.
--Examples--
--Word--
Alsace 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of north-eastern France, on the borders with Germany and Switzerland. Alsace was annexed by Prussia, along with part of Lorraine (forming Alsace-Lorraine), after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870–1, and restored to France after the First World War.

Alsatia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally cant. The precinct of Whitefriars in London, where debtors and criminals were immune from arrest. Now historical.
Allusively. A sanctuary for criminals; a lawless place.

--Word--
alstonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any plant of the genus Alstonia (family Apocynaceae), comprising trees and shrubs with milky sap found in most tropical areas, especially Asia and Australasia, some of which yield a soft, light timber; the wood itself. Also (in form Alstonia): the genus itself.
Any of various medicinal preparations made from the bark or latex of plants of the genus Alstonia, especially the tree A. scholaris of South and South East Asia, and the Australian shrub A. constricta.
--Examples--
--Word--
alstonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral consisting of a double carbonate of calcium and barium, typically occurring as strongly striated colourless or white pseudohexagonal pyramids.
--Examples--
--Word--
alstroemeria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A South American plant with showy flowers similar to those of the lily, cultivated as an ornamental.

--Meanings--
Relating to the Altai Mountains.
Denoting or belonging to a phylum or superfamily of languages which includes the Turkic, Mongolian, Tungusic, and Manchu languages. They are characterized by agglutination and vowel harmony.
The Altaic family of languages.
--Examples--
--Word--
Altair 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The brightest star in the constellation Aquila.
--Examples--
--Word--
altaite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rare mineral consisting of lead telluride, typically occurring in massive aggregates of yellow-tinted tin-white metallic crystals.

Altamira 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The site of a cave with Palaeolithic rock paintings, south of Santander in northern Spain, discovered in 1879.

--Word--
altar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The table in a Christian church at which the bread and wine are consecrated in communion services.
A table or flat-topped block used as the focus for a religious ritual, especially for making sacrifices or offerings to a deity.
--Examples--
--Word--
altarage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The revenue arising from an altar in the form of oblations, offerings, etc.; the right to collect and retain this as income. Also as a count noun (chiefly in plural): an income or revenue so derived.
Chiefly Scottish. An altar maintained for a priest to say mass for a particular individual, family, etc.; a fund, provision, or endowment for this.

--Meanings--

--Word--
altazimuth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A telescope mounting that moves in azimuth (about a vertical axis) and in altitude (about a horizontal axis).
A telescope on an altazimuth mounting.
A surveying instrument for measuring vertical and horizontal angles, resembling a theodolite but larger and more precise.
--Examples--
--Word--
Altdorfer, Albrecht 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1485–1538), German painter and engraver. He was one of the first modern European landscape painters and was principal artist of the Danube School.

Castrate or spay (a domestic animal).

--Word--
alternanthera 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants constituting the cosmopolitan genus Alternanthera (family Amaranthaceae), which comprises low-growing stoloniferous plants (some of which are aquatic), typically having small white flowers and sometimes grown as bedding plants. Also (in form Alternanthera): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
Alternaria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of hyphomycetous fungi which cause various plant diseases; (also alternaria) a fungus of this genus. Frequently attributive: designating a disease caused by such a fungus.
--Examples--
--Word--
alternate 
--Type--
verb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Occur in turn repeatedly.
Do or perform in turn repeatedly.
Change repeatedly between two contrasting conditions.
Every other; every second.
(of two things) each following and succeeded by the other in a regular pattern.
(of leaves or shoots) placed alternately on the two sides of the stem.
A person who acts as a deputy or substitute.
--Examples--
‘bouts of depression alternate with periods of elation’
‘some adults who wish to alternate work with education’
‘the government alternated between the Labour and Conservative parties’
‘she was asked to attend on alternate days’
‘alternate bouts of intense labour and of idleness’
‘a novel set in an alternate universe’
‘he shall be entitled to exercise the vote of the director for whom he is an alternate’

alternative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of one or more things) available as another possibility or choice.
(of two things) mutually exclusive.
Relating to activities that depart from or challenge traditional norms.
One of two or more available possibilities.
--Examples--
‘the various alternative methods for resolving disputes’
‘the facts fit two alternative scenarios’
‘an alternative lifestyle’
‘audio cassettes are an interesting alternative to reading’
‘she had no alternative but to break the law’

altesse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly in French or continental European contexts: a person of high rank, a nobleman or noblewoman. Frequently as a title, usually with possessive and capital initial: ‘Highness’. Sometimes ironic or humorous. Compare altezza. Now historical.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly in Italian or Spanish contexts: a person of high rank; a nobleman or (especially in later use) a noblewoman. Frequently as a title, usually with possessive and capital initial: ‘Highness’.

altezza

--Word--
althea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any plant of, or formerly of, the Eurasian genus Althaea (family Malvaceae), comprising herbaceous perennial plants which include the marsh mallow, A. officinalis, the hollyhock, Alcea rosea, and (more fully "shrub althea") the widely cultivated hibiscus Hibiscus syriacus. Also (in form Althaea): the genus itself.
--Examples--

--Word--
altitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The height of an object or point in relation to sea level or ground level.
Great height.
The apparent height of a celestial object above the horizon, measured in angular distance.
The length of the perpendicular line from a vertex to the opposite side of a figure.
--Examples--
‘flight data including airspeed and altitude’
‘flying at altitudes over 15,000 feet’
‘the mechanism can freeze at altitude’
--Word--
altitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The height of an object or point in relation to sea level or ground level.
Great height.
The apparent height of a celestial object above the horizon, measured in angular distance.
The length of the perpendicular line from a vertex to the opposite side of a figure.

‘flight data including airspeed and altitude’
‘flying at altitudes over 15,000 feet’

Altman, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–2006), American film director. He made his name with MASH (1970), a black comedy set in the Korean war. Other notable films include The Player (1992).

--Word--
alto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(especially in church music) the highest adult male singing voice (sometimes distinguished from the countertenor voice as using falsetto).
The lowest female singing voice; contralto.
A person with an alto voice.
A part written for an alto voice.
Denoting the member of a family of instruments pitched second or third highest.
An alto saxophone.
--Examples--
‘alto flute’

--Word--
altocumulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cloud forming a layer of rounded masses with a level base, occurring at medium altitude (typically 2 to 7 km, 6,500 to 23,000 ft)
--Examples--
‘a layer of altocumulus’
‘altocumuli moved across the sky’
--Word--
altocumulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cloud forming a layer of rounded masses with a level base, occurring at medium altitude (typically 2 to 7 km, 6,500 to 23,000 ft)
--Examples--
‘a layer of altocumulus’
‘altocumuli moved across the sky’
--Word--
cumulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cloud forming rounded masses heaped on each other above a flat base at fairly low altitude.
--Examples--
‘the high cumulus is breaking up to give a lovely summer evening’
‘silent, moving, red-tinged cumuli’

‘I'm not altogether sure that I'd trust him’
‘he had married several times and had forty-six children altogether’
‘altogether it was a great evening’

Altoona 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in south central Pennsylvania, in the Allegheny Mountains; population 46,144 (est. 2008). A noted railroad center, it is near Horseshoe Curve, where rails first crossed the Alleghenies.

--Word--
altricial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a young bird or other animal) hatched or born in an undeveloped state and requiring care and feeding by the parents.
(of a particular species) having altricial young.
--Examples--
--Word--
altruism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others.
Behaviour of an animal that benefits another at its own expense.
--Examples--
‘some may choose to work with vulnerable elderly people out of altruism’
‘reciprocal altruism’
--Word--
altruism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others.
Behaviour of an animal that benefits another at its own expense.
--Examples--
‘some may choose to work with vulnerable elderly people out of altruism’
‘reciprocal altruism’

--Word--
altruistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Showing a disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others; unselfish.
--Examples--
‘it was an entirely altruistic act’
‘I question how altruistic his motives were’

--Word--
alum 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A colourless astringent compound which is a hydrated double sulphate of aluminium and potassium, used in solution in dyeing and tanning.
Any of a number of analogous crystalline double sulphates of a monovalent metal (or group) and a trivalent metal.
A former pupil or student of a school, college, or university; an alumnus or alumna.
--Examples--
‘artificially grown crystals of one of the alums’
‘a fellow Wellesley alum’
--Word--
alum 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A colourless astringent compound which is a hydrated double sulphate of aluminium and potassium, used in solution in dyeing and tanning.
Any of a number of analogous crystalline double sulphates of a monovalent metal (or group) and a trivalent metal.
A former pupil or student of a school, college, or university; an alumnus or alumna.
--Examples--
‘artificially grown crystals of one of the alums’
‘a fellow Wellesley alum’
--Word--
Alumbrado 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of any of several Christian groups active in Spain (or its colonies) in the 16th and 17th centuries, and accused of heresy by the Spanish Inquisition; specifically (a) a movement active in the 16th cent. which challenged the authority of the Church in various matters, particularly by emphasizing direct communion with God; (b) a group of perfectionists or antinomians active in the 17th cent. Also in extended use: a person who makes a (false) claim to spiritual enlightenment.
--Examples--
--Word--
Alumel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: a nickel alloy, typically containing approx. 2 per cent aluminium, 2.5 per cent manganese, and 1 per cent silicon, used in thermocouples, often in conjunction with Chromel.
--Examples--
--Word--
alumen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The mineral alum.

alumian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white mineral originally thought to consist of aluminium sulphate and now identified with natroalunite.

alumina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

aluminate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A compound or salt in which alumina or aluminium hydroxide is combined with an alkali or base. Also: any of various oxyanions or hydroxy anions of aluminium; a compound containing such an anion.
To coat or cover with aluminium; to treat or cause to react with aluminium; to introduce aluminium into.

alumino-ferric 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Containing both aluminium and iron; specifically designating the substance alumino-ferric; relating to this substance.
An impure form of aluminium sulphate containing ferric oxide, used especially as a coagulating and flocculating agent for water purification, sewage treatment, etc.

aluminosilicate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
aluminothermy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The production of high temperatures by the use of aluminium powder as a reducing agent, especially in a reaction with ferric oxide; reaction of aluminium in this way, with the liberation of heat.

--Word--
alumnus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A former pupil or student, especially a male one, of a particular school, college, or university.
A former member of a group, company, or organization.
--Examples--
‘a Harvard alumnus’
‘a mixture of news about the University and articles by alumni’
‘a Royal Ballet alumnus’
‘the Pop Idol alumnus revealed a hitherto hidden falsetto’

--Word--
alundum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: a hard, heat-resistant material produced by fusing alumina in an electric furnace, used chiefly as an abrasive agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
alunite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral which was historically an important source of alum and is now mined for potassium and aluminium, and which occurs in granular or compact masses and also as tabular or rhombohedral crystals, colourless when pure but often yellowish or reddish-brown owing to impurities.
--Examples--
--Word--
alunite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral which was historically an important source of alum and is now mined for potassium and aluminium, and which occurs in granular or compact masses and also as tabular or rhombohedral crystals, colourless when pure but often yellowish or reddish-brown owing to impurities.
--Examples--
--Word--
alunogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral consisting of hydrated aluminium sulphate, typically occurring as masses of feathery or fibrous crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
Alur 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people inhabiting the Nile region of northern Uganda.
The Nilotic language of this people.
Of, belonging to, or designating the Alur or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
alure 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A gallery, balcony, or other (often covered) walkway; specifically (a) one behind the parapets of a castle, tower, etc.; a parapet walk; (b) a covered passageway, a cloister. Also occasionally: †an aisle (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
alutaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a surface: having a texture like that of leather; covered in minute cracks. Formerly also: †having a tan colour (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
al- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Myrdal, Alva 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1902–86), Swedish diplomat and peace activist; full name Alva Reimer Myrdal ; wife of Gunnar Myrdal. She served the United Nations as director of social welfare 1949–50 and was Swedish ambassador to India 1955–61. An advocate of disarmament, she wrote The Game of Disarmament (1976). Nobel Peace Prize (1982), shared with Alfonso Garcia Robles (1911–91).
--Examples--
--Word--
alvar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A region of limestone pavement or plain with little or no soil and vegetation, occurring chiefly in Sweden and Estonia in Europe and in parts of the northern United States and Canada.
--Examples--
--Word--
Alvarez, Luis Walter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–88), American physicist. In 1980 Alvarez and his son identified iridium in sediment from the Cretaceous–Tertiary boundary and proposed that this resulted from a catastrophic meteorite impact that may have resulted in the extinction of the dinosaurs.
--Examples--
--Word--

alveolar 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to an alveolus or the alveoli of the lung or lungs.
Relating to or denoting the bony ridge that contains the sockets of the upper teeth.
(of a consonant) pronounced with the tip of the tongue on or near the alveolar ridge (e.g. n, s, d, t)
An alveolar consonant.
--Examples--
‘voiced and voiceless alveolar stops’
‘boundaries between alveolars and palatals’

alveolus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

An acinus (saclike cavity) in a gland.
The bony socket for the root of a tooth.

alveolo-palatal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Dentistry and Surgery. Of, relating to, or involving the alveolar ridge and the palate or palatine bone. Now rare.
Phonetics. = alveopalatal.

--Word--
Toffler, Alvin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1928–2016), US futurist and writer. He first gained popularity with the publication of Future Shock (1970), coauthored with his wife, Heidi Toffler. Their other coauthored works include The Third Wave (1980), Powershift (1991), and Revolutionary Wealth (2006).
--Examples--
--Word--
alvine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating an excretion from the intestines or (rarely) other organ of the belly. Also: designating the intestinal tract; of or relating to the intestinal tract.
--Examples--
--Word--
alvite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A reddish-brown amorphous mineral found in pegmatites which is an altered or metamict variety of zircon, with elevated concentrations of hafnium, rare earths, and radioactive elements.
--Examples--
--Word--
alway 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
always 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
At all times; on all occasions.
Throughout a long period of the past.
For all future time; forever.
Repeatedly and annoyingly.
As a last resort; failing all else.
--Examples--
‘the sun always rises in the east’
‘Isabel had always been in rude health’
‘she will always be missed’
‘she is always making derogatory remarks’
‘if the marriage doesn't work out, we can always get divorced’
--Word--
Alzheimer's 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Progressive mental deterioration that can occur in middle or old age, due to generalized degeneration of the brain. It is the commonest cause of premature senility.
--Examples--

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A satellite of Jupiter, the third closest to the planet, being reddish in colour and heavily cratered (262 km long and 146 km across).
--Examples--
--Word--
Amana Colonies 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of seven villages in east central Iowa. Settled by a German religious group, they are famous for manufacturing appliances.

Amapá 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of northern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast, lying between the Amazon delta and the border with French Guiana; capital, Macapá. It is a region of dense rainforest.

amass 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Gather together or accumulate (a large amount or number of material or things) over a period of time.
Gather together in a crowd or group.
--Examples--
‘he amassed a fortune estimated at close to a million pounds’
‘the soldiers were amassing from all parts of Spain’
--Word--
amassment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The accumulation of wealth or other resources.
A mass or quantity of something that has gradually gathered or been acquired.
--Examples--
‘capitalism encourages the amassment of money’
‘the sheer amassment of evidence seems convincing’
‘amassments of words’

Amaterasu

--Meanings--

--Word--
amateur 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who engages in a pursuit, especially a sport, on an unpaid basis.
A person who is contemptibly inept at a particular activity.
Engaging or engaged in without payment; non-professional.
Done in an inept or unskilful way.
--Examples--
‘it takes five years for a top amateur to become a real Tour de France rider’
‘his last fight as an amateur’
‘that bunch of stumbling amateurs’
‘an amateur archaeologist’
‘amateur athletics’
‘it's all so amateur!’

adjective
--Meanings--
Done in an unskilful or inept way.
--Examples--
‘her amateurish interviewing technique’

--Word--
Amati 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A family of Italian violin-makers from Cremona. In the 16th and 17th centuries three generations of the Amatis developed the basic proportions of the violin, viola, and cello.

--Word--
amazing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing great surprise or wonder; astonishing.
Very impressive; excellent.
--Examples--
‘an amazing number of people registered’
‘it is amazing how short memories are’
‘she makes the most amazing cakes’
--Word--
amazingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that causes great surprise or wonder.
Very impressively or well.
Very; extremely (usually expressing approval)
--Examples--
‘amazingly, 66 passengers and crew members survived’
‘I genuinely thought Rachel sang amazingly’
‘there's an amazingly diverse range of work under one roof’
‘there are so many amazingly good clarets’
--Word--
Amazon 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A river in South America, flowing over 6,683 km (4,150 miles) through Peru, Colombia, and Brazil into the Atlantic Ocean. It drains two fifths of the continent and in terms of water flow it is the largest river in the world.
A member of a legendary race of female warriors believed by the ancient Greeks to exist in Scythia (near the Black Sea in modern Russia) or elsewhere on the edge of the known world.
A very tall and strong or athletic woman.
A parrot, typically green, found in Central and South America.
--Examples--
--Word--
Amazonas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of NW Brazil; capital, Manaus. It is crossed by the Amazon and its numerous tributaries.
--Examples--
--Word--
Amazonas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of NW Brazil; capital, Manaus. It is crossed by the Amazon and its numerous tributaries.
--Examples--
--Word--
Amazonia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The area around the River Amazon in South America, principally in Brazil, but also extending into Peru, Colombia, and Bolivia. The region comprises approximately one third of the world's remaining tropical rainforest.
A national park protecting 10,000 sq. km (3,850 sq. miles) of tropical rainforest in the state of Pará, northern Brazil.
--Examples--
--Word--
Amazonian 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the River Amazon or its surrounding region.
(of a woman) tall and strong or athletic.
--Examples--
‘the Amazonian rainforest’
‘Amazonian supermodels’
‘an Amazonian physique’

--Word--
amber 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Hard translucent fossilized resin originating from extinct coniferous trees of the Tertiary period, typically yellowish in colour. It has been used in jewellery since antiquity.
A honey-yellow colour typical of amber.
A yellow light used as a cautionary signal between green for ‘go’ and red for ‘stop’
--Examples--
‘her eyes were green flecked with amber’
‘amber eyes’
‘the lights were at amber’

ambidextrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

(of an implement) designed to be used by left-handed and right-handed people with equal ease.

‘few of us are naturally ambidextrous’
‘an ambidextrous tile gauge’

--Word--
ambiguous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning.
Not clear or decided.
--Examples--
‘ambiguous phrases’
‘the election result was ambiguous’
--Word--
ambiguously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
So as to be open to more than one interpretation.
So as to be open to doubt or uncertainty.
--Examples--
‘the new clause is ambiguously worded’
‘a peculiar, ambiguously remembered landscape where past and present seem repeatedly confounded’

ambiguousness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
ambition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strong desire to do or achieve something.

--Examples--

‘he achieved his ambition of making a fortune’
‘young men and women with ambition’

--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or showing a strong desire and determination to succeed.
(of a plan or piece of work) intended to satisfy high aspirations and therefore difficult to achieve.

‘a ruthlessly ambitious workaholic’
‘an ambitious enterprise’

--Type--
noun, noun

--Word--
Perth Amboy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A historic industrial city in northeastern New Jersey, on the Raritan River, across the Arthur Kill from Staten Island in New York; population 48,742 (est. 2008).

Ambon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountainous island in eastern Indonesia, one of the Molucca Islands.
A port on the island of Ambon, the capital of the Molucca Islands; population 204,200 (est. 2005).

--Word--
Bierce, Ambrose 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1842–c.1914), American writer, best known for his sardonic short stories and The Devil's Dictionary (1911); full name Ambrose Gwinnett Bierce. In 1913 he travelled to Mexico and mysteriously disappeared.

--Word--
ace 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
A person who excels at a particular sport or other activity.
A pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft.
(in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point.
A hole in one.
Very good.
(in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
Score an ace on (a hole) or with (a shot)
Achieve high marks in (a test or exam)
Outdo someone in a competitive situation.
--Examples--
‘the ace of diamonds’
‘life had started dealing him aces again’
‘a motorcycle ace’
‘a Battle of Britain ace’
‘Nadal banged down eight aces in the set’
‘his hole in one at the 15th was Senior's second ace as a professional’
‘an ace swimmer’
‘Ace! You've done it!’
‘he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph’
‘there was a prize for the first player to ace the hole’
‘I aced my grammar test’
‘the magazine won an award, acing out its rivals’
--Word--
ambulacrum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in an echinoderm) each of the radially arranged bands, together with their underlying structures, through which the double rows of tube feet protrude.

ambulance 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A vehicle equipped for taking sick or injured people to and from hospital, especially in emergencies.

--Examples--
‘we called an ambulance’
‘he taken by ambulance to the district hospital’
‘the ambulance service’
‘he was ambulanced to accident and emergency’

ambulatory 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or adapted for walking.
(of a patient) able to walk about; ambulant.
Movable; mobile.
A place for walking, especially an aisle or cloister in a church or monastery.
--Examples--
‘continuous ambulatory dialysis’
‘five similar pairs of ambulatory legs’
‘an ambulatory ophthalmic service’
‘the front arch of the old ambulatory’

--Word--
ambush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A surprise attack by people lying in wait in a concealed position.
Make a surprise attack on (someone) from a concealed position.
Confront (someone) suddenly and unexpectedly with unwelcome questions.
--Examples--
‘seven members of a patrol were killed in an ambush’
‘kidnappers waiting in ambush’
‘they were ambushed and taken prisoner by the enemy’
‘Tory representatives were ambushed by camera crews’

amoeba 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A single-celled animal that catches food and moves about by extending fingerlike projections of protoplasm. Amoebas are either free-living in damp environments or parasitic.
--Examples--

--Word--
Modigliani, Amedeo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1920), Italian painter and sculptor, resident in France from 1906. His portraits and nudes are noted for their elongated forms, linear qualities, and earthy colours.

--Word--
Bloomer, Amelia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1818–94), US suffragette and social reformer; full name Amelia Jenks Bloomer. She founded and edited 1849–55 the feminist paper Lily, and she wore full pants that came to be known as “bloomers.”.
--Examples--

--Word--
amend 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make minor changes to (a text, piece of legislation, etc.) in order to make it fairer or more accurate, or to reflect changing circumstances.
Improve the texture or fertility of (soil)
Put right.
--Examples--
‘the rule was amended to apply only to non-members’
‘amend your soil with peat moss or compost’
‘a few things had gone wrong, but these had been amended’

Put right.
--Examples--
‘the rule was amended to apply only to non-members’
‘amend your soil with peat moss or compost’
‘a few things had gone wrong, but these had been amended’
--Word--
amendment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A minor change or addition designed to improve a text, piece of legislation, etc.
An article added to the US Constitution.
Something which is added to soil in order to improve its texture or fertility.
--Examples--
‘an amendment to existing bail laws’
‘the First Amendment’
‘you can add some soil-texturizing amendments to improve soil drainage’

America 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

Used as a name for the United States.
--Examples--

American 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the United States or its inhabitants.
Relating to the continents of America.
A native or citizen of the United States.
A native or inhabitant of any of the countries of North, South, or Central America.
The English language as it is used in the United States; American English.

‘the election of a new American president’
‘the American continent south of the tropic of Cancer’
