--Word--
Americanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word, expression, or other feature that is characteristic of American English.
A custom, quality, or institution characteristic of the United States.
Attachment or allegiance to the traditions, institutions, and ideals of the United States.
--Examples--
‘the term is an Americanism dating back to the late nineteenth century’
‘Americanisms such as the barbecue and the swimming pool’
‘Americans in Europe have almost all preserved their Americanism’

noun

americium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 95, a radioactive metal of the actinide series. Americium does not occur naturally and was first made by bombarding plutonium with neutrons.

--Word--
Vespucci, Amerigo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1451–1512), Italian merchant and explorer. He travelled to the New World, reaching the coast of Venezuela on his first voyage (1499–1500) and exploring the Brazilian coastline in 1501–2. The Latin form of his first name is believed to have given rise to the name of America.
--Examples--

proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–2003), Ugandan soldier and head of state 1971–9; full name Idi Amin Dada. Amin overthrew President Obote in a coup, and was deposed after a period of rule characterized by the murder of political opponents.
--Examples--
--Word--
amino 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The group —NH₂, present in amino acids, amides, and many amines.
--Examples--
‘isocyanic acid reacts with amino groups’
‘amino compounds’
--Word--
amino- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Designating or containing the group —NH₂
--Examples--
‘aminobutyric’
--Word--
para-aminobenzoic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline acid which is widely distributed in plant and animal tissue, and has been used to treat rickettsial infections.
--Examples--
--Word--
amino- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Designating or containing the group —NH₂
--Examples--
‘aminobutyric’
--Word--
aminotransferase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘patients with elevated aminotransferase levels’
--Word--
Amin, Idi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–2003), Ugandan soldier and head of state 1971–9; full name Idi Amin Dada. Amin overthrew President Obote in a coup, and was deposed after a period of rule characterized by the murder of political opponents.

--Word--
Amis, Martin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1949), English novelist, son of Kingsley Amis; full name Martin Louis Amis. Notable works: The Rachel Papers (1973), Money (1984), Time's Arrow (1991), and Night Train (1997).
--Examples--
--Word--
Amish 
--Type--
plural noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The members of a strict Mennonite sect founded by the Swiss preacher Jakob Amman (or Amen) (c.1645–c.1730). Now living mainly in Pennsylvania and Ohio, the Amish migrated to North America from c.1720.
Relating to the Amish.
--Examples--
--Word--
amiss 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Not quite right; inappropriate or out of place.
Wrongly or inappropriately.
--Examples--
‘there was something amiss about his calculations’
‘the prime minister may have constructed his cabinet a little amiss’

--Word--
ammonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless gas with a characteristic pungent smell, which dissolves in water to give a strongly alkaline solution.
A solution of ammonia, used as a cleaning fluid.
--Examples--

ammonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ammonoid fossil, especially one of a later type found chiefly in the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods, typically with intricately frilled suture lines.

--Word--
ammonoid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An extinct cephalopod mollusc with a flat-coiled spiral shell, found commonly as a fossil in marine deposits from the Devonian to the Cretaceous periods.
Relating to the ammonoids.
--Examples--
--Word--
ammonoid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An extinct cephalopod mollusc with a flat-coiled spiral shell, found commonly as a fossil in marine deposits from the Devonian to the Cretaceous periods.
Relating to the ammonoids.

--Word--
amnesiac 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person experiencing a partial or total loss of memory.
Experiencing or relating to a partial or total loss of memory.
--Examples--
‘amnesiacs commonly retain many of their old skills after the onset of amnesia’
‘the police last night launched a public appeal to help identify an amnesiac woman’
‘she stumbles back into town in an amnesiac daze’

--Word--
amnesty 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An official pardon for people who have been convicted of political offences.
An undertaking by the authorities to take no action against specified offences during a fixed period.
Grant an official pardon to.
--Examples--
‘an amnesty for political prisoners’
‘a month-long weapons amnesty’
‘the guerrillas would be amnestied and allowed to return to civilian life’
--Word--
amnestic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

amnion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The innermost membrane that encloses the embryo of a mammal, bird, or reptile.
--Examples--
--Word--
amniocentesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A process in which amniotic fluid is sampled using a hollow needle inserted into the uterus, to screen for abnormalities in the developing fetus.

--Word--
amoeba 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A single-celled animal that catches food and moves about by extending fingerlike projections of protoplasm. Amoebas are either free-living in damp environments or parasitic.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
amole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of a group native to Mexico and the southern US whose roots are used as detergent, especially the soap-plant, Chlorogalum pomeridianum, or the lechuguilla, Agave lecheguilla.
--Examples--
--Word--
amole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of a group native to Mexico and the southern US whose roots are used as detergent, especially the soap-plant, Chlorogalum pomeridianum, or the lechuguilla, Agave lecheguilla.
--Examples--
--Word--
Amun 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A supreme god of the ancient Egyptians, identified with the sun god Ra, and in Greek and Roman times with Zeus and Jupiter (under the name Ammon).
--Examples--
--Word--
among 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
Situated more or less centrally in relation to (several other things)
Being a member or members of (a larger set)
Occurring in or shared by (some members of a group or community)
Indicating a division, choice, or differentiation involving three or more participants.
--Examples--
‘flowers hidden among the roots of the trees’
‘you're among friends’
‘a British woman was among the 54 victims of the disaster’
‘snakes are among the animals most feared by man’
‘a drop in tooth decay among children’
‘members of the government bickered among themselves’
‘the old king called the three princesses to divide his kingdom among them’
‘the State Council would elect a temporary president from among its members’
--Word--
among 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
Situated more or less centrally in relation to (several other things)
Being a member or members of (a larger set)
Occurring in or shared by (some members of a group or community)
Indicating a division, choice, or differentiation involving three or more participants.

‘flowers hidden among the roots of the trees’
‘you're among friends’
‘a British woman was among the 54 victims of the disaster’
‘snakes are among the animals most feared by man’
‘a drop in tooth decay among children’
‘members of the government bickered among themselves’
‘the old king called the three princesses to divide his kingdom among them’
‘the State Council would elect a temporary president from among its members’

--Word--
Amorite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a semi-nomadic people living in Mesopotamia, Palestine, and Syria in the 3rd millennium BC, founders of the ancient city of Mari on the Euphrates and the first dynasty of Babylon.
Relating to the Amorites.
--Examples--
--Word--
amoroso 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
(especially as a direction) in a loving or tender manner.
A dark, sweet sherry.
--Examples--

--Word--
amorphous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without a clearly defined shape or form.
Lacking a clear structure or focus.
(of a solid) not crystalline, or not apparently crystalline.
--Examples--
‘an amorphous, characterless conurbation’
‘amorphous blue forms and straight black lines’
‘an amorphous and leaderless legislature’
‘an amorphous polymer’

--Meanings--

--Word--
morrow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The following day.
The time following an event.
The near future.
--Examples--
‘on the morrow they attacked the city’
‘in the morrow of great victory’
‘the religious enthusiast who takes no thought for the morrow’
--Word--
amortize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Gradually write off the initial cost of (an asset) over a period.
Reduce or pay off (a debt) with regular payments.
Transfer (land) to a corporation in mortmain.
--Examples--
‘the vessel's owners could not amortize her high capital costs’
‘eighty per cent of the proceeds has been used to amortize the public debt’
‘lands amortized without licence’

--Word--
Amos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Hebrew minor prophet (c.760 BC), a shepherd of Tekoa, near Jerusalem.
A book of the Bible containing the prophecies of Amos.
--Examples--

amosite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An iron-rich amphibole asbestos, mined in South Africa.
--Examples--
--Word--
amount 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A quantity of something, especially the total of a thing or things in number, size, value, or extent.
A sum of money.
Come to be (the total) when added together.
Be regarded or classified as; be the equivalent of.
Develop into; become.
--Examples--
‘sport gives an enormous amount of pleasure to many people’
‘the substance is harmless if taken in small amounts’
‘they have spent a colossal amount rebuilding the stadium’
‘losses amounted to over 10 million pounds’
‘their actions amounted to a conspiracy’
‘what this guy was doing clearly did amount to persecution’
‘you'll never amount to anything’
--Word--
amount 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A quantity of something, especially the total of a thing or things in number, size, value, or extent.
A sum of money.

‘what this guy was doing clearly did amount to persecution’
‘you'll never amount to anything’

--Word--
amp 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Play (music) through electric amplification.
Full of nervous energy, especially through taking amphetamines or similar drugs.
Adenosine monophosphate.
--Examples--
‘their willingness to amp up traditional songs virtually began the folk-rock genre’
‘I've got all this manic energy. I feel amped’

--Word--
AMPA 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Alpha-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid, an excitatory amino acid which acts as an agonist at a particular class of glutamate receptor; frequently attributive, designating receptors of this class.

amphetamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A synthetic, addictive, mood-altering drug, used illegally as a stimulant.
--Examples--
‘the amphetamine put him on a high for an hour’
‘he was jailed for three months for possessing amphetamines’
--Word--
amphetamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A synthetic, addictive, mood-altering drug, used illegally as a stimulant.
--Examples--

‘he was jailed for three months for possessing amphetamines’
--Word--
amphi- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Both.
Of both kinds.
On both sides.
Around.
--Examples--
‘amphibian’
‘amphipod’
‘amphiprostyle’
‘amphitheatre’
--Word--
amphi- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Both.
Of both kinds.
On both sides.
Around.
--Examples--
‘amphibian’
‘amphipod’
‘amphiprostyle’
‘amphitheatre’
--Word--
amphibian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A cold-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that comprises the frogs, toads, newts, salamanders, and caecilians. They are distinguished by having an aquatic gill-breathing larval stage followed (typically) by a terrestrial lung-breathing adult stage.
A seaplane, tank, or other vehicle that can operate on land and on water.
Relating to amphibians.
--Examples--
‘amphibian eggs’
--Word--
amphibian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A cold-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that comprises the frogs, toads, newts, salamanders, and caecilians. They are distinguished by having an aquatic gill-breathing larval stage followed (typically) by a terrestrial lung-breathing adult stage.
A seaplane, tank, or other vehicle that can operate on land and on water.
Relating to amphibians.
--Examples--
‘amphibian eggs’

--Word--
amphibious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, living in, or suited for both land and water.
(of a military operation) involving forces landed from the sea.
--Examples--
‘an amphibious vehicle’
‘an amphibious assault’

amphibole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of rock-forming silicate or aluminosilicate minerals typically occurring as fibrous or columnar crystals.
--Examples--
‘acid rocks consist mostly of quartz and feldspars, with a little mica or amphibole’

--Word--
amphitheatre 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(especially in Greek and Roman architecture) an open circular or oval building with a central space surrounded by tiers of seats for spectators, for the presentation of dramatic or sporting events.
A semicircular seating gallery in a theatre.
--Examples--
‘the opera was performed in the Roman amphitheatre’
‘vouchers to reduce the price of tickets in the amphitheatre’
--Word--

adjective

‘she stood with her hands on her ample hips’

--Word--
amplify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Increase the volume of (sound), especially using an amplifier.
Increase the amplitude of (an electrical signal or other oscillation)
Make (something) more marked or intense.
Enlarge upon or add detail to (a story or statement)
Make multiple copies of (a gene or DNA sequence)
--Examples--
‘the accompanying chords have been amplified in our arrangement’
‘the manufacturers have developed a system of amplifying the radio signal’
‘urban policy initiatives amplified social polarization’
‘the notes amplify information contained in the statement’
‘genomic DNA was amplified using the polymerase chain reaction’
--Word--
amplification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of increasing the volume of sound, especially using an amplifier.
The action of increasing the amplitude of an electrical signal or other oscillation.
The action of making something more marked or intense.
The action of enlarging upon or adding detail to a story or statement.
The action of making multiple copies of a gene or DNA sequence.
--Examples--
‘even without amplification, her voice carries to the farthest corners’
‘the amplification of radio signals is possible’
‘you're an actor in that you are using emotion and amplification of ideas to make your point’
‘the words 'no real prospect of succeeding' do not need any amplification’
‘thanks to all who wrote in with corrections and amplifications’
‘a technique known as random amplification of polymorphic DNA’
‘sequences were obtained from multiple amplifications from individual samples’
--Word--
amplification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of increasing the volume of sound, especially using an amplifier.
The action of increasing the amplitude of an electrical signal or other oscillation.
The action of making something more marked or intense.
The action of enlarging upon or adding detail to a story or statement.
The action of making multiple copies of a gene or DNA sequence.
--Examples--
‘even without amplification, her voice carries to the farthest corners’
‘the amplification of radio signals is possible’
‘you're an actor in that you are using emotion and amplification of ideas to make your point’
‘the words 'no real prospect of succeeding' do not need any amplification’
‘thanks to all who wrote in with corrections and amplifications’
‘a technique known as random amplification of polymorphic DNA’
‘sequences were obtained from multiple amplifications from individual samples’
--Word--
amplified 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of music or sound) played through an amplifier.
--Examples--
‘amplified pop music’
--Word--
amplifier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An electronic device for increasing the amplitude of electrical signals, used chiefly in sound reproduction.
A device consisting of an amplifier combined with a loudspeaker and used to increase the volume of the sound produced by electric guitars and other musical instruments.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A device consisting of an amplifier combined with a loudspeaker and used to increase the volume of the sound produced by electric guitars and other musical instruments.

--Word--
amplitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The maximum extent of a vibration or oscillation, measured from the position of equilibrium.
The maximum difference of an alternating electric current or potential from the average value.
The angular distance of a celestial object from the true east or west point of the horizon at rising or setting.
Breadth, range, or magnitude.
The angle between the real axis of an Argand diagram and a vector representing a complex number.
--Examples--
‘the amplitude of alpha rhythms’
‘waves with amplitudes greater than or equal to 20 mm’
‘the detection of signals only a few microvolts in amplitude’
‘the amplitude of the crime of manslaughter lies beneath murder’
--Word--
amplitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The maximum extent of a vibration or oscillation, measured from the position of equilibrium.
The maximum difference of an alternating electric current or potential from the average value.
The angular distance of a celestial object from the true east or west point of the horizon at rising or setting.
Breadth, range, or magnitude.
The angle between the real axis of an Argand diagram and a vector representing a complex number.
--Examples--
‘the amplitude of alpha rhythms’
‘waves with amplitudes greater than or equal to 20 mm’
‘the detection of signals only a few microvolts in amplitude’
‘the amplitude of the crime of manslaughter lies beneath murder’

ampulla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A roughly spherical Roman flask with two handles.
A flask for sacred uses such as holding the oil for anointing the sovereign at a coronation.
A cavity, or the dilated end of a vessel, shaped like a Roman ampulla.

Amritsar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the state of Punjab in north-western India; population 1,194,700 (est. 2009). It became the centre of the Sikh faith and the site of its holiest temple, the Golden Temple. It was the scene of a riot in 1919, in which 400 people were killed by British troops.

--Word--
spend 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give (money) to pay for goods, services, or so as to benefit someone or something.
Use or give out the whole of; exhaust.
Pass (time) in a specified way or in a particular place.
An amount of money paid out.
--Examples--
‘the firm has spent £100,000 on hardware’
‘she couldn't buy any more because she had already spent her money’
‘the initial surge of interest had spent itself’
‘she spent a lot of time travelling’
‘the average spend at the cafe is £10 a head’
--Word--
Amsterdam 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital and largest city of the Netherlands; population 747,093 (2008). It is built on some ninety islands separated by canals. Although Amsterdam is the capital, the country's seat of government and administrative centre is at The Hague.

Amundsen, Roald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1872–1928), Norwegian explorer. Amundsen was the first to navigate the North-West Passage (1903–6), during which expedition he located the site of the magnetic north pole. In 1911 he became the first to reach the South Pole.
--Examples--

Amur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of north-eastern Asia, forming for the greater part of its length the boundary between Russia and China. Its length is about 4,350 km (2,737 miles).

--Word--
amuse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Cause (someone) to find something funny.
Provide interesting and enjoyable occupation for (someone); entertain.
--Examples--
‘he made faces to amuse her’
‘they amused themselves digging through an old encyclopedia’
‘the hotel has planned many activities to amuse its guests’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘people looked on with amused curiosity’

amusedly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘he stared amusedly at him, before breaking out into laughter’
--Word--
amusement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or experience of finding something funny.
The provision or enjoyment of entertainment.
Something that causes laughter or provides entertainment.
A roundabout, game machine, etc. for providing entertainment at a fairground or resort.
--Examples--
‘we looked with amusement at our horoscopes’
‘an evening's amusement’
‘she was like an adult planning amusements for a child’
‘on the promenade the amusements were still open’

--Word--
anachronism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned.
The action of attributing something to a period to which it does not belong.
--Examples--
‘the town is a throwback to medieval times, an anachronism that has survived the passing years’
‘it is anachronism to suppose that the official morality of the age was mere window dressing’
--Word--

--Word--
anachronistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to a period other than that being portrayed.
Belonging or appropriate to an earlier period, especially so as to seem conspicuously old-fashioned.
--Examples--
‘'Titus' benefits from the effective use of anachronistic elements like cars and loudspeakers’
‘she is rebelling against the anachronistic morality of her parents’

--Word--
Anaglypta 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of thick embossed wallpaper, designed to be painted over.
--Examples--
‘being a natural material, Anaglypta expands on pasting’
‘unlike the other Anaglyptas, they have a flat paper backing’
--Word--
anagram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word, phrase, or name formed by rearranging the letters of another, such as spar, formed from rasp.
--Examples--
--Word--
anagrammatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or employing a word, phrase, or name formed by rearranging the letters of another; in the form of an anagram.
--Examples--
‘he would write using anagrammatic versions of his name’
‘anagrammatic puzzles’

--Word--
Anaheim 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in California, on the south-east side of the Los Angeles conurbation; population 335,288 (est. 2008). It is the site of the amusement park Disneyland.
--Examples--
--Word--
anal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or situated near the anus.
(in Freudian theory) relating to or denoting a stage of infantile psychosexual development in which defecation is the major source of sensuous pleasure and the anus forms the centre of self-awareness.
Anal-retentive.
--Examples--
‘the anal sphincter’
‘he's anal about things like that’
--Word--
anal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or situated near the anus.

Anal-retentive.
--Examples--
‘the anal sphincter’
‘he's anal about things like that’
--Word--
analcime 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the zeolite group of minerals occurring in a wide variety of sedimentary rocks and in some igneous rocks, as crystals of various colours.

--Word--
analemma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthographical projection of the celestial sphere on to the plane of the meridian, the observer being supposed to be at an infinite distance at the east or west point of the horizon. In later use chiefly historical (frequently attributive).
An instrument or part constructed on the basis of the analemma projection.
A scale drawn on a terrestrial globe showing the changing position of the true sun over the course of a year; a similar item on a sundial.
The asymmetrical figure-of-eight curve that can be traced in the sky at a given place showing the position of the sun at mean solar noon on successive days of a year.
--Examples--
--Word--
analemma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthographical projection of the celestial sphere on to the plane of the meridian, the observer being supposed to be at an infinite distance at the east or west point of the horizon. In later use chiefly historical (frequently attributive).
An instrument or part constructed on the basis of the analemma projection.
A scale drawn on a terrestrial globe showing the changing position of the true sun over the course of a year; a similar item on a sundial.
The asymmetrical figure-of-eight curve that can be traced in the sky at a given place showing the position of the sun at mean solar noon on successive days of a year.
--Examples--
--Word--
analemmatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a sundial comprising a movable gnomon perpendicular to a dial plane with hour points arranged in an ellipse, the position of the gnomon at a particular time of year being determined by an analemma projection.
--Examples--
--Word--
analepsy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Epilepsy (supposedly) caused by distension or disorder of the stomach. rare. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
analepsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A literary device in narrative, in which a past event is narrated at a point later than its chronological place in a story.
Ascension into heaven.
--Examples--
‘writers make strategic use of both analepsis and prolepsis in telling a story’
‘the analepsis terminated the earthly ministry’
--Word--
analeptic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(chiefly of a drug) tending to restore a person's health or strength; restorative.
A restorative drug.
A drug that stimulates the central nervous system.
--Examples--

analeptical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Analeptic.

--Examples--
--Word--
analyse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Examine (something) methodically and in detail, typically in order to explain and interpret it.
Discover or reveal (something) through close examination.
Identify and measure the chemical constituents of (a substance or specimen)
Resolve (a sentence) into its grammatical elements; parse.
Psychoanalyse (someone).
--Examples--
‘we need to analyse our results more clearly’
‘he tried to analyse exactly what was going on’
‘this DNA can be analysed by various methods, including full base sequencing’

--Word--
analysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Detailed examination of the elements or structure of something.
The process of separating something into its constituent elements.
The identification and measurement of the chemical constituents of a substance or specimen.
The part of mathematics concerned with the theory of functions and the use of limits, continuity, and the operations of calculus.
--Examples--
‘statistical analysis’
‘an analysis of popular culture’
‘the procedure is often more accurately described as one of synthesis rather than analysis’
‘samples are sent to the laboratory for analysis’
‘analyses of the rocks are consistent with a basaltic composition’
‘other schools of analysis have evolved out of the original disciplines established by Freud’

--Type--
noun

--Word--
analytic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
True by virtue of the meaning of the words or concepts used to express it, so that its denial would be a self-contradiction.
(of a language, e.g. Chinese and English) tending not to alter the form of its words but to use word order to express grammatical structure.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
anallagmatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a surface or curve: not changed in form by inversion.
Of a tessellation in which the cells are of one or other of two colours: such that placing any two columns, or any two rows, side by side results in half the adjacent cells having the same colour and half having different colours.
--Examples--
--Word--
anally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
analogue 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or using signals or information represented by a continuously variable physical quantity such as spatial position, voltage, etc.
(of a clock or watch) showing the time by means of hands or a pointer rather than displayed digits.
Not involving or relating to the use of computer technology, as a contrast to a digital counterpart.
A person or thing seen as comparable to another.
A compound with a molecular structure closely similar to that of another.
--Examples--
‘analogue signals’
‘the information on a gramophone record is analogue’
‘old-school analogue paper map skills’
‘an interior analogue of the exterior world’
‘the idea that the fertilized egg contains a miniature analogue of every adult structure’
‘thioacids are sulphur analogues of oxyacids’
--Word--
analogism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or practice of reasoning by analogy; an instance of this. Compare "analogy". Now rare.
Mathematics. Mathematical proportion; a proportional. Now historical and rare.
Medicine. Diagnosis or treatment of one disease by analogy with another. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
analogy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A comparison between one thing and another, typically for the purpose of explanation or clarification.
A correspondence or partial similarity.
A thing which is comparable to something else in significant respects.
A process of arguing from similarity in known respects to similarity in other respects.
A process by which new words and inflections are created on the basis of regularities in the form of existing ones.
The resemblance of function between organs that have a different evolutionary origin.
--Examples--
‘an analogy between the workings of nature and those of human societies’
‘he interprets logical functions by analogy with machines’
‘the syndrome is called deep dysgraphia because of its analogy to deep dyslexia’
‘works of art were seen as an analogy for works of nature’
‘argument from analogy’

--Word--
analogism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or practice of reasoning by analogy; an instance of this. Compare "analogy". Now rare.

--Examples--
--Word--
analogist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who looks for or employs analogy or analogies, or is inclined to do so.
Linguistics and Philosophy. An adherent of the view (particularly associated with a school of Greek grammarians existing between the 2nd cent. b.c. and 1st cent. a.d.) that language has an innate, logical structure deriving from a fundamental correspondence between words and the things they denote. Opposed to anomalist.
--Examples--
--Word--
analogistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characterized by the view that language is based on a correspondence between words and ideas.
--Examples--

verb
--Meanings--
Make a comparison of (something) with something else to assist understanding.
--Examples--
‘he could analogize birth to the coming into being of a poem’
‘analogizing gyroplanes with helicopters is a little surprising’

--Word--
analogous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Comparable in certain respects, typically in a way which makes clearer the nature of the things compared.
(of organs) performing a similar function but having a different evolutionary origin, such as the wings of insects and birds.
--Examples--
‘they saw the relationship between a ruler and his subjects as analogous to that of father and children’

--Meanings--
--Examples--

analogousness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality, state, or condition of being analogous; equivalence, correspondence; similarity, resemblance.
--Examples--
--Word--
analogue 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or using signals or information represented by a continuously variable physical quantity such as spatial position, voltage, etc.
(of a clock or watch) showing the time by means of hands or a pointer rather than displayed digits.
Not involving or relating to the use of computer technology, as a contrast to a digital counterpart.
A person or thing seen as comparable to another.
A compound with a molecular structure closely similar to that of another.
--Examples--
‘analogue signals’
‘the information on a gramophone record is analogue’
‘old-school analogue paper map skills’
‘an interior analogue of the exterior world’
‘the idea that the fertilized egg contains a miniature analogue of every adult structure’
‘thioacids are sulphur analogues of oxyacids’

--Word--
analphabet 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Characterized by ignorance of or lack of familiarity with the letters of the alphabet; wholly or partially illiterate.
Also in form analphabete. A person who is wholly or partially illiterate.
--Examples--
--Word--
analphabet 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Characterized by ignorance of or lack of familiarity with the letters of the alphabet; wholly or partially illiterate.
Also in form analphabete. A person who is wholly or partially illiterate.
--Examples--
--Word--
analphabetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Representing sounds by composite signs rather than by single letters or symbols.
Completely illiterate.
--Examples--
‘Chinese has an analphabetic writing system’
‘at least one of my grandmothers was unlettered, analphabetic’
--Word--
analphabetical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= analphabet.
--Examples--
--Word--
analphabetism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ignorance of or lack of familiarity with the letters of the alphabet; illiteracy.
--Examples--
--Word--
anamnesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Recollection, especially of a supposed previous existence.
A patient's account of their medical history.
The part of the Eucharist in which the Passion, Resurrection, and Ascension of Christ are recalled.
--Examples--
--Word--

anamnestic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting an enhanced reaction of the body's immune system to an antigen which is related to one previously encountered.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
anamorphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to a distorted projection or drawing that appears normal when viewed from a particular point or with a suitable mirror or lens.
--Examples--
‘an anamorphic widescreen image’
‘a special anamorphic lens is put on the camera’
--Word--
anamorphosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A distorted projection or drawing which appears normal when viewed from a particular point or with a suitable mirror or lens.
The process by which anamorphic images are produced.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

ananda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism) extreme happiness, one of the highest states of being.
--Examples--
‘the ananda of divine love’
--Word--
Ananias 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Two figures in the New Testament, the husband of Sapphira, struck dead because he lied (Acts 5), and the Jewish high priest before whom St Paul was brought (Acts 23).

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

anaphylaxis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acute allergic reaction to an antigen (e.g. a bee sting) to which the body has become hypersensitive.
--Examples--
--Word--
anaphora 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of a word referring back to a word used earlier in a text or conversation, to avoid repetition, for example the pronouns he, she, it, and they and the verb do in I like it and so do they.
The repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning of successive clauses.
The part of the Eucharist which contains the consecration, anamnesis, and communion.
--Examples--
--Word--
pro-anaphoral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating, relating to, or consisting of that part of the Eucharistic liturgy which precedes the anaphora.
--Examples--

--Word--
anaplasia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The loss of the mature or specialized features of a cell or tissue, as in malignant tumours.
--Examples--
‘transitional cell carcinomas are graded 1 to 3 or 4 according to the degree of anaplasia’
--Word--
anaplastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting, relating to, or characteristic of cells or tissues that have lost their mature or specialized features, as in malignant tumours.
--Examples--
‘anaplastic thyroid cancer’
‘while most meningiomas are benign, 1% to 3% display anaplastic features’
--Word--
anapsid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A reptile of a group characterized by a lack of temporal openings in the skull, including the turtles and their relatives and many early fossil forms.

anarch 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An anarchist.
Anarchic.
--Examples--
‘she triumphed as a carnivalesque anarch, transforming defeat into publicity’
‘a beauty so anarch, so ungelded’
--Word--
anarchy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A state of disorder due to absence or non-recognition of authority or other controlling systems.
Absence of government and absolute freedom of the individual, regarded as a political ideal.
--Examples--
‘he must ensure public order in a country threatened with anarchy’
--Word--
anarchic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
With no controlling rules or principles to give order.
(of comedy or humour) uncontrolled by convention.
--Examples--
‘an anarchic and bitter civil war’
‘his anarchic wit’
--Word--
anarchical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
anarchically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
anarchy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A state of disorder due to absence or non-recognition of authority or other controlling systems.
Absence of government and absolute freedom of the individual, regarded as a political ideal.
--Examples--
‘he must ensure public order in a country threatened with anarchy’
--Word--
anarchism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Belief in the abolition of all government and the organization of society on a voluntary, cooperative basis without recourse to force or compulsion.
A political force or movement based on belief in anarchism.
--Examples--
‘socialism and anarchism emerged to offer organized protest against the injustices of Spanish society’
--Word--
anarchism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Belief in the abolition of all government and the organization of society on a voluntary, cooperative basis without recourse to force or compulsion.
A political force or movement based on belief in anarchism.
--Examples--
‘socialism and anarchism emerged to offer organized protest against the injustices of Spanish society’

anarchist

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who believes in or tries to bring about anarchy.

--Examples--
--Word--
syndicalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movement for transferring the ownership and control of the means of production and distribution to workers' unions. Influenced by Proudhon and by the French social philosopher Georges Sorel (1847–1922), syndicalism developed in French trade unions during the late 19th century and was at its most vigorous between 1900 and 1914, particularly in France, Italy, Spain, and the US.
--Examples--
--Word--
syndicalist 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--

--Word--
Anasazi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient North American people of the south-western US, who flourished between c.200 BC and AD 1500. The earliest phase of their culture is known as the Basket Maker period; the present-day Pueblo culture developed from a later stage.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anasazi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient North American people of the south-western US, who flourished between c.200 BC and AD 1500. The earliest phase of their culture is known as the Basket Maker period; the present-day Pueblo culture developed from a later stage.

‘these anastomose with branches of the carotid artery’
‘the graft is anastomosed to the vein of the recipient’
--Word--
anastomosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cross-connection between adjacent channels, tubes, fibres, or other parts of a network.
A connection made surgically between adjacent blood vessels, parts of the intestine, or other channels of the body.
--Examples--
‘collateral veins are likely to develop across the anastomosis within a few months’
‘a new technique of intestinal anastomosis was devised’

--Word--
anathema 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes.
A formal curse by a pope or a council of the Church, excommunicating a person or denouncing a doctrine.
A strong curse.
--Examples--
‘racial hatred was anathema to her’
‘the Pope laid special emphasis on the second of these anathemas’
‘the sergeant clutched the ruined communicator, muttering anathemas’

--Word--
France, Anatole 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1844–1924), French writer; pseudonym of Jacques-Anatole-François Thibault. Works include the novel Le Crime de Sylvestre Bonnard (1881) and his ironic version of the Dreyfus case, L'Ile des pingouins (1908). Nobel Prize for Literature (1921).
--Examples--
--Word--
Anatolia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The western peninsula of Asia, bounded by the Black Sea, the Aegean, and the Mediterranean, that forms the greater part of Turkey.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anatolian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Anatolia, its inhabitants, or their ancient languages.
A native or inhabitant of Anatolia.
An extinct group of ancient languages constituting a branch of the Indo-European language family and including Hittite, Luwian, Lydian, and Lycian.
--Examples--
--Word--
anatomy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of science concerned with the bodily structure of humans, animals, and other living organisms, especially as revealed by dissection and the separation of parts.
The bodily structure of an organism.
A person's body.
A study of the structure or internal workings of something.
--Examples--
‘he studied physiology and anatomy’
‘human anatomy’
‘descriptions of the cat's anatomy and behaviour’
‘every part of his anatomy hurt’
‘people should never be reduced to their anatomies’
‘a detailed anatomy of a society and its institutions’
--Word--
anatomic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
annatto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange-red dye obtained from the seed coat of a tropical fruit, used for colouring foods.
The tropical American tree that yields the fruit from which annatto is obtained.
--Examples--
--Word--
annatto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange-red dye obtained from the seed coat of a tropical fruit, used for colouring foods.

--Examples--
--Word--
Anaxagoras 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.500–c.428 BC), Greek philosopher, teaching in Athens. He believed that all matter was infinitely divisible and motionless until animated by mind (nous).
--Examples--
--Word--
Anaximander 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.610–c.545 BC), Greek scientist, who lived at Miletus. He believed the earth to be cylindrical and poised in space, and is reputed to have taught that life began in water and that humans originated from fish.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anaximenes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(fl. 6th century), Greek philosopher and scientist, who lived at Miletus. Anaximenes believed the earth to be flat and shallow, a view of astronomy that was a retrograde step from that of Anaximander.
--Examples--
--Word--
ANC 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
African National Congress.
--Examples--
--Word--
-ance 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming nouns denoting a quality or state or an instance of one.
Forming nouns denoting an action.
--Examples--
‘allegiance’
‘extravagance’
‘perseverance’
‘appearance’
‘utterance’
--Word--
ancestor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person, typically one more remote than a grandparent, from whom one is descended.
An early type of animal or plant from which others have evolved.
An early version of a machine, system, etc.
--Examples--
‘he could trace his ancestors back to James the First’
‘the ancestor of most dolphins is not clear’
‘both species of elephant have a common ancestor’
‘this instrument is an ancestor of the lute’

ancestry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One's family or ethnic descent.
The evolutionary or genetic line of descent of an animal or plant.
The origin or background of something.
--Examples--
‘he was proud of his Irish ancestry’
‘the ancestry of the rose is extremely complicated’
‘the book traces the ancestry of women's poetry’

‘the book traces the ancestry of women's poetry’

--Word--
anchor 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A heavy object attached to a cable or chain and used to moor a ship to the sea bottom, typically having a metal shank with a pair of curved, barbed flukes at one end.
A person or thing that provides stability or confidence in an otherwise uncertain situation.
A large and prestigious department store prominently sited in a new shopping centre.
The brakes of a car.
An anchorman or anchorwoman.
Moor (a ship) to the sea bottom with an anchor.
Secure firmly in position.
Provide with a firm basis or foundation.
Present and coordinate (a television or radio programme)
--Examples--
‘the boat, no longer held fast by its anchor, swung wildly’
‘an anchor chain’
‘the European Community is the economic anchor of the New Europe’
‘this idiot in front slammed on his anchors at a crossing’
‘he signed off after nineteen years as CBS news anchor’
‘the ship was anchored in the lee of the island’
‘we anchored in the harbour’
‘the tail is used as a hook with which the fish anchors itself to coral’
‘it is important that policy be anchored to some acceptable theoretical basis’
‘she anchored a television documentary series in the early 1980s’

adjective, noun
--Meanings--

In addition to something else, but not as important.

Something which functions in a supplementary or supporting role.

--Word--
and 
--Type--
conjunction, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Used to connect words of the same part of speech, clauses, or sentences, that are to be taken jointly.
Used to connect two clauses when the second refers to something that happens after the first.
Used to connect two clauses, the second of which refers to something that results from the first.
Connecting two identical comparatives, to emphasize a progressive change.
Connecting two identical words, implying great duration or great extent.
Used to connect two identical words to indicate that things of the same name or class have different qualities.
Used to connect two numbers to indicate that they are being added together.
Used to connect two numbers, implying succession.
Used to introduce an additional comment or interjection.
Used to introduce a question in connection with what someone else has just said.
Used to introduce a statement about a new topic.
Used after some verbs and before another verb to indicate intention, instead of ‘to’
A Boolean operator which gives the value one if and only if all the operands are one, and otherwise has a value of zero.
A circuit which produces an output signal only when signals are received simultaneously through all input connections.
Andorra (international vehicle registration).
--Examples--
‘bread and butter’
‘they can read and write’
‘a hundred and fifty’
‘he turned round and walked out’
‘there was a flash flood and by the next morning the town was under water’
‘getting better and better’
‘I cried and cried’
‘all human conduct is determined or caused—but there are causes and causes’
‘six and four makes ten’
‘a line of men marching two and two’
‘if it came to a choice—and this was the worst thing—she would turn her back on her parents’
‘‘I found the letter in her bag.’ ‘And did you steam it open?’’
‘and now to the dessert’
‘I would try and do what he said’

--Word--
Andalusia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The southernmost region of Spain, bordering on the Atlantic and the Mediterranean; capital, Seville. The region was under Moorish rule from 711 to 1492. Spanish name Andalucía /Spanish andaluˈθia, Spanish andaluˈsia/.
--Examples--

Andersen, Hans Christian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1805–75), Danish author. He is famous for his fairy tales, published from 1835, such as ‘The Snow Queen’, ‘The Ugly Duckling’, and ‘The Little Match Girl’. Although rooted in Danish folklore, the stories were also shaped by Andersen's own psychological alienation.

--Word--
Andorra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small autonomous principality in the southern Pyrenees, between France and Spain; population 70,000 (estimated 2014); official languages, Catalan and French; capital, Andorra la Vella. Its independence dates from the late 8th century, when Charlemagne is said to have granted the Andorrans self-government for their help in defeating the Moors.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

A native or inhabitant of Andorra.
--Examples--
‘the oldest known church in the Andorran valleys’
‘many Andorrans live in traditional, slate-roofed, stone farmhouses’

--Word--
Previn, André 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1929), German-born US conductor, pianist, and composer; full name André George Previn. He is most famous as a conductor, notably with the London Symphony Orchestra (1968–79), the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra (1976–86), and the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra (1987–91).
--Examples--
--Word--
Palladio, Andrea 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1508–80), Italian architect. He led a revival of classical architecture, in particular promoting the Roman ideals of harmonic proportions and symmetrical planning. A notable example of his many villas, palaces, and churches is the church of San Giorgio Maggiore in Venice.
--Examples--
--Word--
Vesalius, Andreas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1514–64), Flemish anatomist, the founder of modern anatomy. His major work, De Humani Corporis Fabrica (1543), contained accurate descriptions of human anatomy, but owed much of its great historical impact to the woodcuts of his dissections.
--Examples--
--Word--
Sakharov, Andrei 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1921–89), Russian nuclear physicist and civil rights campaigner; full name Andrei Dmitrievich Sakharov. Having helped to develop the Soviet hydrogen bomb, he campaigned against nuclear proliferation. He fought for reform and human rights in the USSR, for which he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975 but was also sentenced to internal exile 1980–6.
--Examples--
--Word--
Segovia, Andrés 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1987), Spanish guitarist and composer. He was largely responsible for the revival of the classical guitar, elevating it to use as a concert instrument and making a large number of transcriptions of classical music to increase the repertoire of the instrument.
--Examples--
--Word--
Young, Andrew 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1932), US politician, civil rights leader, and clergyman; full name Andrew Jackson Young, Jr. He served in various capacities with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference 1964–70 before becoming a Democratic representative from Georgia in the US Congress 1973–77. He was the US ambassador to the United Nations 1977–79 and mayor of Atlanta 1982–90.
--Examples--
--Word--
St. Andrews 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in eastern Scotland, on the North Sea; population 17,100 (est. 2009). It is noted for its university that was founded in 1410 and for its historic golf courses.
--Examples--
--Word--
Vening Meinesz, Felix Andries 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1966), Dutch geophysicist. He devised a technique for making accurate gravity measurements with the aid of a pendulum and pioneered the use of submarines for marine gravity surveys. He located negative gravity anomalies in the deep trenches near island arcs in the Pacific, correctly interpreting them as being due to the downward buckling of the oceanic crust.
--Examples--
--Word--
Vening Meinesz, Felix Andries 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1966), Dutch geophysicist. He devised a technique for making accurate gravity measurements with the aid of a pendulum and pioneered the use of submarines for marine gravity surveys. He located negative gravity anomalies in the deep trenches near island arcs in the Pacific, correctly interpreting them as being due to the downward buckling of the oceanic crust.

Androcles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A runaway slave in a story by Aulus Gellius (2nd century AD) who extracted a thorn from the paw of a lion, which later recognized him and refrained from attacking him when he faced it in the arena.

--Word--
android 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in science fiction) a robot with a human appearance.
An open-source operating system used for smartphones and tablet computers.
--Examples--
‘a space station inhabited only by androids’
‘there were no android security guards to stop him’
‘I have an Android phone and I like it a lot’

--Word--
Andromache 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The wife of Hector. She became the slave of Neoptolemus (son of Achilles) after the fall of Troy.
--Examples--
--Word--
andromeda 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A bog rosemary, especially (marsh andromeda) the common bog rosemary.
An Ethiopian princess whose mother Cassiopeia boasted that she herself (or, in some stories, her daughter) was more beautiful than the Nereids. In revenge Poseidon sent a sea monster to ravage the country; to placate him Andromeda was fastened to a rock and exposed to the monster, from which she was rescued by Perseus.
A large northern constellation between Perseus and Pegasus, with few bright stars. It is chiefly notable for the Andromeda Galaxy (or Great Nebula of Andromeda), a conspicuous spiral galaxy probably twice as massive as our own and located two million light years away.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Andromeda.
--Examples--
‘the star Gamma Andromedae’
--Word--
andro-

combining form
--Meanings--
Of men; male.
--Examples--
‘androcentric’
--Word--
Androscoggin River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river that flows for 175 miles (280 km) from northern New Hampshire through southwestern Maine to the Atlantic Ocean.

--Word--
and 
--Type--
conjunction, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Used to connect words of the same part of speech, clauses, or sentences, that are to be taken jointly.
Used to connect two clauses when the second refers to something that happens after the first.
Used to connect two clauses, the second of which refers to something that results from the first.
Connecting two identical comparatives, to emphasize a progressive change.
Connecting two identical words, implying great duration or great extent.
Used to connect two identical words to indicate that things of the same name or class have different qualities.
Used to connect two numbers to indicate that they are being added together.
Used to connect two numbers, implying succession.
Used to introduce an additional comment or interjection.
Used to introduce a question in connection with what someone else has just said.
Used to introduce a statement about a new topic.
Used after some verbs and before another verb to indicate intention, instead of ‘to’
A Boolean operator which gives the value one if and only if all the operands are one, and otherwise has a value of zero.
A circuit which produces an output signal only when signals are received simultaneously through all input connections.
Andorra (international vehicle registration).
--Examples--
‘bread and butter’
‘they can read and write’
‘a hundred and fifty’
‘he turned round and walked out’
‘there was a flash flood and by the next morning the town was under water’
‘getting better and better’
‘I cried and cried’
‘all human conduct is determined or caused—but there are causes and causes’
‘six and four makes ten’
‘a line of men marching two and two’
‘if it came to a choice—and this was the worst thing—she would turn her back on her parents’
‘‘I found the letter in her bag.’ ‘And did you steam it open?’’
‘and now to the dessert’
‘I would try and do what he said’

anecdotage

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
anecdotal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an account) not necessarily true or reliable, because based on personal accounts rather than facts or research.
Characterized by or fond of telling anecdotes.
(of a painting) depicting small narrative incidents.
--Examples--
‘while there was much anecdotal evidence there was little hard fact’
‘her book is anecdotal and chatty’
‘nineteenth century French anecdotal paintings’

anecdote 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.
An account regarded as unreliable or hearsay.
The depiction of a minor narrative incident in a painting.
--Examples--

‘his wife's death has long been the subject of rumour and anecdote’
‘the use of inversions of hierarchy, anecdote, and paradox by Magritte, Dali, and others’

--Word--
anaemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A condition in which there is a deficiency of red cells or of haemoglobin in the blood, resulting in pallor and weariness.
--Examples--
--Word--
sickle cell anemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A severe hereditary form of anemia in which a mutated form of hemoglobin distorts the red blood cells into a crescent shape at low oxygen levels. It is most common among those of African descent.
--Examples--
--Word--
anaemic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Suffering from anaemia.
Lacking in colour, spirit, or vitality.
--Examples--
‘the doctor said you were a bit anaemic’
‘an anaemic patient’
‘an anaemic aspidistra stood in the grate’
‘Boro gave a thoroughly anaemic performance’

noun

--Word--
naga 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A member of a group of peoples living in or near the Naga Hills of Burma (Myanmar) and north-eastern India.
Any of the Tibeto-Burman languages of the Nagas, with about 340,000 speakers altogether.
Relating to the Nagas or their language.
(in Indian mythology) a member of a semi-divine race, part human, part cobra in form, associated with water and sometimes with mystical initiation.
(in some Hindu sects) a naked wandering ascetic, in particular one belonging to a sect whose members carry arms and serve as mercenaries.
--Examples--
--Word--
Angara River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in the southeastern part of Siberia in Russia that flows northwest and west for 1,039 miles (1,779 km) from Lake Baikal to meet the Yenisei River south of Yeniseysk.
--Examples--
--Word--
angary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The right of a country at war to seize or destroy neutral property out of military necessity, provided that compensation is paid.

--Word--
angel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spiritual being believed to act as an attendant, agent, or messenger of God, conventionally represented in human form with wings and a long robe.
An attendant spirit, especially a benevolent one.
(in traditional Christian angelology) a being of the lowest order of the ninefold celestial hierarchy.
A person of exemplary conduct or virtue.
Used in similes or comparisons to refer to a person's outstanding beauty, qualities, or abilities.
Used in approval to a person who is kind or helpful.
Used as a term of endearment.
A person who supports a business financially, typically one who invests private capital in a small or newly established enterprise.
A financial backer of a theatrical production.
A former English coin minted between the reigns of Edward IV and Charles I and bearing the figure of the archangel Michael killing a dragon.
An aircraft's altitude (often used with a numeral indicating thousands of feet)
An unexplained radar echo.
--Examples--
‘God sent an angel to talk to Gideon’
‘the Angel of Death’
‘there was an angel watching over me’
‘I know I'm no angel’
‘their parents think they are angels’
‘you sang like an angel’
‘be an angel and let us come in’
‘I miss you too, angel’
‘the longer it takes you to get your product into the marketplace, the longer it will be until the angels get their money back’
‘every year we raise the money for the next season and we are always looking for an angel’
‘we rendezvous at angels nine’
--Word--
Merkel, Angela 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1954), German Christian Democratic Union stateswoman, chancellor of Germany since 2005; full name Angela Dorothea Merkel.
--Examples--

Angeleno 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Los Angeles.
--Examples--
‘Angeleno sports fans’
--Word--
Los Angeles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city on the Pacific coast of southern California, the second largest city in the US; population 3,833,995 (est. 2008). It became a major centre of industry, film-making, and television in the 20th century, its metropolitan area having expanded to include towns such as Beverly Hills, Hollywood, Santa Monica, and Pasadena.
--Examples--
--Word--
angel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spiritual being believed to act as an attendant, agent, or messenger of God, conventionally represented in human form with wings and a long robe.
An attendant spirit, especially a benevolent one.
(in traditional Christian angelology) a being of the lowest order of the ninefold celestial hierarchy.
A person of exemplary conduct or virtue.
Used in similes or comparisons to refer to a person's outstanding beauty, qualities, or abilities.
Used in approval to a person who is kind or helpful.
Used as a term of endearment.
A person who supports a business financially, typically one who invests private capital in a small or newly established enterprise.
A financial backer of a theatrical production.
A former English coin minted between the reigns of Edward IV and Charles I and bearing the figure of the archangel Michael killing a dragon.
An aircraft's altitude (often used with a numeral indicating thousands of feet)
An unexplained radar echo.
--Examples--
‘God sent an angel to talk to Gideon’
‘the Angel of Death’
‘there was an angel watching over me’
‘I know I'm no angel’
‘their parents think they are angels’
‘you sang like an angel’
‘be an angel and let us come in’
‘I miss you too, angel’
‘the longer it takes you to get your product into the marketplace, the longer it will be until the angels get their money back’
‘every year we raise the money for the next season and we are always looking for an angel’
‘we rendezvous at angels nine’
--Word--
angelfish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of laterally compressed deep-bodied fishes with extended dorsal and anal fins, typically brightly coloured or boldly striped.
--Examples--

--Word--
angelica 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall aromatic plant of the parsley family, with large leaves and yellowish-green flowers. It is used in cooking and herbal medicine.
The candied stalk of angelica, used in confectionery and cake decoration.

--Word--
Angelico, Fra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1400–55), Italian painter and Dominican friar; born Guido di Pietro; monastic name Fra Giovanni da Fiesole. Notable works: the frescoes in the convent of San Marco, Florence (c.1438–47).

--Word--
noble 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging by rank, title, or birth to the aristocracy.
Having or showing fine personal qualities or high moral principles.
Of imposing or magnificent size or appearance.
Of excellent or superior quality.
(especially in former times) a person of noble rank or birth.
A former English gold coin first issued in 1351.
--Examples--
‘the medieval palace was once owned by a noble Florentine family’
‘the Duchess of Kent and several other noble ladies’
‘the promotion of human rights was a noble aspiration’
‘noble arches and massive granite columns’
‘there is nothing more noble than a mature pine forest’
‘Chardonnay is the noble grape from which some of the finest white wines are produced’
‘the greater a noble's military power, the more land he could control’
‘the king imposed a tax on both nobles and peasants’

angel's trumpet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
seeming 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Appearing to be real or true, but not necessarily being so; apparent.
Giving the impression of having a specified quality.
The outward appearance or aspect of someone or something, especially when considered as deceptive or as distinguished from reality.
--Examples--
‘Ellen's seeming indifference to the woman's fate’
‘an angry-seeming man’
‘that dissidence between inward reality and outward seeming’

--Meanings--

Angelus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Roman Catholic devotion commemorating the Incarnation of Jesus and including the Hail Mary, said at morning, noon, and sunset.
A ringing of church bells announcing the Angelus.
--Examples--
‘the bells in the tower above tolled the first Angelus’

‘he was angered that he had not been told’

Angevin 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native, inhabitant, or ruler of Anjou.
Any of the Plantagenet kings of England, especially those who were also counts of Anjou (Henry II, Richard I, and John).
Relating to Anjou.
Relating to or denoting the Plantagenets.
--Examples--
‘the Angevin kings’
--Word--
angina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A condition marked by severe pain in the chest, often also spreading to the shoulders, arms, and neck, owing to an inadequate blood supply to the heart.
Any of a number of disorders in which there is an intense localized pain.
--Examples--
‘he had high blood pressure and he suffered from angina’
‘Ludwig's angina’

angioid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a blood vessel; "angioid streak"noun a reddish, brown, or grey line in the fundus of the eye, resulting from degenerative changes in Bruch's membrane (a layer of the choroid) and often associated with systemic disorders such as Paget's disease of bone and various forms of anaemia.
--Examples--

--Word--
angiosperm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of a large group that comprises those that have flowers and produce seeds enclosed within a carpel, including herbaceous plants, shrubs, grasses, and most trees.

noun
--Meanings--
A protein whose presence in the blood promotes aldosterone secretion and tends to raise blood pressure.

Angkor 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of the ancient kingdom of Khmer in north-western Cambodia; noted for its temples, especially Angkor Wat (mid 12th century), the site was rediscovered in 1860.

--Word--
angle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The space (usually measured in degrees) between two intersecting lines or surfaces at or close to the point where they meet.
A corner, especially an external projection or an internal recess of a part of a building or other structure.
A measure of the inclination of one line or surface with respect to another.
A position from which something is viewed or along which it travels or acts, typically as measured by its inclination from an implicit horizontal or vertical baseline.
A particular way of approaching or considering an issue or problem.
Each of the four cardinal points of a chart, from which the first, fourth, seventh, and tenth houses extend anticlockwise respectively.
Angle iron or a similar constructional material made of another metal.
Direct or incline at an angle.
Move or be inclined at an angle.
Present (information) to reflect a particular view or have a particular focus.
--Examples--
‘in any triangle, the longest side is opposite the largest angle’
‘spring-loaded hinges open the doors to any angle up to 90°’
‘a skylight in the angle of the roof’
‘sloping at an angle of 33° to the horizontal’
‘from this angle Maggie could not see Naomi's face’
‘discussing the problems from every conceivable angle’
‘he always had a fresh angle on life’
‘the supporting frame is usually of aluminium angle bolted together’
‘he angled his chair so that he could watch her’
‘still the rain angles down’
‘angle your answer so that it is relevant to the job for which you are applying’
--Word--
angleberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rounded, fleshy growth with an uneven surface on the skin of cattle, horses, etc.; a warty excrescence, a papilloma.
--Examples--
--Word--
angled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Placed or inclined at an angle to something else.
Having an angle or angles of a specified type or number.
(of information) presented so as to reflect a particular view or to have a particular focus.
--Examples--
‘he sent an angled shot into the net’
‘a right-angled bend’
‘angled views on dancing’

angledog

noun
--Meanings--

angledozer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of bulldozer with a blade which is or can be set at an oblique angle, so that earth is pushed to one side rather than in the direction of travel.

anglewing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of nymphalid butterflies having notches on the outer edges of the forewings; specifically one of the genus Polygonia, which includes the commas; more fully anglewing butterfly.

--Word--
Anglian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the ancient Angles.
Relating to or denoting a Pleistocene glaciation in Britain, identified with the Elsterian of northern Europe (and perhaps the Mindel of the Alps).
The Anglian glaciation or the system of deposits laid down during it.

Anglic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A simplified form of English spelling devised by the Swedish philologist R. E. Zachrisson (1880–1937), and intended for use as an auxiliary orthography for learners of English.
Of or relating to the Angles, the Anglian kingdoms, or their languages; = "Anglian".
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--
Made English in form or character.
--Examples--
‘an anglicized form of a Navajo word’
--Word--
anglicize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make English in form or character.
--Examples--
‘he anglicized his name to Goodman’
--Word--
Anglicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word or phrase that is peculiar to British English.
The quality of being typically English or of favouring English things.
A word or phrase borrowed from English into a foreign language.
--Examples--
‘this new autobiography is studded with Anglicisms like lorries, plimsolls, and doing a bunk’
‘the French have as an irritating Anglicism: un toast’
--Word--
Anglicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word or phrase that is peculiar to British English.
The quality of being typically English or of favouring English things.
A word or phrase borrowed from English into a foreign language.
--Examples--
‘this new autobiography is studded with Anglicisms like lorries, plimsolls, and doing a bunk’
‘the French have as an irritating Anglicism: un toast’
--Word--
Anglicist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A student or scholar of English language or literature; = Anglist.
Originally and chiefly in India: an advocate of the teaching of English in schools.
--Examples--

--Word--
Anglo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white English-speaking person of British or northern European origin, in particular (in the US) as distinct from a Hispanic American or (in Canada) as distinct from a French-speaker.
An Anglo-Indian.
A person selected for a Scottish, Irish, or Welsh national sports team who plays for an English club.
--Examples--
‘most of the Anglos who moved to Texas came from the Deep South’
‘there is a feeling among Anglos in Quebec that things will never be the same’
‘Anglo neighbourhoods’
‘the Scottish Grand Slam side had four or five Anglos’
--Word--
Anglo- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
English.
Of English origin.
English and …
British and …
--Examples--
‘anglophone’
‘Anglo-Saxon’
‘Anglo-Latin’
‘Anglo-Indian’

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Abyssinia or its people.
A native of Abyssinia.
A cat of a breed having long ears and short brown hair flecked with grey.

--Word--
Anglo-America 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the English-speaking population of North America (before and after independence from Britain). Later: North America, especially as distinct from Latin America; (also) specifically the sector of the North American population with British or northern European ancestry.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anglo-American 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to both Britain and the US.
Of English descent, but born or living in the US.
An American born in England or of English ancestry.
An American whose native tongue is English.
--Examples--
‘Anglo-American folk music’
‘the first Anglo-American agreement on the future of air transport’
‘an Anglo-American architect and historian’
‘I'm an Anglo-American who moved to the US in early adulthood’
‘Anglo-Americans who do not speak Spanish’
--Word--
Anglo-Americanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A characteristically American English word, phrase, or idiom, (now especially) one borrowed into another language.
Cooperation or integration between England (or Britain) and America; allegiance to or advocacy of this.

Australian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Australia, or a person of Australian descent.

Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising only Australia and Tasmania.

--Examples--
--Word--
Anglo-Catholicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tradition within the Anglican Church which is close to Catholicism in its doctrine and worship and is broadly identified with High Church Anglicanism. As a movement, Anglo-Catholicism grew out of the Oxford Movement of the 1830s and 1840s.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anglo-Catholicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tradition within the Anglican Church which is close to Catholicism in its doctrine and worship and is broadly identified with High Church Anglicanism. As a movement, Anglo-Catholicism grew out of the Oxford Movement of the 1830s and 1840s.

adjective
--Meanings--

English (or British) but considered French in character, sympathies, etc.

Anglo-Indian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to both Britain and India.
Of Indian descent but born or living in Britain.
Of mixed British and Indian parentage.
Of British descent or birth but living or having lived long in India.
An Anglo-Indian person.
--Examples--
‘Anglo-Indian business cooperation’
‘the middling positions were all held by Anglo-Indian people of mixed race’
‘the late Colonel Knelle had been both Anglo-Irish and Anglo-Indian’
‘British, Anglo-Indians, and Indians did a splendid job’
--Word--
Anglo-Irish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to both Britain and Ireland (or specifically the Republic of Ireland).
Of English descent but born or resident in Ireland.
Of mixed English and Irish parentage.
--Examples--
‘an impoverished though aristocratic Anglo-Irish family’
--Word--
Irishism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A statement which is manifestly self-contradictory or inconsistent.
A characteristically Irish word, phrase, or idiom. Also occasionally more generally: a characteristically Irish belief, attitude, or trait.
Chiefly depreciative. The fact or quality of being Irish; Irishness.

Anglo-Norman French

--Meanings--

Persian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of ancient or modern Persia (or Iran), or a person of Persian descent.
A long-haired domestic cat of a breed originating in Persia, having a broad round head, stocky body, and short thick legs.
A sheep of a breed common in South Africa.
The modern Persian language, a member of the Iranian branch of the Indo-European family written in Arabic script.
An earlier form of Persian spoken in ancient or medieval Persia.
Relating to ancient Persia or modern Iran or its people or language.

Anglo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white English-speaking person of British or northern European origin, in particular (in the US) as distinct from a Hispanic American or (in Canada) as distinct from a French-speaker.
An Anglo-Indian.
A person selected for a Scottish, Irish, or Welsh national sports team who plays for an English club.
--Examples--
‘most of the Anglos who moved to Texas came from the Deep South’
‘there is a feeling among Anglos in Quebec that things will never be the same’
‘Anglo neighbourhoods’
‘the Scottish Grand Slam side had four or five Anglos’
--Word--
Anglo-Saxon 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the Germanic inhabitants of England from their arrival in the 5th century up to the Norman Conquest.
Of English descent.
Of, in, or relating to the Old English language.
(of an English word or expression) plain, in particular vulgar.
A Germanic inhabitant of England between the 5th century and the Norman Conquest.
A person of English descent.
Any white, English-speaking person.
The Old English language.
Plain English, in particular vulgar slang.
--Examples--
‘using a lot of good old Anglo-Saxon expletives’
--Word--
Anglo-Saxondom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
People of European (especially English or British) heritage or descent considered collectively; the English-speaking world, its civilization, culture, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anglo-Saxonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Anglo-Saxon, in various senses.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anglo-Saxonism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word, phrase, or idiom of Old English origin; (hence) an Anglicism.
Originally US. A word that is regarded as vulgar, considered (especially humorously) to be of traditional Anglo-Saxon origin, with allusion to the idea of an earlier, uncomplicated era of language and culture; a swear word.
Identification with, or belief in the superiority of, England (or Britain), the English-speaking peoples, their civilization, culture, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--

‘the Scottish Highlands’
‘Scottish dancing’

Spanish

--Meanings--
Relating to Spain, its people, or its language.
The people of Spain.
A Romance language spoken in Spain and in much of Central and South America (except Brazil) and several other countries. It is the second most widely spoken first language in the world, with more than 400 millon speakers.

angostura

--Word--
angry 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling or showing strong annoyance, displeasure, or hostility; full of anger.
(of the sea or sky) stormy, turbulent, or threatening.
(of a wound or sore) red and inflamed.
--Examples--
‘why are you angry with me?’
‘I'm angry that she didn't call me’
‘the wild, angry sea’
‘the bruise below his eye looked angry and sore’

Feeling or showing strong annoyance, displeasure, or hostility; full of anger.
(of the sea or sky) stormy, turbulent, or threatening.
(of a wound or sore) red and inflamed.
--Examples--
‘why are you angry with me?’
‘I'm angry that she didn't call me’
‘the wild, angry sea’
‘the bruise below his eye looked angry and sore’
--Word--
angry 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling or showing strong annoyance, displeasure, or hostility; full of anger.
(of the sea or sky) stormy, turbulent, or threatening.
(of a wound or sore) red and inflamed.
--Examples--
‘why are you angry with me?’
‘I'm angry that she didn't call me’
‘the wild, angry sea’
‘the bruise below his eye looked angry and sore’
--Word--
angrily 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a manner resulting from or betraying anger.
Stormily or threateningly.
--Examples--
‘workers reacted angrily to the announcement’
‘the sky was black and thundered angrily’
--Word--
angry-looking 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a sore) red and inflamed.
--Examples--
‘to soothe red, angry-looking breakouts’

--Word--
angst 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A feeling of deep anxiety or dread, typically an unfocused one about the human condition or the state of the world in general.
A feeling of persistent worry about something trivial.
--Examples--
‘the existential angst of the middle classes’
‘rock and pop have a tradition of celebrating adolescent angst’
‘my hair causes me angst’

--Word--
Anguilla 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The most northerly of the Leeward Islands in the Caribbean; population 15,000 (estimated 2015); languages, English (official), English Creole; capital, The Valley. Formerly a British colony, and briefly united with St Kitts and Nevis (1967), the island is now a self-governing British overseas territory.
--Examples--
