--Word--
angular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having angles or sharp corners.
(of a person or part of their body) lean and having a prominent bone structure.
Denoting physical properties or quantities measured with reference to or by means of an angle, especially those associated with rotation.
Relating to or denoting any of the houses that begin at the four cardinal points of a chart.
--Examples--
‘angular chairs’
‘Adam's angular black handwriting’
‘her angular face’
‘angular acceleration’

--Word--
angulate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Hold, bend, or distort (a part of the body) so as to form an angle or angles.
Incline (the upper body) sideways and outwards during a turn.
--Examples--
‘the hindquarters are more strongly angulated than the forequarters’
‘one of the hardest principles for a beginning skier to grasp is the necessity to angulate the upper half of the body’
‘you need to angulate slightly with the knees’

Angus 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A council area of north-eastern Scotland; administrative centre, Forfar. It was known from the 16th century until 1928 as Forfarshire, and between 1975 and 1996 was part of Tayside region.

Saxony-Anhalt 
--Type--

A state of Germany, on the plains of the Elbe and the Saale Rivers; capital, Magdeburg. It corresponds to the former duchy of Anhalt and the central part of the former kingdom of Saxony.

--Word--
any 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to one or some of a thing or number of things, no matter how much or how many.
Anyone.
Whichever of a specified class might be chosen.
At all; in some degree (used for emphasis)
At all (used alone, not qualifying another word)
--Examples--
‘I don't have any choice’
‘do you have any tips to pass on?’
‘someone asked him for a match, but Joe didn't have any’
‘you don't know any of my friends’
‘the city council ceased payments to any but the aged’
‘these constellations are visible at any hour of the night’
‘the illness may be due to any of several causes’
‘he wasn't any good at basketball’
‘why look any further?’
‘no one would be any the wiser’
‘I didn't hurt you any’

Anya-Nya

--Meanings--
(The name of) a southern Sudanese guerrilla organization, engaged in conflict with northern Sudanese Arab troops in the period 1963–72.

--Word--
Anyang 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating the site near the city of Anyang in the Chinese province of Henan at which the ruins of Yin, the final capital city of the Shang dynasty, are situated; (also) designating other sites associated with it. Hence: designating the finds made at these sites, or the period in which they were occupied (13th to 11th centuries bc).
--Examples--

pronoun
--Meanings--

aniline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless oily liquid present in coal tar. It is used in the manufacture of dyes, drugs, and plastics, and was the basis of the earliest synthetic dyes.

--Word--
animal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A living organism which feeds on organic matter, typically having specialized sense organs and nervous system and able to respond rapidly to stimuli.
Any such living organism other than a human being.
A mammal, as opposed to a bird, reptile, fish, or insect.
A person without human attributes or civilizing influences, especially someone who is very cruel, violent, or repulsive.
A particular type of person or thing.
Relating to or characteristic of animals.
Of animals as distinct from plants.
Characteristic of the physical and instinctive needs of animals; of the flesh rather than the spirit or intellect.
Relating to or denoting the pole or extremity of an embryo that contains the more active cytoplasm in the early stages of development.
--Examples--
‘wild animals adapt badly to a caged life’
‘humans are the only animals who weep’
‘are humans superior to animals, or just different?’
‘the snowfall seemed to have chased all birds, animals, and men indoors’
‘those men have to be animals—what they did to that boy was savage’
‘I am a political animal’
‘property development was a different animal altogether’
‘the evolution of animal life’
‘animal welfare’
‘tissues of animal and vegetable protein’
‘a crude surrender to animal lust’

--Word--
animalculism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that the embryo exists as a preformed entity in the spermatozoon (as opposed to in the ovum). Compare "animalcule". Opposed to ovism.
--Examples--
--Word--
animalculist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A proponent of the theory that the embryo exists as a preformed entity in the spermatozoon (as opposed to in the ovum); compare "animalcule" and animalculism. Opposed to ovist.
Of or relating to animalculism; characteristic of animalculists.
--Examples--
--Word--
animalhood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being an animal, or of being brutish like an animal.

animal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A living organism which feeds on organic matter, typically having specialized sense organs and nervous system and able to respond rapidly to stimuli.
Any such living organism other than a human being.
A mammal, as opposed to a bird, reptile, fish, or insect.
A person without human attributes or civilizing influences, especially someone who is very cruel, violent, or repulsive.
A particular type of person or thing.
Relating to or characteristic of animals.
Of animals as distinct from plants.
Characteristic of the physical and instinctive needs of animals; of the flesh rather than the spirit or intellect.
Relating to or denoting the pole or extremity of an embryo that contains the more active cytoplasm in the early stages of development.
--Examples--
‘wild animals adapt badly to a caged life’
‘humans are the only animals who weep’
‘are humans superior to animals, or just different?’
‘the snowfall seemed to have chased all birds, animals, and men indoors’
‘those men have to be animals—what they did to that boy was savage’
‘I am a political animal’
‘property development was a different animal altogether’
‘the evolution of animal life’

animate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Bring to life.
Give inspiration, encouragement, or renewed vigour to.
Give (a film or character) the appearance of movement using animation techniques.
Alive or having life.
--Examples--
‘Prometheus stole fire from heaven to animate his clay men’
‘she has animated the government with a sense of political direction’
‘much-loved characters have been animated in this Franco-Canadian co-production’
‘gods in a wide variety of forms, both animate and inanimate’

animate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Bring to life.
Give inspiration, encouragement, or renewed vigour to.
Give (a film or character) the appearance of movement using animation techniques.
Alive or having life.
--Examples--
‘Prometheus stole fire from heaven to animate his clay men’
‘she has animated the government with a sense of political direction’
‘much-loved characters have been animated in this Franco-Canadian co-production’
‘gods in a wide variety of forms, both animate and inanimate’
--Word--
animatingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an animated or animating manner; so as to give life, inspiration, enlivenment, or encouragement.
--Examples--
--Word--
animation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being full of life or vigour; liveliness.
The state of being alive.
The technique of photographing successive drawings or positions of puppets or models to create an illusion of movement when the film is shown as a sequence.
The manipulation of electronic images by means of a computer in order to create moving images.
--Examples--
‘they started talking with animation’
‘the body began to show tiny signs of animation’
‘a combination of live action with 3-D animation’
‘animations as backdrops for live action’
--Word--
animation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being full of life or vigour; liveliness.
The state of being alive.
The technique of photographing successive drawings or positions of puppets or models to create an illusion of movement when the film is shown as a sequence.
The manipulation of electronic images by means of a computer in order to create moving images.
--Examples--
‘they started talking with animation’
‘the body began to show tiny signs of animation’
‘a combination of live action with 3-D animation’
‘animations as backdrops for live action’
--Word--
animatism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The attribution of qualities of the soul or mind, such as personality and will, to inanimate objects.
--Examples--

animism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The attribution of a living soul to plants, inanimate objects, and natural phenomena.
The belief in a supernatural power that organizes and animates the material universe.
--Examples--
‘a village steeped in ancient animism and rituals’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
The attribution of a living soul to plants, inanimate objects, and natural phenomena.
The belief in a supernatural power that organizes and animates the material universe.

anisotropy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
anisotropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an object or substance) having a physical property which has a different value when measured in different directions. An example is wood, which is stronger along the grain than across it.
(of a property or phenomenon) varying in magnitude according to the direction of measurement.
--Examples--
‘electron scattering is anisotropic’

--Word--
Roddick, Anita 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1943–2007), English businesswoman; full name Anita Lucia Roddick. In 1976 she opened a shop selling cosmetics sourced and produced with minimal harm to the environment. This developed into the Body Shop chain.
--Examples--
--Word--
anything 
--Type--
pronoun
--Meanings--
Used to refer to a thing, no matter what.
Used for emphasis.
Used to indicate a range.

‘I was ready for anything’
‘he trains anything from seven to eight hours a day’

anytime 
--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
anyway 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Used to confirm or support a point or idea just mentioned.
Used in questions to emphasize the speaker's wish to obtain the truth.
Used to end a conversation, to change the subject, or to resume a subject after interruption.
Used to pass over less significant aspects of an account in order to focus on what is important.
Used to indicate that something happened or will happen in spite of something else.
--Examples--
‘I told you, it's all right, and anyway, it was my fault’
‘it's too late now anyway’
‘‘What are you doing here, anyway?’’
‘‘Anyway, Dot, I must dash.’’
‘‘Poor John always enjoyed a drink. Anyway, he died last year.’’
‘nobody invited Miss Honey to sit down but she sat down anyway’
--Word--
anyways 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘you wouldn't understand all them long words anyways’

Anjou 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A former province of western France, on the Loire. It was an English possession from 1154 until 1204.
An egg-shaped variety of pear, the most popular type of which has bright green skin.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ankara 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Turkey since 1923; population 3,763,600 (est. 2007). Prominent in Roman times as Ancyra, it later declined in importance until chosen by Kemal Atatürk in 1923 as his seat of government.
--Examples--

--Word--
ankle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The joint connecting the foot with the leg.
The narrow part of the leg between the ankle joint and the calf.
Walk.
Leave.
Flex the ankles while cycling in order to increase pedalling efficiency.
--Examples--
‘Jennie fell downstairs, breaking her ankle’
‘an ankle injury’
‘her slim ankles’
‘we can ankle off to a new locale’
‘he ankled the series to do a movie’
‘changing my pedalling style from toeing to ankling’

--Word--
Annaba 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port of north-eastern Algeria; population 205,600 (est. 2009). The modern town is adjacent to the site of Hippo Regius, a prominent city in Roman Africa and the home and bishopric of St Augustine of Hippo from 396 to 430.

annatto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange-red dye obtained from the seed coat of a tropical fruit, used for colouring foods.

--Examples--
--Word--
annatto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange-red dye obtained from the seed coat of a tropical fruit, used for colouring foods.
The tropical American tree that yields the fruit from which annatto is obtained.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1665–1714), queen of England and Scotland (known as Great Britain from 1707) and Ireland 1702–14. The last of the Stuart monarchs, daughter of the Catholic James II (but herself a Protestant), she succeeded her brother-in-law William III to the throne. None of her children survived into adulthood, and by the Act of Settlement (1701) the throne passed to the House of Hanover on her death.
--Examples--
--Word--
anneal 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Heat (metal or glass) and allow it to cool slowly, in order to remove internal stresses and toughen it.
Recombine (DNA) in the double-stranded form.
--Examples--
‘copper tubes must be annealed after bending or they will be brittle’
‘the chimneys of annealing furnaces’
‘Dr Lowenstein, annealed to hostility, looked at me coolly’

--Word--
Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1665–1714), queen of England and Scotland (known as Great Britain from 1707) and Ireland 1702–14. The last of the Stuart monarchs, daughter of the Catholic James II (but herself a Protestant), she succeeded her brother-in-law William III to the throne. None of her children survived into adulthood, and by the Act of Settlement (1701) the throne passed to the House of Hanover on her death.
--Examples--
--Word--
annelid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A segmented worm of the phylum Annelida, such as an earthworm or leech.
Relating to or denoting annelids.
--Examples--
--Word--
Annelida 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A large phylum that comprises the segmented worms, which include earthworms, lugworms, ragworms, and leeches.
--Examples--
--Word--
annelidan 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
annelidian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Annelid.
--Examples--
--Word--
annelid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A segmented worm of the phylum Annelida, such as an earthworm or leech.
Relating to or denoting annelids.
--Examples--
--Word--
Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1665–1714), queen of England and Scotland (known as Great Britain from 1707) and Ireland 1702–14. The last of the Stuart monarchs, daughter of the Catholic James II (but herself a Protestant), she succeeded her brother-in-law William III to the throne. None of her children survived into adulthood, and by the Act of Settlement (1701) the throne passed to the House of Hanover on her death.
--Examples--
--Word--
annex 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Add as an extra or subordinate part, especially to a document.
Add or attach as a condition or consequence.
Add (territory) to one's own territory by appropriation.
A building joined to or associated with a main building, providing additional space or accommodation.
An addition to a document.
--Examples--
‘the first ten amendments were annexed to the Constitution in 1791’
‘extreme anointing hath neither ordinance of God to be grounded on, nor promise of grace annexed’
‘the left bank of the Rhine was annexed by France in 1797’
‘the school's one-storey wooden annex’
‘an annex to the report’

--Word--
Oakley, Annie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1926), American markswoman; full name Phoebe Anne Oakley Mozee. In 1885 she joined Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, of which she became a star attraction for the next seventeen years.
--Examples--
--Word--
annihilator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
annihilator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
annihilate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Destroy utterly; obliterate.
Defeat utterly.
Convert (a subatomic particle) into radiant energy.
--Examples--
‘a simple bomb of this type could annihilate them all’
‘a crusade to annihilate evil’
‘the stronger force annihilated its opponent virtually without loss’
‘a fraction of the mass of atomic nuclei is annihilated’
‘mesons are unstable because the quark and antiquark can annihilate each other’

--Word--
annihilation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Complete destruction or obliteration.
Total defeat.
The conversion of matter into energy, especially the mutual conversion of a particle and an antiparticle into electromagnetic radiation.
--Examples--
‘the threat of global annihilation’
‘a show of independence is its only hope of avoiding annihilation in next year's elections’

anniversary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘the 75th anniversary of the RAF’
‘he even forgot our tenth anniversary!’

annoy

verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘your damned cheerfulness has always annoyed me’
‘a gallant Saxon, who annoyed this Coast’
--Word--
annoyance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The feeling or state of being annoyed; irritation.
A thing that annoys someone; a nuisance.
--Examples--
‘there was annoyance at government interference’
‘he turned his charm on Tara, much to Hegarty's annoyance’
‘the Council found him an annoyance’
‘some people like to irritate us with trivial annoyances’

--Word--
announce 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a formal public statement about a fact, occurrence, or intention.
Make known the arrival of (a guest) at a formal social occasion.
Give information about (transport) in a station or airport via a public address system.
--Examples--
‘the President's office announced that the siege would be lifted’
‘he announced his retirement from international football’
‘‘I have a confession to make,’ she announced’
‘they were announcing her train’

--Word--
announcement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A formal public statement about a fact, occurrence, or intention.
The action of making an announcement.
A notice appearing in a newspaper or public place and announcing something such as a birth, death, or marriage.
A piece of information given over a public address system.
--Examples--
‘the minister was about to make an announcement’
‘the announcement of the decision of the European Parliament’
‘an announcement is appearing in the Morning Post tomorrow’
‘a loudspeaker announcement echoed across the field’

--Word--
annual 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Occurring once every year.
Calculated over or covering a period of a year.
(of a plant) living only for a year or less, perpetuating itself by seed.
A book or magazine that is published once a year under the same title but with different contents.
An annual plant.
--Examples--
‘the sponsored walk became an annual event’
‘an annual report’
‘an annual rate of increase’
‘his basic annual income’
‘annual weeds’
‘a Christmas annual’
‘trade journals, annuals, and directories’
‘sow annuals in spring’
--Word--
annually 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Once a year; every year.
--Examples--
‘the prize is awarded annually’
‘sales are increasing by about 17% annually’
--Word--
annualized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a rate of interest, inflation, or return on an investment) recalculated as an annual rate.
--Examples--
‘an annualized yield of about 11.5%’
‘the economy exploded at a rate of over 7% annualized’
--Word--
annually 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Once a year; every year.
--Examples--
‘the prize is awarded annually’
‘sales are increasing by about 17% annually’

--Word--
annuity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fixed sum of money paid to someone each year, typically for the rest of their life.
A form of insurance or investment entitling the investor to a series of annual sums.
--Examples--
‘he left her an annuity of £1,000 in his will’
‘loans secured on an older person's home which are used to purchase a life annuity’
‘an annuity scheme’
--Word--

--Word--
annul 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Declare invalid (an official agreement, decision, or result)
Declare (a marriage) to have had no legal existence.
--Examples--
‘the elections were annulled by the general amid renewed protests’
‘her first marriage was finally annulled by His Holiness’

‘grounds for an annulment’
--Word--
annul 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Declare invalid (an official agreement, decision, or result)
Declare (a marriage) to have had no legal existence.
--Examples--
‘the elections were annulled by the general amid renewed protests’
‘her first marriage was finally annulled by His Holiness’

noun

anonymous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘an anonymous phone call’
‘his impeccable, slightly anonymous Chelsea flat’
--Word--

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that prevents a person from being identified by name.
In a way that produces no outstanding, individual, or unusual features; unremarkably or impersonally.
--Examples--
‘Newman published two novels, both anonymously’
‘the anonymously furnished parlour’

--Word--
another 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Used to refer to an additional person or thing of the same type as one already mentioned or known about; one more; a further.
Used with a proper name to indicate someone or something's similarity to the person or event specified.
Used to refer to a different person or thing from one already mentioned or known about.
Used to refer to someone sharing an attribute in common with the person already mentioned.
--Examples--
‘have another drink’
‘I didn't say another word’
‘she was to become another of his stars’
‘this will not be another Vietnam’
‘come back another day’
‘his wife left him for another man’
‘moving from one place to another’
‘his kiss with another man caused a tabloid rumpus’
--Word--

--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Used to refer to an additional person or thing of the same type as one already mentioned or known about; one more; a further.

--Word--
guess 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Estimate or conclude (something) without sufficient information to be sure of being correct.
Form a correct conclusion about (something) by guessing.
Used to indicate that although one thinks or supposes something, it is without any great conviction or strength of feeling.
An estimate or conclusion formed by guessing.
--Examples--
‘she guessed the child's age at 14 or 15’
‘he took her aside and I guessed that he was offering her a job’
‘we can only guess at Alan's motives’
‘she's guessed where we're going’
‘I guess I'd better tell you everything’
‘my guess is that within a year we will have a referendum’

Ansar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Islam. Any of the inhabitants of Medina who aided Muhammad at the time of the Hegira (Muhammad's flight from Mecca to Medina in 622) and who became early converts to Islam.
Originally: an adherent or follower of Muhammad Ahmad of Dongola in Sudan, who proclaimed himself the Mahdi in 1881; a Mahdist. Later: a member of the Islamic religious and political movement in Sudan led by the descendants of Muhammad Ahmad.

Anschluss 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The annexation of Austria by Germany in 1938. Hitler had forced the resignation of the Austrian Chancellor by demanding that he admit Nazis into his cabinet. The new Chancellor, a pro-Nazi, invited German troops to enter the country on the pretext of restoring law and order.

proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in Liaoning, China; population 1,293,000 (est. 2006). Anshan is situated close to major iron-ore deposits and China's largest iron and steel complex is nearby.
--Examples--
--Word--
ANSI 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
American National Standards Institute.
--Examples--
--Word--
anspessade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An experienced, usually long-serving, soldier, especially in the French or another continental European army. Compare earlier "lancepesade".
--Examples--
--Word--
answer 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing that is said, written, or done as a reaction to a question, statement, or situation.
A thing written or said in reaction to a question in a test or quiz.
The correct solution to a question in a test or quiz.
A solution to a problem or dilemma.
A person or thing regarded as the equivalent to a better-known one from another place.
Say or write something as a reaction to someone or something.
Provide the required response to (a question in a test or quiz)
Respond impudently or disrespectfully to someone, especially when being criticized or told to do something.
Act in reaction to (a sound such as a telephone ringing or a knock or ring on a door)
Be responsible or report to (someone)
Defend oneself against (a charge, accusation, or criticism)
Be required to explain or justify oneself to (someone)
Be responsible or to blame for.
Be suitable for fulfilling (a need); satisfy.
--Examples--
‘he knocked and entered without waiting for an answer’
‘I hurried along the passage in answer to the doorbell's ring’
‘write your answers on a postcard’
‘the answer is 280°’
‘the answer to poverty and unemployment is a properly funded range of services’
‘the press called her Britain's answer to Marilyn Monroe’
‘‘Of course I can,’ she answered’
‘she answered that she would take nothing but the ring’
‘she tried to answer his questions truthfully’
‘Steve was about to answer, but Hazel spoke first’
‘answer the questions below for a chance to win a holiday’
‘I'd usually talk him round, but never answer back’
‘Mary resisted the temptation to answer her mother back’
‘Digby answered the door’
‘she rang Edward's house, hoping the housekeeper would answer’
‘I answer to the Assistant Commissioner of Specialist Operations’
‘he said he would return to Spain to answer all charges’
‘you will have the police to answer to’
‘the dust mite has a lot to answer for, especially if you are asthmatic’
‘entrepreneurship is necessary to answer the needs of national and international markets’
--Word--
answerability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Responsibility for explaining or justifying one's actions.
--Examples--
‘the answerability of governments to the citizenry’
--Word--
answerable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Required to explain or justify one's actions to; responsible or having to report to.
Responsible for.
(of a question) able to be answered.
--Examples--
‘the Attorney General is answerable only to Parliament for his decisions’
‘an employer is answerable for the negligence of his employees’
‘straightforward and answerable questions’
--Word--
answerableness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or fact of corresponding, conformity; adaptation, responsiveness. archaic.
Accountability; responsibility; = "answerability".
--Examples--
--Word--
answerably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Without construction. Correspondingly, proportionally; suitably, appropriately, fittingly.
--Examples--
--Word--
answer-back 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A (typically automated) response to a transmitted message confirming receipt of the message and identifying the device which has received it; a device or system which issues such a response.
(A) A responsive action. (b) A rejoinder, a reply.
--Examples--
--Word--
answer 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing that is said, written, or done as a reaction to a question, statement, or situation.
A thing written or said in reaction to a question in a test or quiz.
The correct solution to a question in a test or quiz.

Act in reaction to (a sound such as a telephone ringing or a knock or ring on a door)
Be responsible or report to (someone)
Defend oneself against (a charge, accusation, or criticism)
Be required to explain or justify oneself to (someone)
Be responsible or to blame for.
Be suitable for fulfilling (a need); satisfy.

‘entrepreneurship is necessary to answer the needs of national and international markets’

--Word--
ant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small insect typically having a sting and living in a complex social colony with one or more breeding queens. It is wingless except for fertile adults, which form large mating swarms, and is proverbial for its industriousness.
--Examples--

Antabuse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A synthetic compound used in the treatment of alcoholics to make drinking alcohol produce unpleasant after-effects.

antacid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(chiefly of a medicine) preventing or correcting acidity, especially in the stomach.
An antacid medicine.
--Examples--
‘I prescribed a kaolin antacid mixture’
‘these drugs have an antacid and analgesic effect’

--Word--
Antaeus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A giant, the son of Poseidon and Earth, who compelled all comers to wrestle with him, overcoming and killing them all until he was defeated by Hercules.

--Word--
antagonist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who actively opposes or is hostile to someone or something; an adversary.
A substance which interferes with or inhibits the physiological action of another.
A muscle whose action counteracts that of another specified muscle.
--Examples--
‘he turned to confront his antagonist’
‘LSD is a serotonin antagonist’
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Showing or feeling active opposition or hostility towards someone or something.
Relating to an antagonist or its action.
--Examples--
‘he was antagonistic to the government's reforms’
‘an antagonistic group of bystanders’

--Word--
Dorati, Antal 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–88), US composer and conductor; born in Hungary. He was musical director of symphonies in Dallas 1945–49, Minneapolis 1949–60, Stockholm 1966–70, Washington, DC 1970–77, and Detroit 1977–81.
--Examples--

antanagoge 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A figure of speech in which an undesirable continuation is averted; specifically (a) introduction of a positive modification of, aspect to, or conclusion from an initial negative statement; (b) use of counter-accusation or recrimination to avoid answering a charge, etc.
--Examples--

Antananarivo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Madagascar, situated in the central plateau; population 1,697,000 (est. 2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
antapex 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The point on the celestial sphere, situated in the southern constellation Columba, away from which the solar system is moving relative to nearby stars; the point diametrically opposite to the solar apex; more fully "solar antapex". Also: the point on the celestial sphere away from which the earth is moving at any given moment in its orbital motion round the sun.
--Examples--
--Word--
antapex 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The point on the celestial sphere, situated in the southern constellation Columba, away from which the solar system is moving relative to nearby stars; the point diametrically opposite to the solar apex; more fully "solar antapex". Also: the point on the celestial sphere away from which the earth is moving at any given moment in its orbital motion round the sun.

Antarctic 
--Type--
adjective, noun

Relating to the south polar region or Antarctica.
Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising New Zealand, southern parts of Chile and Argentina, and islands in the South Atlantic and southern Indian Ocean.

--Examples--
--Word--
Antarctica 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A continent round the South Pole, situated mainly within the Antarctic Circle and almost entirely covered by ice sheets. Its exploitation is governed by an international treaty of 1959, which was renewed in 1991.
--Examples--
--Word--
Antarctical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Antarctic.

Antarctically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an Antarctic manner or direction; especially (cold) as in the Antarctic.
--Examples--

Antares 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The brightest star in the constellation Scorpius. It is a binary star of which the main component is a red supergiant.

noun, adjective

Used to treat arthritis (in early use specifically gout); of or relating to the treatment of arthritis. Compare earlier "arthritic".

ante 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stake put up by a player in poker or brag before receiving cards.
Put up an amount as an ante in poker or brag and similar games.
Pay an amount of money in advance.
--Examples--
‘the antes were at the $10,000–$20,000 level’
‘he anted up $925,000 of his own money’
‘the owners have to ante up if they want to attract the best talent’

anteambulo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person whose job it is to walk in front of another; especially an usher; also figurative. Now specifically in Roman History: a client who walked in front of his patron to clear the way.

--Word--
antecedence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
antecedency 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Precedence in time or order; (occasionally) an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
antecedent 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A thing that existed before or logically precedes another.
A person's ancestors or family and social background.
An earlier word, phrase, or clause to which another word (especially a following relative pronoun) refers back.
The statement contained in the ‘if’ clause of a conditional proposition.
Preceding in time or order; previous or pre-existing.
Denoting or counting as an antecedent.
--Examples--
‘some antecedents to the African novel might exist in Africa's oral traditions’
‘her early life and antecedents have been traced’
‘antecedent events’
--Word--
antecedental 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of an antecedent or precursor.
Mathematics. Designating a method of performing calculus based on the use of the antecedents of certain ratios. See "antecedent". Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
antecedently 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
antecedent 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A thing that existed before or logically precedes another.
A person's ancestors or family and social background.
An earlier word, phrase, or clause to which another word (especially a following relative pronoun) refers back.

Come before (something) in time, order, or position; precede.
--Examples--
‘investigative reporting long antecedes the invention of miniature cameras’
--Word--
antecede 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Come before (something) in time, order, or position; precede.
--Examples--
‘investigative reporting long antecedes the invention of miniature cameras’
--Word--
antecessor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who precedes another as holder of a position, office, title, etc.
An ancestor, a forebear; (more generally) a member of a preceding generation.
Chiefly historical. A predecessor in the possession of property; a person from or through whom property is inherited.
A precursor or antecedent; a thing which has been followed or replaced by another.
A teacher of law at a school or university. Now historical (especially Ancient History).
--Examples--
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
A small room leading to a main one.
--Examples--
‘the antechamber to an interview room’

ante Christum 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Following (or occasionally preceding) a date or time period: before the birth of Christ; in the time before year 1 of the Christian era. Abbreviated A.C.

--Word--
Ante-Communion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "Ante-Communion Service". The earlier part of the Communion Service in the Book of Common Prayer, which extends from the beginning of the office to the end of the general prayer ‘For the whole state of Christ's Church militant here in earth’, or, in the American rite, to the Gospel; (also) the first part of a Eucharistic service in which Communion is not received.
--Examples--

anteconsonantal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Preceding a consonant.

--Word--
ante 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stake put up by a player in poker or brag before receiving cards.
Put up an amount as an ante in poker or brag and similar games.
Pay an amount of money in advance.
--Examples--
‘the antes were at the $10,000–$20,000 level’
‘he anted up $925,000 of his own money’
‘the owners have to ante up if they want to attract the best talent’
--Word--
antedate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Precede in time; come before (something) in date.
Indicate or discover that (a document, event, or word) should be assigned to an earlier date.
--Examples--
‘a civilization that antedated the Roman Empire’
‘there are no references to him that would antedate his birth’

--Word--
antediluvial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Existing or occurring before the Flood described in the biblical book of Genesis, or (in later use) before a widespread flood as described in other mythological traditions; of or relating to the period before such a flood.
Geology. Earlier or older than a period of deposition of diluvial or drift deposits. Now chiefly historical.
Of animals, plants, etc.: prehistoric; long extinct; such as are known only from their fossil remains.
Very antiquated; ridiculously old-fashioned or out-of-date; = "antediluvian". Now somewhat rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
antediluvially 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In times before the Flood described in the biblical book of Genesis, or (later) before any widespread flooding.
--Examples--
--Word--
antediluvian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood.
Ridiculously old-fashioned.
--Examples--
‘gigantic bones of antediluvian animals’
‘they maintain antediluvian sex-role stereotypes’

ecclesiastical

--Meanings--
Relating to the Christian Church or its clergy.
--Examples--
‘the ecclesiastical hierarchy’
--Word--
anting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Behaviour seen in some birds, in which the bird either picks up ants and rubs them on the feathers or stands with the wings spread and allows the ants to crawl over it. It is probable that the ants' secretions help to keep the feathers in good condition.
--Examples--

anteflexed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Bent forwards; specifically (of the uterus) having the fundus bent forwards with respect to the cervix. Contrasted with "retroflexed".
--Examples--
--Word--
anteflexion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition or fact of being bent forwards, especially the condition of the uterus in which the fundus is bent forwards with respect to the cervix. Also: the action of bending something forwards. Contrasted with "retroflexion".
--Examples--
--Word--
antefurca 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the thorax of an insect: the furca of the prothorax, which is the first of three furcas that serve for the attachment of muscles in the thorax.
--Examples--
--Word--
Gothic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Goths or their extinct language, which belongs to the East Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family. It provides the earliest manuscript evidence of any Germanic language (4th–6th centuries AD).
Of or in the style of architecture prevalent in western Europe in the 12th–16th centuries (and revived in the mid 18th to early 20th centuries), characterized by pointed arches, rib vaults, and flying buttresses, together with large windows and elaborate tracery. English Gothic architecture is divided into Early English, Decorated, and Perpendicular.
Belonging to or redolent of the Dark Ages; portentously gloomy or horrifying.
(of lettering) of or derived from the angular style of handwriting with broad vertical downstrokes used in western Europe from the 13th century, including Fraktur and black-letter typefaces.
Relating to goths or goth music.
The extinct language of the Goths.
The Gothic style of architecture.
Gothic type.
--Examples--
‘19th-century Gothic horror’

--Meanings--

--Word--
Justinian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.483–565), Byzantine emperor 527–65; Latin name Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Justinianus. Through his general Belisarius he regained North Africa and Spain. He codified Roman law (529) and carried out a building programme throughout the Empire, of which St Sophia at Constantinople (532) was a part.
--Examples--
--Word--
antelope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A swift-running deerlike ruminant with smooth hair and upward-pointing horns, of a group native to Africa and Asia that includes the gazelles, impala, gnus, and elands.

--Word--
mosaic 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
A picture or pattern produced by arranging together small pieces of stone, tile, glass, etc.
A colourful and variegated pattern.
A combination of diverse elements forming a more or less coherent whole.
An arrangement of photosensitive elements in a television camera.
An individual (especially an animal) composed of cells of two genetically different types.
A virus disease that results in leaf variegation in tobacco, maize, sugar cane, and other plants.
Decorate with a mosaic.
Combine (distinct or disparate elements) to form a picture or pattern.
Denoting an individual composed of cells of two genetically different types.
Of or associated with Moses.
--Examples--
‘mosaics on the interior depict scenes from the Old Testament’
‘the walls and vaults are decorated by marble and mosaic’
‘the bird's plumage was a mosaic of slate-grey, blue, and brown’
‘a cultural mosaic’
‘he mosaicked the walls, ceilings, and floors’
‘the digital data were combined, or mosaicked, to delineate counties’

--Word--
Norman 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A city in central Oklahoma, south of Oklahoma City, home to the University of Oklahoma; population 106,957 (est. 2008).
A member of a people of mixed Frankish and Scandinavian origin who settled in Normandy from about AD 912 and became a dominant military power in western Europe and the Mediterranean in the 11th century.
Any of the Normans who conquered England in 1066, or their descendants.
A native or inhabitant of modern Normandy.
The form of French spoken by the Normans.
Relating to the Normans.
Denoting or relating to the style of Romanesque architecture used in Britain under the Normans.
Relating to modern Normandy.
--Examples--
‘the castle goes right back to the Normans’
‘born c.1080, he was presumably a Norman from Calvados’
‘the Norman invasion’
‘the 11th-century Norman crypt of Winchester Cathedral’
‘Willy rambled on about Norman archways and Perpendicular naves’
‘Norman ore was to have been smelted there with Ruhr coal’

ante-predicament 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Usually in plural Any of various concepts or relations treated at the beginning of Aristotle’s Categories, before the discussion of the categories (the predicaments) themselves; a concept necessary for understanding the Aristotelian categories.

anterior 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Victorian 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the reign of Queen Victoria.
Relating to the attitudes and values of society during Queen Victoria's reign, regarded as characterized especially by prudishness and a high moral tone.
A person who lived during the Victorian period.
Relating to the Australian state of Victoria.
A person from the Australian state of Victoria.
--Examples--
‘a Victorian house’
‘a return to Victorian values’
‘the Victorians had a passion for documenting, cataloguing and classifying the world around them’
‘the Victorian Government has called for tenders to redevelop Melbourne's railway station’
‘the facility has taught thousands of Victorians to use the internet’

--Word--
anthem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rousing or uplifting song identified with a particular group, body, or cause.
A solemn patriotic song officially adopted by a country as an expression of national identity.
A musical setting of a religious text to be sung by a choir during a church service, especially in Anglican or Protestant Churches.
--Examples--
‘the song became the anthem for hippy activists’
‘the crowd stood and sang the national anthem’
‘we decided that the match would not have the anthems of either country as a prelude’

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
anthemis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a camomile, especially Chamaemelum nobile. In later use: any of the aromatic herbaceous plants and subshrubs of (or formerly of) the Eurasian genus Anthemis (family Asteraceae (Compositae)), having daisy-like inflorescences and finely divided foliage. Also (usually in form Anthemis): the genus itself.

anthericum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any plant of the genus Anthericum (family Asparagaceae) or formerly belonging to it, which have rhizomatous or tuberous roots, narrow leaves, and bear racemes or panicles of star-like, usually white flowers; a spiderwort. Also (in form Anthericum): the genus itself.

--Word--
anthias 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of several small, brightly-coloured serranid fishes found in the Mediterranean and referred to by classical authors; especially the swallowtail sea perch, Anthias anthias. In later use: any of numerous small serranid fishes of the subfamily Anthiinae, many of which swarm on coral reefs, are brightly coloured, and are popular with aquarists.

--Word--
anthypophora 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The refutation (with an answer or qualifying statement) by a speaker or writer of a potential objection or counter-argument which has just been anticipated and stated by the speaker him- or herself. Also occasionally: the whole rhetorical figure in which such an objection is raised and then refuted in this way.

Anthomedusae 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. An order of hydroid coelenterates (class Hydrozoa) having a polyp stage that lacks a perisarc and a free-living medusa stage typically having a simple bell shape with the gonads situated primarily on the manubrium.
--Examples--
--Word--
Quinn, Anthony 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–2001), US actor; born in Mexico; full name Anthony Rudolph Oaxaca Quinn. His movies include Viva Zapata (1952), La Strada (1954), Lust for Life (1956), Wild Is the Wind (1957), Zorba the Greek (1964), and A Walk in the Clouds (1995).

Anthozoa 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A large class of sedentary marine coelenterates that includes the sea anemones and corals. They are either solitary or colonial, and have a central mouth surrounded by tentacles.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
anthracosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs and certain other tissues, typically resulting from chronic inhalation of coal dust or smoke; lung disease attributed to this; an instance of such accumulation or disease.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthracothere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extinct artiodactyl ungulate mammal of the group including Anthracotherium, found in Eurasia, Africa, and North America during the Tertiary period, and thought to be related to hippotamuses and possibly to the ancestors of whales.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthracotherium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large extinct ungulate artiodactyl mammal of the genus Anthracotherium (family Anthracotheriidae) or the group including this genus, known from fossil remains in Tertiary deposits, especially of lignite. Also (in form Anthracotherium): the genus itself.

anthraquinone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellow crystalline compound obtained by oxidation of anthracene. It is the basis of many natural and synthetic dyes.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthrax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A serious bacterial disease of sheep and cattle, typically affecting the skin and lungs. It can be transmitted to humans, causing severe skin ulceration (malignant pustule) or a form of pneumonia (wool-sorters' disease).
--Examples--
--Word--
anthraxolite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of hard bitumen resembling coal, occurring in veins and cavities in sedimentary rocks (especially oil shales).
--Examples--
--Word--
anthrol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of compounds which are monohydroxy derivatives of anthracene.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthrone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless crystalline ketone prepared by reduction of anthraquinone and used as a reagent in tests for cellulose and starch.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthropism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief or theory that humanity is the central or most important element of existence or of the universe; anthropocentrism.
In physics, philosophy, and cosmology: (support for) the principle or theory that the nature of the universe must be compatible with the existence of intelligent life, especially human life; advocacy or expression of (a version of) the anthropic principle.
The attribution of human form, feelings, language, etc., to something other than a human being; an instance of this; anthropomorphism, anthropopathy. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthropism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief or theory that humanity is the central or most important element of existence or of the universe; anthropocentrism.
In physics, philosophy, and cosmology: (support for) the principle or theory that the nature of the universe must be compatible with the existence of intelligent life, especially human life; advocacy or expression of (a version of) the anthropic principle.
The attribution of human form, feelings, language, etc., to something other than a human being; an instance of this; anthropomorphism, anthropopathy. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthropism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief or theory that humanity is the central or most important element of existence or of the universe; anthropocentrism.
In physics, philosophy, and cosmology: (support for) the principle or theory that the nature of the universe must be compatible with the existence of intelligent life, especially human life; advocacy or expression of (a version of) the anthropic principle.
The attribution of human form, feelings, language, etc., to something other than a human being; an instance of this; anthropomorphism, anthropopathy. Now rare.

anthropic principle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The cosmological principle that theories of the universe are constrained by the necessity to allow human existence.

anthropoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

‘anthropoid gods’

anthropolatry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The worship of a human as a divine being; the inappropriate or idolatrous elevation of a person to the status of a god.
--Examples--
--Word--
anthropolith 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A petrified human body, or part of one; a fossil of (supposedly) human origin. Also: a human figure made of stone; figurative a person without feelings or emotions.
--Examples--

anthropomorphist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
anthropomorphite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person (especially a member of a religious sect or group) who ascribes a human form to God; specifically (a) a member of a Christian sect that arose in Egypt in the 4th cent.; (b) a member of a party in the Western Church in the 10th cent.
Of, relating to, or characterized by anthropomorphitism; specifically that ascribes human form, character, or attributes to God.

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the doctrines of Jacobus Arminius (Latinized name of Jakob Hermandszoon, 1560–1609), a Dutch Protestant theologian who rejected the Calvinist doctrine of predestination. His teachings had a considerable influence on Methodism.
An adherent of Arminian doctrines.

--Word--
attrition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of reducing something's strength or effectiveness through sustained attack or pressure.
The gradual reduction of a workforce by employees leaving and not being replaced rather than by redundancy.
Wearing away by friction; abrasion.
(in scholastic theology) sorrow for sin, falling short of contrition.
--Examples--
‘the council is trying to wear down the opposition by attrition’
‘the squadron suffered severe attrition of its bombers’
‘the company said that it will reduce its worldwide employment by about 10% through attrition’
‘the skull shows attrition of the edges of the teeth’
--Word--
Australian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Australia, or a person of Australian descent.
Relating to Australia.
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Australasia together with Indonesia east of Wallace's line, in which monotremes and marsupials dominate the fauna.
Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising only Australia and Tasmania.

antibody 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blood protein produced in response to and counteracting a specific antigen. Antibodies combine chemically with substances which the body recognizes as alien, such as bacteria, viruses, and foreign substances in the blood.
--Examples--
--Word--
antibody 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blood protein produced in response to and counteracting a specific antigen. Antibodies combine chemically with substances which the body recognizes as alien, such as bacteria, viruses, and foreign substances in the blood.

Bolshevik 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.
(in general use) a person with politically subversive or radical views; a revolutionary.

--Examples--
‘the Bolshevik revolution’
--Word--
Bolshevism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘enthusiastic supporters of Bolshevism’
--Word--
Bolshevist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A supporter or member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.
(in general use) a person with politically subversive or radical views; a revolutionary.
--Examples--
‘the seizure of power by the Bolshevists’
‘the Bolshevist movement’
‘he is not a bolshevist, but he is by nature a bit of a grumbler’
‘students with bolshevist tendencies’

Grotesque or bizarre.

--Word--
Calvinism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Protestant theological system of John Calvin and his successors, which develops Luther's doctrine of justification by faith alone into an emphasis on the grace of God and centres on the doctrine of predestination.
--Examples--
--Word--
Calvinist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An adherent of the Protestant theological system of John Calvin and his successors.
Relating to the Protestant theological system of John Calvin and his successors.
--Examples--
‘she was a strict Calvinist’
‘the Dutch state was still distinctly Calvinist’

anti- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Opposed to; against.
Preventing.
Relieving.
The opposite of.
Acting as a rival.
Unlike the conventional form.
The antiparticle of a specified particle.

‘anti-hero’
‘antiproton’
--Word--
anticathode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The target (or anode) of an X-ray tube which is struck by electrons from the cathode and from which X-rays are emitted.
--Examples--
--Word--
catholic 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Including a wide variety of things; all-embracing.
Of the Roman Catholic faith.
Of or including all Christians.
Relating to the historic doctrine and practice of the Western Church.
A member of the Roman Catholic Church.
--Examples--
‘her tastes are pretty catholic’
‘the Church of England must not compromise its Catholic principles’
--Word--
Catholicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The faith, practice, and church order of the Roman Catholic Church.
Adherence to the forms of Christian doctrine and practice which are generally regarded as Catholic rather than Protestant or Eastern Orthodox.
--Examples--
--Word--
anticholinergic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(chiefly of a drug) inhibiting the physiological action of acetylcholine, especially as a neurotransmitter.
An anticholinergic drug.
--Examples--
--Word--
Antichrist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in some Christian teachings) a personal opponent of Christ expected to appear before the end of the world.
A person or force seen as opposing Christ or the Christian Church.
A person or thing regarded as supremely evil or as a fundamental enemy or opponent.
--Examples--
‘the battle between Christ and the Antichrist’
‘St Paul really did have to fear for his life at the hands of an Antichrist named Nero’
‘I see the media as the Antichrist’

--Word--
anticyclone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A weather system with high barometric pressure at its centre, around which air slowly circulates in a clockwise (northern hemisphere) or anticlockwise (southern hemisphere) direction. Anticyclones are associated with calm, fine weather.
--Examples--
--Word--
anticyclone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A weather system with high barometric pressure at its centre, around which air slowly circulates in a clockwise (northern hemisphere) or anticlockwise (southern hemisphere) direction. Anticyclones are associated with calm, fine weather.
--Examples--

anticipator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
anticipate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Regard as probable; expect or predict.
Guess or be aware of (what will happen) and take action in order to be prepared.
Look forward to.
Act as a forerunner or precursor of.
Come or take place before (an event or process expected or scheduled for a later time)
--Examples--
‘she anticipated scorn on her return to the theatre’
‘it was anticipated that the rains would slow the military campaign’
‘they failed to anticipate a full-scale invasion’
‘Stephen was eagerly anticipating the break from the routine of business’
‘he anticipated Bates's theories on mimicry and protective coloration’
‘this is to anticipate the argument’

anticipation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of anticipating something; expectation or prediction.
The introduction in a composition of part of a chord which is about to follow in full.
--Examples--
‘her eyes sparkled with anticipation’
‘they manned the telephones in anticipation of a flood of calls’

entente 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A friendly understanding or informal alliance between states or factions.
A group of states in an informal alliance.
The understanding between Britain and France reached in 1904, forming the basis of Anglo-French cooperation in the First World War.
--Examples--
‘the emperor hoped to bring about an entente with Russia’
‘the unsuccessful scheme to lure Greece into the war on the side of the entente’

Antietam 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Europe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A continent of the northern hemisphere, separated from Africa to the south by the Mediterranean Sea and from Asia to the east roughly by the Bosporus, the Caucasus Mountains, and the Ural Mountains. Europe contains approximately 20 per cent of the world's population.
The European Union.
The mainland of continental Europe as distinct from the British Isles.
--Examples--
‘the Prime Minister who took Britain into Europe’
‘A Guide to the Birds of Britain and Europe’
--Word--
European 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Europe or its inhabitants.
Relating to the European Union.
A native or inhabitant of Europe.
A national of a state belonging to the European Union.
A person who is committed to the European Union.
A person of European parentage.
--Examples--
‘twentieth-century European art’
‘the culture and history of the European peoples’
‘a single European currency’
‘they claimed to be the party of good Europeans’

--Word--
fascism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An authoritarian and nationalistic right-wing system of government and social organization.
(in general use) extreme authoritarian, oppressive, or intolerant views or practices.
--Examples--
‘this is yet another example of health fascism in action’
--Word--
antifascist 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Opposed to fascism or to extreme right-wing authoritarianism.
A person who is opposed to fascism or to extreme right-wing authoritarianism.
--Examples--
‘thousands of antifascist protesters blocked a neo-Nazi march in the German city’
‘by the spring of 1937, complex rivalries between political factions were tearing the antifascist forces apart’
‘more than 150 antifascists confronted about 25 white supremacists in front of the state capitol’
--Word--
anti-fascist

adjective, noun

Opposed to fascism or to extreme right-wing authoritarianism.

‘by the spring of 1937, complex rivalries between political factions were tearing the anti-fascist forces apart’
‘rival protests by anti-fascists and BNP supporters outside the Palace of Westminster saw scuffles despite a heavy police presence’

federalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who advocates or supports a system of government in which several states unite under a central authority.
A member or supporter of the Federalist Party.
Relating to or denoting a system of government in which several states unite under a central authority.
Denoting or pertaining to the Federalist Party.
--Examples--
‘the ideas of the European federalists’
‘they captured the legislative and the executive branches of the federal government from the Federalists’
‘the federalist structure of the American system of government’
‘it was not a weapon that could reach the Federalist judges’

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
France 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in western Europe; population 64,400,000 (estimated 2015); official language, French; capital, Paris.
--Examples--

anti-fraud 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designed to prevent fraudulent practices.
--Examples--
‘new anti-fraud measures will save the taxpayer millions in lost revenue’
--Word--
antifreeze 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A liquid, typically one based on ethylene glycol, that can be added to water to lower the freezing point, chiefly used in the radiator of a motor vehicle.
--Examples--
‘most breakdowns were due to people forgetting to put antifreeze in their radiators’
‘formulating antifreezes and de-icers for railways is no easy job’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘formulating antifreezes and de-icers for railways is no easy job’

noun

--Word--
Freud, Sigmund 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1856–1939), Austrian neurologist and psychotherapist.
--Examples--
--Word--
Freudian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or influenced by Sigmund Freud and his methods of psychoanalysis, especially with reference to the importance of sexuality in human behaviour.
Susceptible to analysis in terms of unconscious desires.
A follower of Freud or his methods.
--Examples--
‘the Freudian concept of the superego’
‘he wasn't sure whether his passion for water power had some deep Freudian significance’
--Word--
Freudianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Used to prevent fungal growth; active against fungi.
An antifungal drug or other substance.

‘coconut oil has antifungal and antibacterial properties’
‘the patient responded well to systemic antifungals’

--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘the Gallic retreat from Delphi’
--Word--
Gallican 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the ancient Church of Gaul or France.
Of or holding a doctrine (reaching its peak in the 17th century) which asserted the freedom of the Roman Catholic Church in France and elsewhere from the ecclesiastical authority of the papacy.
An adherent of the Gallican doctrine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Gallicanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
german 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Germane.
A native or inhabitant of Germany, or a person of German descent.
A West Germanic language used in Germany, Austria, and parts of Switzerland, and by communities in the US and elsewhere. It is spoken by some 100 million people.
Relating to Germany, its people, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Germanic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the branch of the Indo-European language family that includes English, German, Dutch, Frisian, and the Scandinavian languages.
Relating to or denoting the peoples of ancient northern and western Europe speaking Germanic languages.
Having characteristics of or attributed to Germans or Germany.
The Germanic languages collectively.
The unrecorded ancient language from which the Germanic languages developed, thought to have been spoken on the shores of the Baltic Sea in the 3rd millennium BC.
--Examples--
‘she had an almost Germanic regard for order’
--Word--
Germanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An idiom, grammatical construction, word, or other linguistic feature particular to German, especially one used or adopted in another language.
(A) German ideas, philosophy, or attitudes; German ways of thinking or acting; (b) attachment to or adoption of these.
German quality, character, or style.
--Examples--
--Word--
Germanization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
Antigone 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Daughter of Oedipus and Jocasta, the subject of a tragedy by Sophocles. She was sentenced to death for defying her uncle Creon, king of Thebes, but she took her own life before the sentence could be carried out, and Creon's son Haemon, who was engaged to her, killed himself over her body.
--Examples--
--Word--
antigorite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral of the serpentine group, occurring typically as thin green plates.

antigravity 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A hypothetical force opposing gravity.

Greek 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Greece, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of modern Greece, or a person of Greek descent.
A Greek-speaking person in the ancient world, especially a native of one of the city states of Greece and the eastern Mediterranean.
The ancient or modern language of Greece, the only representative of the Hellenic branch of the Indo-European family.
A member of a fraternity or sorority having a Greek-letter name.

--Word--
heroic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having the characteristics of a hero or heroine; admirably brave or determined.
Of or representing heroes or heroines.
(of language or a work of art) grand or grandiose in scale or intention.
(of a statue) larger than life size but less than colossal.
Behaviour or talk that is bold or dramatic.
--Examples--
‘heroic deeds’
‘heroic bomb disposal experts’
‘early medieval heroic poetry’
‘one passes under pyramids and obelisks, all on a heroic scale’
‘the England star is getting special treatment because of his World Cup heroics’

noun
--Meanings--
The unrealistic belief in or pursuit of perfection.

--Word--
immune 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resistant to a particular infection or toxin owing to the presence of specific antibodies or sensitized white blood cells.
Relating to immune resistance.
Protected or exempt, especially from an obligation or the effects of something.
Not affected or influenced by something.
--Examples--
‘they were naturally immune to hepatitis B’
‘they are immune from legal action’
‘no one is immune to his immense charm’
--Word--
imperialism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A policy of extending a country's power and influence through colonization, use of military force, or other means.
Rule by an emperor.
--Examples--
‘the struggle against imperialism’
‘French ministers protested at US cultural imperialism’
‘in Russia, imperialism had developed alongside a semi-feudal agrarian structure’

--Word--
indemnity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Security or protection against a loss or other financial burden.
Security against or exemption from legal responsibility for one's actions.
A sum of money paid as compensation, especially one paid by a country defeated in war as a condition of peace.
--Examples--
‘no indemnity will be given for loss of cash’
‘a deed of indemnity’
‘even warranties and indemnities do not provide complete protection’
--Word--
induction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of inducting someone to a post or organization.
A formal introduction to a new job or position.
Enlistment into military service.
The process or action of bringing about or giving rise to something.
The process of bringing on the birth of a baby by artificial means, typically by the use of drugs.
The inference of a general law from particular instances.
The production of facts to prove a general statement.
A means of proving a theorem by showing that if it is true of any particular case it is true of the next case in a series, and then showing that it is indeed true in one particular case.
The production of an electric or magnetic state by the proximity (without contact) of an electrified or magnetized body.
The production of an electric current in a conductor by varying the magnetic field applied to the conductor.
The stage of the working cycle of an internal combustion engine in which the fuel mixture is drawn into the cylinders.
--Examples--
‘induction into membership of a Masonic brotherhood’
‘an induction course’
‘the induction of malformations by radiation’
‘the admission that laws of nature cannot be established by induction’
--Word--
inductive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by the inference of general laws from particular instances.
Relating to or caused by electric or magnetic induction.
Possessing inductance.
--Examples--
‘instinct rather than inductive reasoning marked her approach to life’

Irishism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A statement which is manifestly self-contradictory or inconsistent.
A characteristically Irish word, phrase, or idiom. Also occasionally more generally: a characteristically Irish belief, attitude, or trait.
Chiefly depreciative. The fact or quality of being Irish; Irishness.
--Examples--

isolation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or fact of isolating or being isolated.

--Examples--

--Word--
isolationism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A policy of remaining apart from the affairs or interests of other groups, especially the political affairs of other countries.
--Examples--
‘the country chose a policy of isolationism that made it a secondary player in world political events’
‘sectarian isolationism’

Favouring a policy of remaining apart from the affairs or interests of other groups.
--Examples--
‘there was intense opposition to the proposal from isolationists’
‘the country pursued an isolationist policy’

Italian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Italy, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Italy, or a person of Italian descent.
The Romance language of Italy, descended from Latin and with roughly 60 million speakers worldwide. It is also one of the official languages of Switzerland.

--Word--
Jacobin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a democratic club established in Paris in 1789. The Jacobins were the most radical and ruthless of the political groups formed in the wake of the French Revolution, and in association with Robespierre they instituted the Terror of 1793–4.
An extreme political radical.
A Dominican friar.
A pigeon of a breed with reversed feathers on the back of its neck like a cowl.
A mainly green Central and South American hummingbird, with blue feathers on the head.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
Jesuit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the Society of Jesus, a Roman Catholic order of priests founded by St Ignatius Loyola, St Francis Xavier, and others in 1534, to do missionary work. The order was zealous in opposing the Reformation. Despite periodic persecution it has retained an important influence in Catholic thought and education.
--Examples--
--Word--
Jesuitically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Jesuitical

adjective
--Meanings--
Of or concerning the Jesuits.
Dissembling or equivocating, in the manner once associated with Jesuits.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
Antikythera mechanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mechanical astronomical device believed to have been manufactured in ancient Greece in the first or second century b.c., fragments of which were discovered in 1900 amongst the cargo of an ancient shipwreck off the coast of the Greek island of Antikythera.
--Examples--

--Word--
laissez-faire 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The policy of leaving things to take their own course, without interfering.
Abstention by governments from interfering in the workings of the free market.
--Examples--
‘a laissez-faire attitude to life’
‘laissez-faire capitalism’
--Word--
Lamarckian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the French naturalist Jean Baptiste de Lamarck or his theory about the cause of organic evolution.
An adherent of the French naturalist Jean Baptiste de Lamarck's theory about the cause of organic evolution.
--Examples--
‘the mechanism of Lamarckian evolution’
‘a Lamarckian who believes that acquired characteristics can be inherited’
--Word--
Latin 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The language of ancient Rome and its empire, widely used historically as a language of scholarship and administration.
An inhabitant of ancient Latium in Ιtaly.
A native or inhabitant of a country whose language developed from Latin, especially a Latin American.
Music of a kind originating in Latin America, characterized by dance rhythms and extensive use of indigenous percussion instruments.
Relating to Latin.
Relating to the Western or Roman Catholic Church (as historically using Latin for its rites)
Relating to ancient Latium.
Relating to the countries using languages, such as French and Spanish, that developed from Latin.
Relating to or characteristic of Latin American music.
--Examples--
‘eclectic jazz through Latin into soulful grooves’
‘Latin poetry’
‘the Latin patriarch of Antioch’
‘Mexico and other Latin countries’
‘snapping his fingers to a Latin beat’

--Word--
liberal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Willing to respect or accept behaviour or opinions different from one's own; open to new ideas.
Favourable to or respectful of individual rights and freedoms.
(in a political context) favouring individual liberty, free trade, and moderate political and social reform.
Relating to Liberals or a Liberal Party, especially (in the UK) relating to the Liberal Democrat party.
Regarding many traditional beliefs as dispensable, invalidated by modern thought, or liable to change.
(of education) concerned with broadening a person's general knowledge and experience, rather than with technical or professional training.
(especially of an interpretation of a law) broadly construed or understood; not strictly literal.
Given, used, or occurring in generous amounts.
(of a person) giving generously.
A person of liberal views.
A supporter or member of a Liberal Party, especially (in the UK) a Liberal Democrat.
--Examples--
‘liberal views towards divorce’
‘liberal citizenship laws’
‘a liberal democratic state’
‘the Liberal leader’
‘the provision of liberal adult education’
‘they could have given the 1968 Act a more liberal interpretation’
‘liberal amounts of wine had been consumed’
‘Sam was too liberal with the wine’
‘a concern among liberals about the relation of the citizen to the state’
--Word--
anti-life 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Opposed to or restricting the full development of natural life.
--Examples--
‘the new industrial age was anti-life’
--Word--
Antilles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of islands, forming the greater part of the West Indies. The Greater Antilles, extending roughly east to west, comprise Cuba, Jamaica, Hispaniola (Haiti and the Dominican Republic), and Puerto Rico; the Lesser Antilles, to the south-east, include the Virgin Islands, Leeward Islands, Windward Islands, Barbados, and various small islands to the north of Venezuela.

Malthusian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus or his ideas about population.
A person who supports the theories about population proposed by the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus.
--Examples--
‘it seems we face a curious Malthusian catastrophe’
‘Malthusians spoke of moral restraint’
--Word--
Malthusianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The view that without ‘moral restraint’ the population will increase at a greater rate than its means of subsistence, as proposed by the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus.
--Examples--
‘birth control became associated with Malthusianism only in the last quarter of the century’

Mongolian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Mongolia.
The language of Mongolia, a member of the Altaic family with an unusual vertical cursive script. It has some 2 million speakers, and related forms are spoken by over 3 million people in northern China.
Relating to Mongolia, its people, or their language.

nationalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

‘a nationalist movement’
--Word--
Nebraska 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the central US to the west of the Missouri River; population 1,783,432 (est. 2008); capital, Lincoln. It was acquired as part of the Louisiana Purchase in 1803 and became the 37th state of the US in 1867.
--Examples--

--Word--
anting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Behaviour seen in some birds, in which the bird either picks up ants and rubs them on the feathers or stands with the wings spread and allows the ants to crawl over it. It is probable that the ants' secretions help to keep the feathers in good condition.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Nordic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting Scandinavia, Finland, and Iceland.
Relating to or denoting a physical type of northern European peoples characterized by tall stature, a bony frame, light colouring, and a dolichocephalic head.
Involving the disciplines of cross-country skiing or ski jumping.
A person from Scandinavia, Finland, or Iceland.
--Examples--
‘the Nordic countries’
‘the Nordic races’
‘on one street corner a dusky Moorish maiden, the next a Nordic blonde’
‘Jim competes as a veteran in Nordic events in Scotland’
‘the Nordics might share a common history, speak similar languages, enjoy the same culture’

Antioch 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern Turkey, near the Syrian border; population 186,200 (est. 2007). Antioch was the ancient capital of Syria under the Seleucid kings, who founded it c.300 BC.
A city in ancient Phrygia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Antiochus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of eight Seleucid kings.
Antiochus III (c.242–187 BC), reigned 223–187 BC; known as Antiochus the Great. He restored and expanded the Seleucid empire.
Antiochus IV (c.215–163 BC), son of Antiochus III, reigned 175–163 BC; known as Antiochus Epiphanes. His firm control of Judaea and his attempt to Hellenize the Jews resulted in the revival of Jewish nationalism and the Maccabean revolt.
--Examples--

--Word--
oriental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, from, or characteristic of Asia, especially East Asia.
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Asia south of the Himalayas and Indonesia west of Wallace's line. Distinctive animals include pandas, gibbons, tree shrews, tarsiers, and moonrats.
(of a pearl or other jewel) orient.
A person of East Asian descent.
--Examples--
‘oriental countries’
‘oriental rugs’
--Word--
orientalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Style, artefacts, or traits considered characteristic of the peoples and cultures of Asia.
The representation of Asia in a stereotyped way that is regarded as embodying a colonialist attitude.
--Examples--

antioxidant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
antiparticle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subatomic particle having the same mass as a given particle but opposite electric or magnetic properties. Every kind of subatomic particle has a corresponding antiparticle, e.g. the positron has the same mass as the electron but an equal and opposite charge.
--Examples--
--Word--
antiparticle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subatomic particle having the same mass as a given particle but opposite electric or magnetic properties. Every kind of subatomic particle has a corresponding antiparticle, e.g. the positron has the same mass as the electron but an equal and opposite charge.
--Examples--
