--Word--
Pauline 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of St Paul, his writings, or his doctrines.
(in the Roman Catholic Church) relating to Pope Paul VI, or the liturgical and doctrinal reforms pursued during his pontificate (1963–78) as a result of the Second Vatican Council.
--Examples--

‘Ratzinger's embrace of Gamber was dissent on the Pauline reform’
--Word--
Pelagian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the theological doctrine of Pelagius, especially in denying the doctrines of original sin and predestination, and defending innate human goodness and free will.
A person who believes in the theological doctrine of Pelagius, especially its denial of the doctrines of original sin and predestination, and defence of innate human goodness and free will.
--Examples--
‘the Pelagian definition of sin and holiness’
‘such theology is not only subjective but thoroughly Pelagian’
‘this can be affirmed by none but a Pelagian’

Platonism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The philosophy of Plato or his followers.
Any of various revivals of Platonic doctrines or related ideas, especially Neoplatonism and Cambridge Platonism (a 17th-century attempt to reconcile Christianity with humanism and science).
The theory that numbers or other abstract objects are objective, timeless entities, independent of the physical world and of the symbols used to represent them.

Refinement or elegance in a person or thing.
polish something off
Quickly finish or consume something.
Relating to Poland, its inhabitants, or their language.
The Western Slavic language of Poland, spoken by more than 40 million people.

populist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person, especially a politician, who strives to appeal to ordinary people who feel that their concerns are disregarded by established elite groups.
Relating to or characteristic of a political approach that strives to appeal to ordinary people who feel that their concerns are disregarded by established elite groups.
Appealing to or aimed at ordinary people.
--Examples--
‘he ran as a populist on an anti-corruption platform’
‘right-wing populists seem poised to make electoral gains’
‘party leaders plan to reprise the populist rhetoric that they used in the tax fight’
‘a populist opposition leader’
‘populist tabloid newspapers’
‘it seems their efforts in creating a populist movement for chamber music are paying off’

--Word--
Protestant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member or follower of any of the Western Christian Churches that are separate from the Roman Catholic Church in accordance with the principles of the Reformation, including the Baptist, Presbyterian, and Lutheran Churches.
Relating to or belonging to any of the Protestant Churches.
--Examples--
‘the Protestant religion’
‘the family were staunchly Protestant’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The faith, practice, and Church order of the Protestant Churches.
Adherence to the forms of Christian doctrine which are generally regarded as Protestant rather than Catholic or Eastern Orthodox.

puritan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of English Protestants of the late 16th and 17th centuries who regarded the Reformation of the Church under Elizabeth I as incomplete and sought to simplify and regulate forms of worship.
A person with censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
Relating to the Puritans.
Having or displaying censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
--Examples--
‘my mother was a puritan about sex’
‘don't be such a puritan’
‘a Puritan parliamentarian’
‘he was of Puritan stock’
‘as the puritan ethic has weakened, hedonism has replaced it’
‘a puritan conscience’
--Word--
puritanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The beliefs or principles of a group of English Protestants of the late 16th and 17th centuries who regarded the Reformation of the Church under Elizabeth I as incomplete and sought to simplify and regulate forms of worship.
Censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
--Examples--
‘an era of sexual puritanism’
‘the extreme puritanism of the hardliners grated on people’

--Word--
antique 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A collectable object such as a piece of furniture or work of art that has a high value because of its age and quality.
Having a high value because of age and quality.
Intended to resemble the appearance of high-quality old furniture.
Belonging to ancient times.
Old-fashioned or outdated.
Showing signs of great age or wear.
Make (something) resemble an antique by artificial means.
Search or shop for antiques.
--Examples--
‘Pauline loves collecting antiques’
‘an antique dealer’
‘an antique clock’
‘bookshelves with an antique finish’
‘statues of antique gods’
‘antique work practices’
‘the kitchen had an antique cooker’
‘sanding will change the lustre of the sanded spot, especially if the finish has been antiqued’
‘an antiqued door’
‘they went antiquing almost every weekend’
‘I antiqued all day with my mother’

--Word--
Sabian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to a non-Muslim sect classed in the Koran with Jews, Christians, and Zoroastrians as having a faith revealed by the true God. It is not known who the original Sabians were, but the name was adopted by some groups in order to give themselves legitimacy as People of the Book.
A member of the Sabians.

Scandinavia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A large peninsula in north-western Europe, occupied by Norway and Sweden. It is bounded by the Arctic Ocean on the north, the Atlantic Ocean on the west, and the Baltic Sea on the south and the east.
A cultural region consisting of the countries of Norway, Sweden, and Denmark and sometimes also of Iceland, Finland, and the Faroe Islands.

Socrates 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(469–399 BC), Greek philosopher. As represented in the writings of his disciple Plato, he engaged in dialogue with others in an attempt to define ethical concepts by exposing and dispelling error (the Socratic method). Charged with introducing strange gods and corrupting the young, Socrates was sentenced to death and died by drinking hemlock.
--Examples--
--Word--
Socratic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Socrates or his philosophy.
A follower of Socrates.

A Romance language spoken in Spain and in much of Central and South America (except Brazil) and several other countries. It is the second most widely spoken first language in the world, with more than 400 millon speakers.

Antisthenes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.445–c.360 BC), Greek philosopher and teacher, regarded as the founder of the school of Cynics. A pupil and friend of Socrates, he believed that happiness is based on virtuous action rather than ease and pleasure, and that virtue, once acquired, cannot be lost.

--Word--
antithesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
A contrast or opposition between two things.
A rhetorical or literary device in which an opposition or contrast of ideas is expressed.
(in Hegelian philosophy) the negation of the thesis as the second stage in the process of dialectical reasoning.
--Examples--
‘love is the antithesis of selfishness’
‘the antithesis between occult and rational mentalities’
‘figures of speech such as antithesis’
‘his sermons were full of startling antitheses’

--Word--
Zionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movement for (originally) the re-establishment and (now) the development and protection of a Jewish nation in what is now Israel. It was established as a political organization in 1897 under Theodor Herzl, and was later led by Chaim Weizmann.
(in southern Africa) a religious movement represented by a group of independent Churches which practise a form of Christianity incorporating elements of traditional African beliefs.
The beliefs and practices of the African Zionist movement.
--Examples--
--Word--

Pevsner, Antoine 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1886–1962), Russian-born French sculptor and painter, brother of Naum Gabo. With his brother he was a founder of Russian constructivism; the theoretical basis of the movement was put forward in their Realistic Manifesto (1920).
--Examples--
--Word--
Marie Antoinette 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1755–93), French queen, wife of Louis XVI. A daughter of Maria Theresa, she married the future Louis XVI of France in 1770. Her extravagant lifestyle led to her widespread unpopularity and, like her husband, she was executed during the French Revolution.
--Examples--
--Word--
Rubinstein, Anton

(1829–94), Russian composer and pianist; full name Anton Grigorevich Rubinstein. He composed symphonies, operas, songs, and piano music.

--Word--
Leeuwenhoek, Antoni van 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1632–1723), Dutch naturalist. He developed a lens for scientific purposes and was the first to observe bacteria, protozoa, and yeast. He accurately described red blood cells, capillaries, striated muscle fibres, spermatozoa, and the crystalline lens of the eye.
--Examples--
--Word--

(c.251–356), Egyptian hermit; the founder of monasticism. Feast day, January 17.

Scalia, Antonin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1936–2016), US Supreme Court associate justice 1986–2016. A conservative and an advocate of judicial restraint, he served in several government posts, taught law at various universities, and served on the US Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington, DC, before being appointed to the Supreme Court by President Reagan.
--Examples--
--Word--
antoninianus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally (in plural): †coinage issued by one or more of the Antonine Roman emperors (obsolete). Later: a name given to a Roman coin of the third century having a bust of the emperor wearing a radiate crown on the obverse, with an original face value of two denarii.
--Examples--
--Word--

One of the Six Counties of Northern Ireland, since 1973 an administrative district.
A town in the district of Antrim, on the north-eastern shore of Lough Neagh; population 22,000 (est. 2009).

ant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small insect typically having a sting and living in a complex social colony with one or more breeding queens. It is wingless except for fertile adults, which form large mating swarms, and is proverbial for its industriousness.
--Examples--

Antwerp 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port in northern Belgium, on the River Scheldt; population 472,071 (2008). By the 16th century it had become a leading European commercial and financial centre.
A province of Belgium of which Antwerp is the capital.

Anuradhapura 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north central Sri Lanka, capital of a district of the same name; population 81,500 (est. 2007). The ancient capital of Sri Lanka, it is a centre of Buddhist pilgrimage.

anxiety 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease about something with an uncertain outcome.
A nervous disorder marked by excessive uneasiness and apprehension, typically with compulsive behaviour or panic attacks.
Strong desire or concern to do something or for something to happen.
--Examples--
‘he felt a surge of anxiety’
‘anxieties about the moral decline of today's youth’
‘she suffered from anxiety attacks’
‘the housekeeper's eager anxiety to please’

anxious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling or showing worry, nervousness, or unease about something with an uncertain outcome.

Very eager or concerned to do something or for something to happen.
--Examples--
‘she was extremely anxious about her exams’
‘an anxious look’
‘there were some anxious moments’
‘the company was anxious to avoid any trouble’
‘my parents were anxious that I get an education’

Anzio 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A seaport in western Italy, south of Rome; population 52,192 (2008). It was a popular resort for citizens of ancient Rome. Allied troops landed here in January 1944, amid fierce fighting, to begin their drive to capture Rome.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
apache 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A violent street ruffian, originally in Paris.
A member of a North American people living chiefly in New Mexico and Arizona. Under the leadership of Geronimo, the Apache were the last North American Indian people to be conquered by the European settlers.
Any of the Athabaskan languages of the Apache, which have about 14,000 speakers altogether, though some are virtually extinct.
Relating to the Apache or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
apache 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A violent street ruffian, originally in Paris.
A member of a North American people living chiefly in New Mexico and Arizona. Under the leadership of Geronimo, the Apache were the last North American Indian people to be conquered by the European settlers.
Any of the Athabaskan languages of the Apache, which have about 14,000 speakers altogether, though some are virtually extinct.
Relating to the Apache or their language.

appanage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
apart 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
(of two or more people or things) separated by a specified distance in time or space.
No longer living together or close emotionally.
To or on one side; at a distance from the main body.
Used after a noun to indicate that someone or something has qualities which mark them out from other people or things.
Used to indicate that one is dismissing something from consideration or moving from one tone or topic to another.
So as to be shattered; into pieces.
--Examples--
‘two stone gateposts some thirty feet apart’
‘studies from as far apart as America and Iceland’
‘the two sides remained far apart on the issue of cruise missiles’
‘alcoholism had driven us apart’
‘Isabel stepped away from Joanna and stood apart’
‘wrestlers were a breed apart’
‘Alaska apart, much of America's energy business concentrates on producing gas’
‘joking apart, they do a really remarkable job’
‘he leapt out of the car just before it was blown apart’
--Word--
apartheid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in South Africa) a policy or system of segregation or discrimination on grounds of race.
Segregation on grounds other than race.
--Examples--
‘gender apartheid’

--Word--
apartness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of two or more people or things being separated in time or space.
The state of not being close emotionally.
The state of being isolated or at a distance from the main body.
The quality of being different or distinct from other people or things; individuality.
--Examples--
‘their geographical apartness accentuated the otherness of their sound’
‘national togetherness will shroud our apartness’
‘people for whom apartness and solitude are sources of spiritual strength’
‘the facelessness of the big city world and its apartness’
‘an event that emphasizes difference and apartness’
‘a sense of exotic apartness from the cultural mainstream’

noun
--Meanings--

apatite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A widely occurring pale green to purple mineral, consisting of calcium phosphate with some fluorine, chlorine, and other elements. It is used in the manufacture of fertilizers.

apatite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A widely occurring pale green to purple mineral, consisting of calcium phosphate with some fluorine, chlorine, and other elements. It is used in the manufacture of fertilizers.

ape 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large primate that lacks a tail, including the gorilla, chimpanzees, orangutan, and gibbons.
Used in names of macaque monkeys with short tails, e.g. Barbary ape.
(in general use) any monkey.
An unintelligent or clumsy person.
An inferior imitator or mimic.
Imitate (someone or something), especially in an absurd or unthinking way.
--Examples--
‘cunning is but the ape of wisdom’
‘new architecture can respect the old without aping its style’

Apennine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly with the. The extensive mountain range running the length of the Italian peninsula.
Astronomy. More fully "Lunar Apennines". With the. A prominent mountain range in the northern region of the moon's near side, along the southern edge of the Mare Imbrium.
Of or relating to the Apennines in Italy; originating from or found in the Apennines.
Archaeology. Designating or relating to an Italian Bronze Age culture characterized by dark burnished pottery.
Astronomy. Designating, relating to, or originating from the Lunar Apennines.
--Examples--
--Word--
Apennines 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain range running 1,400 km (880 miles) down the length of Italy, from the north-west to the southern tip of the peninsula.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Examples--
--Word--
aperture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An opening, hole, or gap.
A space through which light passes in an optical or photographic instrument, especially the variable opening by which light enters a camera.
--Examples--
‘the bell ropes passed through apertures in the ceiling’
‘the genital aperture of an insect’
‘a refracting telescope with an aperture of 3 inches’
--Word--
aperture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An opening, hole, or gap.
A space through which light passes in an optical or photographic instrument, especially the variable opening by which light enters a camera.
--Examples--
‘the bell ropes passed through apertures in the ceiling’
‘the genital aperture of an insect’
‘a refracting telescope with an aperture of 3 inches’
--Word--
aperture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An opening, hole, or gap.
A space through which light passes in an optical or photographic instrument, especially the variable opening by which light enters a camera.
--Examples--
‘the bell ropes passed through apertures in the ceiling’
‘the genital aperture of an insect’
‘a refracting telescope with an aperture of 3 inches’
--Word--
ape 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large primate that lacks a tail, including the gorilla, chimpanzees, orangutan, and gibbons.
Used in names of macaque monkeys with short tails, e.g. Barbary ape.
(in general use) any monkey.
An unintelligent or clumsy person.
An inferior imitator or mimic.
Imitate (someone or something), especially in an absurd or unthinking way.
--Examples--
‘cunning is but the ape of wisdom’
‘new architecture can respect the old without aping its style’
--Word--
apetalous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a flower) having no petals.
--Examples--
--Word--
apetalous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a flower) having no petals.
--Examples--
--Word--
apex 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
The top or highest part of something, especially one forming a point.
The highest point in a plane or solid figure, relative to a base line or plane.
The growing point of a shoot.
The highest point of achievement; a climax.
The point in turning a corner when the vehicle is closest to the edge of the track.
Reach a high point or climax.
Turn (a corner) very close to the edge of the track.
A system of reduced fares for scheduled airline flights and railway journeys which must be booked and paid for before a certain period in advance of departure.
--Examples--
‘the apex of the roof’
‘the central bank is at the apex of the financial system’
‘the apex of his career was in 1966 when he hoisted aloft the World Cup for England’
‘melodic lines build up to the chorus and it apexes at the solo’
‘he understands when to apex a corner’
‘Apex fares’
--Word--
apex 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Apgar score 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A measure of the physical condition of a newborn infant. It is obtained by adding points (2, 1, or 0) for heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, response to stimulation, and skin coloration; a score of ten represents the best possible condition.
--Examples--
--Word--
apheresis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The loss of a sound or sounds at the beginning of a word, e.g., in the derivation of adder from nadder.
The removal of blood plasma from the body by the withdrawal of blood, its separation into plasma and cells, and the reintroduction of the cells, used especially to remove antibodies in treating autoimmune diseases.
--Examples--
--Word--
aphaeretic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or involving aphaeresis.
--Examples--
--Word--
aphagia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Inability to swallow.
Chiefly Physiology. Inability, failure, or refusal to eat; absence or loss of the desire or need to eat; an instance of this.

noun

--Word--
apheresis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Omission of the initial sound of a word, as when he is is pronounced he's.
A technique by which a particular substance or component is removed from the blood, the main volume being returned to the body.
--Examples--

--Word--
aphesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The gradual loss of an unstressed vowel at the beginning of a word (e.g. of e from esquire to form squire).
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

aphicide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insecticide used against aphids.
--Examples--
--Word--
aphid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small bug which feeds by sucking sap from plants; a blackfly or greenfly. Aphids reproduce rapidly, sometimes producing live young without mating, and large numbers can cause extensive damage to plants.
--Examples--
--Word--
aphis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aphid, especially one of the genus Aphis (which includes the common greenfly and blackfly).
--Examples--

--Word--
aphorism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pithy observation which contains a general truth.
A concise statement of a scientific principle, typically by a classical author.
--Examples--
‘the old aphorism ‘the child is father to the man’’
‘the debate begins and ends at the level of aphorism, with commentators saying that something must be done’
‘the opening sentence of the first aphorism of Hippocrates’

--Word--
Behn, Aphra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1640–89), English novelist and playwright, regarded as the first professional woman writer in England. Notable works: The Rover (comic play, 1678) and Oroonoko, or the History of the Royal Slave (novel, 1688).
--Examples--
--Word--
Aphrodisias 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city of western Asia Minor, site of a temple dedicated to Aphrodite. Now in ruins, it is situated 80 km (50 miles) west of Aydin, in modern Turkey.
--Examples--
--Word--
aphrodisiac 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A food, drink, or other thing that stimulates sexual desire.
Of the nature of an aphrodisiac; stimulating sexual desire.
--Examples--
‘power is the ultimate aphrodisiac’
‘the aphrodisiac effects of ylang-ylang oil’

--Word--
Aphrodite 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The goddess of beauty, fertility, and sexual love. She is variously described as the daughter of Zeus and Dione, or as being born from the sea.
--Examples--

adjective

--Word--
alveolar 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to an alveolus or the alveoli of the lung or lungs.
Relating to or denoting the bony ridge that contains the sockets of the upper teeth.
(of a consonant) pronounced with the tip of the tongue on or near the alveolar ridge (e.g. n, s, d, t)
An alveolar consonant.
--Examples--
‘voiced and voiceless alveolar stops’
‘boundaries between alveolars and palatals’
--Word--
dental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the teeth.
Relating to dentistry.
(of a consonant) pronounced with the tip of the tongue against the upper front teeth (as th) or the alveolar ridge (as n, d, t).
A dental consonant.
--Examples--
‘dental health’
‘dental councils’

pick up the pieces 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--

--Word--
pinch 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Grip (something, typically a person's flesh) tightly and sharply between finger and thumb.
Use the fingers to remove (buds or leaves) from a plant to encourage bushy growth.
(of a shoe) hurt (a foot) by being too tight.
Compress (one's lips), especially from worry or tension.
Move one's finger and thumb apart or bring them together on (a touchscreen) in order to zoom into or out of an image, activate a function, etc.
Steal or take without permission.
Arrest (someone)
Live in a frugal way.
Sail (a boat) so close to the wind that the sails begin to lose power.
An act of pinching someone.
An amount of an ingredient that can be held between fingers and thumb.
A critical point in the game.
--Examples--
‘she pinched his cheek’
‘pinch out tips of shoots regularly’
‘Mrs Grandison's pointed, Italian-style shoes were already beginning to pinch her feet’
‘if your shoes pinch, take them off’
‘Aunt Rose pinched her thin lips together’
‘to explore in more detail just pinch the screen’
‘you can pinch on the screen and all the open apps will appear’
‘he pinched a handful of sweets’
‘I was pinched for dangerous driving last month’
‘if I scraped and pinched a bit, I might manage’
‘he gave her a gentle pinch’
‘add a pinch of salt’
--Word--
ape 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large primate that lacks a tail, including the gorilla, chimpanzees, orangutan, and gibbons.
Used in names of macaque monkeys with short tails, e.g. Barbary ape.
(in general use) any monkey.
An unintelligent or clumsy person.
An inferior imitator or mimic.
Imitate (someone or something), especially in an absurd or unthinking way.
--Examples--
‘cunning is but the ape of wisdom’
‘new architecture can respect the old without aping its style’

--Word--
aplite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An igneous rock with a homogeneous fine- or medium-grained texture consisting predominantly of alkaline feldspar and quartz, typically pale in colour and most commonly found in dykes and veins in association with granite.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Temporary cessation of breathing, especially during sleep.
--Examples--
‘thousands suffer from sleep apnoea’

--Word--
apocalypse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The complete final destruction of the world, as described in the biblical book of Revelation.
(especially in the Vulgate Bible) the book of Revelation.
An event involving destruction or damage on a catastrophic scale.
--Examples--
‘the bell's ringing is supposed to usher in the Apocalypse’
‘the apocalypse of World War II’
--Word--
apocalypse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The complete final destruction of the world, as described in the biblical book of Revelation.
(especially in the Vulgate Bible) the book of Revelation.
An event involving destruction or damage on a catastrophic scale.
--Examples--
‘the bell's ringing is supposed to usher in the Apocalypse’
‘the apocalypse of World War II’
--Word--
apocalyptic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Describing or prophesying the complete destruction of the world.
Momentous or catastrophic.
Of or resembling the biblical Apocalypse.
--Examples--
‘the apocalyptic visions of ecologists’
‘the struggle between the two countries is assuming apocalyptic proportions’
‘apocalyptic imagery’

apocrine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting multicellular glands which release some of their cytoplasm in their secretions, especially the sweat glands associated with hair follicles in the armpits and pubic regions.

apogee

noun

--Word--
pole 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A long, slender, rounded piece of wood or metal, typically used with one end placed in the ground as a support for something.
A long, slender, flexible rod of wood or fibreglass used by a competitor in pole-vaulting.
A young tree with a straight slender trunk and no lower branches.
A wooden shaft fitted to the front of a cart or carriage drawn by animals and attached to their yokes or collars.
A simple fishing rod.
Propel (a boat) by pushing a pole against the bottom of a river, canal, or lake.
--Examples--
‘a tent pole’
‘new poles should be protected from grazing livestock’
‘they tell you on the tin that their tuna is entirely caught with pole and line’
‘the boatman appeared, poling a small gondola’
‘they poled slowly across to the other bank’

--Word--
Apollinaire, Guillaume 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1880–1918), French poet; pseudonym of Wilhelm Apollinaris de Kostrowitzki. He coined the term surrealist and was acknowledged by the surrealist poets as their precursor. Notable works: Les Alcools (1913) and Calligrammes (1918).
--Examples--
--Word--
Apollinarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or influenced by the bishop Apollinaris of Laodicea.
An adherent of the teachings of the bishop Apollinaris of Laodicea.
--Examples--
‘the sources and text of the Apollinarian literature’
‘he was an Apollinarian on the subject of the incarnation’

--Word--
Apollinaris 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.310–c.390), bishop of Laodicea in Asia Minor. He upheld the heretical doctrine that Christ had a human body and soul but no human spirit, this being replaced by the divine Logos.
--Examples--
--Word--
Apollyon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A name for the Devil (Rev. 9:11).
--Examples--
--Word--
apollo 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A large butterfly which has creamy-white wings marked with black and red spots, found chiefly on the mountains of mainland Europe.
A god, son of Zeus and Leto and brother of Artemis. He is associated with music, poetic inspiration, archery, prophecy, medicine, pastoral life, and the sun.
The American space programme for landing astronauts on the moon. Apollo 8 was the first mission to orbit the moon (1968), Apollo 11 was the first to land astronauts (1969), and five further landings took place up to 1972.
--Examples--
--Word--
Apollonian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the god Apollo.
Relating to the rational, ordered, and self-disciplined aspects of human nature.
--Examples--
‘the struggle between cold Apollonian categorization and Dionysiac lust and chaos’
--Word--
Apollonius 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.260–190 BC), Greek mathematician; known as Apollonius of Perga. He examined and redefined conic sections and was the first to use the terms ellipse, parabola, and hyperbola for these classes of curve.
(3rd century BC), Greek poet and grammarian; known as Apollonius of Rhodes. He is known for his Argonautica, an epic poem in Homeric style dealing with the expedition of the Argonauts.
--Examples--
--Word--
apollo 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A large butterfly which has creamy-white wings marked with black and red spots, found chiefly on the mountains of mainland Europe.
A god, son of Zeus and Leto and brother of Artemis. He is associated with music, poetic inspiration, archery, prophecy, medicine, pastoral life, and the sun.
The American space programme for landing astronauts on the moon. Apollo 8 was the first mission to orbit the moon (1968), Apollo 11 was the first to land astronauts (1969), and five further landings took place up to 1972.

--Word--
poop 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
The aftermost and highest deck of a ship, especially in a sailing ship where it typically forms the roof of a cabin in the stern.
(of a wave) break over the stern of (a ship), sometimes causing it to capsize.
Exhaust (someone)
poop out
Stop functioning.
Excrement.
Defecate.
Up-to-date or inside information.
A stupid or ineffectual person.
--Examples--
‘there on the poop stood Captain Meech’
‘off Rame Head we were badly pooped’
‘I was pooped and just flopped into bed’
‘the analogue tape fluttered slightly in pitch but didn't poop out’
‘dog poop is a major source of water pollution on Cape Cod’
‘here's the latest poop from Hollywood’
‘he was making fun of an old poop’

--Meanings--

--Word--
apophyllite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral occurring typically as white glassy prisms, usually as a secondary mineral in volcanic rocks. It is a hydrated silicate and fluoride of calcium and potassium.

--Word--
apophysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A natural protuberance from a bone, or inside the shell or exoskeleton of a sea urchin or insect, for the attachment of muscles.
A swelling at the base of the sporangium in some mosses.
A small offshoot extending from an igneous intrusion into the surrounding rock.

‘the property of wealthy Christians was liable to confiscation unless they apostatized’
--Word--
apostille 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A legal certification that makes a document from one country valid in another (provided that both are signatories to the 1961 Hague Convention Abolishing the Requirement for Legalization for Foreign Public Documents)
--Examples--
‘she'll need the divorce decree or death certificate for her former spouse, translated into Spanish with an apostille’
--Word--
apostle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the twelve chief disciples of Jesus Christ.
An important early Christian teacher or pioneering missionary.
A vigorous and pioneering advocate or supporter of a particular policy, idea, or cause.
--Examples--
‘Kiril and Metodije, the apostles of the Slavs’
‘a man once known as the apostle of free-market economics’

--Word--
apostrophe 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A punctuation mark (') used to indicate either possession (e.g. Harry's book; boys' coats) or the omission of letters or numbers (e.g. can't; he's; 1 Jan. '99).
An exclamatory passage in a speech or poem addressed to a person (typically one who is dead or absent) or thing (typically one that is personified).
--Examples--

--Examples--

--Word--
Appalachian Mountains 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain system of eastern North America, stretching from Quebec and Maine in the North to Georgia and Alabama in the South. Its highest peak is Mount Mitchell in North Carolina, which rises to 2,037 m (6,684 ft).

--Word--
appeal 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a serious, urgent, or heartfelt request.
(of the bowler or fielders) call on the umpire to declare a batsman out, traditionally with a shout of ‘How's that?’.
Apply to a higher court for a reversal of the decision of a lower court.
Apply to a higher court for a reversal of (the decision of a lower court)
Try to persuade someone to do something by calling on (a particular principle or quality)
Be attractive or interesting.
A serious, urgent, or heartfelt request.
A shout of ‘How's that?’ or a similar call by a bowler or fielder to an umpire to declare a batsman out.
Entreaty.
An attempt to persuade someone to do something by calling on a particular principle or quality.
An application to a higher court for a decision to be reversed.
A request for donations to support a charity or cause.
The quality of being attractive or interesting.
--Examples--
‘police are appealing for information about the incident’
‘she appealed to Germany for political asylum’
‘he said he would appeal against the conviction’
‘they have 48 hours to appeal the decision’
‘I appealed to his sense of justice’
‘the range of topics will appeal to youngsters’
‘his mother made an appeal for the return of the ring’
‘a look of appeal on his face’
‘an appeal to their common cultural values’
‘he has 28 days in which to lodge an appeal’
‘the right of appeal’
‘a public appeal to raise £120,000’
‘the popular appeal of football’
--Word--
appealer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
appealable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a case or ruling) able to be referred to a higher court for review.
--Examples--
‘the decisions of the tribunal are not appealable’

A shout of ‘How's that?’ or a similar call by a bowler or fielder to an umpire to declare a batsman out.
Entreaty.
An attempt to persuade someone to do something by calling on a particular principle or quality.
An application to a higher court for a decision to be reversed.
A request for donations to support a charity or cause.
The quality of being attractive or interesting.
--Examples--
‘police are appealing for information about the incident’
‘she appealed to Germany for political asylum’
‘he said he would appeal against the conviction’
‘they have 48 hours to appeal the decision’
‘I appealed to his sense of justice’
‘the range of topics will appeal to youngsters’
‘his mother made an appeal for the return of the ring’
‘a look of appeal on his face’
‘an appeal to their common cultural values’
‘he has 28 days in which to lodge an appeal’
‘the right of appeal’
‘a public appeal to raise £120,000’
‘the popular appeal of football’
--Word--
appear 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Come into sight; become visible or noticeable, especially without apparent cause.
Come into existence or use.
Be published or offered for sale.
Present oneself formally in a court or tribunal.
Perform publicly in a film, play, etc.
Feature or be shown.
Arrive at a place.
Seem; give the impression of being.
--Examples--
‘smoke appeared on the horizon’
‘the major life forms appeared on earth’
‘the paperback edition didn't appear for another two years’
‘he appeared on six charges of theft’
‘he appeared on Broadway’
‘the symbol appears in many paintings of the period’
‘by ten o'clock Bill still hadn't appeared’
‘she appeared not to know what was happening’
‘it appears unlikely that interest rates will fall’
--Word--
appearance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The way that someone or something looks.
An impression given by someone or something.
An act of performing or participating in a public event.
An act of arriving or becoming visible.
A process of coming into existence or use.
--Examples--
‘she checked her appearance in the mirror’
‘she read it with every appearance of interest’
‘he is well known for his television appearances’
‘the sudden appearance of her daughter startled her’
‘the appearance of the railway’

--Word--
appellation 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A name or title.
The action of giving a name to someone or something.
An appellation contrôlée.
A wine bearing an appellation contrôlée.
The district in which a wine bearing an appellation contrôlée is produced.
--Examples--
‘the city fully justifies its appellation ‘the Pearl of the Orient’’
‘about 20 per cent of French wines with an appellation come from Alsace’
‘the top appellations Saint-Émilion and Pomerol’
‘the north-east corner of the appellation’

--Word--
appendage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing that is added or attached to something larger or more important.
A projecting part of an invertebrate or other living organism, with a distinct appearance or function.
--Examples--
‘they treat Scotland as a mere appendage of England’
‘a pair of feathery appendages through which oxygen is absorbed’

--Word--
appendix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tube-shaped sac attached to and opening into the lower end of the large intestine in humans and some other mammals. In humans the appendix is small and has no known function, but in rabbits, hares, and some other herbivores it is involved in the digestion of cellulose.
A section or table of subsidiary matter at the end of a book or document.
--Examples--
‘I'm merely standing in while Stella is having her appendix out’
‘a list of such activities was published as an appendix to the report’
‘outline answers may be found in Appendix 2’
--Word--
appendicitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A serious medical condition in which the appendix becomes inflamed and painful.
--Examples--
--Word--
enterostomy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ileostomy or similar surgical operation in which the small intestine is diverted to an artificial opening in the abdominal wall or in another part of the intestine.
An opening in the abdominal wall formed during an enterostomy.
--Examples--

appetizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small dish of food or a drink taken before a meal or the main course of a meal to stimulate one's appetite.
Something that arouses or increases anticipation for what is to follow.
--Examples--
‘the meal started off with an assortment of appetizers including mini egg rolls and fried mozzarella’
‘the afternoon games served as an appetizer for the evening's heavyweight clash between Borussia Dortmund and Bayern Munich’

--Examples--

--Word--
Via Appia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Appian Way 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The principal road southward from Rome in classical times, named after the censor Appius Claudius Caecus, who in 312 BC built the section to Capua; it was later extended to Brindisi.
--Examples--
--Word--
applaud 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Show approval or praise by clapping.
Show strong approval of (a person or action); praise.
--Examples--
‘the crowd whistled and applauded’
‘his speech was loudly applauded’
‘Jill applauded the decision’

--Word--
apple 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The round fruit of a tree of the rose family, which typically has thin green or red skin and crisp flesh.
Used in names of unrelated fruits or other plant growths that resemble apples in some way, e.g. custard apple, oak apple.
The tree bearing apples, with hard pale timber that is used in carpentry and to smoke food.

--Word--
fallow 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of farmland) ploughed and harrowed but left for a period without being sown in order to restore its fertility or to avoid surplus production.
(of a period of time) characterized by inaction; unproductive.
(of a sow) not pregnant.
A piece of fallow land.
Leave (land) fallow for a period.
A pale brown or reddish yellow colour.
--Examples--
‘incentives for farmers to let land lie fallow’
‘long fallow periods when nothing seems to happen’
‘a great estate was usually divided between fallows, grazed stubble, and wheat’
‘strips of summer fallow’
‘fallow the ground for a week or so after digging’
‘possible feather colours include fallows, pieds, and yellows’

apply 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a formal application or request.
Put oneself forward formally as a candidate for a job.
Be applicable or relevant.
Bring or put into operation or use.
Put or spread (a substance) on a surface.
Use; exert.
Give one's full attention to a task; work hard.
--Examples--
‘you need to apply to the local authority for a grant’
‘a number of people have applied to vote by proxy’
‘she had applied for a number of positions’
‘prices do not apply to public holiday periods’
‘normal rules apply’
‘the oil industry has failed to apply appropriate standards of care’
‘the sealer can be applied to new wood’
‘smooth over with a cloth, applying even pressure’
‘for two years, she applied herself to her studies with dedication’

--Word--
application 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A formal request to be considered for a position or to be allowed to do or have something, submitted to an authority, institution, or organization.
The action of putting something into operation.
Practical use or relevance.
The action of applying something to a surface.
A medicinal substance applied to the skin.
Sustained effort; hard work.
A program or piece of software designed to fulfil a particular purpose.
--Examples--
‘an application for leave’
‘licences are available on application’
‘an application form’
‘the application of general rules to particular cases’
‘massage has far-reaching medical applications’
‘this principle has no application to the present case’
‘paints suitable for application on fabric’
‘a fresh application of make-up’
‘an application to relieve muscle pain’
‘the job takes a great deal of patience and application’
‘a database application’

--Word--
apposition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The positioning of things side by side or close together.
A relationship between two or more words or phrases in which the two units are grammatically parallel and have the same referent (e.g. my friend Sue; the first US president, George Washington).
--Examples--

appraisal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act of assessing something or someone.
A formal assessment, typically in an interview, of the performance of an employee over a particular period.
--Examples--

‘the report has been subject to appraisal’
‘all appraisals will be held in the next couple of weeks’
‘an appraisal system’

‘they appraised the painting at £200,000’

--Word--
appreciate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Recognize the full worth of.
Be grateful for (something)
Understand (a situation) fully; grasp the full implications of.
Rise in value or price.
--Examples--
‘she feels that he does not appreciate her’
‘I'd appreciate any information you could give me’
‘they failed to appreciate the pressure he was under’
‘I appreciate that you cannot be held totally responsible’
‘the dollar appreciated against the euro by 15 per cent’

--Word--
appreciation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Recognition and enjoyment of the good qualities of someone or something.
Gratitude.
A written assessment of an artist or piece of work, typically a favourable one.
A full understanding of a situation.
Increase in monetary value.
--Examples--
‘I smiled in appreciation’
‘he had a fine appreciation of drawing’
‘they would be the first to show their appreciation’
‘a full appreciation of the professor's life and work will be published in the Scotsman tomorrow’
‘the bank's lack of appreciation of their problems’
‘the appreciation of the dollar against the pound’

apprentice 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who is learning a trade from a skilled employer, having agreed to work for a fixed period at low wages.
A beginner.
Employ (someone) as an apprentice.
Serve as an apprentice.
--Examples--
‘an apprentice electrician’
‘an apprentice barman’
‘Edward was apprenticed to a printer’
‘she apprenticed with midwives in San Francisco’

--Word--
appro 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
On approval.
--Examples--
--Word--
approach 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Come near or nearer to (someone or something) in distance or time.
Come close to (a number, level, or standard) in quality or quantity.
Bring nearer.
Speak to (someone) for the first time about a proposal or request.
Start to deal with (a situation or problem) in a certain way.
A way of dealing with a situation or problem.
An initial proposal or request made to someone.
Behaviour intended to propose personal or sexual relations with someone.
The action of coming near or nearer to someone or something in distance or time.
An approximation to something.
The part of an aircraft's flight in which it descends gradually towards an airfield or runway for landing.
A road, sea passage, or other way leading to a place.
--Examples--
‘the train approached the main line’
‘winter was approaching’
‘the population will approach 12 million by the end of the decade’
‘all those changes shall serve to approach him the faster to the blest mansion’
‘the department had been approached about funding’
‘one must approach the matter with caution’
‘we need a whole new approach to the job’
‘the landowner made an approach to the developer’
‘feminine resistance to his approaches’
‘the approach of winter’
‘the past is impossible to recall with any approach to accuracy’
‘the aircraft completed the approach and touched down’
‘I used to trim the plane back to about 50 mph for the final approach’
‘the northern approaches to London’

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘managers should be approachable’
‘the site is approachable from the roundabout’

--Examples--
‘the train approached the main line’

appropriator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
appropriate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Suitable or proper in the circumstances.
Take (something) for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission.
Devote (money or assets) to a special purpose.
--Examples--
‘this isn't the appropriate time or place’
‘a measure appropriate to a wartime economy’
‘the accused had appropriated the property’
‘there can be problems in appropriating funds for legal expenses’
--Word--
appropriate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Suitable or proper in the circumstances.
Take (something) for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission.
Devote (money or assets) to a special purpose.
--Examples--
‘this isn't the appropriate time or place’
‘a measure appropriate to a wartime economy’
‘the accused had appropriated the property’
‘there can be problems in appropriating funds for legal expenses’
--Word--
appropriately 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a manner that is suitable or proper in the circumstances.
--Examples--
‘volunteers need to be approachable, calm, and able to respond appropriately’
‘walls of raw concrete form a neutral yet appropriately rugged backdrop for the various objects’
--Word--
appropriateness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being suitable or proper in the circumstances.
--Examples--
‘some staff members question the appropriateness of this practice’
‘activities are selected for their appropriateness to the day's weather’
--Word--
appropriate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Suitable or proper in the circumstances.
Take (something) for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission.
Devote (money or assets) to a special purpose.
--Examples--
‘this isn't the appropriate time or place’
‘a measure appropriate to a wartime economy’
‘the accused had appropriated the property’
‘there can be problems in appropriating funds for legal expenses’
--Word--
appropriate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Suitable or proper in the circumstances.
Take (something) for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission.
Devote (money or assets) to a special purpose.
--Examples--
‘this isn't the appropriate time or place’
‘a measure appropriate to a wartime economy’
‘the accused had appropriated the property’
‘there can be problems in appropriating funds for legal expenses’
--Word--
appropriation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of appropriating something.
The deliberate reworking of images and styles from earlier, well-known works of art.
A sum of money allocated officially for a particular use.
--Examples--
‘dishonest appropriation of property’
‘the hallmark of postmodernism has turned out to be appropriation’
‘success in obtaining appropriations for projects’
‘the appropriation accounts’

--Word--
approximant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A function, series, or other expression which is an approximation to the solution of a problem.
A consonant produced by bringing one articulator (the tongue or lips) close to another without actually touching it, as in English r and w.
--Examples--

--Word--
approximate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Close to the actual, but not completely accurate or exact.
Come close or be similar to something in quality, nature, or quantity.
Estimate or calculate (a quantity) fairly accurately.
--Examples--
‘the approximate time of death’
‘a leasing agreement approximating to ownership’
‘reality can be approximated by computational techniques’
‘I had to approximate the weight of my horse’

a priori 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting reasoning or knowledge which proceeds from theoretical deduction rather than from observation or experience.

--Examples--
‘a priori assumptions about human nature’
‘sexuality may be a factor but it cannot be assumed a priori’

--Word--
apron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A protective garment worn over the front of one's clothes and tied at the back.
A garment similar to an apron that is worn as part of official dress, as by a bishop or Freemason.
A sheet of lead worn to shield the body during an X-ray examination.
A small area adjacent to another larger area or structure.
A hard-surfaced area on an airfield used for manoeuvring or parking aircraft.
A projecting strip of stage for playing scenes in front of the curtain.
An area of asphalt where the drive of a house meets the road.
The narrow strip of a boxing ring lying outside the ropes.
An extensive outspread deposit of sediment, typically at the foot of a glacier or mountain.
An endless conveyor made of overlapping plates.
--Examples--
‘a striped butcher's apron’
‘I reached into my apron pocket’
‘a tiny apron of garden’
‘the pilot was instructed to park on the main apron’
‘apron feeders bring coarse ore to a grinding mill’

--Word--
squire 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A man of high social standing who owns and lives on an estate in a rural area, especially the chief landowner in such an area.
Used by a man as a friendly or humorous form of address to another man.
A title given to a magistrate, lawyer, or judge in some rural districts.
A young nobleman acting as an attendant to a knight before becoming a knight himself.
A subadult snapper fish (Chrysophrys auratus ).
(of a man) accompany or escort (a woman)
(of a man) have a romantic relationship with (a woman)
--Examples--
‘the squire of Radbourne Hall’
‘Squire Trelawny’
‘sorry, squire, but I know my limitations’
‘she was squired around Rome by a reporter’
‘he was still squiring Doreen, his high-school sweetheart’

Apuleius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born c.123 AD), Roman writer, born in Africa. His writings are characterized by an exuberant and bizarre use of language. Notable works: Metamorphoses (The Golden Ass).

noun, verb
--Meanings--
A portable breathing apparatus for divers, consisting of cylinders of compressed air strapped on the diver's back, feeding air automatically through a mask or mouthpiece.
Swim under water using an aqualung.
--Examples--
‘you oughtn't to aqualung by yourself’

Aquarius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A large constellation (the Water Carrier or Water Bearer), said to represent a man pouring water from a jar. It contains no bright stars but has several planetary nebulae.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Aquarius.
The eleventh sign of the zodiac, which the sun enters about 21 January.
A person born when the sun is in the sign of Aquarius.
--Examples--
‘the star Alpha Aquarii’
--Word--
quarter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Each of four equal or corresponding parts into which something is or can be divided.
A period of three months regarded as one fourth of a year, used especially in reference to financial transactions such as the payment of bills or a company's earnings.
A period of fifteen minutes or a point of time marking the transition from one fifteen-minute period to the next.
A coin representing 25 cents, a quarter of a US or Canadian dollar.
Each of the four parts into which an animal's or bird's carcass may be divided, each including a leg or wing.
One fourth of a lunar month.
(in basketball, American football, and Australian Rules) each of four equal periods into which a game is divided.
One of four terms into which a school or university year may be divided.
One fourth of a pound weight (avoirdupois, equal to 4 ounces).
One fourth of a hundredweight (in the UK 28 lb or in the US 25lb).
A grain measure equivalent to 8 bushels.
The haunches or hindquarters of a horse.
A part of a town or city having a particular character or use.
The direction of one of the points of the compass, especially as a direction from which the wind blows.
A particular but unspecified person, group of people, or area.
Either side of a ship aft of the beam.
Rooms or lodgings, especially those allocated to people in military or domestic service.
Pity or mercy shown towards an enemy or opponent who is in one's power.
Each of four or more roughly equal divisions of a shield separated by vertical and horizontal lines.
A square charge which covers the top left (dexter chief) quarter of the field.
Divide into four equal or corresponding parts.
Cut (the body of an executed person) into four parts.
Cut (a log) into quarters, and these into planks so as to show the grain well.
Be stationed or lodged in a specified place.
Impose someone on (another person) as a lodger.
Range over or traverse (an area) in every direction.
Move at an angle; go in a diagonal or zigzag direction.
Display (different coats of arms) in quarters of a shield, especially to show arms inherited from heiresses who have married into the bearer's family.
Divide (a shield) into four or more parts by vertical and horizontal lines.
--Examples--
‘she cut each apple into quarters’
‘a page and a quarter’
‘a quarter of a mile’
‘the first quarter of the fiscal year’
‘he sat with his pint until a quarter past nine’
‘there were four scores in the opening quarter’
‘they have strong, muscular quarters’
‘a beautiful port city with a fascinating medieval quarter’
‘we have just had help from an unexpected quarter’
‘he trained his glasses over the starboard quarter’
‘they lived in RAF married quarters’
‘the riot squad gave no quarter’
‘peel and quarter the bananas’
‘the plotters were hanged, drawn, and quartered’
‘many were quartered in tents’
‘you would have had her quartered on you forever’
‘we watched a pair of kingfishers quartering the river looking for minnows’
‘his young dog quartered back and forth in quick turns’
‘Edward III quartered the French royal arms with his own’

--Word--
aquatint 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A print resembling a watercolour, made by etching a copper plate with nitric acid and using resin and varnish to produce areas of tonal shading.
The technique or process of producing aquatints.
Produce (a print) using the aquatint technique or process.
--Examples--
‘twelve coloured aquatints of British battle scenes’
‘a directness and freshness in the use of aquatint’
‘aquatint plates of the Lake District’
‘she studied methods of etching and aquatinting’

Aquila 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A small northern constellation (the Eagle), said to represent the eagle that carried Ganymede to Olympus. It contains the bright star Altair, and some rich star fields of the Milky Way.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Aquila.
A city in east central Italy, capital of Abruzzi region; population 72,988 (2008).
--Examples--
‘the star Beta Aquilae’
--Word--
aquilegia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the buttercup family, which bears showy flowers with backward-pointing spurs. Native to temperate regions of the northern hemisphere, it is widely grown in gardens.

--Word--
Aquitaine 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region and former province of south-western France, on the Bay of Biscay, centred on Bordeaux. It became an English possession by the marriage of Eleanor of Aquitaine to Henry II in 1152, and remained so until 1453.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aquitanian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly historical. Of, relating to, or characteristic of the Roman province of Aquitania, or the historic province or kingdom of Aquitaine. Also occasionally: of or relating to the region of Aquitaine in modern France.
Geology. Designating the earliest stage of the Miocene epoch, between 23.03 and 20.43 million years ago; of, relating to, or dating from this stage.
Chiefly historical. A native or inhabitant of the Roman province of Aquitania, or the historic province or kingdom of Aquitaine; (also) the language formerly spoken in this region, thought to be related to Basque. Also occasionally: a native or inhabitant of the region of Aquitaine in modern France.
Geology. With the: the Aquitanian stage, or the series of rocks dating from this time.
--Examples--
--Word--

Arabia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A peninsula of south-western Asia, largely desert, lying between the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf and bounded on the north by Jordan and Iraq. The original homeland of the Arabs and the historic centre of Islam, it comprises the states of Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Oman, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates.
--Examples--

--Word--
Arabidopsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of small cruciferous herbs, widespread in temperate Eurasia and North America, and found especially in dry, sandy, stony, or saline habitats. Also (also in form arabidopsis): a plant of this genus; (in later use) especially thale cress, Arabidopsis thaliana, which has simple leaves and white flowers, and is used widely in studies of plant genetics.
--Examples--

--Word--
Byzantine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Byzantium (now Istanbul), the Byzantine Empire, or the Eastern Orthodox Church.
Of an ornate artistic and architectural style which developed in the Byzantine Empire and spread to Italy, Russia, and elsewhere. The art is typified by religious wall paintings and icons and the architecture by many-domed churches.
(of a system or situation) excessively complicated, and typically involving a great deal of administrative detail.
Characterized by deviousness or underhand procedure.
A citizen of Byzantium or the Byzantine Empire.
--Examples--
‘Byzantine insurance regulations’
‘he has the most Byzantine mind in politics’
--Word--

A member of a Semitic people, originally from the Arabian peninsula and neighbouring territories, inhabiting much of the Middle East and North Africa.
A horse of a breed originating in Arabia, with a distinctive high-set tail.
Relating to Arabian people.
--Examples--
‘Arab countries’
--Word--
Arabize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give (someone or something) an Arab or Arabic character.
--Examples--
‘an Arabized script’
--Word--
Aracajú 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port in eastern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast, capital of the state of Sergipe; population 520,303 (2007).
--Examples--

aracari 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small toucan with a serrated bill, and typically with a green back and wings, yellow underside, and red rump.
--Examples--
--Word--
arachidonic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A polyunsaturated fatty acid present in animal fats. It is important in metabolism, especially in the synthesis of prostaglandins and leukotrienes, and is an essential constituent of the diet.

--Word--
Arachne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A woman of Colophon in Lydia, a skilful weaver who challenged Athene to a contest. Athene destroyed Arachne's work and Arachne tried to hang herself, but Athene changed her into a spider.
--Examples--
--Word--
arachnid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An arthropod of the class Arachnida, such as a spider or scorpion.
Relating to or denoting arachnids.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arachnida 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A class of chelicerate arthropods that includes spiders, scorpions, mites, and ticks. They have become adapted for a terrestrial life and possess both lungs and tracheae, and many have silk or poison glands.
--Examples--

arachnoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Like a spider or arachnid.
A fine, delicate membrane, the middle one of the three membranes or meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord, situated between the dura mater and the pia mater.
--Examples--
‘intelligent arachnoid killing machines’
--Word--
Arafat, Yasser 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1929–2004), Palestinian statesman, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization 1968–2004 and Palestinian president 1996–2004. He became leader of the new Palestine National Authority in 1994, following the signing of a PLO–Israeli peace accord for which he shared the 1994 Nobel Peace Prize with Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arafura Sea 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A sea lying between northern Australia, the islands of east Indonesia, and New Guinea.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aragon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An autonomous region of north-eastern Spain, bounded on the north by the Pyrenees and on the east by Catalonia and Valencia; capital, Saragossa. Formerly an independent kingdom, it was united with Catalonia in 1137 and with Castile in 1479. Spanish name Aragón.
--Examples--
--Word--
aragonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral consisting of calcium carbonate and typically occurring as colourless prisms in deposits from hot springs.

arrack 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An alcoholic spirit made in Eastern countries from the sap of the coco palm or from rice.

--Word--
rake 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An implement consisting of a pole with a toothed crossbar or fine tines at the end, used especially for drawing together cut grass or smoothing loose soil or gravel.
An implement similar to a rake used for other purposes, e.g. by a croupier drawing in money at a gaming table.
An act of raking.
Draw together with a rake or similar implement.
Make (ground) smooth with a rake.
Scratch or scrape (something, especially a person's flesh) with a long sweeping movement.
Draw or drag (something) through something with a sweeping movement.
Sweep (something) from end to end with gunfire, a look, or a beam of light.
Move across something with a long sweeping movement.
Search or rummage through something.
--Examples--
‘giving the lawn a rake’
‘they started raking up hay’
‘I sometimes rake over the allotment’
‘her fingers raked Bill's face’
‘she raked a comb through her hair’
‘the road was raked with machine-gun fire’
‘his icy gaze raked mercilessly over Lissa's slender figure’
‘he raked through his pockets and brought out a five-pound note’
--Word--
aralia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of a very diverse group of trees and shrubs native to America and Asia. Several kinds are cultivated for their foliage and tiny flowers, and some are used in herbal medicine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Khachaturian, Aram 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–78), Soviet composer, born in Georgia; full name Aram Ilich Khachaturian. His music is richly romantic and reflects his lifelong interest in the folk music of Armenia, Georgia, and Russia. Notable works include Gayane (ballet, 1942), his Second Symphony (1943), and Spartacus (ballet, 1954).
--Examples--
--Word--
Aramaean 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient Aramaic-speaking people inhabiting Aram (modern Syria) and most of Mesopotamia in the 11th–8th centuries BC.
Relating to Aram or the Aramaeans.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aramaic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A branch of the Semitic family of languages, especially the language of Syria used as a lingua franca in the Near East from the 6th century BC. It replaced Hebrew locally as the language of the Jews, and though displaced by Arabic in the 7th century AD, it still has about 200,000 speakers in scattered communities.
Relating to Aramaic.
--Examples--
--Word--

Relating to Aram or the Aramaeans.

noun

Aranyaka 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a set of Hindu sacred treatises based on the Brahmanas, composed in Sanskrit c.700 BC. Intended only for initiates, the Aranyakas contain mystical and philosophical material and explications of esoteric rites.

Arapaho

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American people living chiefly on the Great Plains, especially in Wyoming.
The Algonquian language of the Arapaho, now almost extinct.
Relating to the Arapaho or their language.

--Word--
Ararat, Mount 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A pair of volcanic peaks in eastern Turkey, near the borders with Armenia and Iran. The higher peak, which rises to 5,165 m (16,946 ft), is the traditional site of the resting place of Noah's ark after the Flood (Gen. 8:4).
--Examples--
--Word--
ara 
--Type--
proper noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A small and faint southern constellation (the Altar), in the Milky Way near Scorpius.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Ara.
Associate of the Royal Academy.
--Examples--
‘the star Delta Arae’

Araucanian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of South American peoples of Chile and adjacent parts of Argentina, including the Mapuche.

--Word--
arbitrage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The simultaneous buying and selling of securities, currency, or commodities in different markets or in derivative forms in order to take advantage of differing prices for the same asset.
Buy and sell assets using arbitrage.
--Examples--
‘profitable arbitrage opportunities’
‘much of the short selling was being done by people who were arbitraging between the bond and the equity market’

noun
--Meanings--

arbitrary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
(of power or a ruling body) unrestrained and autocratic in the use of authority.
(of a constant or other quantity) of unspecified value.
--Examples--
‘an arbitrary decision’
‘a country under arbitrary government’
--Word--
arbitrary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
(of power or a ruling body) unrestrained and autocratic in the use of authority.
(of a constant or other quantity) of unspecified value.
--Examples--
‘an arbitrary decision’
‘a country under arbitrary government’
--Word--
arbitrarily 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
On the basis of random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
Without restraint in the use of authority; autocratically.
--Examples--
‘recurrent infection is arbitrarily defined as three or more infections a year’
‘everyone has the right not to be arbitrarily detained’
--Word--
arbitrariness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
A lack of restraint in the use of authority; autocracy.
--Examples--
‘disparate peoples were forced together by the arbitrariness of a colonial map-maker's pen’
‘the law protects the people against the arbitrariness of those in office’

Arbuthnot, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1667–1735), Scottish physician and writer. His satirical History of John Bull (1712) was the origin of John Bull as the personification of the typical Englishman.

--Word--
arc 
--Type--
noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A part of a curve, especially a part of the circumference of a circle.
A shape or structure resembling an arc.
A curving trajectory.
Indicating the inverse of a trigonometrical function.
A luminous electrical discharge between two electrodes or other points.
(in a novel, play, or film) the development or resolution of the narrative or principal theme.
Move with a curving trajectory.
Form an electric arc.
(in the UK) Agricultural Research Council.
AIDS-related complex.
--Examples--
‘the point where a tangential line touches the arc of a circle’
‘the huge arc of the sky’
‘he swung his torch in a wide arc’
‘modern welding generators are designed so that there is a high voltage for striking the arc’
‘his transformation provides the emotional arc of the story’
‘the ball arced across the room’
‘check that switches operate properly with no sign of arcing’
--Word--
arcade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A covered passage with arches along one or both sides.
A covered walk with shops along one or both sides.
A series of arches supporting a wall, or set along it.
--Examples--
‘a shopping arcade’
‘Burlington Arcade’

Arcadia

--Meanings--

arcanely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
arcane 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Understood by few; mysterious or secret.
--Examples--
‘arcane procedures for electing people’
--Word--
Corelli, Arcangelo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1653–1713), Italian violinist and composer. His best-known works are his trio and solo sonatas for the violin and his concerti grossi (published posthumously in 1714), especially the ‘Christmas’ concerto.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arcaro, Eddie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1916–97), US jockey; full name George Edward Arcaro. He was the first two-time Triple Crown winner, riding Whirlaway in 1941 and Citation in 1948.
--Examples--
--Word--
back-arc 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the area behind an island arc.
--Examples--
‘back-arc basin’
--Word--
arc 
--Type--
noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A part of a curve, especially a part of the circumference of a circle.
A shape or structure resembling an arc.
A curving trajectory.
Indicating the inverse of a trigonometrical function.
A luminous electrical discharge between two electrodes or other points.
(in a novel, play, or film) the development or resolution of the narrative or principal theme.
Move with a curving trajectory.
Form an electric arc.
(in the UK) Agricultural Research Council.
AIDS-related complex.
--Examples--
‘the point where a tangential line touches the arc of a circle’
‘the huge arc of the sky’
‘he swung his torch in a wide arc’
‘modern welding generators are designed so that there is a high voltage for striking the arc’
‘his transformation provides the emotional arc of the story’
‘the ball arced across the room’
‘check that switches operate properly with no sign of arcing’
--Word--

--Word--
arch 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A curved symmetrical structure spanning an opening and typically supporting the weight of a bridge, roof, or wall above it.
An arch forming a monument or ornamental feature.
A shape resembling an arch.
The inner side of the foot.
Have the curved shape of an arch.
Form or cause to form the curved shape of an arch.
Deliberately or affectedly playful and teasing.
--Examples--
‘a triumphal arch’
‘the delicate arch of his eyebrows’
‘the muscles in the arch of my right foot suddenly seized up’
‘a beautiful bridge that arched over a canal’
‘her eyebrows arched in surprise’
‘she arched her back’
‘a somewhat arch tone of voice’
--Word--
arch- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Chief; principal.
(in an unfavourable sense) pre-eminent of its kind; out-and-out.
--Examples--
‘archbishop’
‘archdiocese’
‘arch-enemy’
--Word--

--Word--
archaean 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the aeon that constitutes the earlier (or middle) part of the Precambrian, in which there was no life on the earth. It precedes the Proterozoic aeon and (in some schemes) is preceded by the Priscoan aeon.
The Archaean aeon or the system of rocks deposited during it.
--Examples--
--Word--
archaeo- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Relating to archaeology or prehistoric times.
--Examples--
‘archaeoastronomy’
--Word--
archaeology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of human history and prehistory through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artefacts and other physical remains.

--Examples--
‘Chinese archaeologists uncovered life-sized terracotta statues’
--Word--
archaeomagnetism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Magnetism possessed by components of clay and rocks which have in the past been heated above a certain temperature. The orientation and intensity of this remanent magnetism was fixed by the earth's magnetic field when the material cooled, and can be used to study the earth's magnetism and as a method of geological and archaeological dating.
--Examples--
--Word--
archaeopteryx 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The oldest known fossil bird, of the late Jurassic period. It had feathers, wings, and hollow bones like a bird, but teeth, a bony tail, and legs like a small coelurosaur dinosaur.
--Examples--
--Word--
archaic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Very old or old-fashioned.
(of a word or a style of language) no longer in everyday use but sometimes used to impart an old-fashioned flavour.
Of an early period of art or culture, especially the 7th–6th centuries BC in Greece.
--Examples--
‘prisons are run on archaic methods’
‘a term with a rather archaic ring to it’
‘the archaic temple at Corinth’

noun

--Word--
archangel 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
An angel of greater than ordinary rank.
(in traditional Christian angelology) a being of the eighth-highest order of the ninefold celestial hierarchy.
A yellow-flowered Eurasian dead-nettle found in woodland.
A port of north-western Russia, on the White Sea; population 348,700 (est. 2008). It is named after the monastery of the Archangel Michael situated there.
--Examples--

buttress 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

A projecting portion of a hill or mountain.
A source of defence or support.

--Examples--
‘the cathedral's massive buttresses’

archerfish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A freshwater fish that knocks insect prey off overhanging vegetation by shooting water at it from its mouth. It is native to Asia, Australia, and the Philippines.

--Type--
adjective

‘archetypal myths’
‘an archetypal journey representing the quest for identity’

--Word--
archetype 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very typical example of a certain person or thing.
An original which has been imitated; a prototype.
(in Jungian theory) a primitive mental image inherited from the earliest human ancestors, and supposed to be present in the collective unconscious.
A recurrent symbol or motif in literature, art, or mythology.
--Examples--
‘he was the archetype of the old-style football club chairman’
‘an instrument which was the archetype of the early flute’
‘mythological archetypes of good and evil’

--Word--
MacLeish, Archibald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1892–1982), US poet and public official. His award-winning works include Conquistador (1932), Collected Poems (1952), and J.B. (1958). He was librarian of Congress 1939–42.

--Word--
Archilochus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(8th or 7th century BC), Greek poet. Acclaimed in his day as equal in stature to Homer and Pindar, he wrote satirical verse and fables and is credited with the invention of iambic metre.
--Examples--

archil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Archimedean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or invented by Archimedes.
--Examples--
‘an Archimedean globe’
--Word--
Archimedes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.287–212 BC), Greek mathematician and inventor, of Syracuse. He is famous for his discovery of Archimedes' principle (legend has it that he made this discovery while taking a bath, and ran through the streets shouting ‘Eureka!’); among his mathematical discoveries are the ratio of the radius of a circle to its circumference, and formulas for the surface area and volume of a sphere and of a cylinder.
--Examples--
--Word--
arch 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A curved symmetrical structure spanning an opening and typically supporting the weight of a bridge, roof, or wall above it.
An arch forming a monument or ornamental feature.
A shape resembling an arch.
The inner side of the foot.
Have the curved shape of an arch.
Form or cause to form the curved shape of an arch.
Deliberately or affectedly playful and teasing.
--Examples--
‘a triumphal arch’
‘the delicate arch of his eyebrows’
‘the muscles in the arch of my right foot suddenly seized up’
‘a beautiful bridge that arched over a canal’
‘her eyebrows arched in surprise’
‘she arched her back’
‘a somewhat arch tone of voice’

noun

--Word--
Archipenko, Alexander 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1964), Russian-born American sculptor; full name Alexander Porfirevich Archipenko. He adapted cubist techniques to sculpture. Notable works: Walking Woman (1912).
--Examples--
--Word--
architect 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who designs buildings and in many cases also supervises their construction.
A person who is responsible for inventing or realizing a particular idea or project.
Design and configure (a program or system)
--Examples--
‘the great Norman architect of Durham Cathedral’
‘the architects of the reform programme’
‘an architected information interface’

--Word--
architectonic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to architecture or architects.
(of an artistic composition) having a clearly defined structure, especially one that is artistically pleasing.
The scientific study of architecture.
Musical, literary, or artistic structure.
--Examples--
‘the painting's architectonic harmony’
‘his later novels display more concern with architectonics’
--Word--
architectonically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

architectural 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the art or practice of designing and constructing buildings.
