--Examples--
‘an architectural firm’
‘Wootton Bassett has retained much of its architectural heritage’
‘he liked architectural plants, particularly large spiky palms’
--Word--
architecturally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that relates to the design and construction of buildings.
--Examples--
‘the building will blend architecturally with the adjoining town houses’
‘historically or architecturally important churches’
--Word--
architecture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The art or practice of designing and constructing buildings.
The style in which a building is designed and constructed, especially with regard to a specific period, place, or culture.
The complex or carefully designed structure of something.
The conceptual structure and logical organization of a computer or computer-based system.
--Examples--
‘schools of architecture and design’
‘Georgian architecture’
‘the chemical architecture of the human brain’

--Word--
architrave 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in classical architecture) a main beam resting across the tops of columns, specifically the lower third entablature.
The moulded frame round a doorway or window.
A moulding round the exterior of an arch.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
Protestant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member or follower of any of the Western Christian Churches that are separate from the Roman Catholic Church in accordance with the principles of the Reformation, including the Baptist, Presbyterian, and Lutheran Churches.
Relating to or belonging to any of the Protestant Churches.
--Examples--
‘the Protestant religion’
‘the family were staunchly Protestant’
--Word--
arch- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Chief; principal.
(in an unfavourable sense) pre-eminent of its kind; out-and-out.
--Examples--
‘archbishop’
‘archdiocese’
‘arch-enemy’

villain 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in a film, novel, or play) a character whose evil actions or motives are important to the plot.
A criminal.
The person or thing responsible for specified problems, harm, or damage.
--Examples--
‘a pantomime villain’
‘I have played more good guys than villains’
‘some people have been tricked by villains with false identity cards’
‘the armed villains run off into the night’
‘the industrialized nations are the real environmental villains’

--Word--
Whig 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the British reforming and constitutional party that sought the supremacy of Parliament and was eventually succeeded in the 19th century by the Liberal Party.
A supporter of the American side during the War of American Independence.
A member of an American political party in the 19th century, succeeded by the Republicans.
A 17th-century Scottish Presbyterian.
Denoting a historian who interprets history as the continuing and inevitable victory of progress over reaction.
--Examples--
--Word--
arc 
--Type--
noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A part of a curve, especially a part of the circumference of a circle.
A shape or structure resembling an arc.
A curving trajectory.
Indicating the inverse of a trigonometrical function.
A luminous electrical discharge between two electrodes or other points.
(in a novel, play, or film) the development or resolution of the narrative or principal theme.
Move with a curving trajectory.
Form an electric arc.
(in the UK) Agricultural Research Council.
AIDS-related complex.
--Examples--
‘the point where a tangential line touches the arc of a circle’
‘the huge arc of the sky’
‘he swung his torch in a wide arc’
‘modern welding generators are designed so that there is a high voltage for striking the arc’
‘his transformation provides the emotional arc of the story’
‘the ball arced across the room’
‘check that switches operate properly with no sign of arcing’

(especially as a direction) played on a violin or other stringed instrument using the bow.

--Word--
Arctic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the regions around the North Pole.
(of animals or plants) living or growing in the region around the North Pole.
(of weather conditions) very cold.
The regions around the North Pole.
A thick waterproof overshoe extending to the ankle or above.
A drab-coloured hairy butterfly of the arctic and subarctic regions of the New World.
--Examples--
‘an Arctic explorer’
‘Arctic plants’
‘February brought arctic conditions’
‘the arctic weather of 1981’
--Word--
arcticized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Adapted or accustomed to Arctic or very cold conditions.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

arcticize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To adapt or accustom to Arctic or very cold conditions. Also without object: to become accustomed to such conditions (rare).

--Word--
Altaic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Altai Mountains.
Denoting or belonging to a phylum or superfamily of languages which includes the Turkic, Mongolian, Tungusic, and Manchu languages. They are characterized by agglutination and vowel harmony.
The Altaic family of languages.

Arcturus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The fourth-brightest star in the sky, and the brightest in the constellation Boötes. It is an orange giant.

--Word--
ardeb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Egyptian unit of weight and capacity used chiefly for grain, varying with the locality and the commodity but typically equivalent to approx. 330 lb (150 kg) or 5 bushels (190 litres).
--Examples--
--Word--
ardeb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Egyptian unit of weight and capacity used chiefly for grain, varying with the locality and the commodity but typically equivalent to approx. 330 lb (150 kg) or 5 bushels (190 litres).
--Examples--
--Word--
Arden, Elizabeth 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1880–1966), Canadian-born American businesswoman; born Florence Nightingale Graham. She built up an international chain of beauty salons and an extensive range of cosmetics.

Ardennes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A forested upland region extending over parts of south-eastern Belgium, north-eastern France, and Luxembourg. It was the scene of fierce fighting in both world wars.

Ardi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The nickname of a partial female skeleton of a fossil hominid found in Ethiopia in 1994, about 4.4 million years old and 4 feet (1.2 m) in height.

--Word--
area 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A region or part of a town, a country, or the world.
A space allocated for a specific use.
A part of an object or surface.
The extent or measurement of a surface or piece of land.
A subject or range of activity or interest.
A sunken enclosure giving access to the basement of a building.
--Examples--
‘rural areas of Britain’
‘people living in the area are at risk’
‘the dining area’
‘areas of the body’
‘the area of a triangle’
‘the room is twelve square feet in area’
‘the key areas of science’
‘the area steps’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A region or part of a town, a country, or the world.
A space allocated for a specific use.
A part of an object or surface.
The extent or measurement of a surface or piece of land.
A subject or range of activity or interest.
A sunken enclosure giving access to the basement of a building.
--Examples--
‘rural areas of Britain’
‘people living in the area are at risk’
‘the dining area’
‘areas of the body’
‘the area of a triangle’
‘the room is twelve square feet in area’
‘the key areas of science’
‘the area steps’

Arecibo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A community in northwestern Puerto Rico, west of San Juan; population 47,300 (est. 2009). It is an academic center noted for its huge radio telescope facility.

--Word--
Arendt, Hannah 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–75), German-born American philosopher and political theorist. A pupil of Heidegger, she established her reputation as a political thinker with one of the first works to propose that Nazism and Stalinism had common roots. Notable works: The Origins of Totalitarianism (1951), Eichmann in Jerusalem (1963).
--Examples--
--Word--
arene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any aromatic hydrocarbon.
--Examples--
--Word--
aren't 
--Type--
contraction
--Meanings--
Are not.
Am not (only used in questions)
--Examples--
‘they aren't here’
‘I'm right, aren't I?’
‘why aren't I being given a pay rise?’

--Word--
areola 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small circular area, in particular the ring of pigmented skin surrounding a nipple.
Any of the small spaces between lines or cracks on a leaf or an insect's wing.
A reddened patch around a spot or papule.

--Word--
Dionysius the Areopagite 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1st century AD), Greek churchman. His conversion by St Paul is recorded in Acts 17:34 and according to tradition he went on to become the first bishop of Athens. He was later confused with St Denis and with a mystical theologian, Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite, who exercised a profound influence on medieval theology.
--Examples--
--Word--
Areopagus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in ancient Athens) a hill on which was sited the highest governmental council and later a judicial court.
--Examples--

Argentina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A republic occupying much of the southern part of South America; population 43,400,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Spanish; capital, Buenos Aires. Also called the Argentine /ˈɑːdʒənˌtʌɪn, ˈɑːdʒənˌtiːn/.
--Examples--
--Word--
argentine 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or resembling silver.
A small marine fish with a silvery sheen.
Relating to Argentina or its people.
A native or inhabitant of Argentina, or a person of Argentine descent.
--Examples--
‘the argentine domes of our main course arrived’

Dogo Argentino 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A heavily built breed of dog of the mastiff type, typically white in colour, originally bred in Argentina for hunting big game but now often associated with dogfighting; a dog of this breed.

Argyllshire 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former county on the west coast of Scotland. It was divided between Strathclyde and Highland regions in 1975 and in 1996 became part of Argyll and Bute.

argon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 18, an inert gaseous element of the noble gas group. Argon is the commonest noble gas, making up nearly one per cent of the earth's atmosphere.
--Examples--
--Word--
argonaut 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small floating octopus, the female of which has webbed sail-like arms and secretes a thin coiled papery shell in which the eggs are laid.
--Examples--
--Word--
Argonauts 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of heroes who accompanied Jason on board the ship Argo in the quest for the Golden Fleece.
--Examples--
--Word--
Argonne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A wooded plateau in northeastern France, near the Belgian border. The region is thinly populated. A major Allied offensive was staged here during World War I; during World War II the region was occupied by Germany from 1940 until 1944.
--Examples--
--Word--
argon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 18, an inert gaseous element of the noble gas group. Argon is the commonest noble gas, making up nearly one per cent of the earth's atmosphere.
--Examples--
--Word--
Argos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the north-eastern Peloponnese of Greece; population 23,600 (est. 2009). One of the oldest cities of ancient Greece, it dominated the Peloponnese and the western Aegean in the 7th century BC.
--Examples--

A large merchant ship, originally one from Ragusa (now Dubrovnik) or Venice.

arguable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be argued or asserted.
Open to disagreement; not obviously correct.
--Examples--
‘it was arguable that the bank had no authority to honour the cheques’
‘a highly arguable assumption’

arguably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘she is arguably the greatest woman tennis player of all time’
--Word--
argue 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory, typically with the aim of persuading others to share one's view.
Persuade someone to do or not to do (something) by giving reasons.
Exchange or express diverging or opposite views, typically in a heated or angry way.
--Examples--
‘sociologists argue that inequalities in industrial societies are being reduced’
‘he argued for extra resources’
‘‘It stands to reason,’ she argued’
‘I tried to argue him out of it’
‘the two men started arguing in a local pub’
‘I wasn't going to argue with a gun’
‘she was too tired to argue the point’

--Word--
argument 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An exchange of diverging or opposite views, typically a heated or angry one.
A reason or set of reasons given in support of an idea, action or theory.
An independent variable associated with a function or proposition and determining its value. For example, in the expression y = F(x₁, x₂), the arguments of the function F are x₁ and x₂, and the value is y.
Any of the noun phrases in a clause that are related directly to the verb, typically the subject, direct object, and indirect object.
A summary of the subject matter of a book.
--Examples--
‘I've had an argument with my father’
‘heated arguments over public spending’
‘there was some argument about the decision’
‘there is a strong argument for submitting a formal appeal’
‘he rejected the argument that keeping the facility would be costly’
--Word--
argumentation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of reasoning systematically in support of an idea, action, or theory.
--Examples--
‘lines of argumentation used to support his thesis’
--Word--
argumentation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of reasoning systematically in support of an idea, action, or theory.
--Examples--
‘lines of argumentation used to support his thesis’

adjective

--Examples--
‘an argumentative child’
‘the highest standards of argumentative rigour’

--Meanings--

--Word--
argument 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An exchange of diverging or opposite views, typically a heated or angry one.
A reason or set of reasons given in support of an idea, action or theory.
An independent variable associated with a function or proposition and determining its value. For example, in the expression y = F(x₁, x₂), the arguments of the function F are x₁ and x₂, and the value is y.
Any of the noun phrases in a clause that are related directly to the verb, typically the subject, direct object, and indirect object.
A summary of the subject matter of a book.
--Examples--
‘I've had an argument with my father’
‘heated arguments over public spending’
‘there was some argument about the decision’
‘there is a strong argument for submitting a formal appeal’
‘he rejected the argument that keeping the facility would be costly’

The action or process of reasoning systematically in support of an idea, action, or theory.
--Examples--
‘lines of argumentation used to support his thesis’

noun

Ariadne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The daughter of King Minos of Crete and Pasiphaë. She helped Theseus to escape from the Minotaur's labyrinth by giving him a ball of thread, which he unravelled as he went in and used to trace his way out again after killing the Minotaur.

Aryan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a people speaking an Indo-European language who invaded northern India in the 2nd millennium BC, displacing the Dravidian and other aboriginal peoples.
(in Nazi ideology) relating to or denoting people of Caucasian race not of Jewish descent.
A member of the ancient Aryan people.
The language of the Aryan people.
(in Nazi ideology) a person of Caucasian race not of Jewish descent.
--Examples--
‘the Aryans brought Hindu religious thought to India’
‘he looked the image of the ideal Aryan: tall, with Nordic blonde hair’
--Word--
Arianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The main heresy denying the divinity of Christ, originating with the Alexandrian priest Arius (c.250–c.336). Arianism maintained that the son of God was created by the Father and was therefore neither coeternal nor consubstantial with the Father.
--Examples--

--Word--
Joseph of Arimathea, St 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A member of the council at Jerusalem who, after the Crucifixion, asked Pilate for Christ's body, which he buried. He is also known from the medieval story that he came to England with the Holy Grail and built the first church at Glastonbury. Feast day, 17 March.

noun, verb

A violent disturbance of the peace by a crowd.
An uproar.

Uncontrolled revelry; rowdy behaviour.
An impressively large or varied display of something.

‘he was convicted on charges of riot and assault’
‘riot police’

--Word--
ripple 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small wave or series of waves on the surface of water, especially as caused by a slight breeze or an object dropping into it.
A thing resembling a ripple or ripples in appearance or movement.
A gentle rising and falling sound that spreads through a group of people.
A particular feeling or effect that spreads through someone or something.
A wave on a fluid surface, the restoring force for which is provided by surface tension rather than gravity, and which consequently has a wavelength shorter than that corresponding to the minimum speed of propagation.
Small periodic, usually undesirable, variations in electrical voltage superposed on a direct voltage or on an alternating voltage of lower frequency.
A type of ice cream with wavy lines of coloured flavoured syrup running through it.
(of water) form or flow with a series of small waves on the surface.
Cause (the surface of water) to form small waves.
Move in a way resembling a series of small waves.
(of a sound or feeling) spread through a person, group, or place.
--Examples--
‘he dived into the pool leaving barely a ripple’
‘the ripples spread across the pond’
‘the sand undulated and was ridged with ripples’
‘a ripple of laughter ran around the room’
‘his words set off a ripple of excitement within her’
‘ripple current’
‘a family block of raspberry ripple’
‘the Mediterranean rippled and sparkled’
‘a cool wind rippled the surface of the estuary’
‘fields of grain rippling in the wind’
‘applause rippled around the tables’

--Word--
Aristarchus 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(3rd century BC), Greek astronomer; known as Aristarchus of Samos. Founder of an important school of Hellenic astronomy, he was aware of the rotation of the earth around the sun and so was able to account for the seasons.
(c.217–145 BC), Greek scholar; known as Aristarchus of Samothrace. The librarian at Alexandria, he is noted for his editions of the writings of Homer and other Greek authors.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aristides 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(5th century BC), Athenian statesman and general; known as Aristides the Just. He commanded the Athenian army at the battle of Plataea.
--Examples--

Aristides 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(5th century BC), Athenian statesman and general; known as Aristides the Just. He commanded the Athenian army at the battle of Plataea.

--Word--
Aristippus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(late 5th century BC), Greek philosopher; known as Aristippus the Elder. He was a pupil of Socrates and is generally considered the founder of the Cyrenaic school.

aristocracy 
--Type--
noun

Aristophanes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.450–c.385 BC), Greek comic playwright. His surviving plays are characterized by exuberant language and the satirization of leading contemporary figures. Notable works: Lysistrata, the Birds, the Frogs.

noun

noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Arkansas, an Arkansan; specifically one made homeless during the Great Depression and forced to seek employment elsewhere, especially in California. Hence: a simpleton, a country bumpkin (depreciative).
--Examples--
--Word--
arkose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A coarse-grained sandstone which is at least 25 per cent feldspar.

--Word--
ark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the Bible) the ship built by Noah to save his family and two of every kind of animal from the Flood; Noah's ark.
A ship or boat.
A chest or cupboard housing the Torah scrolls in a synagogue.
A small bivalve mollusc which attaches itself to rocks with byssus threads.
A low hut used to house livestock, often incorporating a covered run.
--Examples--
‘we reassembled the pig ark in preparation for our spring arrivals’
‘poultry arks make useful supervised runs for guinea pigs’
--Word--
Arkwright, Sir Richard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1732–92), English inventor and industrialist. In 1767 he patented a water-powered spinning machine capable of producing yarn strong enough to be used as warp.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in south-eastern France; population 53,058 (2006). It was the capital of the medieval kingdom of Arles, formed in the 10th century by the union of the kingdoms of Provence and Burgundy.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in south-eastern France; population 53,058 (2006). It was the capital of the medieval kingdom of Arles, formed in the 10th century by the union of the kingdoms of Provence and Burgundy.

Arlington 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A county in northern Virginia, forming a suburb of Washington. It is the site of the Pentagon.
An industrial city in northern Texas, between Dallas and Fort Worth; population 374,417 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Arlon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in south-eastern Belgium, capital of the province of Luxembourg; population 26,929 (2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
arm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the two upper limbs of the human body from the shoulder to the hand.
A flexible limb of an invertebrate animal, e.g. an octopus.
A sleeve of a garment.
An ability to bowl, pitch, or throw a ball skilfully.
Used to refer to the holding of a person's arm in support or companionship.
Used to refer to something powerful or protective.
A thing comparable to an arm in form or function, typically something that projects from a larger structure.
A side part of a chair or other seat on which a sitter can rest their arm.
A narrow strip of water or land projecting from a larger body.
A branch or division of a company or organization.
Each of the types of troops of which an army is composed, such as infantry or artillery.
Each of the lines enclosing an angle.
--Examples--
‘she held the baby in her arms’
‘he has a good arm’
‘as they walked he offered her his arm’
‘I'm so proud to have you on my arm’
‘they have extended the arm of friendship to developing countries’
‘cables will secure the boom to steel arms installed near the top of the tower’
‘a cat was curled up on an arm of the tree’
‘he draped his legs over the arm of the sofa’
‘a large walnut desk chair with padded arms’
‘the whole place is divided into two equal parts by an arm of the sea’
‘the political arm of the separatist group’

--Word--
armada 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fleet of warships.
A Spanish naval invasion force sent against England in 1588 by Philip II of Spain. It was defeated by the English fleet and almost completely destroyed by storms off the Hebrides.
--Examples--
‘an armada of destroyers, minesweepers, and gunboats’
--Word--
armada 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fleet of warships.
A Spanish naval invasion force sent against England in 1588 by Philip II of Spain. It was defeated by the English fleet and almost completely destroyed by storms off the Hebrides.
--Examples--
‘an armada of destroyers, minesweepers, and gunboats’
--Word--
armadilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small fleet or squadron of warships.
--Examples--
--Word--
armadillo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A nocturnal insectivorous mammal that has large claws for digging and a body covered in bony plates. Armadillos are native to Central and South America and one kind is spreading into the southern US.
--Examples--
--Word--
armadillo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A nocturnal insectivorous mammal that has large claws for digging and a body covered in bony plates. Armadillos are native to Central and South America and one kind is spreading into the southern US.

Armageddon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the New Testament) the last battle between good and evil before the Day of Judgement.
The place where the Armageddon will be fought.
A dramatic and catastrophic conflict, especially one seen as likely to destroy the world or the human race.
--Examples--
‘nuclear Armageddon’

noun
--Meanings--

armatole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Ottoman-ruled Greece: a member of an armed militia composed of Greek mercenaries, serving from the 15th cent. until Greek independence in the 1830s as a form of police force.
--Examples--
--Word--
armature 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rotating coil or coils of a dynamo or electric motor.
Any moving part of an electrical machine in which a voltage is induced by a magnetic field.
A piece of iron or other object acting as a keeper for a magnet.
An open framework on which a sculpture is moulded with clay or similar material.
A framework or formal structure, especially of a literary work.
The protective covering of an animal or plant.
Armour.
--Examples--
‘Shakespeare's plots have served as the armature for many novels’

--Word--
Armenia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A landlocked country in the Caucasus of south-western Asia; population 3,000,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Armenian; capital, Yerevan.
--Examples--
--Word--
Armenian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Armenia or to the Armenian Church.
A native of Armenia, or a person of Armenian descent.
The Indo-European language of Armenia, spoken by around 4 million people and written in a distinctive alphabet of thirty-eight letters.
--Examples--

armenite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rare silicate mineral containing aluminium, calcium, and barium, typically occurring as colourless or greyish-green prismatic crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
Armenoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a division of the Caucasoid race associated with the northern part of Western Asia, including Anatolia, the Caucasus, and the eastern Mediterranean, characterized by a brachycephalic skull shape, a prominent nose, and dark skin and hair. Also as noun: a person of this physical type.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turkish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Turkey or to the Turks or their language.
Relating to or associated with the Ottoman Empire.
The official language of Turkey, a Turkic language spoken by about 50 million people. It was written in the Arabic script until 1928, when the Roman alphabet was adopted.

--Word--
Armeria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of perennial, tufted, flowering herbs of the family Plumbaginaceae, which are native to (especially alpine and coastal) areas in Europe, Asia, America, and North Africa, many being cultivated widely as ornamental plants; (also armeria) a plant of this genus, of which the most widespread is common thrift, Armeria maritima.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
armet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A helmet of Italian origin introduced in the early 15th cent., consisting of a steel skull extending at the rear to form a narrow neck guard, wide hinged cheekpieces overlapping at the chin, and a small hinged pointed visor.
--Examples--

arm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the two upper limbs of the human body from the shoulder to the hand.
A flexible limb of an invertebrate animal, e.g. an octopus.
A sleeve of a garment.
An ability to bowl, pitch, or throw a ball skilfully.
Used to refer to the holding of a person's arm in support or companionship.
Used to refer to something powerful or protective.

A narrow strip of water or land projecting from a larger body.
A branch or division of a company or organization.
Each of the types of troops of which an army is composed, such as infantry or artillery.
Each of the lines enclosing an angle.
--Examples--
‘she held the baby in her arms’
‘he has a good arm’

armil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An arm-ring or bracelet; (now specifically) a golden bracelet worn by the British sovereign at his or her coronation.
A stole worn by the British sovereign at his or her coronation; = armilla. Now rare.
Astronomy= armilla. Now historical.
--Examples--

--Word--
armilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Astronomy= "armillary sphere".
A stole worn by the British sovereign at his or her coronation.
Chiefly Archaeology. An arm-ring or bracelet.
--Examples--
--Word--
armillary sphere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A model of the celestial globe constructed from rings and hoops representing the equator, the tropics, and other celestial circles, and able to revolve on its axis.
--Examples--
--Word--
armillaria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fungus of a genus that includes the honey fungus, found chiefly in woodland. Its mycelia can grow for a considerable distance, enabling individuals of parasitic species to invade more than one tree.
--Examples--

Arminian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the doctrines of Jacobus Arminius (Latinized name of Jakob Hermandszoon, 1560–1609), a Dutch Protestant theologian who rejected the Calvinist doctrine of predestination. His teachings had a considerable influence on Methodism.
An adherent of Arminian doctrines.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arminianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Arminianize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To hold or express Arminian views. Also with object: to render Arminian; to convert or conform to Arminian ideas.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arminianize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To hold or express Arminian views. Also with object: to render Arminian; to convert or conform to Arminian ideas.

--Word--
armlock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A method of restraining someone by holding their arm tightly behind their back.
--Examples--
‘one of the cops put an armlock on me’
‘the prime minister has begun inching out of the pro-European armlock in which he is held’

--Word--
armour 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The metal coverings formerly worn to protect the body in battle.
The tough metal layer covering a military vehicle or ship to defend it from attack.
Military vehicles collectively.
The protective layer or shell of some animals and plants.
A person's emotional, social, or other defences.
Provide (someone) with emotional, social, or other defences.
--Examples--
‘knights in armour’
‘a suit of armour’
‘infantry, armour, and logistic units’
‘his armour of self-confidence’
‘the knowledge armoured him against her’
--Word--
armour-bearer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who carries the armour or weapons of a soldier, warrior, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
armour-clad 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Clad in, protected by, or covered with armour; specifically (of a warship) covered wholly or partly with thick defensive metal plates.
Of an animal, or a part of its body: having the surface protected by a defensive outer layer of scales, bones, plates, etc.
An armour-clad warship. Compare "ironclad". Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
armoured 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Covered with or protected by armour.
(of some animals and plants) having a protective layer or shell.
--Examples--
‘armoured vehicles’
‘armoured fish’

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Armstrong, Neil 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1930–2012), American astronaut; full name Neil Alden Armstrong. He commanded the Apollo 11 mission, during which he became the first man to set foot on the moon (20 July 1969).

Arnhem 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in the eastern Netherlands, situated on the River Rhine, capital of the province of Gelderland; population 143,582 (2008). During the Second World War, in September 1944, Allied airborne troops made a landing nearby but were overwhelmed by German forces.

proper noun

--Word--
roar 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A full, deep, prolonged cry uttered by a lion or other large wild animal.
A loud, deep sound uttered by a person or crowd, generally as an expression of pain, anger, or approval.
A loud outburst of laughter.
A very loud, deep, prolonged sound made by something inanimate.
(of a lion or other large wild animal) utter a full, deep, prolonged cry.
(of a person or crowd) utter a loud, deep, prolonged sound, typically from anger, pain, or excitement.
(of something inanimate) make a very loud, deep, prolonged sound.
Utter or express in a loud tone.
(of a crowd) encourage (someone) to do something by loud shouts or cheering.
Laugh loudly.
(of a horse) make a loud noise in breathing as a symptom of disease of the larynx.
(especially of a vehicle) move at high speed making a loud prolonged sound.
Act or happen fast and decisively or conspicuously.
--Examples--
‘she waited for the lion's roar’
‘he gave a roar of rage’
‘her remarks brought a roar of laughter from the old man’
‘the roar of the sea’
‘we heard a lion roar’
‘Manfred roared with rage’
‘a huge fire roared in the grate’
‘the crowd roared its approval’
‘‘Get out of my way!’ he roared’
‘Damon Hill will be roared on this weekend by a huge home crowd’
‘Shirley roared in amusement’
‘a car roared past’
‘Swindon roared back with two goals’

--Word--
aromatic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a pleasant and distinctive smell.
Relating to or denoting organic compounds containing a planar unsaturated ring of atoms which is stabilized by an interaction of the bonds forming the ring, e.g. benzene and its derivatives.
A substance or plant emitting a pleasant and distinctive smell.
An aromatic compound.
--Examples--
‘a massage with aromatic oils’

room 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Space that can be occupied or where something can be done.
Opportunity or scope for something to happen or be done.
A part or division of a building enclosed by walls, floor, and ceiling.
The people present in a room.
A set of rooms, typically rented, in which a person, couple, or family live.
Share a room, house, or flat, especially a rented one at a college or similar institution.
Provide with a shared room or lodging.
--Examples--
‘there's only room for a single bed in there’
‘she made room for Josh on the sofa’
‘he was trapped without room to move’
‘there's room for improvement in the way the programme is managed’
‘a policy which left the government with very little room to manoeuvre’
‘he wandered from room to room’
‘the whole room burst into an uproar of approval’
‘my rooms at Mrs Jenks's house’
‘I was rooming with my cousin’
‘they roomed us together’
--Word--
root 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The part of a plant which attaches it to the ground or to a support, typically underground, conveying water and nourishment to the rest of the plant via numerous branches and fibres.
The persistent underground part of a plant, especially when fleshy and enlarged and used as a vegetable, e.g. a turnip or carrot.
Any plant grown for its root.
The embedded part of a bodily organ or structure such as a hair, tooth, or nail.
The part of a thing attaching it to a greater or more fundamental whole; the end or base.
The basic cause, source, or origin of something.
Family, ethnic, or cultural origins.
Denoting or relating to something from a particular ethnic or cultural origin, especially a non-Western one.
(in biblical use) a scion; a descendant.
A morpheme, not necessarily surviving as a word in itself, from which words have been made by the addition of prefixes or suffixes or by other modification.
The fundamental note of a chord.
A number or quantity that when multiplied by itself, typically a specified number of times, gives a specified number or quantity.
A value of an unknown quantity satisfying a given equation.
A user account with full and unrestricted access to a system.
An act of sexual intercourse.
A sexual partner of a specified ability.
Cause (a plant or cutting) to grow roots.
(of a plant or cutting) establish roots.
Establish deeply and firmly.
Have as an origin or cause.
Cause (someone) to stand immobile through fear or amazement.
Gain access to the root account of (a smartphone or computer)
Have sexual intercourse with.
Exhaust (someone) or frustrate their efforts.
--Examples--
‘cacti have deep and spreading roots’
‘a tree root’
‘root growth’
‘you should never wash roots before storing’
‘roots like beet and carrot cannot be transplanted’
‘her hair was fairer at the roots’
‘a little lever near the root of the barrel’
‘they disappeared from sight behind the root of the crag’
‘money is the root of all evil’
‘jealousy was at the root of it’
‘the root cause of the problem’
‘it's always nice to return to my roots’
‘roots music’
‘the root of David’
‘many European words stem from this linguistic root’
‘the root form of the word’
‘in the sequence the roots of the chords drop by fifths’
‘the roots of the equation differ by an integer’
‘make sure that these files can only be accessed by the root user’
‘I need to log in as root on my system to resolve an issue’
‘root your own cuttings from stock plants’
‘large trees had rooted in the canal bank’
‘vegetarianism is rooted in Indian culture’
‘the Latin verb is rooted in an Indo-European word’
‘she found herself rooted to the spot in disbelief’
‘we explained how to manually root almost any Android device’
‘grab a pew—you must be rooted’

arose 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
around 
--Type--
adverb, preposition
--Meanings--
Located or situated on every side.
So as to face in the opposite direction.
In or to many places throughout a locality.
Aimlessly or unsystematically; here and there.
Present, living, in the vicinity, or in active use.
(used with a number or quantity) approximately.
On every side of.
(of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focal point.
In or to many places throughout (a community or locality)
So as to pass (a place or object) in a curved or approximately circular route.
So as to encircle or embrace (someone or something)
--Examples--
‘the mountains towering all around’
‘Guy seized her by the shoulders and turned her around’
‘word got around that he was on the verge of retirement’
‘one of them was glancing nervously around’
‘there was no one around’
‘maize has been around for a long time’
‘software costs would be around £1,500’
‘I returned to my hotel around 3 a.m’
‘the palazzo is built around a courtyard’
‘the hills around the city’
‘our entire culture is built around those loyalties’
‘cycling around the village’
‘a number of large depots around the country’
‘he walked around the airfield’
‘it can drill around corners’
‘he put his arm around her’

arouse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

Awaken (someone) from sleep.
--Examples--

‘the letter aroused in him a sense of urgency’
‘an ability to influence the audience and to arouse the masses’
‘I was surprised to find that this look aroused me’
‘she had been aroused from deep slumber’

‘I felt very aroused’
--Word--
aroused 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Sexually excited.
--Examples--
‘I felt very aroused’
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Word--
aroused 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Sexually excited.
--Examples--
‘I felt very aroused’
--Word--
arouse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Evoke or awaken (a feeling, emotion, or response)
Excite or provoke (someone) to anger or strong emotions.
Excite (someone) sexually.
Awaken (someone) from sleep.
--Examples--
‘something about the man aroused the guard's suspicions’
‘the letter aroused in him a sense of urgency’
‘an ability to influence the audience and to arouse the masses’
‘I was surprised to find that this look aroused me’
‘she had been aroused from deep slumber’
--Word--
arouse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Evoke or awaken (a feeling, emotion, or response)
Excite or provoke (someone) to anger or strong emotions.
Excite (someone) sexually.
Awaken (someone) from sleep.
--Examples--
‘something about the man aroused the guard's suspicions’
‘the letter aroused in him a sense of urgency’
‘an ability to influence the audience and to arouse the masses’
‘I was surprised to find that this look aroused me’
‘she had been aroused from deep slumber’
--Word--
row 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A number of people or things in a more or less straight line.
A line of seats in a theatre.
A street with a continuous line of houses along one or both of its sides.
A horizontal line of entries in a table.
A complete line of stitches in knitting or crochet.
--Examples--
‘her villa stood in a row of similar ones’
‘they sat in the front row’
‘he lives at 23 Saville Row’
‘visualize the subject in the form of a sheet of paper divided into columns and rows’
--Word--
ARP 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Air-raid precautions.
Adjustable-rate preferred.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

‘he perceptibly arpeggiates the Sonata's first chord’
‘an arpeggiated fanfare’

--Word--
arpent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An old French unit of land area equivalent to 3,420 square metres (about 1 acre), the standard measure of land in those areas settled during the French regime and in use until the 1970s.
A unit of linear measure equivalent to about 58 m (190 feet), used in New France.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

arrah 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
array 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An impressive display or range of a particular type of thing.
An ordered series or arrangement.
An arrangement of troops.
An arrangement of quantities or symbols in rows and columns; a matrix.
An indexed set of related elements.
Elaborate or beautiful clothing.
A list of jurors impanelled.
Display or arrange (things) in a particular way.
Dress someone in (the clothes specified)
Impanel (a jury).
--Examples--
‘there is a vast array of literature on the topic’
‘a bewildering array of choices’
‘several arrays of solar panels will help provide power’
‘the lens focuses light on to an array of pixels’
‘I shall have my men drawn up here in battle array ready to come to your help’
‘he was clothed in fine array’
‘the manifesto immediately divided the forces arrayed against him’
‘they were arrayed in Hungarian national dress’

--Word--
arraign 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Call or bring (someone) before a court to answer a criminal charge.
Find fault with; censure.
--Examples--
‘her sister was arraigned on charges of attempted murder’
‘social workers were relieved it was not they who were arraigned in the tabloids’
--Word--
arraignment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of arraigning someone in court.
--Examples--
‘he's scheduled for arraignment in New York on Thursday’
‘she pleaded not guilty at her arraignment’

--Word--
arrange 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Put (things) in a neat, attractive, or required order.
Organize or make plans for (a future event)
Reach agreement about an action or event in advance.
Ensure that (something) is done or provided by organizing it in advance.
Adapt (a musical composition) for performance with instruments or voices other than those originally specified.
Settle (a dispute or claim)
--Examples--
‘she had just finished arranging the flowers’
‘the columns are arranged in 12 rows’
‘they hoped to arrange a meeting’
‘my aunt arranged for the furniture to be stored’
‘I arranged with my boss to have the time off’
‘they arranged to meet at eleven o'clock’
‘accommodation can be arranged if required’
‘songs arranged for viola and piano’
‘the quarrel, partly by the interference of the Crown Prince, was arranged’
--Word--
arrangeable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Type--
verb

--Word--
arrangement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action, process, or result of arranging or being arranged.
A thing that has been arranged in a neat or attractive way.
A plan or preparation for a future event.
An agreement with someone to do something.
A musical composition arranged for performance with instruments or voices differing from those originally specified.
A settlement of a dispute or claim.
--Examples--
‘the arrangement of the furniture in the room’
‘an intricate arrangement of gravel paths’
‘all the arrangements for the wedding were made’
‘the travel agents have an arrangement with the hotel’
‘by special arrangement, students can take a course in other degree programmes’
‘Mozart's symphonies in arrangements for cello and piano’

--Word--
arras 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A wall hanging made of a rich tapestry fabric, typically used to conceal an alcove.
A town in north-eastern France; population 43,663 (2006). In medieval times it was a centre for the manufacture of tapestries.
--Examples--
‘he pulled back the arras on the far wall and went into his secret chamber’

--Word--
guard 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Watch over in order to protect or control.
Watch over (someone) to prevent them from escaping.
Stay close to (an opponent) in order to prevent them getting or passing the ball.
Protect against damage or harm.
Take precautions against.
A person who keeps watch, especially a soldier or other person assigned to protect a person or to control access to a place.
A body of soldiers serving to protect a place or person.
The household troops of the British army.
A member of the Irish police force; a Garda.
A prison warder.
A device worn or fitted to prevent injury or damage.
A defensive posture that is adopted in a boxing or martial arts contest or in a fight.
A state of vigilance or preparedness against adverse circumstances.
An official who rides on and is in general charge of a train.
Each of two players either side of the centre.
Each of two players chiefly responsible for marking opposing players.
--Examples--
‘two men were left to guard the stockade’
‘the gates were guarded by soldiers’
‘his task was to help guard Japanese prisoners’
‘when a player is so closely guarded he cannot pass the ball’
‘the company fiercely guarded its independence’
‘farmers must guard against sudden changes in the market’
‘a security guard’
‘soldiers on guard duty’
‘he's the captain of the palace guard’
‘There's bends all the way from Portlaoise to Carlow. The responsibility for speeding traffic rests with the guards’
‘a retractable blade guard’
‘before Seb could raise his guard Boz swung a wild punch’
‘he let his guard slip enough to make some unwise comments’
--Word--
arrears 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Money that is owed and should have been paid earlier.
--Examples--
‘he was suing the lessee for the arrears of rent’
‘mortgage arrears’
--Word--
-ward 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
(forming adverbs) towards the specified place or direction.
(forming adjectives) turned or tending towards.
--Examples--
‘eastwards’
‘homewards’
‘onward’
‘upward’
--Word--
arrest 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Seize (someone) by legal authority and take them into custody.
Seize and detain (a ship) by legal authority.
Stop or check (progress or a process)
Suffer a heart attack.
Attract the attention of (someone)
The action of seizing someone and taking them into custody.
A stoppage or sudden cessation of motion.
--Examples--
‘the police arrested him for possession of marijuana’
‘two youths aged 16 were arrested’
‘they got arrested during a police raid’
‘they arrested a vessel with a ton of salmon on board’
‘the spread of the disease can be arrested’
‘they were trying to resuscitate a patient who had arrested’
‘the church's stillness arrested her’
‘I have a warrant for your arrest’
‘they placed her under arrest’
‘at least 69 arrests were made’
‘a respiratory arrest’
--Word--
arrestable offence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An offence for which there is a fixed mandatory penalty or which carries a sentence of at least five years' imprisonment (e.g. theft).
--Examples--
--Word--
arrestment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An attachment of property for the satisfaction of a debt.
--Examples--
‘the Scottish clearing banks are unable to handle the volume of arrestments’

Seize and detain (a ship) by legal authority.
Stop or check (progress or a process)
Suffer a heart attack.
Attract the attention of (someone)
The action of seizing someone and taking them into custody.
A stoppage or sudden cessation of motion.
--Examples--
‘the police arrested him for possession of marijuana’
‘two youths aged 16 were arrested’
‘they got arrested during a police raid’
‘they arrested a vessel with a ton of salmon on board’
‘the spread of the disease can be arrested’
‘they were trying to resuscitate a patient who had arrested’
‘the church's stillness arrested her’
‘I have a warrant for your arrest’
‘they placed her under arrest’
‘at least 69 arrests were made’
‘a respiratory arrest’

--Examples--
--Word--
arrive 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Reach a place at the end of a journey or a stage in a journey.
(of a thing) be brought or delivered.
(of an event or a particular moment) happen or come.
(of a new development or product) come into existence or use.
Reach (a conclusion or decision)
(of a baby) be born.
Achieve success or recognition.
--Examples--
‘we arrived at his house and knocked at the door’
‘the team arrived in New Delhi on July 30’
‘they had recently arrived from Turkey’
‘the invitation arrived a few days later’
‘we will be in touch with them when the time arrives’
‘microcomputers arrived at the start of the 1970s’
‘they arrived at the same conclusion’
‘he will feel jealous when a new baby arrives’
‘he still has to pinch himself to be sure he really has arrived’

--Word--
arroba 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of weight, used (especially formerly) in Spain, Portugal, and South America, varying locally from approx. 24 to 35 pounds (11 to 16 kg); specifically (a) a unit of weight used in Spain and some (former) Spanish colonies, equal to 25 Spanish pounds (11.5 kg); (b) a unit of weight used in Portugal and some (former) Portuguese colonies, equal to approx. 32 pounds (14.5 kg).
A unit of liquid measure, used (especially formerly) in Spain and some (former) Spanish colonies, varying locally and according to the liquid, from approx. 2.6 to 3.6 gallons (11.8 to 16.4 litres).
--Examples--
--Word--
arroba 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of weight, used (especially formerly) in Spain, Portugal, and South America, varying locally from approx. 24 to 35 pounds (11 to 16 kg); specifically (a) a unit of weight used in Spain and some (former) Spanish colonies, equal to 25 Spanish pounds (11.5 kg); (b) a unit of weight used in Portugal and some (former) Portuguese colonies, equal to approx. 32 pounds (14.5 kg).
A unit of liquid measure, used (especially formerly) in Spain and some (former) Spanish colonies, varying locally and according to the liquid, from approx. 2.6 to 3.6 gallons (11.8 to 16.4 litres).

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

--Word--
arrowwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
†(a) alder buckthorn, Frangula alnus (family Rhamnaceae) (obsolete); (b) any of several North American shrubs of the genus Viburnum (family Adoxaceae), especially V. dentatum, having stiff, straight stems formerly used by North American Indians to make arrows; (c) any of various other North American shrubs, especially of the genus Euonymus, which typically grow in dense thickets and have tough, straight stems; also called arrowweed, burning bush, wahoo.
--Examples--
--Word--
arrowwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
†(a) alder buckthorn, Frangula alnus (family Rhamnaceae) (obsolete); (b) any of several North American shrubs of the genus Viburnum (family Adoxaceae), especially V. dentatum, having stiff, straight stems formerly used by North American Indians to make arrows; (c) any of various other North American shrubs, especially of the genus Euonymus, which typically grow in dense thickets and have tough, straight stems; also called arrowweed, burning bush, wahoo.

--Meanings--
A person's buttocks or anus.
A stupid, irritating, or contemptible person.
Behave in a stupid way; waste time.
Make a botched attempt at something.
Not want to do something because one has no interest in or enthusiasm for it.
--Examples--
--Word--
arsehole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's anus.
A stupid, irritating, or contemptible person.

‘leave me alone, you arseholes’

noun, adjective

Gorky, Arshile 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–48), Turkish-born American painter. An exponent of abstract expressionism, he is best known for his work of the early 1940s, for example Waterfall (1943).

--Word--
art 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture, producing works to be appreciated primarily for their beauty or emotional power.
Works produced by human creative skill and imagination.
Creative activity resulting in the production of paintings, drawings, or sculpture.
The various branches of creative activity, such as painting, music, literature, and dance.
Subjects of study primarily concerned with human creativity and social life, such as languages, literature, and history (as contrasted with scientific or technical subjects)
A skill at doing a specified thing, typically one acquired through practice.
--Examples--
‘the art of the Renaissance’
‘great art is concerned with moral imperfections’
‘she studied art in Paris’
‘his collection of modern art’
‘an art critic’
‘she's good at art’
‘the visual arts’
‘the art of photography’
‘the belief that the arts and sciences were incompatible’
‘the Faculty of Arts’
‘the art of conversation’

art. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Article.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--
Characterized by art; skilful, ingenious.

--Word--
Artaud, Antonin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1896–1948), French actor, director, and poet. He developed the concept of the non-verbal Theatre of Cruelty, which concentrated on the use of sound, mime, and lighting, expounding his theory in a series of essays Le Théâtre et son double (1938).
--Examples--
--Word--
art. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Article.
--Examples--
--Word--
conscious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Aware of and responding to one's surroundings.
Having knowledge of something.
Concerned with or worried about a particular matter.
(of an action or feeling) deliberate and intentional.
(of the mind or a thought) directly perceptible to and under the control of the person concerned.
--Examples--
‘although I was in pain, I was conscious’
‘we are conscious of the extent of the problem’
‘they were growing increasingly security-conscious’
‘a conscious effort to walk properly’
‘when you go to sleep it is only the conscious mind which shuts down’
--Word--
Arte Povera 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An artistic movement that originated in Italy in the 1960s, combining aspects of conceptual, minimalist, and performance art, and making use of worthless or common materials such as earth or newspaper, in the hope of subverting the commercialization of art.
--Examples--
--Word--
artefact 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An object made by a human being, typically one of cultural or historical interest.
Something observed in a scientific investigation or experiment that is not naturally present but occurs as a result of the preparative or investigative procedure.
--Examples--
‘gold and silver artefacts’
‘the curvature of the surface is an artefact of the wide-angle view’

Ward, Artemas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1727–1800), American politician and soldier. He served as a general during the American Revolution, second in command to George Washington. Later he was a member of the Continental Congress 1780–82 and of the US House of Representatives 1791–95.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ward, Artemas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1727–1800), American politician and soldier. He served as a general during the American Revolution, second in command to George Washington. Later he was a member of the Continental Congress 1780–82 and of the US House of Representatives 1791–95.
--Examples--
--Word--
Artemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of branchiopod crustaceans (order Anostraca) comprising small shrimp-like animals found in salt lakes, salt pans, and other aquatic habitats with a high salinity. Also: an animal of this genus, especially one of the common species A. salina, sometimes bred as aquarium food (also in form artemia); also called brine shrimp.
--Examples--
--Word--
Artemis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A goddess, daughter of Zeus and sister of Apollo. She was a huntress and is typically depicted with a bow and arrows.
--Examples--
--Word--
artemisia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aromatic or bitter-tasting plant of a genus that includes wormwood, mugwort, and sagebrush. Several kinds are used in herbal medicine and many are cultivated for their feathery grey foliage.

--Word--
artery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the muscular-walled tubes forming part of the circulation system by which blood (mainly that which has been oxygenated) is conveyed from the heart to all parts of the body.
An important route in a system of roads, rivers, or railway lines.
--Examples--
‘George Street, main artery of Edinburgh's Golden Mile’

‘one of the main arterial routes from York’

artesian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a well bored perpendicularly into water-bearing strata lying at an angle, so that natural pressure produces a constant supply of water with little or no pumping.
--Examples--
‘the availability of water from artesian wells makes agriculture possible’
‘water from the island's artesian supply’

arthrodia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
arthrodire 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the extinct order Arthrodira of placoderm fishes, which are known from Devonian fossil deposits and have a bony head-shield that is articulated at the neck to another bony shield covering the upper part of the body.
--Examples--
--Word--
arthrography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Radiological examination of a joint, especially by the injection of a contrast medium.
--Examples--
--Word--
arthrogryposis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Persistent contracture or rigidity of one or more joints; specifically (more fully "arthrogryposis multiplex congenita") any of a group of syndromes characterized by congenital contractures of a number of joints, especially of the hands and feet, and associated with various abnormalities of muscle, nerve, or connective tissue.
--Examples--
--Word--
arthrology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The systematic use of the fingers and hands as a means of communication; a manual alphabet. Compare "dactylology", "chirology". Now historical.
Anatomy. The branch of anatomy dealing with the joints.
--Examples--

arthropod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An invertebrate animal of the large phylum Arthropoda, such as an insect, spider, or crustacean.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arthropoda 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A large phylum of invertebrate animals that includes insects, spiders, crustaceans, and their relatives. They have a segmented body, an external skeleton, and jointed limbs, and are sometimes placed in different phyla.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Examples--
--Word--
arthrosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy. Articulation (of bones), specifically by a joint which permits movement; an instance of this; a joint of this kind. Compare earlier "diarthrosis", "enarthrosis", "synarthrosis". Now rare.
Medicine. Disease of the joints; (in later use) specifically degenerative or other non-inflammatory disease; an instance of this. Compare earlier "arthrosia", and later "haemarthrosis", "hydrarthrosis", osteoarthrosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
arthrosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy. Articulation (of bones), specifically by a joint which permits movement; an instance of this; a joint of this kind. Compare earlier "diarthrosis", "enarthrosis", "synarthrosis". Now rare.
Medicine. Disease of the joints; (in later use) specifically degenerative or other non-inflammatory disease; an instance of this. Compare earlier "arthrosia", and later "haemarthrosis", "hydrarthrosis", osteoarthrosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
arthrospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various kinds of spore or spore-like body produced by fungi and bacteria, specifically a fungal conidium formed by segmentation and fragmentation of an articulated hypha.

--Word--
arthrozoic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(In some former classifications) designating a division of the Metazoa including arthropods and segmented worms (corresponding broadly to the Articulata of Cuvier); relating to this group.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arthur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A legendary king of Britain, historically perhaps a 5th- or 6th-century Romano-British chieftain or general. Stories of his life, the exploits of his knights, and the Round Table of his court at Camelot were developed by Malory, Chrétien de Troyes, and other medieval writers and became the subject of many legends.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arthurian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the legendary King Arthur of Britain, or any of the stories of his life.
--Examples--
‘the Arthurian literary tradition’
--Word--
arty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Making a strong, affected, or pretentious display of being artistic or interested in the arts.
--Examples--
‘television people and arty types’
‘a very arty film’
--Word--
artiad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An element or radical whose valency is represented by an even number. Contrasted with "perissad". Now historical and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
artic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An articulated lorry.
--Examples--
--Word--
artichoke 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A European plant resembling a thistle, cultivated for its large flower heads.
The unopened flower head of the artichoke, of which the heart and the fleshy bases of the bracts are edible.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
artichoke 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A European plant resembling a thistle, cultivated for its large flower heads.

--Examples--
--Word--
article 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A particular item or object.
A piece of writing included with others in a newspaper, magazine, or other publication.
A separate clause or paragraph of a legal document or agreement, typically one outlining a single rule or regulation.
A period of training with a firm as a solicitor, architect, surveyor, or accountant.
The terms on which crew members take service on a ship.
The definite or indefinite article.
Bind (a trainee solicitor, architect, surveyor, or accountant) to undergo a period of training with a firm in order to become qualified.
--Examples--
‘small household articles’
‘articles of clothing’
‘an article about middle-aged executives’
‘it is an offence under Article 7 of the Treaty’
‘he is already in articles’
‘it may be worth taking articles in a specialized firm’
‘he was articled to a firm of solicitors in York’

--Word--
Articulata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A major group of animals comprising invertebrates with bilateral symmetry and an external skeleton, having the body and limbs composed of segments jointed together, comprising principally annelids (segmented worms) and arthropods; (also articulata) animals of this group collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
articulate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently.
Having joints or jointed segments.
Denoting a brachiopod which has projections and sockets that form a hinge joining the two halves of the shell.
Pronounce (something) clearly and distinctly.
Express (an idea or feeling) fluently and coherently.
Form a joint.
Be connected by joints.
--Examples--
‘an articulate account of their experiences’
‘he was not very articulate’
‘delicate articulate plants with a slender central stem’
‘he articulated each word with precision’
‘they were unable to articulate their emotions’
‘the mandible is a solid piece articulating with the head’
‘the wing is articulated to the thorax’
--Word--
articulated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having two or more sections connected by a flexible joint.
(of an idea or feeling) expressed; put into words.
--Examples--
‘an articulated lorry’
‘the trilobite's thorax has a variable number of articulated segments’
‘one of the first articulated emotions that you will hear from a child’
‘the lack of a clearly articulated policy’

--Word--
articulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The formation of clear and distinct sounds in speech.
The action of putting into words an idea or feeling.
The formation of a speech sound by constriction of the air flow in the vocal organs at a particular place (e.g. the tongue, teeth, or palate) and in a particular way (as a plosive, affricate, etc.).
Clarity in the production of successive notes.
The state of being jointed.
A specified joint.
--Examples--
‘the articulation of vowels and consonants’
‘it would involve the articulation of a theory of the just war’
‘beautifully polished articulation from the violins’
‘the area of articulation of the lower jaw’
‘the leg articulation’

artefact 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
artificial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made or produced by human beings rather than occurring naturally, especially as a copy of something natural.
(of a situation or concept) not existing naturally; contrived or false.
(of a person or their behaviour) insincere or affected.
(of a bid) conventional as opposed to natural.
--Examples--
‘her skin glowed in the artificial light’
‘an artificial limb’
‘artificial flowers’
‘the artificial division of people into age groups’
‘she gave an artificial smile’
‘the Italian team began with an artificial club’
--Word--
artificialism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
As a count noun: an artificial thing or characteristic; = "artificiality". More usually as a mass noun: the quality or state of being artificial; artificial character.
--Examples--
--Word--
artificiality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being made or produced by human beings rather than occurring naturally.
The quality of being contrived or false.
Insincerity or affectedness.
--Examples--
‘vigorous debates about the authenticity of the original and the artificiality of the copy’
‘users complain about the artificiality of war games’
‘he claimed to have been horrified by the artificiality of his actors during the making of his first feature film’

‘I'm next to him, smiling artificially through my misery’

‘rip-off artists’

art 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture, producing works to be appreciated primarily for their beauty or emotional power.
Works produced by human creative skill and imagination.
Creative activity resulting in the production of paintings, drawings, or sculpture.
The various branches of creative activity, such as painting, music, literature, and dance.
Subjects of study primarily concerned with human creativity and social life, such as languages, literature, and history (as contrasted with scientific or technical subjects)
A skill at doing a specified thing, typically one acquired through practice.
--Examples--
‘the art of the Renaissance’
‘great art is concerned with moral imperfections’
‘she studied art in Paris’
‘his collection of modern art’
‘an art critic’
‘she's good at art’
‘the visual arts’
‘the art of photography’
‘the belief that the arts and sciences were incompatible’
‘the Faculty of Arts’
‘the art of conversation’
--Word--
art-for-art's-saker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A proponent of art for art's sake.
--Examples--
--Word--
arty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Making a strong, affected, or pretentious display of being artistic or interested in the arts.
--Examples--
‘television people and arty types’
‘a very arty film’
--Word--
arty-crafty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Interested or involved in making decorative artistic objects, especially ones perceived as quaint or homespun.
--Examples--
‘he mixed with the arty-crafty set’
--Word--
arts-and-craftsy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of arts and crafts, or of the Arts and Crafts Movement, especially what is regarded as its more pretentious side.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘she holds a Master of Arts in Social Work and Sociology’
‘I am, as of today, a Master of Arts’
--Word--
Rubinstein, Artur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1888–1982), Polish-born American pianist. He toured extensively in Europe and the US and among his many recordings are the complete works of Chopin.
--Examples--
--Word--
Toscanini, Arturo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1867–1957), Italian conductor. He was musical director at La Scala in Milan (1898–1903; 1906–8) before becoming a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, New York (1908–21).
--Examples--
--Word--
artwork 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Illustrations, photographs, or other non-textual material prepared for inclusion in a publication.
Paintings, drawings, or other artistic works.
--Examples--
‘the technology can produce finished artwork for anything from press ads to corporate brochures’
‘the artwork on the dust jacket is repeated on the cover’
‘a collection of artwork from tribal cultures’
‘each artwork is reproduced in colour on a full page’

--Word--
Aruba 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in the Caribbean Sea, close to the Venezuelan coast; population 104,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Oranjestad. Formerly part of the Netherlands Antilles, it separated from that group in 1986 to become a self-governing territory of the Netherlands.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
arum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A European plant which has arrow-shaped leaves and a broad leafy spathe enclosing a club-shaped spadix. Pollination is by small flies which are temporarily trapped by the plant.
--Examples--

--Word--
as 
--Type--
abbreviation, adverb, conjunction, preposition
--Meanings--
Anglo-Saxon.
Assam.
Used in comparisons to refer to the extent or degree of something.
Used to emphasize an amount.
Used to indicate that something happens during the time when something else is taking place.
Used to indicate by comparison the way that something happens or is done.
Used to add or interject a comment relating to the statement of a fact.
Because; since.
Even though.
Used to refer to the function or character that someone or something has.
During the time of being (the thing specified)
--Examples--
‘go as fast as you can’
‘it tasted like grape juice but not as sweet’
‘as many as twenty-two rare species may be at risk’
‘Frank watched him as he ambled through the crowd’
‘as she grew older, she kept more to herself’
‘they can do as they wish’
‘she kissed him goodbye, as usual’
‘as you can see, I didn't go after all’
‘I must stop now as I have to go out’
‘sweet as he is, he doesn't pay his bills’
‘try as he might, he failed to pull it off’
‘it came as a shock’
‘she got a job as a cook’
‘he had often been ill as a child’

as- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
a 
--Type--
determiner, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
Used when mentioning someone or something for the first time in a text or conversation.
Used with units of measurement to mean one such unit.
One single; any.
Used when mentioning the name of someone not known to the speaker.
Someone like (the name specified)
Used to indicate membership of a class of people or things.
In, to, or for each; per (used when expressing rates or ratios)
(in travel timetables) arrives.
(in units of measurement) atto-.
(with reference to sporting fixtures) away.
(used before a date) before.
Acceleration.
The first letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the first in a set of items, categories, sizes, etc.
Denoting the first of two or more hypothetical people or things.
The highest class of academic mark.
(in the UK) denoting the most important category of road, other than a motorway.
Denoting the highest-earning socio-economic category for marketing purposes, including top management and senior professional personnel.
Denoting the first file from the left, as viewed from White's side of the board.
The first constant to appear in an algebraic expression.
Denoting the uppermost soil horizon, especially the topsoil.
The human blood type (in the ABO system) containing the A antigen and lacking the B.
(with numeral) denoting a series of international standard paper sizes each twice the area of the next, as A0, A1, A2, A3, A4, etc., A4 being 210 × 297 mm.
A shape like that of a capital A.
The sixth note of the diatonic scale of C major. The A above middle C is usually used as the basis for tuning and in modern music has a standard frequency of 440 Hz.
A key based on a scale with A as its keynote.
--Examples--
‘a man came out of the room’
‘it has been an honour to meet you’
‘a hundred’
‘a quarter of an hour’
‘I simply haven't a thing to wear’
‘a Mr Smith telephoned’
‘you're no better than a Hitler’
‘he is a lawyer’
‘this car is a BMW’
‘typing 60 words a minute’
‘a move to raise petrol prices by 3p a litre’
‘Penzance a 0915’
‘March 15 Sheffield United (a)’
‘a1200’
‘suppose A had killed B’
‘a dazzling array of straight A's’
‘the A34’
‘busy A-roads’
‘an A-shape’

--Word--
asafoetida 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fetid resinous gum obtained from the roots of a herbaceous plant, used in herbal medicine and Indian cooking.
A Eurasian plant of the parsley family, from which asafoetida gum is obtained.
--Examples--

Ashanti 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A region of central Ghana. It was annexed by Britain in 1902, becoming part of the former British colony of the Gold Coast.
A member of a people of south central Ghana.
The dialect of Akan spoken by the Ashanti.
Relating to the Ashanti or their language.

asbestos 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A highly heat-resistant fibrous silicate mineral that can be woven into fabrics, and is used in brake linings and in fire-resistant and insulating materials.

‘asbestos shingles’

--Word--
asbestosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A lung disease resulting from the inhalation of asbestos particles, marked by severe fibrosis and a high risk of mesothelioma (cancer of the pleura).
--Examples--

--Word--
A-scan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A radar or ultrasound scan in which the echo signals are used to generate a linear trace on an oscilloscope screen, the height of a peak being proportional to the strength of the echo; an image obtained by such a scan. Frequently attributive Compare B-scan.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
ascend 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Go up or climb.
Climb to the summit of (a mountain or hill)
(of a fish or boat) move upstream along (a river)
Rise or move up through the air.
(of a road or flight of steps) slope or lead up.
Move up to a higher social or professional rank.
(of a spiritual being or soul) go to heaven.
(of a voice or sound) rise in pitch.
--Examples--
‘she ascended the stairs’
‘we had ascended 3,000 ft’
‘the first traveller to ascend the mountain’
‘salmon ascend rivers from the sea to spawn’
‘the lift ascended from his sight’
‘the road ascends to the loch’
‘some executives ascend to top-level positions’
‘the Prophet ascended to heaven’
‘Carolyn's voice had ascended into high-pitched giggles’
--Word--
ascending 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Increasing in size or importance.
Sloping or leading upwards.
--Examples--
‘incomes ranked in ascending order of size’
‘a gently ascending forest path’
‘blood pressure in the ascending aorta’

--Word--
ascendant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Rising in power or influence.
(of a planet, zodiacal degree, or sign) on or close to the intersection of the ecliptic with the eastern horizon.
The point on the ecliptic at which it intersects the eastern horizon at a particular time, typically that of a person's birth.
--Examples--
‘the newly ascendant liberal party’

--Word--
Ascham, Roger 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1515–68), English humanist scholar and writer, noted for his treatise on archery, Toxophilus (1545), and The Scholemaster (1570), a practical and influential tract on education.
--Examples--
--Word--
aschelminth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An invertebrate animal belonging to a group of phyla that are distinguished by the lack of a well-developed coelom and blood vessels. Most are minute wormlike animals, including the nematodes, rotifers, and water bears.

--Word--
ASCII 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
American Standard Code for Information Interchange, a set of digital codes representing letters, numerals, and other symbols, widely used as a standard format in the transfer of text between computers.
--Examples--
‘ASCII codes’
‘ASCII format’

--Word--
ascomycete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fungus whose spores develop within asci (cylindrical sacs). They include most moulds, mildews, and yeasts, the fungal component of most lichens, and a few large forms such as morels and truffles.
--Examples--
--Word--
ascomycete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fungus whose spores develop within asci (cylindrical sacs). They include most moulds, mildews, and yeasts, the fungal component of most lichens, and a few large forms such as morels and truffles.
--Examples--
--Word--
ascon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sponge of a grade of structure of the simplest type, in the form of a tube or bag lined with choanocytes.
--Examples--

ascorbate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt, ester, or the anion of ascorbic acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
ascorbic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A vitamin found particularly in citrus fruits and green vegetables. It is essential in maintaining healthy connective tissue, and is also thought to act as an antioxidant. Severe deficiency causes scurvy.
--Examples--

A man's broad silk necktie.

--Word--
ascribe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Regard something as being due to (a cause)
Regard a text, quotation, or work of art as being produced by or belonging to (a particular person or period)
Regard a quality as belonging to.
--Examples--
‘he ascribed Jane's short temper to her upset stomach’
‘a quotation ascribed to Thomas Cooper’
‘tough-mindedness is a quality commonly ascribed to top bosses’

--Word--
ascription 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The attribution of something to a cause.
The attribution of a text, quotation, or work of art to a particular person or period.
The action of regarding a quality as belonging to someone or something.
A preacher's words ascribing praise to God at the end of a sermon.
--Examples--
‘the ascription of effect to cause’
‘her ascription of the text to Boccaccio’
‘questions of authorial ascription’
‘the ascription of special personal qualities to political leaders’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The expanse of salt water that covers most of the earth's surface and surrounds its land masses.

A large lake.
Used to refer to waves as opposed to calm sea.
Large waves.
A vast expanse or quantity of something.
--Examples--

‘rocky bays lapped by vivid blue sea’
‘a sea view’
‘the Black Sea’
‘the Sea of Galilee’
