‘the lifeboat met seas of thirty-five feet head-on’
‘she scanned the sea of faces for Stephen’

seethe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a liquid) boil or be turbulent as if boiling.
Cook (food) by boiling it in a liquid.
(of a person) be filled with intense but unexpressed anger.
(of a place) be crowded with people or things moving about in a rapid or hectic way.
(of a crowd of people) move in a rapid or hectic way.
--Examples--
‘the grey ocean seethed’
‘others were cut into joints and seethed in cauldrons made of the animal's own skins’
‘inwardly he was seething at the slight to his authority’
‘the entire cellar was seething with spiders’
‘we cascaded down the stairs and seethed across the station’

ash 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The powdery residue left after the burning of a substance.
The remains of a human body after cremation or burning.
The mineral component of an organic substance, as assessed from the residue left after burning.
A trophy for the winner of a series of Test matches in a cricket season between England and Australia.

‘cigarette ash’
‘I turned over the ashes’
‘his ashes were scattered on the waters of the Ganges River’
‘coal contains higher levels of ash than premium fuels’
--Word--
shake 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a structure or area of land) tremble or vibrate.
Cause to tremble or vibrate.
(of a person, part of the body, or the voice) tremble uncontrollably from a strong emotion.
Move (an object) up and down or from side to side with rapid, forceful, jerky movements.
Remove (an object or substance) from something by movements of this kind.
Grasp (someone) and move them roughly to and fro, either in anger or to rouse them from sleep.
Brandish in anger or as a warning; make a threatening gesture with.
Get rid of or put an end to.
Upset the composure or confidence of; shock or astonish.
Cause a change of mood or attitude by shocking or disturbing (someone)
An act of shaking.
An amount of something that is sprinkled by shaking a container.
A fit of trembling or shivering.
An earth tremor.
A trill.
A kind of rough wooden shingle, used especially on rustic buildings.
--Examples--
‘buildings shook in Sacramento and tremors were felt in Reno’
‘a severe earthquake shook the area’
‘Luke was shaking with rage’
‘her voice shook with passion’
‘she stood in the hall and shook her umbrella’
‘they shook the sand out of their shoes’
‘he gently shook the driver awake and they set off’
‘men shook their fists and shouted’
‘I couldn't shake the feeling that everyone was laughing at me’
‘rumours of a further loss shook the market’
‘the boy was visibly shaken’
‘if the bombing cannot shake the government out of its complacency, what will?’
‘she gave her red curls a vehement shake’
‘add a few shakes of sea salt and black pepper’
‘I wouldn't go in there, it gives me the shakes’
‘cedar shakes’

Ashanti 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A region of central Ghana. It was annexed by Britain in 1902, becoming part of the former British colony of the Gold Coast.
A member of a people of south central Ghana.
The dialect of Akan spoken by the Ashanti.
Relating to the Ashanti or their language.

--Word--
sharp 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of an object) having an edge or point that is able to cut or pierce something.
Tapering to a point or edge.
(of sand or gravel) composed of angular grains.
Producing a sudden, piercing physical sensation or effect.
(of a food, taste, or smell) acidic and intense.
(of a sound) sudden and penetrating.
(of words or a speaker) critical or hurtful.
(of an emotion or experience) felt acutely or intensely; painful.
Distinct in outline or detail; clearly defined.
(of an action or change) sudden and marked.
(of a bend, angle, or turn) making a sudden change of direction.
Having or showing speed of perception, comprehension, or response.
Quick to take advantage, especially in an unscrupulous or dishonest way.
(of musical sound) above true or normal pitch.
(of a note) a semitone higher than a specified note.
(of a key) having a sharp or sharps in the signature.
(of clothes or their wearer) smart and stylish.
Precisely (used after an expression of time)
In a sudden or abrupt way.
Above the true or normal pitch of musical sound.
A musical note raised a semitone above natural pitch.
The sign ♯, indicating a sharp.
A long, sharply pointed needle used for general sewing.
A thing with a sharp edge, such as a blade or a fragment of glass.
A swindler or cheat.
Raise the pitch of (a note).
Cheat or swindle (someone), especially at cards.
--Examples--
‘cut the cake with a very sharp knife’
‘keep tools sharp’
‘a sharp pencil’
‘her face was thin and her nose sharp’
‘I suddenly felt a sharp pain in my back’
‘fresh goats' milk cheese has a slightly sharper flavour than fromage frais’
‘there was a sharp crack of thunder’
‘she feared his sharp tongue’
‘he could be very sharp with her’
‘her sharp disappointment was tinged with embarrassment’
‘the job was a sharp contrast from her past life’
‘the scene was as sharp and clear in his mind as a film’
‘there was a sharp increase in interest rates’
‘he heard her sharp intake of breath’
‘the bus creaked round a sharp hairpin bend’
‘her sharp eyes missed nothing’
‘his old mind was not so sharp as it once was’
‘Paul's a sharp operator’
‘F sharp’
‘they were greeted by a young man in a sharp suit’
‘the meeting starts at 7.30 sharp’
‘turn sharp right at the corner’
‘he was brought up sharp by Helen's voice’
‘he heard him playing a little sharp on the high notes’
‘the safe disposal of sharps and clinical waste’
‘the fellow is drunk, let's sharp him’

noun

Ashcroft, John David 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1942), US attorney general 2001–05. Under him, the Justice Department was reorganized to focus on antiterrorism, following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.

Ashdown, Sir Paddy

Ashe, Arthur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1943–93), American tennis player; full name Arthur Robert Ashe. He won the US Open singles championship in 1968 and Wimbledon in 1975, and was the first black male player to achieve world rankings.

--Word--
shiver 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Shake slightly and uncontrollably as a result of being cold, frightened, or excited.
A momentary trembling movement.
A spell or an attack of trembling, typically as a result of fear or horror.
Each of the small fragments into which something such as glass is shattered when broken; a splinter.
Break into such splinters or fragments.
--Examples--
‘they shivered in the damp foggy cold’
‘she gave a little shiver as the wind flicked at her bare arms’
‘the way he looked at her sent shivers down her spine’
‘a look that gave him the shivers’
‘the world seemed to shiver into a million splinters of prismatic colour’
--Word--
Ashkenazi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Jew of central or eastern European descent. More than 80 per cent of Jews today are Ashkenazim; they preserve Palestinian rather than Babylonian Jewish traditions and some still use Yiddish.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northeastern Kentucky, on the Ohio River; population 21,346 (est. 2008). It is a center of the area's coal industry.

noun

ashlaring 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ashlar masonry.
Upright boarding fixed from the joists to the rafters of an attic to cut off the acute angle between the roof and the floor.

--Word--
ash 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The powdery residue left after the burning of a substance.
The remains of a human body after cremation or burning.
The mineral component of an organic substance, as assessed from the residue left after burning.
A trophy for the winner of a series of Test matches in a cricket season between England and Australia.
--Examples--
‘cigarette ash’
‘I turned over the ashes’
‘his ashes were scattered on the waters of the Ganges River’
‘coal contains higher levels of ash than premium fuels’
--Word--
Ashley, Laura 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–85), Welsh fashion and textile designer, known for her use of floral patterns and romantic Victorian and Edwardian styles.
--Examples--
--Word--
aisling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of allegorical poem in the Irish language, often serving as a vehicle for political or social comment, which depicts the poet's conversation with a spirit woman who is usually a personification of Ireland.

Ashmolean Museum 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A museum of art and antiquities in Oxford. It opened in 1683 and was the first public institution of its kind in England.

Assur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city state of Mesopotamia, situated on the River Tigris to the south of modern Mosul. It was the traditional capital of the Assyrian empires.

--Word--
Ashurbanipal 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
King of Assyria c.668–627 BC, grandson of Sennacherib. A patron of the arts, he established a library of more than 20,000 clay tablets at Nineveh.
--Examples--

Ash Wednesday 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first day of Lent in the Western Christian Church, marked by services of penitence.

--Word--
white ash 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An ash tree native to eastern North America, Fraxinus americana, widely cultivated for its timber; (also) the strong, pale wood of this tree, now favoured especially for the manufacture of baseball bats (frequently attributive).
Chiefly Australian. Any of various other trees thought to resemble the white ash, or producing similar timber, especially Eucalyptus fraxinoides (family Myrtaceae).
Refined sodium carbonate, prepared from black ash by washing with water followed by evaporation.

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Asia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The largest of the world's continents, constituting nearly one third of the land mass, lying entirely north of the equator except for some SE Asian islands. It is connected to Africa by the Isthmus of Suez, and borders Europe (part of the same land mass) along the Ural Mountains and across the Caspian Sea.

--Word--
aside 
--Type--
adverb, noun
--Meanings--
To one side; out of the way.
In reserve; for future use.
Used to indicate that one is dismissing a topic or changing to a new subject.
A remark or passage in a play that is intended to be heard by the audience but unheard by the other characters in the play.
A remark not intended to be heard by everyone present.
A remark that is not directly related to the main topic of discussion.
--Examples--
‘he pushed his plate aside’
‘they stood aside to let a car pass’
‘she must put aside all her antagonistic feelings’
‘she set aside some money for rent’
‘joking aside, I've certainly had my fill’
‘Shakespeare's use of asides and soliloquies’
‘‘Does that make him a murderer?’ whispered Alice in an aside to Fred’
‘the recipe book has little asides about the importance of home and family’
--Word--
aside 
--Type--
adverb, noun
--Meanings--
To one side; out of the way.
In reserve; for future use.
Used to indicate that one is dismissing a topic or changing to a new subject.
A remark or passage in a play that is intended to be heard by the audience but unheard by the other characters in the play.
A remark not intended to be heard by everyone present.
A remark that is not directly related to the main topic of discussion.
--Examples--
‘he pushed his plate aside’
‘they stood aside to let a car pass’
‘she must put aside all her antagonistic feelings’
‘she set aside some money for rent’
‘joking aside, I've certainly had my fill’
‘Shakespeare's use of asides and soliloquies’
‘‘Does that make him a murderer?’ whispered Alice in an aside to Fred’
‘the recipe book has little asides about the importance of home and family’

simmer 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of water or food that is being heated) stay just below boiling point while bubbling gently.
Keep (food) just below boiling point when cooking or heating it.
Exist in a suppressed state.
Show or feel barely suppressed anger or other strong emotion.
Become calmer and quieter.
A state or temperature just below boiling point.
--Examples--
‘the goulash was simmering slowly in the oven’
‘simmer the sauce gently until thickened’
‘the disagreement simmered for years and eventually boiled over’
‘she was simmering with resentment’
‘she gave him time to simmer down after their argument’
‘bring the water to a simmer’

‘gravitational asymmetries had pulled the sphere out of shape’

asynchronous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not existing or occurring at the same time.
Controlling the timing of operations by the use of pulses sent when the previous operation is completed rather than at regular intervals.
(of a machine or motor) not working in time with the alternations of current.
(of a satellite) revolving round the parent planet at a different rate from that at which the planet rotates.

--Word--
ask 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.
Talk to different people in order to find out something.
Enquire about the health or well-being of.
Say to (someone) that one wants them to do or give something.
Say that one wants permission to do something.
Say that one wants to speak to.
Say that one wants (a specified amount) as a price for selling something.
Expect or demand (something) of someone.
Invite (someone) to one's home or a function.
Invite someone to join one on a group outing.
Invite someone out on a date.
A demand or situation that requires a specified degree of effort or commitment.
A request, especially for a donation.
The price at which an item, especially a financial security, is offered for sale.
--Examples--
‘I asked her what she meant’
‘people are always asking questions’
‘‘How much further?’ I asked’
‘the old man asked about her job’
‘there are fine meals to be had if you ask around’
‘if I see him I'll tell him you were asking after him’
‘Mary asked her father for money’
‘I asked him to call the manager’
‘don't be afraid to ask for advice’
‘she asked if she could move in’
‘he asked to see the officer involved’
‘you should have asked my permission first’
‘when I arrived I asked for Katrina’
‘he was asking £250 for the guitar’
‘it's asking a lot, but could you look through Billy's things?’
‘it's about time we asked Pam to dinner’
‘she asked him round for a drink’
‘do you want to ask him along?’
‘a few boys asked her out but never the right ones’
‘it is a big ask for him to go and play 90 minutes’
‘it was a tough ask, but they delivered’
‘it was an awkward ask for more funding’
‘ask prices for bonds’
--Word--
askable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be asked for; possible or suitable as a request.
Able to be asked; suitable for asking.
North American. Of a person (especially a parent): easy to ask questions of; specifically approachable and open to questions concerning sexuality.
--Examples--
--Word--
askance 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With an attitude or look of suspicion or disapproval.
--Examples--
‘the reformers looked askance at the mystical tradition’
‘a waiter looked askance at his jeans’

askos

noun
--Meanings--

‘a few boys asked her out but never the right ones’
‘it is a big ask for him to go and play 90 minutes’
‘it was a tough ask, but they delivered’
‘it was an awkward ask for more funding’
‘ask prices for bonds’

--Word--
slug 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A tough-skinned terrestrial mollusc which typically lacks a shell and secretes a film of mucus for protection. It can be a serious plant pest.
A slow, lazy person.
An amount of alcoholic drink that is gulped or poured.
An elongated, typically rounded piece of metal.
A bullet, especially a lead one.
A missile for an airgun.
A line of type in Linotype printing.
A part of a URL which identifies a particular page on a website in a form readable by users.
Drink (something, typically alcohol) in a large draught; swig.
Strike (someone) with a hard blow.
Settle a dispute or contest by fighting or competing fiercely.
A hard blow.
--Examples--
‘he took a slug of whisky’
‘the reactor uses embedded slugs of uranium’
‘writers can edit the slug that will become an article or page URL’
‘she picked up her drink and slugged it straight back’
‘he was the one who'd get slugged’
‘they went outside to slug it out’

Messily blur the outline of (something such as writing or paint); smudge.
Damage the reputation of (someone) by false accusations; slander.
A mark or streak of a greasy or sticky substance.
A sample of tissue or other material taken from part of the body, spread thinly on a microscope slide for examination, typically for medical diagnosis.
A false accusation intended to damage someone's reputation.
An insecure foothold.

‘soon you're eyeballing the top, just one smear away’

A snorting sound made by an animal, typically when excited or frightened.
A quantity of an illegal drug, especially cocaine, inhaled in powdered form through the nose.

Make a sudden explosive sound through one's nose, especially to express indignation or derision.
(of an animal) make a sudden explosive sound through the nose, especially when excited or frightened.
Inhale (the powdered form of an illegal drug, especially cocaine) through the nose.

soak

verb, noun
--Meanings--

(of a liquid) penetrate or permeate completely.
Remove something by immersing it in water for a period of time.
Impose heavy charges or taxation on.
Drink heavily.
An act of immersing someone or something in liquid for a period of time.
A heavy drinker.
A hollow where rainwater collects; a waterhole.
soak oneself in
Immerse oneself in (a particular experience, activity, or interest)
soak something up
Absorb a liquid.
Expose oneself to or experience something beneficial or enjoyable.
Cost or use up money.
--Examples--

The southern part of England.
The southern states of the United States.
The less industrialized and economically advanced nations of the world.
The player sitting opposite and partnering North.

To or towards the south.
Below (a particular amount, cost, etc.)
Move towards the south.
(of a celestial object) cross the meridian.

aspartic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acidic amino acid which is a constituent of most proteins, and also occurs in sugar cane. It is important in the metabolism of nitrogen in animals, and also acts as a neurotransmitter.

aspect 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A particular part or feature of something.
A particular way in which something may be considered.
A particular appearance or quality.
The positioning of a building or other structure in a particular direction.
The side of a building facing a particular direction.
Any of a number of particular angular relationships between one celestial body or point on the ecliptic and another.
A category or form which expresses the way in which time is denoted by a verb.
(of a planet) form an aspect with (another celestial body)
--Examples--
‘personal effectiveness in all aspects of life’
‘the financial aspect can be overstressed’
‘from every aspect theirs was a changing world’
‘the air of desertion lent the place a sinister aspect’
‘a man of decidedly foreign aspect’
‘a greenhouse with a southern aspect’
‘the front aspect of the hotel was unremarkable’
‘the sun in Aries formed an adverse aspect with Uranus in Capricorn’
‘the semantics of tense and aspect’
‘four verbal aspects’
‘the sun is superbly aspected by your ruler Mars on the 19th’

--Word--
aspirate 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Pronounce (a sound) with an exhalation of breath.
Pronounce the sound of h at the beginning of a word.
Breathe (something) in; inhale.
Draw (fluid) by suction from a vessel or cavity.
Provide (an internal combustion engine) with air.
An aspirated consonant.
A sound of h.
Matter that has been drawn from the body by suction.
(of a sound) pronounced with an exhalation of breath; aspirated.
--Examples--
‘the aspirated allophone of p occurs in ‘pie’’
‘Londoners are always aspirating where they should not, and never aspirating where they should’
‘some drowning victims don't aspirate any water’
‘bile was aspirated through a catheter’
‘the superchargers produce twice the power of standard aspirated engines’
‘gastric aspirate’
‘oesophageal aspirates’
--Word--

An aspirated consonant.
A sound of h.
Matter that has been drawn from the body by suction.

spout 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tube or lip projecting from a container, through which liquid can be poured.
A stream of liquid issuing from somewhere with great force.
The plume of water vapour ejected from the blowhole of a whale.
A pipe or trough through which water may be carried away or from which it can flow out.
A sloping trough for conveying grain, coal, etc. to a lower level; a chute.
A lift in a pawnshop used to convey pawned items up for storage.
Send out (liquid) forcibly in a stream.
(of a liquid) flow out forcibly in a stream.
(of a whale or dolphin) eject (water vapour and air) through its blowhole.
Express (one's views or ideas) in a lengthy, declamatory, and unreflecting way.
--Examples--
‘a teapot with a chipped spout’
‘the tall spouts of geysers’
‘the spout of an occasional whale’
‘volcanoes spouted ash and lava’
‘blood was spouting from the cuts on my hand’
‘he was spouting platitudes about our furry friends’

--Word--
spread 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Open out (something) so as to extend its surface area, width, or length.
Stretch out (arms, legs, hands, fingers, or wings) so that they are far apart.
Extend over a large or increasing area.
(of a group of people) move apart so as to cover a wider area.
Distribute or disperse (something) over an area.
Gradually reach or cause to reach a wider area or more people.
(of people, animals, or plants) become distributed over a large or larger area.
Distribute in a specified way.
Apply (a substance) to an object or surface in an even layer.
Cover (a surface) with a substance in an even layer.
Be able to be applied in an even layer.
Lay (a table) for a meal.
The fact or process of spreading over an area.
The extent, width, or area covered by something.
The wingspan of a bird.
An expanse or amount of something.
A large farm or ranch.
The range or variety of something.
The difference between two rates or prices.
A soft paste that can be applied in a layer to bread or other food.
An article or advertisement covering several columns or pages of a newspaper or magazine, especially one on two facing pages.
A large and impressively elaborate meal.
A bedspread.
--Examples--
‘I spread a towel on the sand and sat down’
‘she helped Colin to spread out the map’
‘Bobby spread his arms wide’
‘rain over north-west Scotland will spread south-east during the day’
‘the Marines spread out across the docks’
‘volcanic eruptions spread dust high into the stratosphere’
‘the violence spread from the city centre to the suburbs’
‘she's always spreading rumours’
‘the owls have spread as far north as Kuala Lumpur’
‘you can spread the payments over as long a period as you like’
‘he sighed, spreading jam on a croissant’
‘spread each slice thinly with mayonnaise’
‘a tub of unsalted butter that spreads so well’
‘warmer temperatures could help reduce the spread of the disease’
‘the spread of the urban population into rural areas’
‘the male's antlers can attain a spread of six feet’
‘the red-tailed hawk has a four-and-a-half-foot spread’
‘the green spread of the park’
‘a wide spread of ages’
‘the very narrow spread between borrowing and deposit rates’
‘low-fat spreads’
‘cheese spread’
‘a double-page spread’
‘his mother laid on a huge spread’
‘a patchwork spread’

verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a plant) put out shoots.
Grow (plant shoots or hair)
(of a plant, flower, or hair) start to grow; spring up.

‘the weeds begin to sprout’
‘many black cats sprout a few white hairs’

squat 
--Type--
verb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Crouch or sit with one's knees bent and one's heels close to or touching one's buttocks or the back of one's thighs.
Crouch down with one's knees bent and rise again while holding (a specified weight) across one's shoulders.
Unlawfully occupy an uninhabited building or settle on a piece of land.
Unlawfully occupy (an uninhabited building)
Occupy a tract of Crown land in order to graze cattle or sheep.
Short and thickset; disproportionately broad or wide.
A squatting position.
An exercise in which a person squats down and rises again while holding a barbell across one's shoulders.
(in gymnastics) an exercise involving a squatting movement or action.
A building occupied by people living in it without the legal right to do so.
An unlawful occupation of an uninhabited building.
--Examples--
‘I squatted down in front of him’
‘he can squat 850 pounds’
‘eight families are squatting in the house’

‘many people moved further out and squatted on the land’
‘he was muscular and squat’
‘a squat grey house’

--Word--
Assad, Hafiz al- 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1930–2000), Syrian statesman; president 1971–2000. While in office he ensured the strengthening of Syria's oil-based economy and suppressed political opposition such as the uprising of Muslim extremists (1979–82). He supported the coalition forces during the 1991 Gulf War. His son Bashar al-Assad (born 1965) succeeded him: in 2011 a series of protests against his rule led to the Syrian civil war.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
assassin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who murders an important person for political or religious reasons.
A member of the Nizari branch of Ismaili Muslims at the time of the Crusades, when the newly established sect ruled part of northern Persia (1094–1256). They were renowned as militant fanatics, and were popularly reputed to use hashish before going on murder missions.
--Examples--

assault 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a physical attack on.
Carry out a military attack or raid on (an enemy position)
Bombard with something undesirable or unpleasant.
A physical attack.
An act that threatens physical harm to a person, whether or not actual harm is done.
A military attack or raid on an enemy position.
A strong verbal attack.
A concerted attempt to do something demanding.
--Examples--
‘he pleaded guilty to assaulting a police officer’
‘she was sexually assaulted as a child’
‘they left their strong position to assault the hill’
‘thunder assaulted the ears’
‘his imprisonment for an assault on the film director’
‘a sexual assault’
‘he admitted an assault and two thefts’
‘he appeared in court charged with assault’
‘troops began an assault on the city’
‘an articulate assault on all forms of prejudice’
‘a winter assault on Mt Everest’

A military attack or raid on an enemy position.
A strong verbal attack.
A concerted attempt to do something demanding.
--Examples--
‘he pleaded guilty to assaulting a police officer’
‘she was sexually assaulted as a child’
‘they left their strong position to assault the hill’
‘thunder assaulted the ears’
‘his imprisonment for an assault on the film director’
‘a sexual assault’
‘he admitted an assault and two thefts’
‘he appeared in court charged with assault’
‘troops began an assault on the city’
‘an articulate assault on all forms of prejudice’
‘a winter assault on Mt Everest’
--Word--
ass-backwards 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
In a manner contrary to what is usual, expected, or logical.
Contrary to what is usual, expected, or logical.
--Examples--
‘I never did like to do anything simple when I could do it ass-backwards’

--Word--
assegai 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slender, iron-tipped, hardwood spear used chiefly by southern African peoples.
A South African tree of the dogwood family, which yields hard timber.

--Examples--
‘he was a very brave man but he was eventually assegaied’

assemble 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of people) gather together in one place for a common purpose.
Cause (people or things) to gather together for a common purpose.
(of male moths) gather for mating in response to a pheromone released by a female.
Fit together the separate component parts of (a machine or other object)
Translate (a program) from a higher-level programming language into machine code.
A leap in which the feet are brought together before landing.
--Examples--
‘a crowd had assembled outside the gates’
‘he assembled the surviving members of the group for a tour’
‘my new machine is being assembled and my old one dismantled’
‘assemble the program and produce a file suitable to input to the simulator’

--Word--
assembly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A group of people gathered together in one place for a common purpose.
A group of people elected to make laws or decisions for a particular country or region.
The action of gathering together as a group for a common purpose.
The regular gathering of the teachers and pupils of a school at the start or end of the day.
A signal for troops to assemble, given by drum or bugle.
The action of fitting together the component parts of a machine or other object.
A unit consisting of components that have been fitted together.
The conversion of instructions in low-level code to machine code.
--Examples--
‘an assembly of dockers and labourers’
‘the 577-seat National Assembly’
‘the UN General Assembly’
‘a decree guaranteeing freedom of assembly’
‘he was told off for talking in assembly’
‘a car assembly plant’
‘the tail assembly of the aircraft’

assessor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
assign 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allocate (a job or duty)
Appoint (someone) to a job, task, or organization.
Designate or set (something) aside for a specific purpose.
Attribute something as belonging to.
Transfer (legal rights or liabilities)
--Examples--
‘Congress had assigned the task to the agency’
‘his leader assigned him this mission’
‘she has been assigned to a new job’
‘managers happily assign large sums of money to travel budgets’
‘it is difficult to decide whether to assign the victory to Godwin’
‘they will ask you to assign your rights against the airline’
‘this agreement shall be binding upon the parties and their successors and assigns’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who legally transfers a right or liability to someone else.
--Examples--
‘a valid assignment of copyright signed by the assignor’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be allotted to someone or designated for a specific purpose.
Legally transferable to another person's possession.
--Examples--
‘he breaks the work down into assignable tasks’
‘your membership is not assignable to any third party’
--Word--
assignor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who legally transfers a right or liability to someone else.
--Examples--
‘a valid assignment of copyright signed by the assignor’
--Word--
assignation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An appointment to meet someone in secret, typically one made by lovers.
The allocation or attribution of someone or something as belonging to something.
--Examples--
‘his assignation with an older woman’
‘this document explains the principles governing the assignation of lexical units to lexemes’
--Word--
assignation 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
assign 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allocate (a job or duty)
Appoint (someone) to a job, task, or organization.
Designate or set (something) aside for a specific purpose.
Attribute something as belonging to.
Transfer (legal rights or liabilities)
--Examples--
‘Congress had assigned the task to the agency’
‘his leader assigned him this mission’
‘she has been assigned to a new job’
‘managers happily assign large sums of money to travel budgets’
‘it is difficult to decide whether to assign the victory to Godwin’
‘they will ask you to assign your rights against the airline’
‘this agreement shall be binding upon the parties and their successors and assigns’
--Word--
assignee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person to whom a right or liability is legally transferred.
A person appointed to act for another.
--Examples--

--Word--
assignment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A task or piece of work allocated to someone as part of a job or course of study.
The allocation of a job or task to someone.
The allocation of someone or something as belonging to a particular group or category.
An act of making a legal transfer of a right or liability.
A document effecting a legal transfer of a right or liability.
--Examples--
‘a homework assignment’
‘the effective assignment of tasks’
‘the assignment of individuals to particular social positions’
‘an assignment of leasehold property’

--Word--
assimilator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who assimilates or engages in assimilation.
--Examples--
‘even for dedicated assimilators like my parents, a Christmas tree would have been a bridge too far’
‘he was a successful assimilator and developer of European influences’
--Word--
assimilable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
assimilate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take in and understand fully (information or ideas)
Absorb and integrate (people, ideas, or culture) into a wider society or culture.
Become absorbed and integrated into a society or culture.
(of the body or any biological system) absorb and digest (food or nutrients)
Regard as similar; liken.
Become similar.
Make (a sound) more like another in the same or next word.
--Examples--
‘Marie tried to assimilate the week's events’
‘pop trends are assimilated into the mainstream with alarming speed’
‘the older generation had more trouble assimilating’
‘the sugars in the fruit are readily assimilated by the body’
‘philosophers had assimilated thought to perception’
‘the Churches assimilated to a certain cultural norm’
‘the ‘v’ in ‘fivepence’ may be assimilated to a voiceless ‘f’ (because of the ‘p’)’

--Word--
assimilation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of taking in and fully understanding information or ideas.
The absorption and integration of people, ideas, or culture into a wider society or culture.
The absorption and digestion of food or nutrients by the body or any biological system.
The process of becoming similar to something.
The fact of a sound being made more like another in the same or next word.
--Examples--
‘the assimilation of the knowledge of the Greeks’
‘the assimilation of Italians into American society’
‘nitrate assimilation usually takes place in leaves’
‘Watson was ready to work for the assimilation of Scots law to English law where he thought it was justified’
‘when p is preceded by some Latin prefixes, it is doubled because of the assimilation of a consonant, as in 'apparent' (ad-parent)’
‘there are many assimilations and elisions of consonants and vowels’
--Word--
assimilationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who advocates or participates in racial or cultural integration.
--Examples--
‘the assimilationist policies of the right’

assimilation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
assimilativeness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being assimilative; capacity for assimilation; specifically the ease with which one culture assimilates something from another culture, or the extent to which integration with another (especially dominant) social, racial, or cultural group is or may be achieved.
Biology. The capacity of a nutrient to be assimilated; the efficiency with which a food is assimilated. rare.
--Examples--

Assiniboin 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an indigenous people formerly living in southern Manitoba, but now living in Montana, Alberta, and Saskatchewan.
The Siouan language of the Assiniboin.
Relating to the Assiniboin or their language.

--Word--
Assyria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient country in what is now northern Iraq. From the early part of the 2nd millennium BC Assyria was the centre of a succession of empires; it was at its peak in the 8th and late 7th centuries BC, when its rule stretched from the Persian Gulf to Egypt. It fell in 612 BC to a coalition of Medes and Babylonians.
--Examples--
--Word--
Assyrian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of ancient Assyria.
The language of ancient Assyria, a dialect of Akkadian.
A dialect of Aramaic still spoken by a group of people of mainly Christian faith living in the mountains of Syria, northern Iraq, and surrounding regions.
Relating to ancient Assyria or its language.
Relating to or denoting modern Assyrian or its speakers.
--Examples--

--Word--
magna assisa eligenda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "writ de magna assisa eligenda". A writ directing a sheriff to return four knights responsible for selecting twelve others and forming with them the jury of a grand assize to try a matter of right.
--Examples--
--Word--
Assisi 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in the region of Umbria in central Italy; population 27,507 (2008). It is famous as the birthplace of St Francis, whose tomb is located there.
--Examples--
--Word--
assist 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Help (someone), typically by doing a share of the work.
Help by providing money or information.
Be present as a helper.
An act of giving help, typically by providing money.
(in sport) an act of touching the ball in a play in which a teammate scores or an opposing batter is put out.
--Examples--
‘a senior academic would assist him in his work’
‘their presence would assist in keeping the peace’
‘they were assisting police with their inquiries’
‘funds to assist with capital investment’
‘two midwives who assisted at a water birth’
‘the budget must have an assist from tax policies’
‘Elliot had 10 points and five assists’
--Word--
assistance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of helping someone by sharing work.
The provision of money, resources, or information to help someone.
--Examples--
‘the work was completed with the assistance of carpenters’
‘schemes offering financial assistance to employers’
‘she will be glad to give advice and assistance’

--Word--
assize 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A court which formerly sat at intervals in each county of England and Wales to administer the civil and criminal law. In 1972 the civil jurisdiction of assizes was transferred to the High Court, and the criminal jurisdiction to the Crown Court.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
associate 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Connect (someone or something) with something else in one's mind.
Connect (something) with something else because they occur together or one produces the other.
Be involved with.
Allow oneself to be connected with or seen to be supportive of.
Meet or have dealings with someone regarded with disapproval.
A partner or companion in business or at work.
A person with limited or subordinate membership of an organization.
A concept connected with another.
Connected with an organization or business.
Having shared function or membership but with a lesser status.
--Examples--
‘I associated wealth with freedom’
‘the environmental problems associated with nuclear waste’
‘she has been associated with the project from the first’
‘I cannot associate myself with some of the language used’
‘he began to associate with the Mafia’
‘a close associate of the Minister’
‘an Associate of the Linnaean Society’
‘the patient was asked to commit to memory a list of five paired associates’
‘an associate company’
‘the associate director of the academy’
--Word--
associated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or thing) connected with something else.
(of a company) connected or amalgamated with another company or companies.
(of liquids) in which the molecules are held together by hydrogen bonding or other weak interaction.
--Examples--
‘two associated events’

associate 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Connect (someone or something) with something else in one's mind.

--Word--
association 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(often in names) a group of people organized for a joint purpose.
A stable plant community including a characteristic group of dominant plant species.
A connection or cooperative link between people or organizations.
The process or state of becoming a subordinate member of an organization.
The linking of molecules through hydrogen bonding or other interaction short of full bond formation.
A mental connection between things.
The action of making a mental connection.
The state of occurring with something else; co-occurrence.
--Examples--
‘the National Association of Probation Officers’
‘a bog association containing ericaceous plants’
‘he developed a close association with the university’
‘the programme was promoted in association with the Department of Music’
‘an association agreement between Bulgaria and the EU’
‘the word bureaucracy has unpleasant associations’
‘there's nothing new in the association of fasting with spirituality’
‘cases of cancer found in association with colitis’
--Word--
associational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
associationism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A theory in philosophy or psychology which regards the simple association or co-occurrence of ideas or sensations as the primary basis of meaning, thought, or learning.
--Examples--
--Word--
associationist 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
association 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(often in names) a group of people organized for a joint purpose.
A stable plant community including a characteristic group of dominant plant species.
A connection or cooperative link between people or organizations.
The process or state of becoming a subordinate member of an organization.
The linking of molecules through hydrogen bonding or other interaction short of full bond formation.
A mental connection between things.
The action of making a mental connection.
The state of occurring with something else; co-occurrence.

‘the National Association of Probation Officers’
‘a bog association containing ericaceous plants’

‘the word bureaucracy has unpleasant associations’
‘there's nothing new in the association of fasting with spirituality’
‘cases of cancer found in association with colitis’
--Word--
associative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or involving the association of things.
Of or denoting computer storage in which items are identified by content rather than by address.
Involving the condition that a group of quantities connected by operators gives the same result whatever their grouping, i.e. in whichever order the operations are performed, as long as the order of the quantities remains the same, e.g. (a × b) × c = a × (b × c).
--Examples--
‘making associative links’

--Word--
assonance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Resemblance of sound between syllables of nearby words, arising particularly from the rhyming of two or more stressed vowels, but not consonants (e.g. sonnet, porridge), but also from the use of identical consonants with different vowels (e.g. killed, cold, culled)
--Examples--
‘the use of assonance throughout the poem creates the sound of despair’
‘alliterative assonances such as ‘fail’ and ‘fall’ are very common in Old English poetry’
--Word--
assonance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Resemblance of sound between syllables of nearby words, arising particularly from the rhyming of two or more stressed vowels, but not consonants (e.g. sonnet, porridge), but also from the use of identical consonants with different vowels (e.g. killed, cold, culled)
--Examples--
‘the use of assonance throughout the poem creates the sound of despair’
‘alliterative assonances such as ‘fail’ and ‘fall’ are very common in Old English poetry’

--Word--
assuming 
--Type--
conjunction, adjective
--Meanings--
Used for the purpose of argument to indicate a premise on which a statement can be based.
Arrogant or presumptuous.
--Examples--
‘assuming that the treaty is ratified, what is its relevance?’
--Word--
assume 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Suppose to be the case, without proof.
Take or begin to have (power or responsibility)
Seize (power or control)
Begin to have (a specified quality, appearance, or extent)
Take on or adopt (a manner or identity), sometimes falsely.
--Examples--
‘topics which assume detailed knowledge of local events’
‘it is reasonable to assume that such changes have significant social effects’
‘they were assumed to be foreign’
‘he assumed full responsibility for all organizational work’
‘the rebels assumed control of the capital’
‘militant activity had assumed epidemic proportions’
‘Oliver assumed an expression of penitence’
‘she puts on a disguise, assumes a different persona, and cruises the squalid bars on the bad side of town’
--Word--
assumed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a manner or identity) taken on or adopted, sometimes falsely.
Adopted as a basis of reasoning; expected.
--Examples--
‘a man living under an assumed name’
‘the assumed result of the election’
‘the assumed rate of return’

--Word--
assumption 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing that is accepted as true or as certain to happen, without proof.
The action of taking on power or responsibility.
The reception of the Virgin Mary bodily into heaven. This was formally declared a doctrine of the Roman Catholic Church in 1950.
The feast in honour of the Assumption, celebrated on 15 August.
Arrogance or presumption.
--Examples--
‘they made certain assumptions about the market’
‘we're working on the assumption that the time of death was after midnight’
‘the assumption of an active role in regional settlements’

Assur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city state of Mesopotamia, situated on the River Tigris to the south of modern Mosul. It was the traditional capital of the Assyrian empires.

noun

--Word--
assure 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Tell someone something positively to dispel any doubts.
Make sure of something.
Make (something) certain to happen.
Be certain to get.
Cover (a life) by assurance.
Secure the future payment of (an amount) with insurance.
--Examples--
‘Tony assured me that there was a supermarket in the village’
‘‘I quite understand,’ Mrs Lewis assured her’
‘they assured him of their full confidence’
‘she assured herself that he was asleep’
‘victory was now assured’
‘their influence assured that the report would be tough’
‘you would be assured of a welcome’
‘we guarantee to assure your life’
‘the sum assured can be paid as a lump sum’

--Word--
stay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Remain in the same place.
Delay leaving so as to join in (an activity)
(of food) remain in the stomach, rather than be thrown up as vomit.
Remain in a specified state or position.
(of a person) live somewhere temporarily as a visitor or guest.
Live permanently.
Stop, delay, or prevent (something), in particular suspend or postpone (judicial proceedings) or refrain from pressing (charges)
Assuage (hunger) for a short time.
Curb; check.
Wait a moment in order to allow someone time to think or speak.
Support or prop up.
A period of staying somewhere, in particular of living somewhere temporarily as a visitor or guest.
A curb or check.
A suspension or postponement of judicial proceedings.
A device used as a brace or support.
A corset made of two pieces laced together and stiffened by strips of whalebone.
Power of endurance.
--Examples--
‘you stay here and I'll be back soon’
‘Jenny decided to stay at home with their young child’
‘he stayed with the firm as a consultant’
‘why not stay to lunch?’
‘he gagged but the sandwich stayed down’
‘her ability to stay calm’
‘tactics used to stay in power’
‘I managed to stay out of trouble’
‘the girls had gone to stay with friends’
‘Minton invited him to stay the night’
‘where do you stay?’
‘there are some cases the Crown feels so serious they don't want to stay the charges’
‘I grabbed something to stay the pangs of hunger’
‘he tries to stay the destructive course of barbarism’
‘stay, stand apart, I know not which is which’
‘it did not matter to you whether the building was stayed up or not?’
‘an overnight stay at a luxury hotel’
‘there is likely to be a good public library as a stay against boredom’
‘a stay of prosecution’
‘some men are always great at beginnings; but they have no stay in them’

Astaire, Fred

--Meanings--
(1899–1987), American dancer, singer, and actor; born Frederick Austerlitz. He is famous for starring in a number of film musicals, including Top Hat (1935), in a successful partnership with Ginger Rogers.

--Word--
start 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Begin or be reckoned from a particular point in time or space; come into being.
Embark on a continuing action or a new venture.
Use a particular point, action, or circumstance as an opening for a course of action.
Begin to move or travel.
Begin to engage in (an occupation), live through (a period), or attend (an educational establishment)
Begin one's working life.
Cost at least a specified amount.
Cause to happen or begin.
Cause (a machine) to begin to work.
(of a machine) begin operating or being used.
Cause or enable to begin doing something.
Give a signal to (competitors) to start in a race.
Jerk or give a small jump from surprise or alarm.
Move or appear suddenly.
(of eyes) bulge so as to appear to burst out of their sockets.
Be displaced or displace by pressure or shrinkage.
Rouse (game) from its lair.
The point in time or space at which something has its origin; the beginning.
The point or moment at which a race begins.
An act of beginning to do or deal with something.
Used to indicate that a useful initial contribution has been made but that more remains to be done.
A person's position or circumstances at the beginning of their life.
An advantage consisting in having set out in a race or on a journey earlier than one's rivals.
A sudden movement of surprise or alarm.
A surprising occurrence.
--Examples--
‘the season starts in September’
‘we ate before the film started’
‘below Roaring Springs the real desert starts’
‘I'm starting on a new book’
‘I started to chat to him’
‘we plan to start building in the autumn’
‘the teacher can start by capitalizing on children's curiosity’
‘I shall start with the case you mention first’
‘we started out into the snow’
‘he started for the door’
‘she will start school today’
‘he started work at a travel agent’
‘they started their married life’
‘he started as a mess orderly’
‘he started off as doctor in the house’
‘fees start at £300’
‘two men started the blaze’
‘those women started all the trouble’
‘I'm starting a campaign to get the law changed’
‘we had trouble starting the car’
‘he starts up his van’
‘the noise of a lorry starting up’
‘there was a moment of silence before the organ started’
‘his father started him off in business’
‘what he said started me thinking’
‘‘Oh my!’ she said, starting’
‘she had seen Meg start suddenly from a thicket’
‘his eyes started out of his head like a hare's’
‘the mortar in the joints had started’
‘he takes over as chief executive at the start of next year’
‘the event was a shambles from start to finish’
‘his bicycle was found close to the start of a forest trail’
‘make sure you are not over the line at the start’
‘I can make a start on cleaning up’
‘an early start enabled us to avoid the traffic’
‘if he would tell her who had put him up to it, it would be a start’
‘she's anxious to give her baby the best start in life’
‘he had a ninety-minute start on them’
‘she awoke with a start’
‘the woman gave a nervous start’
‘you hear of some rum starts there’
--Word--
Astarte 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Phoenician goddess of fertility and sexual love who corresponds to the Babylonian and Assyrian goddess Ishtar and who became identified with the Egyptian Isis, the Greek Aphrodite, and others.
--Examples--
--Word--
astasia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally (more fully "muscular astasia"): a condition characterized by muscle tremors which inhibit movement (now rare). In later use: the inability to stand, especially in an individual who has no demonstrable sensory impairment or motor weakness.
--Examples--
--Word--
astasia-abasia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The inability to stand and walk, especially in an individual who has no demonstrable sensory impairment or motor weakness, occurring as a symptom of psychiatric conversion disorder and of certain types of organic brain disease.
--Examples--

astatine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 85, a radioactive member of the halogen group. Astatine was first produced by bombarding bismuth with alpha particles, and it occurs in traces in nature as a decay product.

--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A symbol (*) used in text as a pointer to an annotation or footnote.
Mark (a word or piece of text) with an asterisk.
--Examples--
‘he had asterisked the things about the case that still bothered him’
--Word--
asterisk 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A symbol (*) used in text as a pointer to an annotation or footnote.
Mark (a word or piece of text) with an asterisk.
--Examples--
‘he had asterisked the things about the case that still bothered him’
--Word--
asterisked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a word or piece of text) marked with an asterisk.
--Examples--
‘asterisked entries’
--Word--
asterism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A prominent pattern or group of stars that is smaller than a constellation.
A group of three asterisks (⁂) drawing attention to a piece of text.

astern 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Behind or toward the rear of a ship or aircraft.
(of a ship) backwards; stern foremost.
--Examples--
‘the engine rooms lay astern’
‘the lifeboat was carried astern by the tide’

--Word--
asteroid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small rocky body orbiting the sun. Large numbers of these, ranging enormously in size, are found between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter, though some have more eccentric orbits.
An echinoderm of the class Asteroidea, which comprises the starfishes.
Relating to or denoting echinoderms of the class Asteroidea.
--Examples--
--Word--
asteroidal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Asteroidea 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A class of echinoderms that comprises the starfishes.
--Examples--

asthenosphere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

asthma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A respiratory condition marked by attacks of spasm in the bronchi of the lungs, causing difficulty in breathing. It is usually connected to allergic reaction or other forms of hypersensitivity.

astigmatism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A defect in the eye or in a lens caused by a deviation from spherical curvature, which results in distorted images, as light rays are prevented from meeting at a common focus.

Aston, Francis William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1877–1945), English physicist. He invented the mass spectrograph (with J. J. Thomson) and eventually discovered many of the 287 naturally occurring isotopes of non-radioactive elements. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1922).

--Word--
Astor, Nancy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Viscountess (1879–1964), American-born British Conservative politician; born Nancy Witcher Langhorne. She became the first woman to sit in the House of Commons when she succeeded her husband as MP for Plymouth in 1919.

Astoria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northwestern Oregon, near the mouth of the Columbia River on the Pacific coast; population 9,851 (est. 2008). In the 19th century it was a noted fur-trading center.
A section of northwestern Queens in New York City, noted for its large Greek-American population.

--Word--
strain 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Force (a part of one's body or oneself) to make an unusually great effort.
Make an unusually great effort.
Injure (a limb, muscle, or organ) by overexerting it.
Make severe or excessive demands on.
Pull or push forcibly at something.
Stretch (something) tightly.
Embrace (someone) tightly.
Pour (a mainly liquid substance) through a porous or perforated device or material in order to separate out any solid matter.
Cause liquid to drain off (food which has been boiled, soaked, or canned) by using a porous or perforated device.
Drain (liquid) off food by using a porous or perforated device.
A force tending to pull or stretch something to an extreme or damaging degree.
An injury to a part of the body caused by overexertion.
The magnitude of a deformation, equal to the change in the dimension of a deformed object divided by its original dimension.
A severe or excessive demand on the strength, resources, or abilities of someone or something.
A state of tension or exhaustion resulting from severe demands on one's strength or resources.
The sound of a piece of music.
--Examples--
‘I stopped and listened, straining my ears for any sound’
‘his voice was so quiet that I had to strain to hear it’
‘on cold days you are more likely to strain a muscle’
‘glare from the screen can strain your eyes’
‘he strained her tolerance to the limit’
‘the bear strained at the chain around its neck’
‘his stomach was swollen, straining against the thin shirt’
‘the barbed wire fence was strained to posts six feet high’
‘she strained the infant to her bosom again’
‘strain the custard into a bowl’
‘she turned to the sink to strain the noodles’
‘strain off the surplus fat’
‘the usual type of chair puts an enormous strain on the spine’
‘aluminium may bend under strain’
‘he has a slight groin strain’
‘the accusations put a strain on relations between the two countries’
‘she's under considerable strain’
‘the telltale signs of nervous strain’
‘the distant strains of the brass band grew louder’

strand 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Drive or leave (a boat, sailor, or sea creature) aground on a shore.
Leave (someone) without the means to move from somewhere.
The shore of a sea, lake, or large river.
A single thin length of something such as thread, fibre, or wire, especially as twisted together with others.
A single hair or thin lock of hair.
A string of beads or pearls.
An element that forms part of a complex whole.
--Examples--
‘the ships were stranded in shallow water’
‘quantities of sea creatures were left stranded’
‘two of the firm's lorries are stranded in France’
‘a heron glided to rest on a pebbly strand’

‘strands of dark hair had fallen over his brows’
‘the journal has carried articles representing many different strands of opinion on the left’

--Word--
astrograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Astronomy. A device for determining the positions of stars; especially a telescope used for photographing the night sky, specifically one using wide-angle photographs to detect celestial objects or to determine their position.
Aeronautics and Nautical. A navigational device that projects a set of curves of equal altitude for a given star on to a navigational chart or plotting sheet. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
astrography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The description of the fixed stars; the determination of the positions of the stars; (in later use) specifically the use of an astrograph.
--Examples--

astrographic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
astroite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A star-shaped fossil, especially a stem ossicle from certain fossil crinoids. Now historical.
A form of stony coral having starlike apertures; = star stone. Now historical and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
astrolabe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument used to make astronomical measurements, typically of the altitudes of celestial bodies, and in navigation for calculating latitude, before the development of the sextant.

astrometeorology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of the (supposed) influence on the weather and climate of planetary and stellar phenomena, such as sunspots, the phases of the moon, comets, and planetary conjunctions.

astroscope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of several instruments for assisting an observer in identifying stars and constellations, specifically one consisting of a pair of inscribed cones. In recent use: an instrument for observing stars; an astronomical telescope.

--Word--
Aswan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city on the River Nile in southern Egypt, 16 km (10 miles) north of Lake Nasser; population 266,000 (est. 2006). Two dams across the Nile have been built nearby. The controlled release of water from Lake Nasser behind the High Dam produces the greater part of Egypt's electricity.

sweat 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Moisture exuded through the pores of the skin, typically in profuse quantities as a reaction to heat, physical exertion, fever, or fear.
An instance or period of being covered with sweat.
A state of flustered anxiety or distress.
Hard work; effort.
A laborious task or undertaking.
Denoting loose casual garments made of thick, fleecy cotton.
Exude sweat.
Get rid of something from the body by exuding sweat.
Cause (a person or animal) to exude sweat by exercise or exertion.
(of food or an object) ooze or exude beads of moisture on to its surface.
(of a person) exert a great deal of strenuous effort.
(of a person) be or remain in a state of extreme anxiety, typically for a prolonged period.
Worry about (something)
Heat (chopped vegetables) slowly in a pan with a small amount of fat, so that they cook in their own juices.
(of chopped vegetables) be cooked slowly in a pan with a small amount of fat.
Subject (metal) to surface melting, especially to fasten or join by solder without a soldering iron.
--Examples--
‘beads of sweat broke out on her brow’
‘even thinking about him made me break out in a sweat’
‘we'd all worked up a sweat in spite of the cold’
‘I don't believe he'd get into such a sweat about a girl’
‘computer graphics take a lot of the sweat out of animation’
‘helping to run the meeting was a bit of a sweat’
‘sweat tops and bottoms’
‘he was sweating profusely’
‘a well-hydrated body sweats out waste products more efficiently’
‘cold as it was, the climb had sweated him’
‘cheese stored at room temperature will quickly begin to sweat’
‘I've sweated over this for six months’
‘if we let them sweat for a week, they'll be a lot more cooperative’
‘he's not going to have a lot of time to sweat the details’
‘sweat the celery and onions with olive oil and seasoning’
‘let the chopped onion sweat gently for five minutes’
‘the tyre is sweated on to the wooden parts’

swing 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Move or cause to move back and forth or from side to side while suspended or on an axis.
Be executed by hanging.
Turn (a ship or aircraft) to all compass points in succession, in order to test compass error.

Move quickly round to the opposite direction.
Move with a rhythmic swaying gait.
Move or cause to move in a smooth, curving line.
Bring down (something held) with a curving movement, typically in order to hit an object.

Deliver (a punch) with a wide curving movement of the arm.
(of a bowler) make a delivery of (a ball) deviate sideways from a regular course in the air.
(of a delivery) deviate sideways from a regular course.
Shift or cause to shift from one opinion, mood, or state of affairs to another.
Have a decisive influence on (something, especially a vote or election)
Succeed in bringing about.
Play music with a flowing but vigorous rhythm.
(of music) be played with a flowing but vigorous rhythm.
(of an event, place, or way of life) be lively, exciting, or fashionable.
Engage in group sex or swap sexual partners within a group, especially on a habitual basis.
A seat suspended by ropes or chains, on which someone may sit and swing back and forth.
A period of time spent swinging back and forth on a seat suspended by ropes or chains.
An act of swinging.
The manner in which a golf club or a bat is swung.
The motion of swinging.
An attempted blow or punch.
Sideways deviation of the ball from a regular path.
A discernible change in opinion, especially the amount by which votes or points scored change from one side to another.
A style of jazz or dance music with a flowing but vigorous rhythm.
The rhythmic feeling or drive of swing.
A swift tour involving a number of stops, especially one undertaken as part of a political campaign.
(in musical theatre) an understudy, typically one who covers multiple roles in the chorus of a particular production.
--Examples--
‘her long black skirt swung about her legs’
‘the door swung shut behind him’
‘a priest began swinging a censer’
‘now he was going to swing for it’
‘we swung across like two trapeze artists’
‘the Irishman swung himself into the saddle’
‘Ronni had swung round to face him’
‘the riflemen swung along smartly’
‘she swung her legs to the side of the bed’
‘the cab swung into the car park’
‘I swung the club and missed the ball’
‘he swung at me with the tyre wrench’
‘she swung a punch at him’
‘opinion swung in the Chancellor's favour’
‘the failure to seek peace could swing sentiment the other way’
‘an attempt to swing the vote in their favour’
‘what swung it was the £17,000 she offered the panel to let her win’
‘the band swung on’
‘with the swing of her arm, the knife flashed through the air’
‘the flaws in his swing weren't evident when he was an amateur’
‘this short cut gave her hair new movement and swing’
‘Neil took a swing at her’
‘a swing bowler’
‘a five per cent swing to Labour’

--Word--
at 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
Expressing location or arrival in a particular place or position.
Used in speech to indicate the sign @ in email addresses, separating the address holder's name from their location.
Expressing the time when an event takes place.
(followed by a noun without a determiner) denoting a particular period of time.
(followed by a noun without a determiner) denoting the time spent by someone attending an educational institution or workplace.
Denoting a particular point or level on a scale.
Referring to someone's age.
Expressing a particular state or condition.
Expressing a relationship between an individual and a skill.
Expressing the object of a look, thought, action, or plan.
Expressing the target of a shot from a weapon.
Expressing an incomplete or attempted action, typically involving repeated movements.
Expressing the means by which something is done.
--Examples--
‘they live at Conway House’
‘they stopped at a small trattoria’
‘the children go to bed at nine o'clock’
‘his death came at a time when the movement was split’
‘the sea is cooler at night’
‘it was at university that he first began to perform’
‘prices start at £18,500’
‘driving at 50 mph’
‘at fourteen he began to work as a postman’
‘his ready smile put her at ease’
‘they were at a disadvantage’
‘boxing was the only sport I was any good at’
‘she was getting much better at hiding her reactions’
‘I looked at my watch’
‘Leslie pointed at him’
‘policies aimed at reducing taxation’
‘they tore down the main street, firing at anyone in sight’
‘she clutched at the thin gown’
‘he hit at her face with the gun’
‘holding a prison officer at knifepoint’
‘her pride had taken a beating at his hands’

Atatürk, Kemal 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1881–1938), Turkish general and statesman, president 1923–38; also called Kemal Pasha. He was elected the first president of the Turkish republic, taking the name of Atatürk (‘father of the Turks’) in 1934. He abolished the caliphate and introduced other policies designed to make Turkey a modern secular state.

--Word--
crown 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A circular ornamental headdress worn by a monarch as a symbol of authority, usually made of or decorated with precious metals and jewels.
The monarchy or reigning monarch.
An ornament, emblem, or badge shaped like a crown.
A wreath of leaves or flowers, especially that worn as an emblem of victory in ancient Greece or Rome.
An award or distinction gained by a victory or achievement, especially in sport.
The top or highest part of something.
The top part of a person's head or a hat.
The part of a plant just above and below the ground from which the roots and shoots branch out.
The upper branching or spreading part of a tree or other plant.
The upper part of a cut gem, above the girdle.
The part of a tooth projecting from the gum.
An artificial replacement or covering for the upper part of a tooth.
A British coin with a face value of five shillings or 25 pence, now minted only for commemorative purposes.
A foreign coin with a name meaning ‘crown’, especially the krona or krone.
A paper size, 384 × 504 mm.
A book size, 186 × 123 mm.
A book size, 246 × 189 mm.
Ceremonially place a crown on the head of (someone) in order to invest them as a monarch.
Declare or acknowledge (someone) as the best, especially at a sport.
(in draughts) promote (a piece) to king by placing another on top of it.
Rest on or form the top of.
Be the triumphant culmination of (an effort or endeavour, especially a prolonged one)
Fit a crown to (a tooth)
Hit on the head.
(of a baby's head during labour) fully appear in the vaginal opening prior to emerging.
--Examples--
‘their loyalty to the Church came before their loyalty to the Crown’
‘shiny covers embossed with gold crowns’
‘the world heavyweight crown’
‘the crown of the hill’
‘his hair was swept straight back over his crown’
‘mulch should be mounded around the crowns of the shrubs’
‘an erect evergreen tree with a dense crown’
‘a thin layer of enamel covers the crown’
‘emergency treatment for loose crowns’
‘he went to Rome to be crowned’
‘she was crowned queen in 1953’
‘he was crowned world champion last September’
‘with his crowned piece he jumped them all’
‘the distant knoll was crowned with trees’
‘years of struggle were crowned by a state visit to Paris’
‘simple fillings no longer suffice and the tooth has to be crowned’
‘she contained the urge to crown him’
‘I was able to see our baby's head crowning’

tent 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--

Composed of or provided with tents.
Arrange in a shape like that of a tent.
(especially of travelling circus people) live in a tent.
A deep red sweet wine chiefly from Spain, used especially as sacramental wine.
A piece of absorbent material inserted into an opening to keep it open, or especially to widen it gradually as the material absorbs moisture.

--Word--
Athabasca River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in Canada that flows northeast for 765 miles (1,230 km) from the Rocky Mountains across Alberta to Lake Athabasca, Canada's fourth-largest lake. The river valley has large oil tar deposits.

--Word--
Athabaskan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to a family of North American languages including especially Navajo and various Apache languages of the south-west US, several languages of coastal California and Oregon, and many languages of Alaska and north-western Canada, including Chipewyan.
Denoting or relating to speakers of any of the Athabaskan languages.
The Athabaskan family of languages, sometimes classified in the Na-Dene phylum.
A speaker of any of the Athabaskan languages.

--Word--
Athos, Mount 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A narrow, mountainous peninsula in north-eastern Greece, projecting into the Aegean Sea. It is inhabited by monks of the Orthodox Church, who forbid women and even female animals to set foot on the peninsula.

verb, noun

--Word--
atlas 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A book of maps or charts.
The topmost vertebra of the backbone, articulating with the occipital bone of the skull.
A stone carving of a male figure, used as a column to support the entablature of a Greek or Greek-style building.
One of the Titans, who was punished for his part in their revolt against Zeus by being made to support the heavens. He became identified with the Atlas Mountains.
--Examples--
‘I looked in the atlas to see where Naples was’
‘a road atlas’

noun, abbreviation

--Examples--

atmosphere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The envelope of gases surrounding the earth or another planet.
The air in any particular place.
A unit of pressure equal to mean atmospheric pressure at sea level, 101,325 pascals.
The pervading tone or mood of a place, situation, or creative work.
A pleasurable and interesting mood.
--Examples--
‘part of the sun's energy is absorbed by the earth's atmosphere’
‘these beetles breed best in a damp atmosphere’
‘the hotel has won commendations for its friendly, welcoming atmosphere’
‘a superb restaurant, full of atmosphere’

adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of an atom or atoms; consisting of or involving atoms. Compare "atomic". Now rare.
Chiefly History of Science. Designating or adhering to the doctrine of atoms as understood in ancient Greek philosophy or later.

Atreus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The son of Pelops and father of Agamemnon and Menelaus. He quarrelled with his brother Thyestes and invited him to a banquet at which he served up the flesh of Thyestes' own children.

--Word--
try 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make an attempt or effort to do something.
Use, test, or do (something new or different) in order to see if it is suitable, effective, or pleasant.
Attempt to achieve or attain.
Compete or audition for (a post or place on a team)
Attempt to contact.
Push or pull (a door or window) to determine whether it is locked.
Make severe demands on (a person or a quality, typically patience)
Subject (someone) to trial.
Investigate and decide (a case or issue) in a formal trial.
Smooth (roughly planed wood) with a plane to give an accurately flat surface.
Extract (oil or fat) by heating.
An effort to accomplish something; an attempt.
An act of trying something new or different to see if it is suitable, effective, or pleasant.
An act of touching the ball down behind the opposing goal line, scoring points and entitling the scoring side to a kick at goal.
An attempt to score an extra point after a touchdown.
--Examples--
‘he tried to regain his breath’
‘I started to try and untangle the mystery’
‘I decided to try writing fiction’
‘three times he tried the manoeuvre and three times he failed’
‘everyone wanted to know if I'd tried jellied eel’
‘these methods are tried and tested’
‘they decided to try for another baby’
‘she tried out for the team’
‘I've tried the apartment, but the number is engaged’
‘I tried the doors, but they were locked’
‘Mary tried everyone's patience to the limit’
‘he was arrested and tried for the murder’
‘the case is to be tried by a jury in the Crown Court’
‘some of the fat may be tried out and used’
‘he got his membership card on his third try’
‘she agreed that they should give the idea a try’
--Word--
atrium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An open-roofed entrance hall or central court in an ancient Roman house.
A central hall in a modern building, typically rising through several stories and having a glazed roof.
The forecourt of a large church built on the basilican plan.
Each of the two upper cavities of the heart from which blood is passed to the ventricles. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the veins of the body, the left atrium oxygenated blood from the pulmonary vein.
--Examples--

--Word--
trip 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Catch one's foot on something and stumble or fall.
Cause to stumble and fall.
Make a mistake.
Detect or expose someone in a mistake or inconsistency.
Walk, run, or dance with quick light steps.
(of words) flow lightly and easily.
Activate (a mechanism), especially by contact with a switch, catch, or other electrical device.
(of part of an electric circuit) disconnect automatically as a safety measure.
Release and raise (an anchor) from the seabed by means of a cable.
Turn (a yard or other object) from a horizontal to a vertical position for lowering.
Experience hallucinations induced by taking a psychedelic drug, especially LSD.
Be behaving in an irrational or crazy way.
Go on a short journey.
A journey or excursion, especially for pleasure.
The distance from start to finish of a race.
A stumble or fall due to catching one's foot on something.
A mistake.
A hallucinatory experience caused by taking a psychedelic drug, especially LSD.
An exciting or stimulating experience.
A self-indulgent attitude or activity.
A device that activates or disconnects a mechanism, circuit, etc.
A light, lively movement of a person's feet.
--Examples--
‘he tripped over his cat’
‘she tripped up during the penultimate lap’
‘she shot out her foot to trip him up’
‘taxpayers often trip up by not declaring taxable income’
‘the man was determined to trip him up on his economics’
‘they tripped up the terrace steps’
‘a name which trips off the tongue’
‘somebody tripped the alarm’
‘the plugs will trip as soon as any change in current is detected’
‘a couple of boys were tripping’
‘he smoked weed and tripped out on acid’
‘you're tripping if you think I'm hanging around’
‘I would like to know if I'm the one who's trippin' or if it's him’
‘when tripping through the Yukon take some time to explore our museums’
‘Sammy's gone on a school trip’
‘a trip to America’
‘the dog clocked a tremendous 27.47 secs for the 450 metres trip’
‘trips and falls cause nearly half of all accidents’
‘an occasional trip in the performance’
‘acid trips’
‘it was quite a trip talking to you’
‘I'm not sure if she really liked me or if I was just part of her power trip’
‘a trip mechanism’
‘yonder comes Dalinda; I know her by her trip’

--Meanings--
An extremely wicked or cruel act, typically one involving physical violence or injury.
A highly unpleasant or distasteful object.
--Examples--
‘a textbook which detailed war atrocities’
‘atrocities in cheap red nylon’
--Word--
atrocity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extremely wicked or cruel act, typically one involving physical violence or injury.
A highly unpleasant or distasteful object.
--Examples--
‘a textbook which detailed war atrocities’
‘atrocities in cheap red nylon’
--Word--
atrophy 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of body tissue or an organ) waste away, especially as a result of the degeneration of cells, or become vestigial during evolution.
Gradually decline in effectiveness or vigour due to underuse or neglect.
The process of atrophying or state of having atrophied.
--Examples--
‘the calf muscles will atrophy’
‘the imagination can atrophy from lack of use’
‘gastric atrophy’
‘extensive TV viewing may lead to atrophy of children's imaginations’
--Word--
atrophic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
atrophied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of body tissue or an organ) wasted away or rudimentary.
Having lost effectiveness or vigour due to underuse or neglect.
--Examples--
‘atrophied muscles’
‘in some beetles, the hindwings are atrophied’
‘the atrophied global economy contains numerous areas of chronic weakness’

--Word--
atropine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poisonous compound found in deadly nightshade and related plants. It is used in medicine as a muscle relaxant, e.g. in dilating the pupil of the eye.
--Examples--
--Word--
atropine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poisonous compound found in deadly nightshade and related plants. It is used in medicine as a muscle relaxant, e.g. in dilating the pupil of the eye.

proper noun
--Meanings--
