--Word--
at 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
Expressing location or arrival in a particular place or position.
Used in speech to indicate the sign @ in email addresses, separating the address holder's name from their location.
Expressing the time when an event takes place.
(followed by a noun without a determiner) denoting a particular period of time.
(followed by a noun without a determiner) denoting the time spent by someone attending an educational institution or workplace.
Denoting a particular point or level on a scale.
Referring to someone's age.
Expressing a particular state or condition.
Expressing a relationship between an individual and a skill.
Expressing the object of a look, thought, action, or plan.
Expressing the target of a shot from a weapon.
Expressing an incomplete or attempted action, typically involving repeated movements.
Expressing the means by which something is done.
--Examples--
‘they live at Conway House’
‘they stopped at a small trattoria’
‘the children go to bed at nine o'clock’
‘his death came at a time when the movement was split’
‘the sea is cooler at night’
‘it was at university that he first began to perform’
‘prices start at £18,500’
‘driving at 50 mph’
‘at fourteen he began to work as a postman’
‘his ready smile put her at ease’
‘they were at a disadvantage’
‘boxing was the only sport I was any good at’
‘she was getting much better at hiding her reactions’
‘I looked at my watch’
‘Leslie pointed at him’
‘policies aimed at reducing taxation’
‘they tore down the main street, firing at anyone in sight’
‘she clutched at the thin gown’
‘he hit at her face with the gun’
‘holding a prison officer at knifepoint’
‘her pride had taken a beating at his hands’

--Word--
attach 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Join or fasten (something) to something else.
Add or fasten (a related document) to another, or to an email.
Include (a condition) as part of an agreement.
Accompany (a person or group) without being invited.
Appoint (someone) for special or temporary duties.
Attribute importance or value to.
(of importance or value) be attributed to.
Seize (a person or property) by legal authority.
--Examples--
‘attach your safety line to the bridge’
‘I attach a copy of the memo for your information’
‘the Commission can attach appropriate conditions to the operation of the agreement’
‘they were all too ready to attach themselves to you for the whole day’
‘I was attached to another working group’
‘he doesn't attach too much importance to fixed ideas’
‘a good deal of prominence attaches to the central union federations’
‘the Earl Marshal attached Gloucester for high treason’
--Word--
attachable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
attacher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Law. An officer who seizes and takes a person, or goods or property, into legal custody.
A person who attaches something, by tacking, hooking on, tying, stitching, sticking, clipping, stapling, etc.
A device for attaching something; a fastener, a tie, etc. Often as the second element of compounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
attaché 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person on the staff of an ambassador having a specialized area of responsibility.
--Examples--
‘naval and air attachés’
--Word--
attached 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Joined, fastened, or connected to something.
Full of affection or fondness.
Married or having an established romantic or sexual partner; not single.
Appointed to (an organization) for special or temporary duties.
(of an organization) affiliated to (a larger organization)
--Examples--
‘please complete the attached form’
‘a ground floor bedroom with a toilet attached’
‘during the journey Mark became increasingly attached to Tara’
‘she's cute—is she attached?’
‘he was attached to Military Intelligence’
‘a science policy agency attached to the Council of Ministers’

--Word--
attachment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extra part or extension that is or may be attached to something to perform a particular function.
A computer file appended to an email.
Affection, fondness, or sympathy for someone or something.
An affectionate relationship.
Temporary secondment to an organization.
The action of attaching something.
Legal seizure of property.
--Examples--
‘the processor comes complete with a blender attachment’
‘she felt a sentimental attachment to the place creep over her’
‘he formed an attachment with a young widow’
‘the students are placed on attachment to schools for one day a week’
‘the case has a loop for attachment to your waist belt’

--Word--
attack 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take aggressive military action against (a place or enemy forces) with weapons or armed force.
Act against (someone or something) aggressively in an attempt to injure or kill.
(of a disease, organism, or other agent) act harmfully or destructively on.
Criticize or oppose fiercely and publicly.
Begin to deal with (a problem or task) in a determined and vigorous way.
(in sport) make a forceful attempt to score a goal or point or otherwise gain an advantage against an opposing team or player.
Move into or be in a position to capture (an opponent's piece or pawn)
(of a reagent or reactive species) approach and interact with (an atom, group, or bond in a molecule), thereby breaking a bond or forming a new bond.
An aggressive and violent act against a person or place.
Destructive action by a disease, chemical, or insect.
A determined attempt to tackle a problem or task.
Forceful and decisive style in performing music or another art.
An instance of fierce public criticism or opposition.
A sudden short bout of an illness or stress.
(in sport) an aggressive attempt to score a goal or point or otherwise gain an advantage.
The players in a team who are in the position of trying to score a goal or win points.
A threat to capture an opponent's piece or pawn.
--Examples--
‘in February the Germans attacked Verdun’
‘the terrorists did not attack again until March’
‘a doctor was attacked by two youths’
‘Ebola attacks the immune system’
‘she was diagnosed with a potentially fatal condition in which bacteria attack the intestinal lining’
‘he attacked the government's defence policy’
‘a plan of action to attack unemployment’
‘Crystal Palace attacked swiftly down the left’
‘the white queen attacks the black rook’
‘the nucleophile attacks the epoxide from the opposite side of the ring to the oxygen’
‘he was killed in an attack on a checkpoint’
‘three classrooms were gutted in the arson attack’
‘the north-western suburbs came under attack in the latest fighting’
‘the tissue is open to attack by fungus’
‘an attack on inflation’
‘the sheer attack of Hendrix's playing’
‘he launched a stinging attack on the Prime Minister’
‘an attack of nausea’
‘an asthma attack’
‘a Cardiff attack broke down inside Llanelli's 22’
‘United hardly did a thing in attack’
‘Baxter was recalled to the attack’
‘the move opens up an attack from the black bishop against White's knight’

--Meanings--

--Word--
attempt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make an effort to achieve or complete (something difficult)
Try to climb to the top of (a mountain)
Try to take (a life)
An effort to achieve or complete a difficult task or action.
An effort to surpass a record or conquer a mountain.
A bid to kill someone.
A thing produced as a result of trying to make or achieve something.
--Examples--
‘she attempted a comeback in 2001’
‘troops shot civilians who attempted to flee’
‘the expedition was the first to attempt Everest’
‘he would not have attempted the life of a friend’
‘an attempt to halt the bombings’
‘an attempt on the unclimbed north-east ridge’
‘Karakozov made an attempt on the Tsar's life’
‘she picked her first attempt at a letter out of the wastebasket’

‘Karakozov made an attempt on the Tsar's life’
‘she picked her first attempt at a letter out of the wastebasket’
--Word--
attempt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make an effort to achieve or complete (something difficult)
Try to climb to the top of (a mountain)
Try to take (a life)
An effort to achieve or complete a difficult task or action.
An effort to surpass a record or conquer a mountain.
A bid to kill someone.
A thing produced as a result of trying to make or achieve something.
--Examples--
‘she attempted a comeback in 2001’
‘troops shot civilians who attempted to flee’
‘the expedition was the first to attempt Everest’
‘he would not have attempted the life of a friend’
‘an attempt to halt the bombings’
‘an attempt on the unclimbed north-east ridge’
‘Karakozov made an attempt on the Tsar's life’
‘she picked her first attempt at a letter out of the wastebasket’

--Word--
Attenborough, Richard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Baron Attenborough of Richmond-upon-Thames (1923–2014), English film actor, producer, and director; brother of David Attenborough; full name Richard Samuel Attenborough. Notable films directed: Oh! What a Lovely War (1969), Gandhi (1982), and Shadowlands (1993).

--Word--
attend 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Be present at (an event, meeting, or function)
Go regularly to (a school, church, or clinic)
Deal with.
Give practical help and care to; look after.
Pay attention to.
Escort and wait on (a member of royalty or other important person)
Occur with or as a result of.
--Examples--
‘the whole sales force attended the conference’
‘her family were not invited to attend’
‘all children are required to attend school’
‘he muttered that he had business to attend to’
‘the severely wounded had two medics to attend to their wounds’
‘each of the beds in the intensive-care unit is attended by a nurse’
‘Alice hadn't attended to a word of his sermon’
‘Her Royal Highness was attended by Mrs Jane Stevens’
‘people feared that the switch to a peacetime economy would be attended by a severe slump’

attendant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person employed to provide a service to the public in a particular place.
An assistant to an important person; a servant or courtier.
A person who is present on a particular occasion.
Occurring with or as a result of.
(of a person) accompanying another as a companion or assistant.
--Examples--
‘a cloakroom attendant’
‘a mosaic of the Empress Theodora with her attendants’
‘he had become a regular attendant at chapel’
‘the sea and its attendant attractions’
‘a child in a pram with attendant nursemaid’

--Word--
attention 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Notice taken of someone or something; the regarding of someone or something as interesting or important.
The mental faculty of considering or taking notice of someone or something.
The action of dealing with or taking special care of someone or something.
Things done to express interest in or please someone.
A position assumed by a soldier, standing very straight with the feet together and the arms straight down the sides of the body.
An order to assume a straight standing position.
--Examples--
‘he drew attention to three spelling mistakes’
‘he turned his attention to the educational system’
‘her business needed her attention’
‘he was found guilty of failing to give a patient adequate medical attention’
‘she felt flattered by his attentions’
‘Saunders stood stolidly to attention’

--Word--
attentively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
While paying close attention.
While assiduously attending to the comfort or wishes of others; very politely or courteously.
--Examples--

‘though many of these places see few visitors, they are all attentively staffed by local people who are eager to help’
--Word--
attentiveness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of paying close attention to something.
The action of assiduously attending to the comfort or wishes of others; politeness or courtesy.
--Examples--
‘half the children who ate the cereal showed no improvement in attentiveness’
‘the past scenes are beautifully handled, with a clear attentiveness to detail’
‘this sight has maintained its top grading due to the attentiveness of the staff’

--Word--
attenuate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Reduce the force, effect, or value of.
Reduce the amplitude of (a signal, electric current, or other oscillation)
Reduce the virulence of (a pathogenic organism or vaccine)
Reduce in thickness; make thin.
Reduced in force, effect, or physical thickness.
--Examples--
‘her intolerance was attenuated by an unexpected liberalism’
‘the filter must severely attenuate frequencies above 10 Hz’
‘researchers hoped that the substance would attenuate the course of the disease’
‘the doctrines of Christianity became very attenuate and distorted’
--Word--
attenuated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of a person) extremely thin.
(of a pathogenic organism or vaccine) reduced in virulence.
--Examples--
‘she was a drooping, attenuated figure’
‘attenuated strains of rabies virus’

noun

The reduction of the amplitude of a signal, electric current, or other oscillation.
--Examples--

‘the products are used mostly by aircraft manufacturers for noise attenuation in engine housings’
‘attenuations of the order of 50 to 200 dB are required’

atter 
--Type--

--Word--
attest 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Provide or serve as clear evidence of.
Declare that something exists or is the case.
Witness or certify formally.
Enrol as ready for military service.
Recruit (someone) for military service by putting them on oath to serve if called upon.
--Examples--
‘his status is attested by his becoming an alderman’
‘his numerous drawings of babies attest to his fascination with them’
‘I can attest to his tremendous energy’
‘the deceased's solicitor attested that he had been about to institute divorce proceedings’
‘the witnesses must attest and sign the will in the testator's presence’
‘unfortunately for him, he attested’
‘2,000,000 men were attested under this system’

attic 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A space or room inside or partly inside the roof of a building.
Relating to ancient Athens or Attica, or the dialect of Greek spoken there.
The dialect of Greek used by the ancient Athenians. It was the chief literary form of classical Greek.
--Examples--
‘I discovered a dozen rolls of the original wallpaper in a tin trunk in the attic’
‘there are five attic bedrooms’
--Word--
Attica 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A triangular promontory of eastern Greece. With the islands in the Saronic Gulf it forms a department of Greece, of which Athens is the capital.
--Examples--
--Word--

Attila 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(406–53), king of the Huns 434–53. He ravaged vast areas between the Rhine and the Caspian Sea before being defeated by the joint forces of the Roman army and the Visigoths at Châlons in 451.
--Examples--

--Word--
Attis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in Anatolian mythology) the youthful consort of Cybele, whose death and resurrection were associated with the spring festival.
--Examples--
--Word--
attitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A settled way of thinking or feeling about something.
A position of the body indicating a particular mental state.
A position in which one leg is lifted behind with the knee bent at right angles and turned out, and the corresponding arm is raised above the head, the other extended to the side.
Truculent or uncooperative behaviour.
Individuality and self-confidence.
The orientation of an aircraft or spacecraft, relative to the direction of travel.
--Examples--
‘he was questioned on his attitude to South Africa’
‘being competitive is an attitude of mind’
‘the boy was standing in an attitude of despair’
‘I asked the waiter for a clean fork and all I got was attitude’
‘she snapped her fingers with attitude’
--Word--

--Type--
noun

‘the boy was standing in an attitude of despair’
‘I asked the waiter for a clean fork and all I got was attitude’
‘she snapped her fingers with attitude’
--Word--
attitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A settled way of thinking or feeling about something.
A position of the body indicating a particular mental state.
A position in which one leg is lifted behind with the knee bent at right angles and turned out, and the corresponding arm is raised above the head, the other extended to the side.
Truculent or uncooperative behaviour.
Individuality and self-confidence.
The orientation of an aircraft or spacecraft, relative to the direction of travel.
--Examples--
‘he was questioned on his attitude to South Africa’
‘being competitive is an attitude of mind’
‘the boy was standing in an attitude of despair’
‘I asked the waiter for a clean fork and all I got was attitude’
‘she snapped her fingers with attitude’
--Word--
attitudinal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to attitudes.
--Examples--
‘attitudinal changes do not just come out of the blue’
--Word--
attitudinize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘her column is an exercise in smug attitudinizing’

--Word--
Attleboro 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in southeastern Massachusetts, northeast of Providence in Rhode Island; population 42,833 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Attlee, Clement 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Earl Attlee (1883–1967), British Labour statesman, prime minister 1945–51; full name Clement Richard Attlee. His term saw the creation of the modern welfare state and the nationalization of major industries.
--Examples--
--Word--
attn 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
(on an envelope or at the top of a letter or fax) attention (i.e. for the attention of)
--Examples--
‘attn: Harold Carter’

atto-

--Meanings--

--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--

--Word--
attract 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Cause to come to a place or participate in a venture by offering something of interest or advantage.
Evoke (a specified reaction)
Cause (someone) to have a liking for or interest in something.
Have a sexual or romantic interest in.
Exert a force on (an object) that is directed towards the source of the force.
--Examples--
‘a campaign to attract more visitors to Shetland’
‘he hoped this strategy would attract foreign investment by multinationals’
‘I did not want to attract attention’
‘his criticism of the government attracted widespread support’
‘I was attracted to the idea of working for a ballet company’
‘I am not attracted to him at all’
‘the negatively charged ions attract particles of dust’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
attraction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or power of evoking interest in or liking for someone or something.
A quality or feature that evokes interest, liking, or desire.
A place which draws visitors by providing something of interest or pleasure.
A force under the influence of which objects tend to move towards each other.
The influence exerted by one word on another which causes it to change to an incorrect form, e.g. the wages of sin is (for are) death.
--Examples--
‘the timeless attraction of a good tune’
‘she has very romantic ideas about sexual attraction’
‘this reform has many attractions for those on the left’
‘the church is the town's main tourist attraction’
‘gravitational attraction’
--Word--
attractionally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of attraction.
--Examples--

--Word--
attractive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Pleasing or appealing to the senses.
(of a person) appealing to look at; sexually alluring.
Having qualities or features which arouse interest.
Relating to attraction between physical objects.
--Examples--
‘an attractive village’
‘foliage can be as attractive as flowers’
‘a stunningly attractive, charismatic man’
‘the site is close to other prestige schemes which should make it attractive to developers’
‘the attractive force between the magnets and the metal plate’
--Word--
attractively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that is pleasing or appealing to the senses.
(with reference to a person) in such a way as to be appealing or sexually alluring to look at.
In a way that arouses interest.
--Examples--
‘desserts were attractively presented’
‘I like to dress attractively’
‘the properties are attractively priced’
--Word--
attractiveness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being pleasing or appealing to the senses.
(in a person) the quality of being appealing or sexually alluring to look at.
The possession of qualities or features that arouse interest.
--Examples--
‘this scheme could enhance the attractiveness of the area’
‘my aunt did not marry until late in life in spite of her attractiveness’
‘simply smiling can increase your attractiveness to others’
‘the new agreements will enhance the city 's attractiveness to overseas investors’

--Word--
attributable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Regarded as being caused by.
(of a work or remark) able to be ascribed to a particular author, artist, or speaker.
--Examples--
‘43 percent of all deaths in Ireland were attributable to cardiovascular disease’
‘some 50 liturgical works by or attributable to him have survived’
‘this may be Leonardo 's earliest securely attributable painting’
--Word--
attribute 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Regard something as being caused by.
Ascribe a work or remark to (a particular author, artist, or speaker)
Regard a quality or feature as characteristic of or possessed by.
A quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something.
A material object recognized as symbolic of a person, especially a conventional object used in art to identify a saint or mythical figure.
A piece of information which determines the properties of a field or tag in a database or a string of characters in a display.
An attributive adjective or noun.
A real property which a statistical analysis is attempting to describe.
--Examples--
‘he attributed the firm's success to the efforts of the managing director’
‘his resignation was attributed to stress’
‘the building was attributed to Inigo Jones’
‘ancient peoples attributed magic properties to certain stones’
‘flexibility and mobility are the key attributes of Britain's army’
‘it was not until the end of the fifteenth century that the sandglass was depicted as the attribute of Father Time’

--Word--
attribution 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of regarding something as being caused by a person or thing.
The action of ascribing a work or remark to a particular author, artist, or person.
The action of regarding a quality or feature as characteristic of or possessed by a person or thing.
--Examples--
‘the electorate was disillusioned with his immediate attribution of the bombings to a separatist group’
‘the study of Constable is fraught with problems of attribution’
‘the attribution to Mozart on the title page is correct’
‘none of the texts in the collection contained author attributions’
‘the attribution of human emotions to inanimate objects’
‘attributions of false motives, especially of greed, are commonplace’

--Word--
attributive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an adjective or other modifier) preceding the word that it modifies and expressing an attribute, as old in the old dog (but not in the dog is old) and expiry in expiry date.

--Examples--

attrit 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Wear down (an opponent or enemy) by sustained action.
--Examples--
‘his defense was designed to attrit us’
--Word--
attrite

--Word--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘his defense was designed to attrit us’
--Word--
attrition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of reducing something's strength or effectiveness through sustained attack or pressure.
The gradual reduction of a workforce by employees leaving and not being replaced rather than by redundancy.
Wearing away by friction; abrasion.
(in scholastic theology) sorrow for sin, falling short of contrition.
--Examples--
‘the council is trying to wear down the opposition by attrition’
‘the squadron suffered severe attrition of its bombers’
‘the company said that it will reduce its worldwide employment by about 10% through attrition’
‘the skull shows attrition of the edges of the teeth’
--Word--
attritional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
attritive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That causes attrition; gradually wearing away or weakening something or someone.
--Examples--
--Word--
attritus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Matter produced when something is ground down or rubbed or worn away.
--Examples--
--Word--
Attu 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in southwestern Alaska, the westernmost of the Aleutian Islands. During World War II, it was occupied by Japanese forces.
--Examples--
--Word--
attune 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make receptive or aware.
Accustom or acclimatize.
Make harmonious.
--Examples--
‘a society more attuned to consumerism than ideology’
‘students are not attuned to making decisions’
‘the interests of East and West are now closely attuned’

--Meanings--

--Word--
tumble 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fall suddenly, clumsily, or headlong.
Move or rush in a headlong or uncontrolled way.
Fall rapidly in amount or value.
Rumple; disarrange.
Perform acrobatic feats, typically handsprings and somersaults in the air.
(of a breed of pigeon) repeatedly turn over backwards in flight.
Dry (washing) in a tumble dryer.
Understand the meaning or hidden implication of (a situation)
Have sexual intercourse with.
Clean (castings, gemstones, etc.) in a tumbling barrel.
A sudden or headlong fall.
A rapid fall in amount or value.
An untidy or confused arrangement or state.
A handspring, somersault in the air, or other acrobatic feat.
An act of sexual intercourse.
A friendly sign of recognition, acknowledgement, or interest.
--Examples--
‘she pitched forward, tumbling down the remaining stairs’
‘police and dogs tumbled from the vehicle’
‘property prices tumbled’
‘he slept fitfully for the third night in a row, tumbling the covers about him as he tried to get comfortable’
‘the machine gentle tumbles the clothes in cool air for ten minutes’
‘she'll ring again as soon as she tumbles to what she's done’
‘he was tumbling a strange woman’
‘I took a tumble in the nettles’
‘a tumble in share prices’
‘her hair was a tumble of untamed curls’
‘not a soul gave him a tumble’
--Word--
ATV 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
(in the UK) Associated Television, an independent television company founded in 1956 and replaced in 1981 by Central Television.
--Examples--
‘they passed a law that allows ATVs on roads with speed limits of 35 mph or lower’

--Word--
twist 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Form into a bent, curling, or distorted shape.
Form (something) into a particular shape by taking hold of one or both ends and turning them.
Turn or bend into a specified position or in a specified direction.
Remove something by pulling and rotating it.
Move one's body so that the shoulders and hips are facing in different directions.
Move in a wriggling or writhing fashion.
Injure (a joint) by wrenching it.
Distort or misrepresent the meaning of (words)
Cause to rotate around a stationary point; turn.
Wind around or through something.
Move or cause to move around each other; interlace.
Make (something) by interlacing or winding strands together.
Take or have a winding course.
Dance the twist.
Cheat; defraud.
(in pontoon) request, deal, or be dealt a card face upwards.
An act of twisting something around a stationary point.
An act of turning one's body or part of one's body.
A dance with a twisting movement of the body, popular in the 1960s.
The extent of twisting of a rod or other object.
Force producing twisting; torque.
Forward motion combined with rotation about an axis.
The rifling in the bore of a gun.
A thing with a spiral shape.
A paper packet with twisted ends.
A small quantity of tobacco, sugar, salt, or a similar substance, wrapped in such a packet.
A curled piece of lemon peel used to flavour a drink.
A distorted shape.
An unusual feature of a person's personality, typically an unhealthy one.
A swindle.
A point at which something turns or bends.
An unexpected development of events.
A new treatment or outlook; a variation.
A fine strong thread consisting of twisted strands of cotton or silk.
A drink consisting of two ingredients mixed together.
A carpet with a tightly curled pile.
--Examples--
‘a strip of metal is twisted to form a hollow tube’
‘her pretty features twisted into a fearsome expression’
‘she twisted her handkerchief into a knot’
‘he grabbed the man and twisted his arm behind his back’
‘beetroot can be stored once the leaves have been twisted off’
‘she twisted in her seat to look at the buildings’
‘he twisted himself free’
‘he twisted his ankle trying to avoid his opponent's lunge’
‘they twisted my words and made a mockery of me’
‘she twisted her ring round and round on her finger’
‘I twisted a strand of hair around my finger’
‘she twisted her hands together nervously’
‘the machine twists together strands to make a double yarn’
‘he could twist a rope strong enough to hold a mule’
‘the railway lines twist and turn round the hills’
‘the taps needed a single twist to turn them on’
‘with a sudden twist, she got away from him’
‘lets do the twist’
‘barrels with a 1:24 inch twist’
‘a barley sugar twist’
‘he handed her a twist of paper’
‘he bought a packet of crisps with a blue twist of salt in them’
‘she drank vodka and tonic with a twist of lemon’
‘he had a cruel twist to his mouth’
‘her lack of considerateness is a personality twist which could bring her problems’
‘the car negotiated the twists and turns of the mountain road’
‘it was soon time for the next twist of fate in his extraordinary career’
‘she takes conventional subjects and gives them a twist’
--Word--
atwitter 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
In a state of agitation or nervous excitement.
--Examples--
‘the locals are all atwitter about the performance’

--Word--
two 
--Type--
cardinal number
--Meanings--
Equivalent to the sum of one and one; one less than three; 2.
A group or unit of two people or things.
Two years old.
Two o'clock.
A size of garment or other merchandise denoted by two.
A playing card or domino with two pips.
--Examples--
‘two years ago’
‘a romantic weekend for two in Paris’
‘two of Amy's friends’
‘they would straggle home in ones and twos’
‘he is only two’
‘the pub closed at two’
--Word--
Atwood, Margaret 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1939), Canadian novelist, poet, critic, and short-story writer; full name Margaret Eleanor Atwood. Notable works: The Edible Woman (1969), The Handmaid's Tale (1985), Cat's Eye (1989), and The Blind Assassin (Booker Prize, 2000).

aubergine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The purple egg-shaped fruit of a tropical Old World plant, which is eaten as a vegetable.
A dark purple colour like the skin of an aubergine.
The large plant of the nightshade family which bears aubergines.

--Word--
Aubrey, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1626–97), English antiquarian and author. He is chiefly remembered for Brief Lives, a collection of biographies of eminent people.

AUC 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Word--
Auchincloss, Louis Stanton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1917–2010), US lawyer and author; early pseudonym Andrew Lee. His novels and short stories often depict life among the elite of New York City.
--Examples--
--Word--
Auckland 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The largest city and chief seaport of New Zealand, in the North Island; population 404,658 (2006). It was the site of the first Parliament of New Zealand in 1854, remaining the capital until 1865.
--Examples--
--Word--
auction 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A public sale in which goods or property are sold to the highest bidder.
The action or process of selling something to the highest bidder.
The part of the play in which players bid to decide the contract in which the hand shall be played.
Sell or offer for sale at an auction.
--Examples--
‘the books are expected to fetch a six-figure sum at tomorrow's auction’
‘the Ferrari sold at auction for £10 million’
‘the painting was auctioned at Christie's’

--Word--
Auden, W. H. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1907–73), British-born poet, resident in America from 1939; full name Wystan Hugh Auden. Look, Stranger! (1936) and Spain (1937, on the Civil War) secured his position as a leading left-wing poet. He was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for The Age of Anxiety (1947).
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
Murphy, Audie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1924–71), US soldier and actor; full name Audie Leon Murphy. The most decorated combat soldier of World War II, he appeared in war adventure movies such as Beyond Glory (1948) and To Hell and Back (1955), the latter being a movie version of his autobiography.
--Examples--
--Word--
audience 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The assembled spectators or listeners at a public event such as a play, film, concert, or meeting.
The people who watch or listen to a television or radio programme.
The readership of a newspaper, magazine, or book.
The people giving attention to something.
A formal interview with a person in authority.
Formal hearing.
--Examples--
‘he asked for questions from members of the audience’
‘the programme attracted an audience of almost twenty million’
‘the newspaper has a sophisticated audience’
‘the report deserves consideration by a much wider audience’
‘he demanded an audience with the Pope’

audiencer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Spanish Netherlands: (the title of) a senior chancery official.
In France: (the title of) a chancery official whose responsibilities included auditing letters patent prior to sealing and collecting fees payable on these.

audion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An early form of triode valve, developed by Lee De Forest and used as a detector and amplifier for radio signals. Frequently attributive, as "audion amplifier", "audion tube", etc.

--Word--
audit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An official inspection of an organization's accounts, typically by an independent body.
A systematic review or assessment of something.
Conduct an official financial inspection of (a company or its accounts)
Conduct a systematic review of.
Attend (a class) informally, without working for credit.
--Examples--
‘audits can't be expected to detect every fraud’
‘a complete audit of flora and fauna at the site’
‘unlimited companies must also have their accounts audited’
‘a method of auditing obstetric and neonatal care’
‘he made use of the knowledge gleaned from economics classes he audited’

--Word--
audition 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An interview for a role or job as a singer, actor, dancer, or musician, consisting of a practical demonstration of the candidate's suitability and skill.
The power of hearing or listening.
Perform an audition.
Assess the suitability of (someone) for a role by means of an audition.
--Examples--
‘the Royal Ballet gave Nicola an audition’
‘I auditioned and was lucky enough to get the part’
‘she was auditioning people for her new series’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘the National Indoor Arena is a magnificent auditorium and one of Britain's premier indoor venues’

auditory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the sense of hearing.
--Examples--
‘the auditory nerves’
‘teaching methods use both visual and auditory stimulation’
--Word--
auditory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the sense of hearing.
--Examples--
‘the auditory nerves’
‘teaching methods use both visual and auditory stimulation’
--Word--
auditorium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a theatre, concert hall, or other public building in which the audience sits.
A large building or hall used for public gatherings, typically speeches or stage performances.
--Examples--
‘the stage was small and the auditorium had only 366 seats’
‘the National Indoor Arena is a magnificent auditorium and one of Britain's premier indoor venues’
--Word--
auditorium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a theatre, concert hall, or other public building in which the audience sits.
A large building or hall used for public gatherings, typically speeches or stage performances.
--Examples--
‘the stage was small and the auditorium had only 366 seats’
‘the National Indoor Arena is a magnificent auditorium and one of Britain's premier indoor venues’
--Word--
auditor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who conducts an audit.
A listener.
A person who attends a class informally without working for credit.
--Examples--
‘the company is required to appoint auditors at each general meeting’
‘external auditors report on the financial statements’
‘so low was Deems's voice that his auditors had to give it close attention’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
audit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An official inspection of an organization's accounts, typically by an independent body.
A systematic review or assessment of something.
Conduct an official financial inspection of (a company or its accounts)
Conduct a systematic review of.
Attend (a class) informally, without working for credit.
--Examples--
‘audits can't be expected to detect every fraud’
‘a complete audit of flora and fauna at the site’
‘unlimited companies must also have their accounts audited’
‘a method of auditing obstetric and neonatal care’
‘he made use of the knowledge gleaned from economics classes he audited’
--Word--
AUD 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Australian dollar(s).
--Examples--
--Word--
Hepburn, Audrey 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1929–93), British actress, born in Belgium. After pursuing a career as a stage and film actress in England, she moved to Hollywood, where she starred in such films as Roman Holiday (1953), for which she won an Oscar, and My Fair Lady (1964).
--Examples--
--Word--
Audubon, John James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1785–1851), American naturalist and artist. He is noted for The Birds of America (1827–38).
--Examples--
--Word--
Auer, Carl 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Baron von Welsbach (1858–1929), Austrian chemist. He separated the supposed rare earth element didymium into neodymium and praseodymium.
--Examples--
--Word--
Auerbach, Red 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1917–2006), US basketball coach; full name Arnold Jacob Auerbach. As coach of the Boston Celtics 1950–66, he led the team to nine National Basketball Association (NBA) championships 1957, 1959–66. Basketball Hall of Fame (1968).
--Examples--

--Word--
Augean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to Augeas.
(of a task or problem) requiring so much effort to complete or solve as to seem impossible.
--Examples--
‘the Augean stables’
‘there are Augean amounts of debris to clear’
--Word--
Augeas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A legendary king whose vast stables had never been cleaned. Hercules cleaned them in a day by diverting the River Alpheus to flow through them.
--Examples--
--Word--
augend 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The number to which another is added.
--Examples--
‘we can begin with the combination in which both the addend and the augend are 0's but the carry bit from the previous column is a 1’

--Word--
gabbro 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark, coarse-grained plutonic rock of crystalline texture, consisting mainly of pyroxene, plagioclase feldspar, and often olivine.
--Examples--
‘a house of gabbro’
‘olivine gabbros’
--Word--
gneiss 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A metamorphic rock with a banded or foliated structure, typically coarse-grained and consisting mainly of feldspar, quartz, and mica.
--Examples--
--Word--
auger 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tool resembling a large corkscrew, for boring holes in wood.
A large tool similar to an auger, used for boring holes in the ground.
A marine mollusc of warm seas with a slender tapering spiral shell.

--Word--
augite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark green or black aluminosilicate mineral of the pyroxene group. It occurs in many igneous rocks, including basalt, gabbro, and dolerite.

--Word--
augment 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make (something) greater by adding to it; increase.
A vowel prefixed to past tenses of verbs in Greek and certain other Indo-European languages.
--Examples--
‘he augmented his summer income by painting houses’
--Word--
augmented 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having been made greater in size or value.
Denoting or containing an interval which is one semitone greater than the corresponding major or perfect interval.
--Examples--
‘augmented pensions for those retiring at 65’
‘augmented fourths’
--Word--
augmentation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of making or becoming greater in size or amount.
The lengthening of the time values of notes in a melodic part.
An addition to a coat of arms granted as a mark of special honour.
--Examples--
‘the augmentation of the curriculum with new subjects’

--Word--
augmentative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an affix or derived word) reinforcing the idea of the original word, especially by meaning ‘a large one of its kind’, as with the Italian suffix -one in borrone ‘ravine’, compared with borro ‘ditch’.
--Examples--

--Word--
augur 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of an event or circumstance) portend a good or bad outcome.
Portend or bode (a specified outcome)
Foresee or predict.
(in ancient Rome) a religious official who observed natural signs, especially the behaviour of birds, interpreting these as an indication of divine approval or disapproval of a proposed action.
--Examples--
‘the end of the cold war seemed to augur well’
‘they feared that these happenings augured a neo-Nazi revival’
--Word--
augural 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Acting as a sign or warning of a good or bad event in the future.
--Examples--
‘there is no controversy about the interpretation of augural signs’

august 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Respected and impressive.
The eighth month of the year, in the northern hemisphere usually considered the last month of summer.
--Examples--
‘she was in august company’
‘the sultry haze of late August’
‘the wettest August in six years’

--Meanings--
A resort in eastern Georgia in the US; population (with Richmond) 199,486 (est. 2008).
The state capital of Maine; population 18,282 (est. 2008).

--Word--
Augustan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Connected with or occurring during the reign of the Roman emperor Augustus.
Relating to or denoting Latin literature of the reign of Augustus, including the works of Virgil, Horace, Ovid, and Livy.
Relating to or denoting 17th- and 18th-century English literature of a style considered refined and classical, including the works of Pope, Addison, and Swift.
A writer of the (Latin or English) Augustan period or style.
--Examples--
‘a Roman villa of the Augustan period’
‘poets of the Augustan age’
--Word--
Rodin, Auguste 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1840–1917), French sculptor. He was chiefly concerned with the human form. Notable works: The Thinker (1880) and The Kiss (1886).

Sainte-Beuve, Charles Augustin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1804–69), French critic and writer. In his criticism he concentrated on the influence of social and other factors in the development of character.

--Word--
Pinochet, Augusto 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–2006), Chilean general and statesman, president 1974–90; full name Augusto Pinochet Ugarte. Having masterminded the military coup which overthrew President Allende in 1973, he imposed a military dictatorship until forced to call elections in 1989. He was replaced by a democratically elected president in 1990.
--Examples--
--Word--
Augustus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(63 BC–AD 14), the first Roman emperor; born Gaius Octavius; also called (until 27 BC) Octavian. He was adopted by the will of his great-uncle Julius Caesar and gained supreme power by his defeat of Antony in 31 BC. In 27 BC he was given the title Augustus (‘venerable’) and became in effect the first Roman emperor.
--Examples--

--Word--
Vitellius, Aulus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(15–69), Roman emperor. He was acclaimed emperor in January 69 by the legions in Germany during the civil wars that followed the death of Nero. He defeated Otho but was killed by the supporters of Vespasian.

Aur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
aura 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The distinctive atmosphere or quality that seems to surround and be generated by a person, thing, or place.
(in spiritualism and some forms of alternative medicine) a supposed emanation surrounding the body of a living creature and regarded as an essential part of the individual.
Any invisible emanation, especially an odour.
A warning sensation experienced before an attack of epilepsy or migraine.
--Examples--
‘the ceremony retains an aura of mystery’
‘emotional, mental, and spiritual levels form an energy field around the body known as the aura’
‘muddy colours in the aura indicate negative emotions’
‘there was a faint aura of disinfectant’
--Word--
aura 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The distinctive atmosphere or quality that seems to surround and be generated by a person, thing, or place.
(in spiritualism and some forms of alternative medicine) a supposed emanation surrounding the body of a living creature and regarded as an essential part of the individual.
Any invisible emanation, especially an odour.
A warning sensation experienced before an attack of epilepsy or migraine.
--Examples--
‘the ceremony retains an aura of mystery’
‘emotional, mental, and spiritual levels form an energy field around the body known as the aura’
‘muddy colours in the aura indicate negative emotions’
‘there was a faint aura of disinfectant’

Aurangzeb

--Meanings--

--Type--
noun

--Word--
aureate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made of or having the colour of gold.
(of language) highly ornamented or elaborate.
--Examples--
‘the aureate dollar’
‘the aureate diction frequently conceals the tritest sentiments’
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made of or having the colour of gold.
(of language) highly ornamented or elaborate.

‘the aureate diction frequently conceals the tritest sentiments’
--Word--
aureus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Roman coin of the late republic and empire, worth 25 silver denarii.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aurelian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.215–75), Roman emperor 270–5; Latin name Lucius Domitius Aurelianus. Originally a common soldier, he rose through the ranks and was elected emperor by the army.
--Examples--
--Word--
Aurelius, Marcus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(121–80), Roman emperor 161–80; full name Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus. He was occupied for much of his reign with wars against invading Germanic tribes. His Meditations, a collection of aphorisms and reflections, are evidence of his philosophical nature.
--Examples--
--Word--
aureole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A circle of light or brightness surrounding something, especially as depicted in art around the head or body of a person represented as holy.
A corona around the sun or moon.
The zone of metamorphosed rock surrounding an igneous intrusion.
--Examples--
‘her hair framed her face in a golden aureole’

auric 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the aura supposedly surrounding a living creature.

--Examples--

--Word--
auricle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A structure resembling an ear or ear lobe.
The external part or pinna of the ear.
A small muscular flap on the surface of each atrium of the heart.
--Examples--
‘grass leaves often have two auricles at the junction between the leaf sheath and the blade’
‘blood passes downward from the auricle to the ventricle’

auricula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Alpine primula from which a wide range of flowering cultivars have been developed. It has leaves that supposedly resemble bears' ears.

Auriga 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A large northern constellation (the Charioteer), said to represent a man holding a whip.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Auriga.
--Examples--
‘the star Theta Aurigae’
--Word--
Aurignacian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the early stages of the Upper Palaeolithic culture in Europe and the Near East. It is dated in most places to about 34,000–29,000 years ago, and is associated with Cro-Magnon Man.
The Aurignacian culture or period.
--Examples--
--Word--
iodide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound of iodine with another element or group, especially a salt of the anion I-.

auriscope

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
aurochs 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large wild Eurasian ox that was the ancestor of domestic cattle. It was probably exterminated in Britain in the Bronze Age, and the last one was killed in Poland in 1627.
--Examples--
--Word--
aurochs 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large wild Eurasian ox that was the ancestor of domestic cattle. It was probably exterminated in Britain in the Bronze Age, and the last one was killed in Poland in 1627.
--Examples--
--Word--
aurora 
--Type--
noun, proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A natural electrical phenomenon characterized by the appearance of streamers of reddish or greenish light in the sky, especially near the northern or southern magnetic pole. The effect is caused by the interaction of charged particles from the sun with atoms in the upper atmosphere. In northern and southern regions it is respectively called aurora borealis or Northern Lights and aurora australis or Southern Lights.
The dawn.
Goddess of the dawn.
A city in north central Colorado, east of Denver; population 319,057 (est. 2008).
An industrial city in northeastern Illinois; population 171,782 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
aurora 
--Type--
noun, proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A natural electrical phenomenon characterized by the appearance of streamers of reddish or greenish light in the sky, especially near the northern or southern magnetic pole. In northern and southern regions it is respectively called aurora borealis or Northern Lights and aurora australis or Southern Lights.

Goddess of the dawn.

--Word--
Austen, Jane 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1775–1817), English novelist. Her major novels are Sense and Sensibility (1811), Pride and Prejudice (1813), Mansfield Park (1814), Emma (1815), Northanger Abbey (1818), and Persuasion (1818). They are notable for skilful characterization, dry wit, and penetrating social observation.
--Examples--
--Word--
austenite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A solid solution of carbon in a non-magnetic form of iron, stable at high temperatures. It is a constituent of some forms of steel.
--Examples--
--Word--
austenitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Auster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The south wind, frequently personified; (Roman Mythology) the god of the south wind.
--Examples--
--Word--
austere 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Severe or strict in manner or attitude.
(of living conditions or a way of life) having no comforts or luxuries.
Having a plain and unadorned appearance.
--Examples--
‘he was an austere man, with a rigidly puritanical outlook’
‘conditions in the prison could hardly be more austere’
‘the cathedral is impressive in its austere simplicity’

--Word--
austerity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Sternness or severity of manner or attitude.
Plainness and simplicity in appearance.
A feature of an austere way of life.
Difficult economic conditions created by government measures to reduce public expenditure.
--Examples--
‘he was noted for his austerity and his authoritarianism’
‘the room was decorated with a restraint bordering on austerity’
‘his uncle's austerities had undermined his health’
‘the country was subjected to acute economic austerity’
‘the austerities of post-war London’

--Word--
Austerlitz, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle in 1805 near the town of Austerlitz (now in the Czech Republic), in which Napoleon defeated the Austrians and Russians.
--Examples--
--Word--
Austin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The state capital of Texas; population 757,688 (est. 2008). First settled in 1835, it was named in 1839 after Stephen F. Austin, son of Moses Austin, leader of the first Texas colony.

--Word--
Australia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island country and continent in the southern hemisphere, in the south-western Pacific Ocean, a member state of the Commonwealth of Nations; population 28,500,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Canberra; official language, English.
--Examples--
--Word--
Australian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Australia, or a person of Australian descent.
Relating to Australia.
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Australasia together with Indonesia east of Wallace's line, in which monotremes and marsupials dominate the fauna.
Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising only Australia and Tasmania.

--Word--
australopithecine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A fossil bipedal primate with both ape-like and human characteristics, found in Pliocene and Lower Pleistocene deposits (circa 4 million to 1 million years old) in Africa.
Denoting or relating to an australopithecine.
--Examples--
‘the flat forehead of extinct australopithecines’
‘australopithecine fossils’
--Word--
Australopithecus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fossil bipedal primate with both ape-like and human characteristics, found in Pliocene and Lower Pleistocene deposits (c.4 million to 1 million years old) in Africa.
--Examples--
--Word--
Australorp 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Austro-Asiatic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a phylum or superfamily of languages spoken in SE Asia, consisting of the Mon-Khmer family, the Munda family, and one or two other isolated languages.
The Austro-Asiatic family of languages.

--Word--
Hungarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Hungary, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Hungary, or a person of Hungarian descent.
The official language of Hungary, spoken also by some 2.5 million people in Romania. Hungarian is a Finno-Ugric language and is the only major language of the Ugric branch.

Austronesian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a family of languages spoken in an area extending from Madagascar in the west to the Pacific islands in the east.
The Austronesian family of languages.

--Word--
autarky 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Economic independence or self-sufficiency.
A country, state, or society which is economically independent.
--Examples--
‘rural community autarchy is a Utopian dream’

--Word--
auth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or action of verifying the identity of a user or process; authentication.
--Examples--
‘they may choose to operate without online auth’
‘we will set an auth cookie, which will log in the user’
--Word--
auth. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Authentic.
Author.
Authority.
Authorized.
--Examples--
--Word--
authentic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of undisputed origin and not a copy; genuine.
Made or done in the traditional or original way, or in a way that faithfully resembles an original.
Based on facts; accurate or reliable.
(in existentialist philosophy) relating to or denoting an emotionally appropriate, significant, purposive, and responsible mode of human life.
(of a church mode) containing notes between the final (the principal note) and the note an octave higher.
--Examples--
‘the letter is now accepted as an authentic document’
‘the restaurant serves authentic Italian meals’
‘every detail of the film was totally authentic’
‘an authentic depiction of the situation’
--Word--
authentical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Legally valid; possessing legal force. Also of a person: legally or duly qualified. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
authentically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Undisputedly; genuinely.
In the traditional or original way, or in a way that faithfully resembles an original.
(in existentialist philosophy) in accordance with an emotionally appropriate, significant, purposive, and responsible mode of human life.
--Examples--
‘her dances are as authentically Brazilian as their creator’
‘finding someone to cook curry authentically can be a real challenge’
‘the film authentically recreates 17th-century Delft’
‘am I living authentically, in a way that embodies my personal values?’
--Word--
authenticness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact or quality of being in accordance with truth or fact; credibility, veracity; authentic character, authenticity.
--Examples--
--Word--
authenticator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
authenticate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Prove or show (something) to be true, genuine, or valid.
(of a user or process) have one's identity verified.
--Examples--
‘they were invited to authenticate artefacts from the Italian Renaissance’
‘it only accepts commands from users who have authenticated as ‘clients’’

--Word--
authentication 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process or action of proving or showing something to be true, genuine, or valid.
The process or action of verifying the identity of a user or process.
--Examples--
‘the prints will be stamped with his seal and accompanied by a letter of authentication’
‘the authentications were both carried out by the Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Justice’
‘user authentication for each device ensures that the individual using the device is recognized by the company’
‘passwords and authentications are necessary parts of system security’
--Word--
authentication 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘passwords and authentications are necessary parts of system security’

--Word--
author 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A writer of a book, article, or document.
Someone who writes books as a profession.
The writings produced by a particular author.
An originator of a plan or idea.
Be the author of (a book or piece of writing)
Be the originator of.
--Examples--
‘he is the author of several books on the subject’
‘I had to read authors I disliked’
‘the authors of the peace plan’
‘she has authored several articles on wildlife’
‘the concept has been authored largely by insurance companies’
--Word--
authorcraft

noun
--Meanings--
The art or skill of an author; the exercise of this.
--Examples--

--Word--
authoritarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Favouring or enforcing strict obedience to authority at the expense of personal freedom.
Showing a lack of concern for the wishes or opinions of others; dictatorial.
An authoritarian person.
--Examples--
‘the transition from an authoritarian to a democratic regime’
‘he had an authoritarian and at times belligerent manner’
--Word--
authoritarianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The enforcement or advocacy of strict obedience to authority at the expense of personal freedom.
Lack of concern for the wishes or opinions of others.
--Examples--
--Word--
authoritarianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The enforcement or advocacy of strict obedience to authority at the expense of personal freedom.
Lack of concern for the wishes or opinions of others.
--Examples--
--Word--
authoritarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Favouring or enforcing strict obedience to authority at the expense of personal freedom.
Showing a lack of concern for the wishes or opinions of others; dictatorial.
An authoritarian person.
--Examples--
‘the transition from an authoritarian to a democratic regime’
‘he had an authoritarian and at times belligerent manner’
--Word--
authoritative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be trusted as being accurate or true; reliable.
(of a text) considered to be the best of its kind and unlikely to be improved upon.
Commanding and self-confident; likely to be respected and obeyed.
Proceeding from an official source and requiring compliance or obedience.
--Examples--
‘clear, authoritative information and advice’
‘an authoritative source’
‘this is likely to become the authoritative study of the subject’
‘his voice was calm and authoritative’
‘authoritative directives’
--Word--
authoritatively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that is trusted as being accurate or true; with authority.
In a commanding and self-confident manner that induces respect and obedience.
In an official capacity or with official sanction, and therefore requiring compliance or obedience.
--Examples--
‘he could speak authoritatively on art, philosophy, literature, history, current affairs’
‘she shouted authoritatively, 'Hey you! Drop your weapon, now!'’
‘the correct interpretation of the Convention can be authoritatively expounded only by the Strasbourg court’
--Word--
authoritativeness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
authority 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.
The right to act in a specified way, delegated from one person or organization to another.
Official permission; sanction.
A person or organization having political or administrative power and control.
The power to influence others, especially because of one's commanding manner or one's recognized knowledge about something.
The confidence resulting from personal expertise.
A person with extensive or specialized knowledge about a subject; an expert.
A book or other source able to supply reliable information or evidence.
--Examples--
‘he had absolute authority over his subordinates’
‘a rebellion against those in authority’
‘military forces have the legal authority to arrest drug traffickers’
‘the money was spent without parliamentary authority’
‘health authorities issued a worldwide alert’
‘he has the natural authority of one who is used to being obeyed’
‘he hit the ball with authority’
‘he was an authority on the stock market’
‘the court cited a series of authorities supporting their decision’
--Word--
authority 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.
The right to act in a specified way, delegated from one person or organization to another.

adjective
--Meanings--

Without the presence of an author or authors; containing no authors.

--Word--
authorship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or fact of being the writer of a book, article, or document, or the creator of a work of art.
The occupation of writing.
--Examples--
‘the single authorship of the book gives it a uniformity of style and a proper balance between chapters’
‘a number of paintings have been attributed to him on stylistic grounds, though his authorship is not certain’
‘he took to authorship’

--Word--
autoactivation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The activation of something (especially an enzyme, a gene, etc.) or initiation of a process (e.g. the germination of a spore) without an external stimulus; automatic activation; self-activation.
--Examples--
--Word--
autoactive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Spontaneously active; able to be activated without an external stimulus.
--Examples--
--Word--
autoagglutination 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine agglutination of red blood cells in their own serum, especially as a result of the action of an autoantibody.
Biology spontaneous aggregation of bacteria or protozoa.
--Examples--
--Word--
auto-alarm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An automatic fire alarm, burglar alarm, etc.; specifically a ship's alarm which transmits a distress signal by radio when triggered.

noun

noun
--Meanings--

autobasidiomycete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fungus belonging to the Autobasidiomycetes, a former division of the phylum Basidiomycota (the basidiomycetes), including mushrooms, toadstools, and related fungi having an autobasidium.
--Examples--
--Word--
autobasidium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A basidium that has no septum; an undivided basidium; also called holobasidium.

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
autocephalic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
autocephalous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an Eastern Christian Church) appointing its own head, not subject to the authority of an external patriarch or archbishop.

noun
--Meanings--
A mechanism for the automatic substitution of one CD or record for another during use.

--Word--
autochrome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An early form of colour photography using plates coated with dyed starch grains, patented by the Lumière brothers in 1904.
A colour photograph made using the autochrome process.
--Examples--
‘the autochrome process’

autocide 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who kills himself or herself.
Death caused by or involving a motor vehicle, especially a car; specifically suicide committed by deliberately crashing one's car; an instance of this.
Chiefly humorous. The destruction or ‘killing’ of a car.
Autocidal control of insects.

--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

autocollimation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The procedure of passing a beam of light though a converging lens on to a plane surface that reflects it back the way it has come (initially as a parallel beam); the use of an autocollimator; an instance of this.

noun

autocracy

noun
--Meanings--
A system of government by one person with absolute power.

--Examples--

--Word--
autocrat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ruler who has absolute power.
An imperious person who insists on complete obedience from others.
--Examples--
‘like many autocrats, Franco found the exercise of absolute power addictive’
‘Eva was an autocrat—people didn't argue unless they had a lot of courage’
--Word--
autocratic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to a ruler who has absolute power.
Taking no account of other people's wishes or opinions; domineering.
--Examples--
‘the constitutional reforms threatened his autocratic power’
‘a man with a reputation for an autocratic management style’

autodial 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a device) automatically dial a phone number or establish a connection with a computer.
A facility incorporated into a phone, computer, etc., that enables the device to dial and establish a connection with a particular number stored in its memory, either automatically or when activated by a simple command.
--Examples--
‘have a telephone with autodial by your bed’

autoecious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Mycology. Of parasitic fungi (especially rusts and smuts): inhabiting the same host throughout their life.
Botany. Of a bryophyte or its inflorescence: having both male and female sexual organs (antheridia and archegonia), but on separate shoots; also called autoicous.
--Examples--

autofrettage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of strengthening a tube, especially a gun barrel, by subjecting it to internal pressure high enough to enlarge the bore and push the inner metal (but not the outer metal) beyond its elastic limit.

autogiro 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of aircraft with freely rotating horizontal blades and a propeller. It differs from a helicopter in that the blades are not powered but rotate in the slipstream, propulsion being by a conventional mounted engine.

--Word--
autograph 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A signature, especially that of a celebrity written as a memento for an admirer.
A manuscript or musical score in an author's or musician's own handwriting.
A person's handwriting.
Write one's signature on (something); sign.
Written in the author's own handwriting.
(of a painting or sculpture) done by the artist, not by a copier.
--Examples--
‘fans surged around the car asking for autographs’
‘the earliest version of the work is possibly an autograph’
‘a songbook in Purcell's autograph’
‘the whole team autographed a shirt for him’
‘an autograph manuscript’
‘five of the drawings are accepted as autograph’

--Meanings--

autoinduction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Electricity= "self-induction". Now rare.
Biology and Medicine. The induction of something by itself or without external stimuli. In later use: (Pharmacology) the induction by a substance (especially a drug) of enzymes responsible for its own degradation.

--Word--
autoionization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chemistry. The spontaneous ionization of a substance or molecule; a reaction between two identical neutral molecules, especially in a solution, to produce an anion and a cation.
Physics. The spontaneous transition of an atom to an ionized state of lower energy with the emission of an electron (but no emission of radiation).

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
autokinesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Voluntary movement (of a muscle or the body). rare.
Metaphysics. The self-generated or spontaneous motion of the soul.
An optical illusion in which a small stationary object in a uniform background, especially a light source in an otherwise dark field, appears to move.
--Examples--
--Word--
autokinetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Producing voluntary movement; self-moving; automatic.
Psychology. Of or relating to the optical illusion of autokinesis.

autolaryngoscopy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

automaton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A moving mechanical device made in imitation of a human being.

Used in comparisons to refer to a person who seems to act in a mechanical or unemotional way.

‘a collection of 19th century French automata: acrobats, clowns, and musicians’
‘sophisticated automatons continue to run factory assembly lines’
‘like an automaton, she walked to the door’

--Word--
automatic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a device or process) working by itself with little or no direct human control.
(of a firearm) self-loading and able to fire continuously until the ammunition is exhausted or the pressure on the trigger is released.
(of a motor vehicle or its transmission) using gears that change by themselves according to speed and acceleration.
Done or occurring spontaneously, without conscious thought or attention.
Done or occurring as a matter of course and without debate.
(especially of a legal sanction) given or imposed as a necessary and inevitable result of a fixed rule or particular set of circumstances.
A gun that continues firing until the ammunition is exhausted or the pressure on the trigger is released.
A vehicle with automatic transmission.
--Examples--
‘an automatic kettle that switches itself off when it boils’
‘calibration is fully automatic’
‘automatic weapons’
‘a four-speed automatic gearbox’
‘automatic physical functions such as breathing’
‘‘Nice to meet you,’ he said, with automatic politeness’
‘he is the automatic choice for the senior team’
‘he received an automatic one-match suspension’
‘the rapid fire of automatics’
‘a Mercedes 300SL five-speed automatic’
--Word--
automatical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Automatic. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
automatically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
(with reference to a device or process) by itself with little or no direct human control.
(with reference to a firearm) continuously until the ammunition is exhausted or the pressure on the trigger is released.
Without conscious thought or attention; spontaneously.
As a necessary and inevitable result of a fixed rule or particular set of circumstances.
--Examples--
‘the kettle automatically switched off when it boiled’
‘the recovered weapons had been illegally modified to fire fully automatically’
‘although I used my best Italian, the receptionists automatically replied in English’
‘his passport was automatically revoked’
‘the winners of the Division 2 final are not automatically promoted’

--Meanings--

--Word--
automatic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a device or process) working by itself with little or no direct human control.
(of a firearm) self-loading and able to fire continuously until the ammunition is exhausted or the pressure on the trigger is released.
(of a motor vehicle or its transmission) using gears that change by themselves according to speed and acceleration.
Done or occurring spontaneously, without conscious thought or attention.
Done or occurring as a matter of course and without debate.
(especially of a legal sanction) given or imposed as a necessary and inevitable result of a fixed rule or particular set of circumstances.
A gun that continues firing until the ammunition is exhausted or the pressure on the trigger is released.
A vehicle with automatic transmission.
--Examples--
‘an automatic kettle that switches itself off when it boils’
‘calibration is fully automatic’

--Word--
automatism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The performance of actions without conscious thought or intention.
An action performed unconsciously or involuntarily.
The avoidance of conscious intention in producing works of art, especially by using mechanical techniques or subconscious associations.
--Examples--
‘diabetic patients who commit crimes while hypoglycaemic may be able to plead automatism’
‘automatisms occurred in all four epileptic syndromes’
--Word--
automatist 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A maker of automata.
Chiefly Spiritualism. A person engaged in or subject to automatism; specifically a medium who produces automatic writing.
An artist, writer, etc., whose technique is based upon automatism.
An adherent of the theory or doctrine of automatism; a person who believes organisms are motivated by mechanical and physical causes rather than consciousness or will. Now chiefly historical.
Of, relating to, or using automatism.

automorphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Mathematics. Of a function: invariant with respect to a group of linear transformations of a certain kind. Of a transformation: †leaving a certain function invariant (obsolete).
Characterized by automorphism; formed on oneself.
Crystallography= idiomorphicrare.
Mathematics. Designating an n-digit number which when raised to a power gives a number whose last n digits are the same as the original number.

autonym

noun

One's own name, a person's real name; especially the real name of an author, as distinguished from a pseudonym. Hence: a person who publishes a book under his or her own name; a book so published.

autonomy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The right or condition of self-government.
A self-governing country or region.
Freedom from external control or influence; independence.
(in Kantian moral philosophy) the capacity of an agent to act in accordance with objective morality rather than under the influence of desires.
--Examples--
‘between the First and Second World Wars, Canada gained greater autonomy from Britain’
‘the national autonomies of the Russian Republic’
‘the courts enjoy a considerable degree of autonomy’
‘economic autonomy is still a long way off for many women’

--Word--
objective 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person or their judgement) not influenced by personal feelings or opinions in considering and representing facts.
Not dependent on the mind for existence; actual.
Relating to or denoting a case of nouns and pronouns serving as the object of a transitive verb or a preposition.
A thing aimed at or sought; a goal.
The objective case.
The lens in a telescope or microscope nearest to the object observed.
--Examples--
‘historians try to be objective and impartial’
‘a matter of objective fact’
‘the system has achieved its objective’
‘examine with high power objective’
--Word--
observation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of closely observing or monitoring something or someone.
The ability to notice things, especially significant details.
The act of taking the altitude of the sun or another celestial body to find a latitude or longitude.
A statement based on something one has seen, heard, or noticed.
--Examples--
‘she was brought into hospital for observation’
‘units kept enemy forces under observation for days’
‘detailed observations were carried out on the students' behaviour’
‘his powers of observation’
‘he made a telling observation about Hughie’

noun
--Meanings--
The splitting of a protein or peptide into smaller molecules which is catalysed by the enzymic activity of the protein or peptide itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
autopsy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A post-mortem examination to discover the cause of death or the extent of disease.
Perform an autopsy on (a body or organ)
--Examples--
‘a Home Office pathologist carried out the autopsy’
‘on autopsy it was established that he had suffered from a rare brain condition’
‘the animal must be autopsied as soon as possible’
‘an autopsied brain’
--Word--
autopsic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to (an) autopsy; autoptic.
--Examples--
--Word--
autopsical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= autopsic.
--Examples--
--Word--
autopsychic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a person's consciousness of his or her own psychology.
--Examples--

auto-psychology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study or analysis of one's own psychology.

autoregulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Regulation of a system or process by itself or from within, especially in such a way as to maintain a stable state.
Genetics. Regulation of the expression of a gene by a product of that gene.
--Examples--

autoregulatory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or involving autoregulation; contributing to autoregulation.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in South Asia) a motorized, three-wheeled rickshaw for public hire.
--Examples--
--Word--
rifle 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A gun, especially one fired from shoulder level, having a long spirally grooved barrel intended to make a bullet spin and thereby have greater accuracy over a long distance.
Troops armed with rifles.
Make spiral grooves in (a gun or its barrel or bore) to make a bullet spin and thereby have greater accuracy over a long distance.
Hit or kick (a ball) hard and straight.
Search through something in a hurried way in order to find or steal something.
Steal.
--Examples--
‘a hunting rifle’
‘the Burma Rifles’
‘a line of replacement rifled barrels’
‘Ferguson rifled home his fourth goal of the season’
‘she rifled through the cassette tapes’
‘she rifled the house for money’
‘he rifled the dead man's possessions’
--Word--
autorotate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of an object) rotate spontaneously as a result of a surrounding flow of moving air or water.
(of the rotor blades of a helicopter) rotate without engine power during a descent.
--Examples--
‘seeds with double-winged shapes managed to autorotate’
‘the rotors don't need to autorotate during an emergency landing’
--Word--
autorotation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Rotation of an object caused by the flow of moving air or water around the shape of the object (e.g. a winged seed).
Autorotation in the rotor blades of a helicopter that is descending without engine power.

--Meanings--

--Word--
autoscope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An auto-ophthalmoscope or autolaryngoscope; (also) a laryngoscope through which the larynx can be seen directly (as opposed to by a mirror) (now historical).
An object or device used as an indicator of psychic or parapsychological processes or phenomena. Now historical and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
autoscopy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Visual inspection or examination of one's own organs; specifically = autolaryngoscopy.
In full "internal autoscopy". The visualization or enhanced awareness of one's own internal organs (typically occurring as a symptom of mental illness).
More fully "external autoscopy". A form of visual hallucination in which a person sees an image of himself outside his own body. Later also: = "out-of-body experience".
--Examples--
--Word--
autoscopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine. Of or relating to visual examination of one's own organs or to direct examination of the larynx. Now historical.
Chiefly Psychology and Psychiatry. Of or relating to autoscopy.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
Sensitization to a foreign antigen already present within the body (now rare or disused).
The development or production of autoimmunity or autoallergy.

autosite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The larger and more completely developed member of a pair of unequal conjoined twins, on which the less developed member (parasite) is dependent. In early use also: †either of a pair of equally developed conjoined twins (obsolete).
