autotransfusion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Displacement of blood from the periphery of the body towards the heart and vital organs, especially by elevation or compression of the limbs; an instance of this.
Transfusion of a person's own blood or blood products (either saved after a haemorrhage or removed and stored for later use, e.g. following surgery); an instance of this.

--Word--
autotropism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. The tendency of a plant part, especially a root or shoot, to grow in a straight line or to retain its normal spatial orientation even in the presence of altered tropic stimuli (such as light or gravity).
Mycology. The tendency of a fungal hypha to grow towards or away from another hypha in the same mycelium, or of the germ-tube of a germinating spore to grow towards or away from a spore of the same species.
--Examples--

Autry, Gene 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1907–98), US singer and actor; full name Orvon Gene Autry ; known as the Singing Cowboy. His credits include the first cowboy song recording (1929) and many musical western movies.
--Examples--
--Word--
autumn 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The season after summer and before winter, in the northern hemisphere from September to November and in the southern hemisphere from March to May.
The period from the autumn equinox to the winter solstice.
--Examples--
‘the countryside is ablaze with colour in autumn’
‘Europe can expect warmer summers and wetter autumns’
‘autumn leaves’
‘he was in the autumn of his life’

--Examples--
‘rich autumnal colours’

--Word--
auxiliary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Providing supplementary or additional help and support.
(of troops) engaged in the service of a nation at war but not part of the regular army.
(of a sailing vessel) equipped with a supplementary engine.
An auxiliary person or thing.
A group of volunteers giving supplementary support to an organization or institution.
An auxiliary verb.
A naval vessel with a supporting role, not armed for combat.
--Examples--
‘auxiliary airport staff’
‘the ship has an auxiliary power source’
‘an auxiliary schooner’
‘a nursing auxiliary’
‘there are two main fuel tanks and two auxiliaries’
‘members of the Volunteer Fire Department's women's auxiliary’
--Word--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--

avail 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Help or benefit.
Use or take advantage of (an opportunity or available resource).
Use or benefit.
--Examples--
‘no amount of struggle availed Charles’
‘you can avail discounts on food’
‘students in the district avail of the free meal scheme in schools’
‘he begged her to reconsider, but to no avail’
‘calls to tech support have been of no avail’
‘Latin was of little avail in the practical affairs of life’
--Word--
availability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being able to be used or obtained.
The state of being otherwise unoccupied; freedom to do something.
The state of not being currently involved in a sexual or romantic relationship.
--Examples--
‘turkey producers had been losing sales because of the all-year-round availability of beef’
‘the availability of social housing varies widely in rural areas’
‘they enquired as to my availability for a game the following evening’
‘if you call yourself 'Miss' you're advertising your availability to any man who takes a fancy’
--Word--
availability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being able to be used or obtained.
The state of being otherwise unoccupied; freedom to do something.
The state of not being currently involved in a sexual or romantic relationship.

--Word--
available 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be used or obtained; at someone's disposal.
(of a person) not otherwise occupied; free to do something.
Not currently involved in a sexual or romantic relationship.
--Examples--
‘refreshments will be available all afternoon’
‘community health services available to Londoners’
‘the nurse is only available at certain times’
‘the minister was not available for comment’
‘the larger the pool of available singles the greater your chance of finding someone special’
‘do you think he's available?’

avail 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Help or benefit.
Use or take advantage of (an opportunity or available resource).
Use or benefit.
--Examples--
‘no amount of struggle availed Charles’
‘you can avail discounts on food’
‘students in the district avail of the free meal scheme in schools’
‘he begged her to reconsider, but to no avail’
‘calls to tech support have been of no avail’
‘Latin was of little avail in the practical affairs of life’

--Word--
avalanche 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mass of snow, ice, and rocks falling rapidly down a mountainside.
A large mass of mud or other material moving rapidly downhill.
A sudden arrival or occurrence of something in overwhelming quantities.
A cumulative process in which a fast-moving ion or electron generates further ions and electrons by collision.
(of a mass of snow, ice, etc.) descend rapidly down a mountainside.
Engulf or carry off by an avalanche.
Undergo a rapid increase in conductivity due to an avalanche process.
--Examples--
‘he was swept to his death by an avalanche in 1988’
‘an avalanche of mud’
‘we have had an avalanche of applications for the post’
‘the climbers were avalanched down the south face of the mountain’

Avar 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a nomadic equestrian people from central Asia who built up a large kingdom in south-eastern Europe from the 6th century but were conquered by Charlemagne (791–9).
A member of a pastoral people of Dagestan in Russia, of uncertain relationship to the ancient Avars.
The North Caucasian language of the modern Avars.
Relating to the Avars or their language.

Avebury 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A village in Wiltshire, site of one of Britain's major henge monuments of the late Neolithic period. The monument consists of a bank and ditch containing the largest known stone circle, with two smaller circles within it.

--Word--
average 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A number expressing the central or typical value in a set of data, in particular the mode, median, or (most commonly) the mean, which is calculated by dividing the sum of the values in the set by their number.
An amount, standard, level, or rate regarded as usual or ordinary.
The apportionment of financial liability resulting from loss of or damage to a ship or its cargo.
Reduction in the amount payable under an insurance policy, e.g. in respect of partial loss.
Constituting the result obtained by adding together several amounts and then dividing this total by the number of amounts.
Of the usual or ordinary amount, standard, level, or rate.
Having qualities that are seen as typical of a particular person, group, or thing.
Mediocre; not very good.
Amount to or achieve as an average rate or amount over a period of time; mean.
Calculate or estimate the average of.
Result in an even distribution; even out.
Result in an average figure of.
--Examples--
‘the proportion of over-60s is above the EU average of 19 per cent’
‘underground water reserves are below average’
‘they take about thirty minutes on average’
‘the average temperature in May was 4°C below normal’
‘a woman of average height’
‘the average lad likes a good night out’
‘a very average director making very average movies’
‘annual inflation averaged 2.4 per cent’
‘they earned only £35 weekly when their seasonal earnings were averaged out’
‘it is reasonable to hope that the results will average out’
‘the cost should average out at about £6 per page’

--Word--
Harriman, Averell 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1891–1986), US diplomat and financier; full name William Averell Harriman. The chairman of the board of the Union Pacific Railroad 1932–46, he was US secretary of commerce 1946–48 and governor of New York 1955–59. He also served as ambassador to the Soviet Union 1943–46, to Britain 1946, and as ambassador-at-large 1968–69.
--Examples--

Avernus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A lake near Naples in Italy, which fills the crater of an extinct volcano. It was described by Virgil and other Latin writers as the entrance to the underworld.

--Word--
Averroës 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1126–98), Spanish-born Islamic philosopher, judge, and physician; Arabic name ibn-Rushd. His highly influential commentaries on Aristotle sought to reconcile Aristotle with Plato and the Greek philosophical tradition with the Arabic.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strong dislike or disinclination.
Someone or something that arouses a strong dislike or disinclination.
--Examples--
‘they made plain their aversion to the use of force’
‘my dog's pet aversion is visitors, particularly males’

--Word--
Avicenna 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(980–1037), Persian-born Islamic philosopher and physician; Arabic name ibn-Sina. His philosophical system, drawing on Aristotle but in many ways closer to Neoplatonism, was the major influence on the development of scholasticism. His Canon of Medicine was a standard medieval medical text.
--Examples--
--Word--
avicularium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in some bryozoans) any of a number of modified zooids that take the form of a pair of snapping jaws resembling a bird's head, serving to prevent other organisms from settling on the colony.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in some bryozoans) any of a number of modified zooids that take the form of a pair of snapping jaws resembling a bird's head, serving to prevent other organisms from settling on the colony.

--Word--
Avignon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city on the Rhône in south-eastern France; population 94,787 (2006). From 1309 until 1377 it was the residence of the popes during their exile from Rome, and was papal property until the French Revolution.
--Examples--
--Word--
Teresa of Ávila, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1515–82), Spanish Carmelite nun and mystic. She instituted the “discalced” reform movement with St. John of the Cross. Her writings include The Way of Perfection (1583) and The Interior Castle (1588). Feast day, October 15.
--Examples--
--Word--
par avion 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By airmail (written on a letter or parcel to indicate how it is to reach its destination).
--Examples--
--Word--
canon 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A general law, rule, principle, or criterion by which something is judged.
A Church decree or law.
A collection or list of sacred books accepted as genuine.
The works of a particular author or artist that are recognized as genuine.
The list of works considered to be permanently established as being of the highest quality.
(in the Roman Catholic Church) the part of the Mass containing the words of consecration.
A piece in which the same melody is begun in different parts successively, so that the imitations overlap.
--Examples--
‘the appointment violated the canons of fair play and equal opportunity’
‘a set of ecclesiastical canons’
‘legislation which enables the Church of England General Synod to provide by canon for women to be ordained’
‘the biblical canon’
‘the Shakespeare canon’
‘Hopkins was firmly established in the canon of English poetry’
‘the very simple rhythmic structure of this double canon’
‘two quartets sing in close canon throughout’

avocado 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pear-shaped fruit with a rough leathery skin and smooth, oily edible flesh.
A light green colour like that of the flesh of avocados.
The tropical evergreen tree which bears the avocado fruit, native to Central America and widely cultivated elsewhere.

‘a salad of avocados and oranges’
‘serve with slices of avocado’

Avogadro, Amedeo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1776–1856), Italian chemist and physicist. His law, formulated in 1811, was used to derive both molecular weights and a system of atomic weights.
--Examples--
--Word--
avoid 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Keep away from or stop oneself from doing (something)
Contrive not to meet (someone)
Not go to or through (a place)
Prevent from happening.
Repudiate, nullify, or render void (a decree or contract)
--Examples--
‘avoid excessive exposure to the sun’
‘Gerard avoided meeting his eye’
‘boys queued up to take Gloria out, but avoided Deirdre’
‘this route avoids downtown Boston’
‘book early to avoid disappointment’
‘if the original owner had avoided his contract with the rogue, ownership of the goods would have reverted to him’
--Word--
avoidable

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the accident was entirely avoidable’
‘avoidable costs’
--Word--
avoidably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
avoidance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of keeping away from or not doing something.
The action of preventing something from happening.
The action of repudiating, nullifying, or rendering void a decree or contract.
--Examples--
‘one third of cancer deaths could be prevented by avoidance of smoking’
‘a pilotless passenger aircraft would rely on computers and automatic collision avoidance’
‘insurance underwriters could not rely on non-disclosure to justify avoidance of the contract’
--Word--

--Word--
avoirdupois 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of weights based on a pound of 16 ounces or 7,000 grains, widely used in English-speaking countries.
Weight; heaviness.
--Examples--
‘avoirdupois weights’
‘a pound avoirdupois’
‘she was putting on the avoirdupois like nobody's business’
--Word--
Avon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of central England which rises near the Leicestershire–Northamptonshire border and flows 154 km (96 miles) south-west through Stratford to the River Severn.
A river of south-western England which rises near the Gloucestershire–Wiltshire border and flows 121 km (75 miles) through Bath and Bristol to the River Severn.
A former county of south-western England, formed in 1974 from parts of north Somerset and Gloucestershire and replaced in 1996 by unitary councils of North Somerset, Bristol, South Gloucestershire, and Bath and north-eastern Somerset.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--
A city in south central Arizona, a western suburb of Phoenix; population 81,299 (est. 2008).

aandblom

noun

avulsion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of pulling or tearing away.
The sudden separation of land from one property and its attachment to another, especially by flooding or a change in the course of a river.

avunculate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The special relationship in some societies between a man and his sister's son.
--Examples--
‘kinship relations such as the avunculate’
--Word--
aw 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
Used to express mild protest, entreaty, or sympathy.
Used to express mild disappointment or self-deprecation.
Used to express pleasure, delight, or affection, especially in response to something regarded as sweet or endearing.
--Examples--
‘aw, come on, Andy’
‘aww, you poor thing’
‘aw, it's a shame I can't make it’
‘aww, thanks for the nice comments’
‘aww, the kitten is too cute!’
‘aww, are you guys an item?’
--Word--
A/W 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Autumn/winter (denoting or relating to fashion designed for the autumn and winter seasons of a particular year)
--Examples--
‘his A/W 2013 womenswear collection was hailed a resounding success’
‘make sure you're on board with the A/W must-have—a trouser suit’
--Word--
AWACS 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
An airborne radar system for detecting enemy aircraft and directing friendly forces.
--Examples--
‘AWACS aircraft’
--Word--
away 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
To or at a distance from a particular place, person, or thing.
At a specified distance.
At a specified future distance in time.
Towards a lower level; downwards.
Conceptually to one side, so as no longer to be the focus of attention.
(with reference to a sports fixture) at the opponents' ground.
Into an appropriate place for storage or safekeeping.
Into non-existence.
Constantly, persistently, or continuously.
(of a sports fixture) played at the opponents' ground.
Relating to or denoting a sports team that is playing at the opponents' ground.
An away match or win.
--Examples--
‘she landed badly, and crawled away’
‘they walked away from the vicarage in silence’
‘we'll only be away for four nights’
‘when he was ten or twelve feet away he stopped’
‘we have had patients from as far away as Wales’
‘the wedding is only weeks away’
‘in front of them the land fell away to the river’
‘the Museum has shifted its emphasis away from research towards exhibitions’
‘Oh what fun it is to see the Mariners win away’
‘we are away to Morecambe on Saturday’
‘he put away the pistol’
‘Marie felt her distress ebbing away’
‘there was Morrissey crooning away’
‘tomorrow night's away game at Leicester’
‘an away victory’
‘the away side scored first’
‘away fans chanted and cheered’
--Word--
going-away 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Marking or celebrating a departure.
(of a bride's clothes) to be worn while leaving for her honeymoon.
With victory assured before the end of a race or other sporting contest.
--Examples--
‘a going-away party’
‘she's changing into her going-away outfit’
‘he caught the Nigerian coming around the final curve and won going away’

--Word--
await 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Wait for (an event)
(of an event or circumstance) be in store for (someone)
--Examples--
‘we await the proposals with impatience’
‘remand prisoners awaiting trial’
‘an eagerly awaited debut’
‘many dangers await them’

--Word--
awake 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Stop sleeping; wake from sleep.
Cause (someone) to wake from sleep.
Regain consciousness.
Become aware of; come to a realization of.
Make or become active again.
Not asleep.
Aware of.
--Examples--
‘she awoke to find the streets covered in snow’
‘my screams awoke my parents’
‘I awoke none the worse for the operation’
‘the authorities finally awoke to the extent of the problem’
‘there were echoes and scents which awoke some memory in me’
‘the noise might keep you awake at night’
‘too few are awake to the dangers’

--Type--
verb

--Examples--

‘he sighed but did not awaken’
‘different images can awaken new emotions within us’
‘the film helped to awaken many to the horrors of apartheid’

--Word--
awakening 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An act of waking from sleep.
An act or moment of becoming suddenly aware of something.
The beginning or rousing of something.
Coming into existence or awareness.
--Examples--
‘since my awakening I had realized it was a very special day’
‘the war came as a rude awakening to the hardships of life’
‘her sexual awakening’
‘the awakening of vigorous political debate’
‘his awakening desire’
‘an awakening conscience’

--Examples--
--Word--
war 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A state of armed conflict between different countries or different groups within a country.
A state of competition or hostility between different people or groups.
A sustained campaign against an undesirable situation or activity.
Engage in a war.
--Examples--
‘Japan declared war on Germany’
‘the two countries were at war for the next eight years’
‘I fought in two wars’
‘she was at war with her parents’
‘a price war among tour operators’
‘the authorities are waging war against smuggling’
‘a war on drugs’
‘small states warred against each another’
‘conflicting emotions warred within her’
--Word--
award 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give or order the giving of (something) as an official payment, compensation, or prize to (someone)
Grant or assign (a contract or commission) to (a person or organization)
A prize or other mark of recognition given in honour of an achievement.
An amount of money given as an official payment, compensation, or grant.
The action of giving a payment, compensation, or prize.
--Examples--
‘he was awarded the Military Cross’
‘a 3.5 per cent pay rise was awarded to staff’
‘the company was awarded a contract to refurbish the timber mill’
‘the company's annual award for high-quality service’
‘a 1.5 per cent pay award’
‘the award of an honorary doctorate’
‘an award of damages’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.
Concerned and well informed about a particular situation or development.
--Examples--
‘most people are aware of the dangers of sunbathing’
‘he was aware that a problem existed’
‘everyone needs to become more environmentally aware’
--Word--
awareness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.
Concern about and well-informed interest in a particular situation or development.
--Examples--
‘we need to raise public awareness of the issue’
‘there is a lack of awareness of the risks’
‘a growing environmental awareness’
‘his political awareness developed’
--Word--
awash 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Covered or flooded with water, especially seawater or rain.
Containing large numbers or amounts of someone or something.
Level with the surface of water so that it just washes over.
--Examples--
‘the boat rolled violently, her decks awash’
‘the city was awash with journalists’
‘a rock awash outside the reef entrance’

noun

awe 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A feeling of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder.
Capacity to inspire awe.
Inspire with awe.
--Examples--
‘they gazed in awe at the small mountain of diamonds’
‘the sight filled me with awe’
‘is it any wonder that Christmas Eve has lost its awe?’
‘they were both awed by the vastness of the forest’

--Word--
weather 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The state of the atmosphere at a particular place and time as regards heat, cloudiness, dryness, sunshine, wind, rain, etc.
Cold, wet, and unpleasant or unpredictable atmospheric conditions.
Denoting the side from which the wind is blowing, especially on board a ship; windward.
Wear away or change the appearance or texture of (something) by long exposure to the atmosphere.
(of rock or other material) be worn away or altered by long exposure to the atmosphere.
(of a ship) come safely through (a storm)
Withstand (a difficulty or danger)
Get to the windward of (a cape).
Make (boards or tiles) overlap downwards to keep out rain.
(in building) slope or bevel (a surface) to throw off rain.
Allow (a hawk) to spend a period perched in the open air.
--Examples--
‘if the weather's good we can go for a walk’
‘stone walls provide shelter from wind and weather’
‘the weather side of the yacht’
‘his skin was weathered almost black by his long outdoor life’
‘the ice sheet preserves specimens that would weather away more quickly in other regions’
‘the sturdy boat had weathered the storm well’
‘this year has tested industry's ability to weather recession’

commanding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(in military contexts) having a position of authority.
Indicating or expressing authority; imposing.
Possessing or giving superior strength.
(of a place or position) dominating from above; giving a wide view of an area.
--Examples--
‘a commanding officer’
‘a man of commanding presence’
‘her style is commanding’
‘a commanding 13–6 lead’
‘the castle is built in a commanding position on a hill looking out over the sea’
--Word--
compelling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Evoking interest, attention, or admiration in a powerfully irresistible way.
Not able to be refuted; inspiring conviction.
Not able to be resisted; overwhelming.
--Examples--
‘his eyes were strangely compelling’
‘a compelling film’
‘there is compelling evidence that the recession is ending’
‘a compelling argument’
‘the temptation to give up was compelling’

--Word--
week 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of seven days.
The period of seven days generally reckoned from and to midnight on Saturday night.
Workdays as opposed to the weekend; the five days from Monday to Friday.
The time spent working during a week.
Used after the name of a day to indicate that something will happen seven days after that day.
--Examples--
‘the course lasts sixteen weeks’
‘he'd cut the grass a week ago’
‘she has an art class twice a week’
‘I work during the week, so I can only get to this shop on Saturdays’
‘she works a 48-hour week’
‘the programme will be broadcast on Sunday week’

--Word--
inspired 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of extraordinary quality, as if arising from some external creative impulse.
(of a person) displaying a creative impulse in the activity specified.
(of air or another substance) that is breathed in.
--Examples--
‘they had to thank the goalkeeper for some inspired saves’
‘she was an inspired gardener’
‘inspired air must be humidified’

--Word--
west 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction towards the point of the horizon where the sun sets at the equinoxes, on the left-hand side of a person facing north, or the part of the horizon lying in this direction.
The compass point corresponding to west.
The western part of the world or of a specified country, region, or town.
Europe and North America seen in contrast to other civilizations.
The non-Communist states of Europe and North America, contrasted with the former Communist states of eastern Europe.
The western part of the United States, especially the states west of the Mississippi.
The player sitting to the right of North and partnering East.
Lying towards, near, or facing the west.
(of a wind) blowing from the west.
Of or denoting the western part of a specified area, city, or country or its inhabitants.
To or towards the west.
--Examples--
‘the evening sun glowed from the west’
‘a patrol aimed to create a diversion to the west of the city’
‘it will become windy in the west’
‘Aboriginal religion is closer to the Orient than the West’
‘Mr Yeltsin was seen by the West as the driving force behind market reforms’
‘West butts in with a bid of three spades’
‘the west coast’
‘the formation is caused by the prevalent west winds’
‘West Africa’
‘he faced west and watched the sunset’
‘the accident happened a mile west of Bowes’

--Word--
awful 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Very bad or unpleasant.
Extremely shocking; horrific.
(of a person) very unwell or troubled.
Used to emphasize the extent of something, especially something unpleasant or negative.
Inspiring reverential wonder or fear.
Awfully; very.
--Examples--
‘the place smelled awful’
‘I look awful in a swimsuit’
‘an awful speech’
‘awful, bloody images’
‘I felt awful for being so angry with him’
‘you look awful—you should go and lie down’
‘I've made an awful fool of myself’
‘we're an awful long way from the motorway’

--Word--
wing 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
(in a bird) a modified forelimb that bears large feathers and is used for flying.
(in a bat or pterosaur) a modified forelimb with skin stretched between or behind the fingers.
(in most insects) each of two or four flat extensions of the thoracic cuticle, either transparent or covered in scales.
The wing of a bird as food.
Used with reference to ease and swiftness of movement.
A rigid horizontal structure that projects from both sides of an aircraft and supports it in the air.
A pilot's certificate of ability to fly a plane, indicated by a badge representing a pair of wings.
A raised part of the body of a car or other vehicle above the wheel.
A part of a large building, especially one that projects from the main part.
A group within a political party or other organization having particular views or a particular function.
The sides of a theatre stage out of view of the audience.
(in soccer, rugby, and hockey) the part of the field close to the sidelines.
An attacking player positioned near to one of the sidelines.
A lateral part or projection of an organ or structure.
A thin membranous appendage of a fruit or seed that is dispersed by the wind.
An air force unit of several squadrons or groups.
The right or left flank of the main body of a battle formation.
A flock of plovers (birds)
Travel on wings or by aircraft; fly.
Move, travel, or be sent quickly, as if flying.
Send or convey (something) quickly, as if by air.
Enable (someone or something) to fly or move rapidly.
Shoot (a bird) in the wing, so as to prevent flight without causing death.
Wound (someone) superficially, especially in the arm or shoulder.
Speak or act without preparation; improvise.
--Examples--
‘the thought gave wings to her feet’
‘Michael earned his wings as a commercial pilot’
‘a maternity wing’
‘a candidate from the liberal wing of the party’
‘some sportsmen make no scruple about firing into the thick of a wing of plover’
‘George satisfied his keen urge to fly by winging homewards with the Royal Air Force’
‘the prize will be winging its way to you soon’
‘just jot down the title on a postcard and wing it to us’
‘the convent was at some distance, but fear would wing her steps’
‘one bird was winged for every bird killed’
‘a little preparation puts you ahead of the job-seekers who try to wing it’
--Word--
wink 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Close and open one eye quickly, typically to indicate that something is a joke or a secret or as a signal of affection or greeting.
Pretend not to notice (something bad or illegal)
(of a bright object or a light) shine or flash intermittently.
An act of winking.
--Examples--
‘he winked at Nicole as he passed’
‘the authorities winked at their illegal trade’
‘the diamond on her finger winked in the moonlight’
‘Barney gave him a knowing wink’

awkward

adjective

‘she felt awkward alone with him’
‘Luther's awkward movements impeded his progress’
‘make sure the baby isn't sleeping in an awkward position’

--Word--
awkwardly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an ungainly manner; not smoothly or gracefully.
In a way that shows uneasy embarrassment.
In a way that causes difficulty.
--Examples--
‘she waddled up the stairs awkwardly’
‘he landed awkwardly after both of his vaults’
‘the conclusion seems awkwardly grafted on to the main text’
‘Seth responded awkwardly, allowing the silence once again to settle between them’
‘I cleared my throat awkwardly’
‘the cruise control is placed awkwardly on the control column’
‘the ball bounced awkwardly, but Auguste controlled it with his chest’

wrack 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of coarse brown seaweeds which grow on the shoreline, frequently each kind forming a distinct band in relation to high- and low-water marks. Many have air bladders for buoyancy.
A wrecked ship; a shipwreck.
Wreckage.
--Examples--

axe 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tool used for chopping wood, typically of iron with a steel edge and wooden handle.
A measure intended to reduce costs drastically, especially one involving redundancies.
A musical instrument used in popular music or jazz, especially a guitar or (originally) a saxophone.
End, cancel, or dismiss suddenly and ruthlessly.
Reduce (costs or services) drastically.
Cut or strike with an axe, especially violently or destructively.
--Examples--
‘I started swinging the axe at the lumps of driftwood’
‘an axe blade’
‘thirty staff are facing the axe at the Royal Infirmary’
‘the company is axing 125 jobs’
‘2,500 staff were axed as part of a rationalization programme’
‘the Chancellor warned the cabinet to axe public spending’
‘the mahogany panelling had been axed’

A particular theory of axiology.
--Examples--
‘one of the central questions in axiology is this: what elements can contribute to the intrinsic value of a state of affairs?’
‘all consequentialists start with an axiology which tells us what things are valuable or fitting to desire’
--Word--
axiom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A statement or proposition which is regarded as being established, accepted, or self-evidently true.
A statement or proposition on which an abstractly defined structure is based.
--Examples--
‘the axiom that sport builds character’
--Word--
axiomatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Self-evident or unquestionable.
Relating to or containing axioms.
--Examples--
‘it is axiomatic that dividends have to be financed’
‘1914 saw the first axiomatic declaration of exactly what constitutes a ring’

axiomatically

adverb

adverb
--Meanings--

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Express (a theory) as a set of axioms.
--Examples--
‘the attempts that are made to axiomatize linguistics’

--Word--
axion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hypothetical subatomic particle postulated to account for the rarity of processes which break charge–parity symmetry.
--Examples--
--Word--
axis 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An imaginary line about which a body rotates.
An imaginary straight line passing through the centre of a symmetrical solid, about which a plane figure can be conceived as rotating to generate the solid.
An imaginary line which divides something into equal or roughly equal halves, especially in the direction of its greatest length.
A fixed reference line for the measurement of coordinates.
A straight central part in a structure to which other parts are connected.
The central column of an inflorescence or other growth.
The skull and backbone of a vertebrate animal.
The second cervical vertebra, below the atlas at the top of the backbone.
An agreement or alliance between two or more countries that forms a centre for an eventual larger grouping of nations.
The alliance of Germany and Italy formed before and during the Second World War, later extended to include Japan and other countries.
A deer that has lyre-shaped antlers and a yellowish-brown coat with white spots, native to India and Sri Lanka.
--Examples--
‘the Earth revolves on its axis once every 24 hours’
‘the variable that is thought of as a cause is placed on the horizontal axis, and the variable that is thought of as an effect on the vertical axis’
‘the leaflets are arranged in rows on a slender axis’
‘the Anglo-American axis’
‘the Axis Powers’

--Word--
Aksum 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Azilian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting an early Mesolithic culture in Europe, succeeding the Magdalenian and dated to about 11,500–9,500 years ago. It is characterized by flat bone harpoons, painted pebbles, and microliths.
The Azilian culture or period.
--Examples--
--Word--
Tardenoisian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a late Mesolithic culture of west and central Europe, especially France, dated to about 8,000–6,000 years ago.
The Tardenoisian culture or period.
--Examples--
--Word--
azimuth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The direction of a celestial object from the observer, expressed as the angular distance from the north or south point of the horizon to the point at which a vertical circle passing through the object intersects the horizon.
The horizontal angle or direction of a compass bearing.

Azores

--Examples--
--Word--
azoturia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Abnormal excess of nitrogen compounds in the urine.
A condition that can affect horses exercised after a period of stabling, causing painful stiffness in the hindquarters and back, and dark urine containing products of muscle cell destruction.
--Examples--

Aztec 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the indigenous people dominant in Mexico before the Spanish conquest of the 16th century.
The extinct language of the Aztecs, a Uto-Aztecan language from which modern Nahuatl is descended.
Relating to or denoting the Aztecs or their language.

Uto-Aztecan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a language family of Central America and western North America including Nahuatl (the language of the Aztecs), Shoshone, and Paiute.
The Uto-Aztecan language family.

azure 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Bright blue in colour like a cloudless sky.
Blue.
A bright blue colour.
The clear sky.
A small butterfly which is typically blue or purplish.
--Examples--
‘thin streaks of cloud trailed across an azure sky’
‘white beaches surrounded by azure seas’
‘the adult male's back and flanks are azure blue’
‘a saltire azure’
‘a flash of azure drew my eye to a kingfisher’
‘the azure of the sky’

Blue.
A bright blue colour.
The clear sky.
A small butterfly which is typically blue or purplish.
--Examples--
‘thin streaks of cloud trailed across an azure sky’
‘white beaches surrounded by azure seas’
‘the adult male's back and flanks are azure blue’
‘a saltire azure’
‘a flash of azure drew my eye to a kingfisher’
‘the azure of the sky’
--Word--
azure 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Bright blue in colour like a cloudless sky.
Blue.
A bright blue colour.
The clear sky.
A small butterfly which is typically blue or purplish.
--Examples--

‘white beaches surrounded by azure seas’
‘the adult male's back and flanks are azure blue’
‘a saltire azure’
‘a flash of azure drew my eye to a kingfisher’
‘the azure of the sky’

--Word--
azurite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blue mineral consisting of basic copper carbonate. It occurs as blue prisms or crystal masses, typically with malachite.
--Examples--
--Word--
azurite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blue mineral consisting of basic copper carbonate. It occurs as blue prisms or crystal masses, typically with malachite.
--Examples--
--Word--
Azusa 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southwestern California, northeast of Los Angeles; population 46,847 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
